In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.

**Introduction to the Book**

The Imam, the Scholar, the Role Model, the Unique, the Hafiz, Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Ash'ari al-Qurtubi al-Hanafi, may Allah have mercy on him, said:

Praise be to Allah, who favored us with sciences and arts, and made the lineage of the Arabs the noblest of lineages. Blessings and peace be upon the Chosen One, from the core of the core, transferred from the honor of the loins, and upon his family and companions, the best of companions, and upon his pure wives, the close ones, and upon those who follow them in goodness until the Day of Return.

To proceed, I have read books on Arab genealogy, so I mentioned [this] for those who aspire to noble status and seek superiority in their community through the mention of lineages. I mention for him primary sources that succeed if sought. I have gathered for him from the origins of tribes and the branches of the ancestors that which reaches the middle of the lineage and ensures safety from error.

In summary: It is not fitting for anyone with understanding and intellect, or noble lineage [to ignore this], due to what it contains of maintaining family ties and knowing rulings. Among the examples is the command of the Prophet (peace be upon him). The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Learn enough about your lineages to maintain ties with your kin, for maintaining ties of kinship increases wealth and extends life [delays the term]." He (peace be upon him) also said: "Whoever claims lineage to other than his father or seeks other than his patrons, Allah will not accept from him any obligatory or voluntary act." It is narrated from him (peace be upon him) that he said: "The Arabs are favored for three reasons: because I am an Arab, the Qur'an is Arabic, and the speech of Allah is Arabic."

It is narrated from Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) that he said: "Learn your lineages to maintain your kinship ties, and do not be like the Nabateans of the Sawad; when one of them is asked, 'Where are you from?' he says, 'From such-and-such village.' By Allah, there may be something between a man and his brother, but if he knew what was between him and them, it would deter him from violating it." It is narrated from Abdullah bin Umar that he said to his father: "Preserve your own lineage and the mothers of your son."

Allah the Almighty, the most truthful of speakers, said, and His word is prioritized at all times: {O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another.} [Al-Hujurat: 13].

The exegetes said: 'Sha'ub' (Peoples) are the origins from which 'Qaba'il' (Tribes) dispersed. Then the Arabs dispersed from the Tribes, then the Tribes dispersed from the Peoples, then the Peoples dispersed from the 'Ama'ir' (Clans), then the Clans dispersed from the Tribes, then the 'Butun' (Bellies/Sub-tribes) dispersed from the Clans, then the 'Afkhadh' (Thighs/Branches) dispersed from the Bellies, then the 'Fasa'il' (Families/Sections) dispersed from the Thighs. There is nothing below the Fasilah. So they are: Sha'ub (Peoples), Qaba'il (Tribes), 'Ama'ir (Clans), Butun (Bellies), Afkhadh (Thighs), and Fasa'il (Families).

An example of this is that Banu Abd al-Muttalib is the 'Fasilah' of the Prophet (peace be upon him), Banu Hashim is his 'Fakhdh', Banu Abd Manaf is his 'Batn', Quraysh is his 'Imarah', Kinanah is his 'Qabilah', and Mudar is his 'Sha'b'.

It is narrated from the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) that he said: "Verily Allah chose the Arabs, then chose Mudar from the Arabs, then chose Al-Nadr bin Kinanah from them, then chose Quraysh from them, then chose Banu Hashim from them, then chose me from Banu Hashim."

Neither the Chosen Prophet nor the righteous Companions were ignorant of this measure. It is narrated from him (peace be upon him) that he said: "Aslam, Ghifar, Muzaynah, and some of Juhaynah are better in the sight of Allah on the Day of Resurrection than Ghatafan, Hawazin, Asad, Tamim, and the two sons of Amir bin Sa'sa'ah." This indicates his (peace be upon him) knowledge of lineages in reports that would take long to mention. Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) was the most knowledgeable of people about lineages, and likewise Jubayr bin Mut'im was among the narrators of lineages.

We will now mention a part of what we promised. It has been the custom of genealogists to begin the lineage of the people of the Levant with the lineage of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), then with the tribes of Mudar, then with the lineage of Quraysh because they were honored by the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Then with the tribes of Rabi'ah because they are the brother-branch of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Among the people of Yemen, [they begin] with the Ansar because they were honored by supporting the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), then with the tribes of Azd because they are the origin of the Ansar, then with the tribes of Kahlan because they are a branch of Azd, then the tribes of Himyar.

Our beginning in this summary is with:

**The Lineage of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him)**

The first of the lineages is the lineage of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).

He is Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Abd al-Muttalib bin Hashim bin Abd Manaf. Manaf was the greatest of their idols, and Abd Manaf was named after it; his [real] name was Al-Mughira. Bin Qusayy, who is Mujammi', and his name is Zaid. Bin Kilab bin Murrah bin Ka'b bin Lu'ay bin Ghalib bin Fihr bin Malik bin Al-Nadr bin Kinanah bin Khuzaymah bin Mudrikah bin Ilyas bin Mudar bin Nizar bin Ma'ad bin Adnan bin Add bin Alyasa' bin Al-Hamisa' bin Salaman bin Haml bin Qedar bin Isma'il (Ishmael) bin Ibrahim (Abraham), peace be upon him, bin Azar - who is Terah - bin Nahor bin Sarug bin Reu bin Peleg bin Eber bin Shelah bin Arpachshad bin Shem bin Noah, peace be upon him, bin Lamech bin Methuselah bin Enoch - who is Idris the Prophet, peace be upon him - bin Jared bin Mahalalel bin Kenan bin Enos bin Seth - who is Hiba-Allah - bin Adam the Chosen, the Father of Mankind, peace be upon him and upon all the prophets.

This is the lineage of the Prophet (peace be upon him). There have been differences regarding the names of the men above Adnan; some added, some decreased, some advanced, and some delayed names. Allah knows best what is correct. It is narrated from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that she said: "We did not find anyone who knew what is beyond Adnan, nor what is beyond Qahtan, except by conjecture."

It is narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that when the lineage reached Ma'ad bin Adnan, he said: "The genealogists have lied," and he recited the verse: {And many generations between them.} [Al-Furqan: 38]. This withholding is nothing [significant in preventing knowledge of major tribes], for they have preserved the mothers of tribes and the peoples of the ancients, though they differed on some and some were hidden from them. Know that genealogy is knowledge that does not [necessarily] benefit [in the Hereafter] and ignorance that does not harm. Perhaps some narrated this report from the Prophet (peace be upon him), but it is not proven according to most scholars, nor did they adhere to it in what we have mentioned in this book.

**The Children of the Prophet**
Then we return to mentioning the lineages. He said: The Prophet (peace be upon him) had eight children: four men and four women. As for the men: Al-Qasim, Al-Tahir (who is Abdullah), Al-Tayyib, and Ibrahim (whose mother is Mariya the Copt). The women are Fatima, Ruqayyah, Umm Kulthum, and Zainab. Their mother is Khadijah bint Khuwaylid bin Asad bin Abd al-Uzza bin Qusayy bin Kilab. (The first to meet the Prophet's lineage [from his ancestors] is Banu Abd al-Muttalib, and he was nicknamed Shaybah al-Hamd).

The uncles of the Prophet (peace be upon him) are Al-Harith (the eldest), Al-Abbas, Hamzah, Abu Talib, Dirar, Al-Muqawwim, Mus'ab (who is Jahll, 'Wa'a' al-Khamrah'), Al-Zubayr, Abu Lahab (whose name is Abd al-Uzza), and Al-Ghaydaq (it is said Al-Ghaydaq is Jahll). These are ten, the sons of Abd al-Muttalib.

**The Children of His Uncles**
The children of Al-Abbas are Abdullah, Ubaidullah, Al-Fadl, Qutham, Abd al-Rahman, Tamam, Kathir, and Al-Harith.
The children of Abdullah are Al-Abbas bin Muhammad al-Kamil bin Ali al-Alim, Abbas, Abdullah, Al-Fadl, and Abd al-Rahman; their mother is Zur'ah bint Mashrah al-Kindiyyah.
The Caliphs are from the descendants of Muhammad bin Ali bin Abdullah bin Al-Abbas. In our time today, they are: Al-Rashid bin Al-Mustarshid bin Al-Mustazhir bin Al-Muqtadi. Among them is Muhammad bin Al-Muqtafi bin Al-Mustazhir. Al-Muqtadi is Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Al-Qa'im bi-Amrillah, who is Abdullah bin Al-Qadir Billah, who is Ahmad bin Ishaq bin Al-Muqtadir bin Ahmad Al-Mu'tadid bin Talha bin Al-Muwaffaq bin Al-Mu'tazz Billah bin Ja'far Al-Mutawakkil bin Muhammad Al-Mu'tasim Billah bin Harun Al-Rashid bin Muhammad Al-Mahdi bin Abdullah Al-Mansur bin Muhammad Al-Kamil bin Ali Al-Alim bin Abdullah bin Al-Abbas.

From the children of Ali bin Abdullah are: Muhammad, Salih, Abdullah, Abd al-Rahman, Isma'il, Al-Namir, Layth, Isa, Dawud, and Abd al-Samad.
From the children of Muhammad bin Ali are: Abu Ali Abu al-Abbas, Abdullah Al-Mansur, Musa, Muhammad, Ibrahim, and Al-Abbas.
From the children of Al-Mansur are: Ja'far, Sulayman, Ali, Isa, Ya'qub, Al-Qasim, Salih, and Muhammad Al-Mahdi (the Caliph).
From the children of Al-Mahdi are: Musa Al-Hadi, Ibrahim bin Shakla, Mansur, Ishaq, and Harun Al-Rashid.
From the children of Harun Al-Rashid are: Muhammad Al-Amin, Abdullah Al-Ma'mun, his brother Al-Qasim Al-Mu'taman, Abu Ya'qub, Abu al-Abbas, Abu Abdullah, and Qutr bin Al-Mu'tasim.
From the children of Al-Mu'tasim are: Harun Al-Wathiq, Ahmad Al-Musta'in, and Ja'far Al-Mutawakkil.
From the children of Harun Al-Wathiq is Muhammad Al-Mahdi.
From the children of Ja'far Al-Mutawakkil are: Ahmad Al-Mu'tamid, Al-Zubayr Al-Mu'tazz, Al-Muntasir, Talha Al-Muwaffaq, and Ibrahim - Al-Mu'ayyad Billah.

Talha begot Ahmad Al-Mu'tadid. Ahmad Al-Mu'tadid begot Ali Al-Muktafi, Muhammad Al-Qahir, and Ja'far Al-Muqtadir. Ali Al-Muktafi begot Abdullah Al-Mustakfi. Ja'far Al-Muqtadir begot Ishaq, Ibrahim Al-Muttaqi, Muhammad Al-Radi, and Al-Fadl Al-Muti'. Al-Muti' begot Abu Bakr Al-Ta'i bin Abd al-Karim Al-Muti'. Ishaq bin Al-Muqtadir begot Ahmad Al-Qadir. We have mentioned the descendants of Al-Qadir up to Al-Rashid.
Abdullah bin Al-Abbas was born three years before the Hijra. The Prophet (peace be upon him) died when he was thirteen years old.

(Section)
As for Abu Talib, whose name is Abd Manaf, his children are Ja'far, Aqil, Talib, Al-Abbas, Al-Mansur, Abdullah, and Ali. The children of Ali, may Allah honor his face, are Al-Hasan, Al-Husayn, and Muhsin; their mother is Fatimah, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Muhsin died young. And Muhammad, whose mother is Khawlah Al-Hanafiyyah, and Al-Abbas, Abu Bakr, Umar, Uthman, Yahya, and Ja'far. Al-Hasan died poisoned; his wife, the daughter of Al-Ash'ath Al-Kindi, poisoned him at the instigation of Mu'awiyah.

From the descendants of Al-Hasan bin Ali are Sulayman and Musa, sons of Abdullah bin Musa bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face. The Banu Sulayman are tribes in our time, and the Banu Musa are tribes. Among them is Muhammad bin Yahya bin Abdullah bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Husayn [sic, context suggests Hasan] bin Ali, who settled at Mount Athib; his descendants are known as the Athbiyyin. Among them is Al-Qasim bin Ibrahim bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Hasan bin Ali, who settled at Mount Al-Rass; his descendants are known as the Rassiyyin. Among them is Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Hasan bin Hasan bin Al-Hasan the Third bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Hasan.

As for Al-Husayn bin Ali, among his descendants is Muhammad Al-Mahdi bin Al-Husayn bin Al-Shahid bin Al-Nasih bin Muhammad Al-Sabir bin Ali Al-Kazim bin Musa Al-Radi bin Ja'far Al-Sadiq bin Muhammad Al-Baqir bin Zayn al-Abidin bin Al-Husayn bin Ali. From the descendants of Zayn al-Abidin the Younger is Ali Zayn al-Abidin. Among them is the Alawi of Basra, who is Ali bin Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Isa bin Zaid bin Ali bin Zayn al-Abidin. Among them is Yahya bin Amr bin Yahya bin Al-Husayn bin Zaid bin Ali bin Zayn al-Abidin. Among them are Al-Sharif Al-Radi and his brother Al-Murtada, sons of Al-Husayn bin Musa bin Muhammad bin Musa bin Ibrahim bin Musa Al-Radi bin Ja'far Al-Sadiq.

Among them are the Caliphs of Tamim: Al-Qa'im bi-Ahkam Allah, who is Abu Ali Al-Mansur bin Ahmad Al-Musta'li bin Ma'ad Abu Tamim Al-Mustansir bin Al-Tahir bin Al-Hakim bin Al-Aziz bin Al-Mu'izz (the first to enter Egypt) bin Al-Mansur Al-Qa'im bin Al-Mahdi (Lord of Mahdia) bin the Hidden Ones (Al-Masturin) bin Muhammad bin Isma'il bin Ja'far Al-Sadiq, to the end of the lineage.

From the children of Abu Talib are Abdullah bin Ja'far bin Abi Talib and Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Aqil bin Abi Talib.
From the children of Abd al-Muttalib are Ubaydah, Abu Sufyan, Rabi'ah, Sa'id, Abdullah, and Nawfal bin Al-Harith.
From the children of Abu Lahab are Utbah, Mu'attib, and Attab. Among them is the poet Abu Ja'far Al-Fadl bin Amir bin Utbah bin Abi Lahab.

(Section)
The mother of Hashim is from Banu Sulaym. The children of Hashim bin Abd Manaf are Abd al-Muttalib, Asad, Abu Asad, Nadlah, Abu Fadlah, Sayfi, Abu Sayfi, Amr, and Abu Amr; these are Banu Hashim. From the children of Asad bin Hashim is Hunayn [or Hubayr], who did not leave offspring, and Fatimah, the mother of Ali bin Abi Talib.

(Section)
(And from the children of Abd Manaf), who is Abu al-Mughira bin Qusayy, are Hashim (whom we mentioned), Al-Muttalib, Nawfal, Abd Shams, Abu Shams, Abu Amr, Makhramah, and Alqamah.
From Banu Al-Muttalib are Al-Harith, Attab, Makhramah, and Hashim the Younger. From Banu Hashim is Imam Al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him. From Banu Al-Muttalib is Mistah bin Uthatha bin Abd al-Muttalib. The mother of Abd al-Muttalib is Salma bint Amr Al-Ansariyyah from Banu Al-Najjar.
Al-Shafi'i is Muhammad bin Idris bin Uthman bin Shafi' bin Al-Sa'ib bin Ubayd bin Abd Yazid bin Hashim bin Al-Muttalib bin Abd Manaf.
From the children of Nawfal bin Abd Manaf are Al-Khiyar, and Mut'im bin Adi bin Nawfal. From his [Mut'im's] descendants is Jubayr bin Mut'im bin Adi bin Nawfal, the genealogist of the Arabs, and he is the scribe of the Qur'an compilations for Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. The brothers of Mut'im bin Jubayr are Rabi'ah, Abdullah, and Salih, sons of Adi bin Nawfal bin Abd Manaf.

From Banu Abd Shams are Umayyah the Elder, Abd al-Uzza, Habib, and Rabi'ah. And children called Al-Abalat because their mother is Asma bint Mujib from Al-Tarahim from Tamim; they are Umayyah the Younger, Nawfal, Abu Sufyan, Umayyah the Younger, Abd Umayyah, and Nawfal.
From Banu Umayyah the Elder is Uthman bin Affan bin Al-As bin Umayyah bin Abd Shams. The children of Uthman bin Affan bin Al-As bin Umayyah bin Abd Shams are Abdullah the Elder, Abdullah the Younger, Amr, Aban, Khalid, Umar, Sa'id, Al-Walid, Al-Mughira, and Abd al-Malik. Also Muhammad bin Abdullah, who is the poet Al-Arji, bin Amr bin Uthman.
Among them are the Caliphs of Banu Umayyah: Mu'awiyah bin Yazid bin Abi Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan bin Harb bin Umayyah. Also Al-Walid bin Yazid bin Abd al-Malik bin Marwan bin Al-Hakam bin Abi Al-As bin Umayyah. From the children of Marwan are Aban, Abd al-Aziz, and Muhammad bin Abd al-Malik. Among them is Umar bin Abd al-Aziz bin Marwan and Marwan bin Muhammad bin Marwan. From Banu Abd al-Malik are Al-Walid, Hisham, Sulayman, Yazid, and Maslamah. Among them are Yazid and Ibrahim, sons of Al-Walid bin Abd al-Malik.
From Banu Umayyah is Uqbah bin Abi Mu'ayt bin Abi Amr bin Umayyah.
From Banu Umayyah is Uthman bin Asad bin Abi Al-Is bin Umayyah bin Abi Al-Ma'is bin Umayyah. Among them is Sa'id bin Al-As. He said: The A'yas are Al-As, Abu Al-As, Al-Is, Abu Al-Is, and Al-Uways from Banu Umayyah bin Abd Shams, known as Al-A'yas.
From Banu Abd al-Uzza bin Abd Shams is Abu Al-As bin Al-Rabi' bin Abd al-Uzza bin Abd Shams.
Among them are Utbah and Shaybah, sons of Rabi'ah bin Abd Shams, and Abu Hudhayfah and Al-Walid, sons of Utbah.
From Banu Umayyah the Younger is Al-Thurayya, whom Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah Al-Makhzumi used to flirt with in poetry. Her father is Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Umayyah the Younger bin Abd Shams, and she is the client of Al-Arid [?]. Suhayl bin Abd al-Rahman bin Awf married her, and regarding him Umar bin Abi Rabi'ah says in poetry:
O you who marries Thurayya to Suhayl...
May Allah prolong your life, how will they meet?
She is Syrian (Northern) when she rises,
And Suhayl (Canopus) when he rises is Yemeni (Southern).

He said: The 'Abbasids' (Anbas) are two [groups or individuals? likely refers to a group name]: Harb, Abu Harb, Sufyan, Amr, Abu Amr, and sons of Umayyah... [text unclear, likely referring to Al-Anbasa]. Asbar bin Abd Shams were killed in some of the days of Al-Fijar and were named 'Anbasiyyin', and Al-Anbas implies the strongest. The children of Amina are ten: four are the A'yas, and six are the Anbasiyyin, and we have mentioned them.

(Section)
Qusayy begot Abd Manaf (whom we mentioned), Abd al-Dar, Abd al-Uzza, and Asad. From Banu Abd al-Dar is Mus'ab bin Umayr bin Hashim bin Abd Manaf bin Abd al-Dar. Among them is Shaybah bin Uthman bin Abi Talha, who is Abdullah bin Abd al-Uzza bin Qusayy.
Al-Zubayr bin Al-Awwam bin Khuwaylid bin Asad bin Abd al-Uzza bin Qusayy. The children of Al-Zubayr are Abdullah, Mus'ab, Urwah, Al-Mundhir, Amir, Hamzah, Amr, Ubayd, and Ja'far, and nine daughters.
From Banu Qusayy is Hakim bin Hizam bin Khuwaylid bin Asad, and Abdullah bin Zam'ah bin Al-Aswad bin Al-Muttalib bin Asad, and Abu al-Bakhtari Al-As bin Hisham bin Al-Harith bin Asad, and Rabi'ah bin Nawfal bin Asad.
From Banu Abd bin Qusayy are Uthman and Jubayr, sons of Al-Harith bin Nufayl bin Abd bin Qusayy.

(Section)
Kilab begot Qusayy and Zuhrah.
From Banu Zuhrah is Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, who is Malik bin Uhayb bin Abd Manaf bin Zuhrah bin Kilab. Among them is the maternal uncle of the Prophet (peace be upon him), Abd al-Rahman bin Awf bin Abd Awf bin Al-Harith bin Zuhrah bin Kilab.

(Section)
From the descendants of Murrah are Banu Taym and Banu Makhzum.
From Banu Taym is Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him), Abdullah bin Uthman bin Amr bin Amir bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Taym bin Murrah. The children of Abu Bakr (may Allah be pleased with him) are Abdullah, Abd al-Rahman, and Muhammad. Among them is Talha bin Ubaidullah bin Uthman bin Amr bin Amir bin Ka'b.
From Banu Makhzum is Khalid bin Al-Walid bin Al-Walid bin Al-Mughira bin Abdullah bin Umar bin Makhzum bin Yaqazah bin Murrah. And Abu Salamah bin Abd al-Asad bin Al-Mughira. And Abu Jahl, whose name is Amr, and Al-Harith, sons of Hisham bin Al-Mughira. And Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib bin Hazn bin Abi Wahb bin Umar bin Makhzum. And Al-Muttalib bin Hanzalah bin Al-Harith bin Ubayd bin Umar bin Makhzum bin Yaqazah bin Murrah. Among them is the poet Umar bin Abdullah bin Abi Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Makhzum bin Yaqazah bin Murrah.

(Section)
From Banu Makhzum is the wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him), Umm Salamah bint Umayyah [sic, her father is Abu Umayyah].
From Banu Ka'b bin Lu'ay are Banu Adi and Banu Husays.
From Banu Adi is Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) bin Nufayl bin Abd al-Uzza bin Riah bin Abdullah bin Qurt bin Razah bin Adi. Born to Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) were Abdullah, Ubaidullah, Asim, Zaid the Elder, Zaid the Younger, Abd al-Rahman the Elder, Abd al-Rahman the Middle (who is Al-Mujabbar), Abd al-Rahman the Younger (who is Abu Shahmah), and Iyad. Abdullah bin Umar had children: Abdullah, Ubaidullah, Musalim, Asim, Waqid, Hamzah, Khalil, and Zaid.
From the descendants of Al-Khattab is Zaid bin Al-Khattab (who is older than Umar), Salim, and Qubaylah. Among them is Sa'id bin Zaid bin Amr bin Nufayl, to the end of the lineage.
From Banu Adi is Abu Khuzaymah bin Ghanim bin Abdullah bin Awf bin Abd Uwayj bin Adi.

As for Banu Husays, they are Jumah and Sahm, sons of Amr bin Husays bin Ka'b.
From Jumah are Uthman bin Abdullah and Qudamah, sons of Maz'un bin Habib bin Wahb bin Hudhafah bin Jumah. Among them is the Mu'adhin of the Prophet (peace be upon him), whose name is Aws bin Mughir bin Awdan bin Rabi'ah bin Uwayj bin Sa'id bin Jumah. Among them is Safwan bin Umayyah bin Khalaf bin Wahb bin Hudhafah bin Jumah, and Jamil bin Ma'mar bin Hudhafah. And Abu Mahdhurah, the Mu'adhin of the Prophet (peace be upon him), and he had children: Sa'd, Sa'id, Umar, Abd al-Aziz, and Rabab bin Maymun (from your saying 'Ra'aytu al-shay' meaning I repaired it).
Among them [Sahm] is Amr bin Al-As bin Wa'il bin Hashim bin Sa'id bin Sahm. Among them is Abdullah bin Al-Ziba'ra bin Qais bin Diyab bin Sahm. He said: There were men from Banu Sahm called Al-Ghayat (or Al-Ghaytal), and Al-Ghaytal is tangled trees. They are Harith, Adi, Hudhayfah, Al-Falkah, Abu Umayyah, Khaytab, and Diyab. It is said they were named that because they were attributed to their mother called Al-Ghaytalah.

(Section)
As for Lu'ay bin Ghalib...

He had children: Ka'b, Amir, Samah, Al-Harith, Abdullah, Khuzaymah, Sa'd, and Awf. The children of Al-Harith are called Banu Jusham; their nurse was a slave of Lu'ay called Jusham, so they were attributed to him.
As for Samah bin Lu'ay, he fell into Oman and died there, and there is a story about him. All names of Arabs are Usamah with Hamza on the Sin [sic, likely meant Alif/Hamza at start], except Samah bin Lu'ay. Al-Sam refers to veins of gold, singular Samah.
As for Amir bin Lu'ay, his children are Husayl and Uwayd. As for the children of Hisl (who is Al-A'lam): Suhayl bin Amr bin Abd Shams bin Abd Wudd bin Nasr bin Malik bin Hisl bin Amir bin Lu'ay. Among them is Amr bin Abd Wudd, whom Ali, may Allah honor his face, killed in a duel on the Day of the Trench, and his age was close to one hundred and forty years. Among them is the wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him), Sawdah bint Zam'ah bin Qais bin Abd Shams bin Abd Wudd. Among them is Abu Sabrah (and Sabrah is the prominent necklace) bin Abi Ruhm bin Abd al-Uzza bin Abi Qais bin Abd Wudd. Among them is Ibn Umm Maktum, the Mu'adhin of the Prophet (peace be upon him); Umm Maktum is his mother, and he is Abdullah bin Qais bin Malik bin Al-Asam bin Rawahah.
As for Sa'd bin Lu'ay, Abu Bananah: From his clan is Thabit Al-Bunani, and his children were attributed to her [Bunanah], who is his wife. Among them is Luqnan bin Juhayr bin Zaid bin Muqis bin Hisl bin Amir bin Lu'ay.

(Section)
Among them is Sa'd bin Abi Sarh bin Harith bin Habib bin Khuzaymah bin Nasr bin Malik bin Hisl bin Amir bin Lu'ay.
Ghalib begot Amr, Qais, and Taym (who is Al-Adram). Al-Adram begot Al-Harith, Tha'labah, Kathir, Wahb, and Haram. From them is Bishr bin Jabir bin Kathir. And Dhuhl bin Amr bin Abd Shams bin Makhzumah. And Amir bin Abdullah bin Makhzumah bin Abi Qais bin Urwah bin Hafs bin Malik bin Amr bin Ghalib.
As for Khuzaymah bin Lu'ay, from them are A'idh and Ma'ash the poet; Kathir Al-A'idhi is from them.

(Section)
Fihr begot Al-Harith and Muharib. From the descendants of Al-Harith is Abu Ubaidah, who is Amir bin Abdullah bin Al-Jarrah bin Hilal bin Uhayb bin Dabbah bin Al-Harith bin Fihr bin Malik.
Muharib bin Fihr begot Khalid the Elder bin Wahb bin Tha'labah bin Wa'ilah bin Amr bin Shayban bin Muharib bin Fihr. Among them is Dirar bin Al-Khattab bin Mirdas bin Kathir bin Amr bin Habib bin Amr bin Shayban bin Fihr bin Malik bin Al-Nadr. And he is Qurashi.
These are the clans of Quraysh: They are Banu Hashim, Banu Al-Muttalib, Banu Nawfal, Banu Umayyah, Banu Abd Shams, Banu Abd al-Dar, Banu Asad, Banu Shaybah, Banu Husays, Banu Amir bin Lu'ay, Banu Jusham, and Banu Al-Adram bin Ghalib (who are Muharib and Al-Harith, sons of Fihr bin Malik).
He said: There is no Hashimi on earth except from the descendants of Abd al-Muttalib, nor Husayni except from the descendants of Ali bin Al-Husayn.
He said: Quraysh is divided into two parts: Quraysh al-Bitah (of the valley) and Quraysh al-Zawahir (of the outskirts).
Quraysh al-Bitah are Banu Abd Manaf (who are Banu Hashim, Banu Al-Muttalib, Banu Nawfal, Banu Umayyah, Banu Abd Shams), Banu Qusayy bin Abd al-Dar, Abd al-Uzza bin Qusayy, Banu Zuhrah bin Kilab, Banu Taym bin Murrah, Banu Makhzum bin Yaqazah bin Murrah, Banu Ka'b, the children of Adi, and the children of Jumah and Sahm sons of Amr bin Husays bin Ka'b bin Lu'ay. These are Quraysh al-Bitah.
As for Quraysh al-Zawahir, they are Banu Fihr bin Muharib and Al-Harith sons of Fihr, Banu Al-Adram bin Ghalib bin Fihr, and Samah bin Amr bin Lu'ay.
As for Al-Hums, they are Quraysh, Kinanah, and those who followed their religion from Banu Amir bin Sa'sa'ah. It is said that Khuza'ah is also from Al-Hums. In Jahiliyyah, they used to be strict (yatahammasun) in their religion, meaning strictness and zeal (Hamasah). They would not go out to the plains during the days of Mina nor enter houses through their doors [during Hajj].
This is the lineage of Quraysh, who are the children of Al-Nadr bin Kinanah. It is said that Quraysh is the son of Fihr bin Malik, and it is said he is a gatherer because no Qurashi is found attributed to a father above Fihr. It is said the gatherer of all Quraysh is Fihr and Al-Harith sons of Malik bin Al-Nadr, and whoever traces lineage to Al-Nadr is not Qurashi because Al-Nadr begot Malik and Yakhlud. The first saying is the correct one.

(Section) Lineage of Kinanah in Khuzaymah

He said: Khuzaymah begot four: Kinanah, Asad, Asadah, and Al-Hun. The descendants of Asadah entered into Banu Asad.
Kinanah begot Abd Manat, Malik, Malkan, Amir, Ghanam, Makhzumah, Jadwal, Ghazwan, Jadal, Al-Nadr (who is Quraysh, and we have mentioned him), Nasr, Amr, Al-Harith, Sa'd, and Awf.
Abd Manat begot Bakr, Sa'd, Amir (who is Al-Adram), and Al-Harith. Ali bin Mas'ud bin Mazin bin Zi'b bin Adi bin Amr bin Mazin Al-Ghassani succeeded upon their mother after their father Abd Manat. She bore him Makhzumah, Awf, and Sa'idah. He nursed the sons of Abd Manat along with his own sons, so they were all attributed to him. Thus, Banu Abd Manat were called Banu Ali. Some people mistakenly said Abd Manat's name was Ali.
Bakr bin Abd Manat begot Layth, Damrah, and Al-Du'il (with Damma on Dal and Kasra on Hamza). If you attribute to it, you open the Hamza and say 'Du'ali', just as you say 'Namari' in attribution to Namir. And Al-Harith and Adi.
From the descendants of Layth bin Bakr is Al-Tu'il Amir bin Wa'ilah bin Abdullah bin Hams bin Judi bin Sa'd bin Layth. Among them is Al-Shaddakh Wathilah bin Al-Asqa' Abd al-Uzza bin Nufayl bin Nashib bin Ghirah bin Sa'd bin Layth; he accompanied the Prophet (peace be upon him) and narrated from him. Among them is Al-Shaddakh (with Damma on Shin and Fatha on Dal) bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Amir bin Layth. He was named Al-Shaddakh because he crushed (Shaddakha) the blood [money/feud] between Khuza'ah and Quraysh, saying: "I have crushed their blood under my foot," and he paid the blood money to his people excluding Khuza'ah.
From Banu Damrah is Amr bin Umayyah Al-Damri bin Qisan bin Talha bin Hudi bin Damrah. Among them is Abu Dharr, who is Jundub bin Junadah bin Sufyan bin Ubayd bin Abdullah bin Ghifar bin Alil bin Malik bin Damrah bin Bakr bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah. In the Hadith from him (peace be upon him) he said: "Ghifar, may Allah forgive it; and Aslam, may Allah keep it safe."
From Banu Al-Du'il is Abu al-Aswad al-Du'ali, who is Uthman bin Amr bin Sufyan bin Jandal bin Ya'mar bin Hulays bin Thafathah bin Adi bin Al-Du'il.
From the descendants of Sa'd bin Abd Manat is Qasim bin Ubayd bin Abdullah bin Sa'd bin Al-Ramah bin Sa'd bin Abd Manat.
From the descendants of Murrah [likely meant Amrah or similar from context] bin Abd Manat is Suraqah bin Malik bin Ju'shum bin Muhriz bin Al-A'war bin Ja'dah bin 'Adh bin 'Itwarah bin Amr bin Mudlij bin Murrah bin Abd Manat. Among them is Alqamah bin Muhriz, who was a tracker (Qa'if). Banu Mudlij are the trackers.
From Abd Manat are Habib and Al-Harith, sons of Taym bin Zaid bin Murrah bin Abd Manat. Among them is Qais bin Amir bin Abd Manat. Among them are Banu Khuzaymah bin Amir bin Murrah bin [text unclear, possibly Lamjad Mashah] bin Kinanah.

(Section)
From the children of [text missing, likely Kinanah] are Al-Harith, Adi, Tha'labah, Haddad, Sa'd, Sa'idah, and Khashashah.
From the descendants of Al-Harith is Al-Husayn bin Amir bin Abdullah bin Al-Muqsim bin Muhammad bin Maymun bin Ubayd bin Raziq bin Amir. And Haml bin Shaqq bin Raqabah bin Makhdaj bin Amir bin Tha'labah bin Al-Harith bin Malik. Among them are the two Qa'ims: Hudhayfah bin Adi bin Fuqaym bin Adi bin Alqamah bin Tha'labah bin Al-Harith bin Malik. Banu Fuqaym are the Nasi'ah (postponers of sacred months). Among them is Al-Qalammas bin Fuqaym, who used to make war lawful one month and postpone it another month. Among them is Rabi'ah bin Amir bin Hadman bin Khalid bin Alqamah bin Firas bin Malik bin Kinanah.
From the descendants of Adi bin Malik is Mashhar bin Qamhur bin Hunayf bin Lajrif bin Hararah bin Awf bin Amtah bin Qala' bin Iyad bin Hudhayfah Al-Ba'as bin Adi bin Malik.

(Section)
From the descendants of Malkan (with Kasra on Mim or Fatha with Sukun on Lam) bin Kinanah are Tha'labah, Sa'd, Ghanam, Haram, Awf, Malik, and Majdaj. Among them is Al-Qalammas bin Amir bin Ka'b bin Amir bin Majdaj bin Malkan bin Kinanah.
These are the clans of Kinanah: Banu Al-Layth, Banu Damrah, Banu Ghifar, Banu Fuqaym, Banu Mudlij, Banu Firas, and Banu Ubar.
As for the Ahabish, they are those who allied (tahabbashu) together. They are Banu Al-Harith bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah, Banu Nufathah, Banu Al-Haya from Khuza'ah, and Al-Qarah from Banu Al-Hun bin Khuzaymah. The one who contracted the alliance of Al-Qarah is Taym bin Amir bin Awf bin Al-Harith bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah. The one who contracted the alliance of the rest is the brother of Malik bin Amir bin Awf bin Al-Harith bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah.

**Lineage of Asad bin Khuzaymah**

Asad bin Khuzaymah was the brother of Quraysh through his mother Barrah bint Murr bin Add bin Tabikhah.
The children of Asad bin Khuzaymah are: Dudan, Kahil, Amr, Khuzaymah, Burdah, Sa'b, and Jalhubah.
From the descendants of Dudan bin Asad are: Ghanam, Tha'labah, Al-Harith, Sa'd, and Malik.
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Tha'labah is Yahda' (with dotted Ya) bin Asfan bin Sa'd bin Al-Harith bin Jahm Al-Usayyid bin Jahwan. And Qu'ayn bin Amr bin Qu'ayn. And Al-Sayda' Abdullah bin Amr bin Qu'ayn bin Zarif. And Qu'ayn bin Habib bin Usamah bin Malik bin Nasr bin Qu'ayq bin Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Dudan bin Asad. The name of Al-Sayda' is Amr, and he had children: Nukrah, Khuzaymah, Nawfal, and Muqashshar.
Among them is Tulayhah bin Khuwaylid bin Nawfal bin Nadlah bin Al-Ashyad bin Hijran to the end of the lineage. He was considered a knight. He is the one who claimed prophethood, was captured on the Day of Apostasy, and returned to Islam.
Among them is Bishr bin Abi Khazim, who is Amr bin Awf bin Humayri bin Mashirah bin Usamah bin Walibah bin Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Dudan bin Asad.
Among them is Abd Bani Al-Has'has, Suhaym bin Hudandi Saqa bin Ghifar bin Ka'b bin Tha'labah bin Asad bin Dudan bin Asad.

(Section)
From the descendants of Sa'd bin Tha'labah is Ubayd bin Al-Abras bin Jusham bin Amir bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Tha'labah.
Among them is Al-Kumayt bin Zaid Al-Akhnas bin Zaid bin Mukhalid bin Rabi'ah bin Qais bin Al-Harith bin Wahb bin Amir bin Amr bin Malik bin Sa'd bin Tha'labah.
From Banu Malik bin Tha'labah is Nathib bin Salamah bin Malik bin Tha'labah. And Ghadirah and Amr bin Malik bin Tha'labah bin Dudan bin Asad.

(Section)
From Banu Dudan is the Companion of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), Abs bin Ya'mar bin Sabrah bin Murrah bin Kabir bin Ghanam bin Dudan. His mother is Zainab bint Jahsh, the wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him). He had brothers: Abu Ahmad and Abdullah. They all migrated to Abyssinia. Umm Habibah bint Abi Sufyan was the wife of Ubaydullah bin Jahsh; he converted to Christianity in Abyssinia and died there as a Christian, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) married Umm Habibah after him.
From Banu Ghadirah is Ibn Husayn bin Hurayth bin Aws bin Bilal bin Sa'd bin Jamal bin Nasr bin Ghadirah bin Malik bin Tha'labah bin Dudan bin Asad.
Among them is Ukashah bin Mihsan bin Harthan bin Qais bin Murrah bin Ka'b bin Ghanam bin Dudan bin Asad.

(Section)
From the descendants of Amr bin Asad are Al-Musayyib, Al-Namir, Al-Qulayb, Al-Musallih, Hashim, and Al-Halik. Al-Halik was the first to work iron, and because of him, the Arabs used to taunt Banu Asad and Banu Amr specifically, calling them 'Al-Quyun' (The Smiths). It is said iron is 'Haliki', attributed to Al-Halik bin Amr bin Asad.

(Section)
From Banu Kahil bin Asad is Al-Hadidi bin Man bin Kahil, and 'Ilba' bin Al-Harith bin Harithah bin Hilal bin Kahil.
From Banu Sa'b bin Asad is Abdullah bin Sa'b bin Asad.
These are the clans of Banu Asad. Among them are Kahil, Faq'as, Al-Sayda', Qu'ayn, Walibah, Nashib, and Ghadirah, and we have mentioned their lineages.

**Lineage of Al-Hun bin Khuzaymah**
He said: Khuzaymah begot three: Kinanah, Asad (we have mentioned them), and Al-Hawn (with Fatha on Ha, and it is said Al-Hun with Damma, but the first is more correct) bin Al-Ma'um bin Khuzaymah.
He begot Malih and Al-Hakam. Malih begot Yashay', and they entered into Madhhij and attributed themselves to them. Al-Hakam bin Al-Hun attributed himself to Sa'd al-Ashirah bin Madhhij, so they said Al-Hakam bin Sa'd. They are the clan of the Emir Al-Jarrah bin Abdullah Al-Hakami. The poet said:
"O Hakam bin Al-Hun, are you not Madhhij?
While you have settled in a flow from Jadhimah, clear and bright."
The correct view is that Al-Hakam is son of Sa'd bin Madhhij, and Allah knows best.
Banu Al-Hun are Al-Qarah, and their brothers are Adal (with Damma on Ayn and Fatha on Dad).
From Al-Qarah is Mas'ud bin Amir bin Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Abd al-Uzza bin Muhallim bin Ghalib bin Abid Yattaba' bin Malih bin Al-Hun bin Khuzaymah.
Al-Qarah are the descendants of Muhallim bin Ghalib entirely except Adal. It is said that Adal is also Qarah. Al-Qarah was named Qarah because Ya'mar bin Awf Al-Kinani wanted to disperse them among the clans of Kinanah, so a man from them said a verse:
"Leave us as Qarah (a settled mass), do not scatter us,
Lest we flee like the fleeing of the ostrich."
So they were named Al-Qarah for that. Al-Qarah is a small mountain. It is said that Adal and Al-Qarah are sons of Yattaba' bin Al-Hun bin Khuzaymah, and Allah knows best.

**Lineage of Hudhayl bin Mudrikah**

The derivation of Hudhayl is from 'Al-Hadhal', which is agitation/disorder.
He said: Hudhayl begot Sa'd, Lihyan, Umar, and Harmah. Sa'd bin Hudhayl begot Tamim, Haras, Man'ah, Quda'ah, Jiham, 'Aym, Qadin, and Tahwil.
From the descendants of Sa'd are: Abdullah and Utbah, sons of Mas'ud bin Ghafil (with dotted Ghayn) bin Habib bin Shamkh bin Qadin bin Makhzum. And Khuzaymah bin Sahilah bin Kahil bin Al-Harith bin Tamim bin Sa'd bin Hudhayl.
Among them is Abu Bakr Kabir bin Thabit bin Abd Shams bin Khalid bin Amr bin Abd Ka'b bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Kahil.
Among them is Rib'i bin Habib bin Suwayd bin Rabah bin Kulayb bin Ka'b bin Kahil.
Among them is Abu Dhu'ayb the poet, who is Khuwaylid bin Zaid bin Makhzum bin Sahilah to the end of the lineage from the descendants of Lihyan bin Hudhayl.
Among them is Ghirah bin Ariyah bin Ka'b bin Tanjeh bin Hudhayl.
Among them is Hababah bin Sa'd bin Hudhayl.
The sons of Sa'd bin Hudhayl are: Khuna'ah, Human, Da'ah, Urf, Rahm, Rayb, Hurayth, Huwayyah, Jiham, and Ghanam. Lihyan with Kasra on Lam in Hudhayl, and with Damma in Jamhar.
The clans of Hudhayl are Banu Lihyan, Banu Wahman, Banu Ghaziyah, Banu Sahilah, Banu Za'inah (from Za'n meaning travel), and Banu Khuna'ah (from Khunu' meaning submissiveness).

**Lineage of the Descendants of Tabikhah bin Ilyas bin Mudar**
He said: Tabikhah begot Add. Add begot Abd Manat, Amr, Khamis, and Murr (who is Abu Tamim bin Murr).
Abd Manat begot Tamim, Adi, Awf, Ashayb, and Thawr Al-Mahl. Al-Mahl is a mountain to which Thawr was attributed, so it was said Thawr Al-Mahl.
The descendants of Abd Manat are called Al-Rabab. Some count Dabbah bin Add among them, and others count Muzaynah bin Add among them. They were called Al-Rabab because they allied against Banu Sa'd bin Zaid bin Tamim and gathered like the gathering of 'Rababah' (a bundle of arrows), or it is said they dipped their hands in 'Rubb' (syrup/thick juice) when they allied.
As for Ukl, she was a slave woman who nursed the children of Awf bin Aqyas bin Wa'il bin Awf bin Abd Manat, so they were attributed to her.
He said: From Ukl is the poet Al-Namir bin Tawlab bin Zuhayr bin Aqyas bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Awf bin Add bin Al-Harith bin Ukl bin Awf bin Aqyas bin Wa'il bin Awf bin Abd Manat. Ukl is part of Al-Rabab.
From the descendants of Taym bin Abd Manat is Jassas (with light Jim) bin Sabbah bin Rabi' bin Rabi' bin Amr bin Abdullah bin Lu'ay bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Taym.
From the descendants of Adi bin Abd Manat is Dhu al-Rummah, who is Ghaylan, and his brothers Hisham and Mas'ud, sons of Harithah bin Adi bin Rabi'ah bin Sa'idah bin Ka'b bin Awf bin Tha'labah bin Rabi'ah bin Malkan bin Adi bin Abd Manat.
From the descendants of Thawr bin Abd Manat is the ascetic jurist Al-Rabi' bin Khuthaym. It is said there were thirty men in Banu Thawr, none of whom was less than Al-Rabi' bin Khuthaym. They are in Kufa.
Among them is Sufyan bin Sa'd bin Murrah bin Habib bin Rafi' bin Abdullah bin Mawhibah from Banu Abdullah bin Munqidh bin Nasr bin Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Amir bin Malkan bin Thawr bin Abd Manat.

**Lineage of Dabbah bin Add**
He said: Dabbah bin Add begot Sa'd, Amr, and Basil. Basil is the father of the Daylam according to what is said; that is because Basil bin Dabbah went out to the land of Daylam and dressed them like the dress of Arabs and prepared them in the manner of Arabs in raids and seeking revenge.
He said: It is said Sa'd had no offspring. All of Dabbah traces back to Sa'd bin Dabbah [sic, text says Sa'd had no offspring then traces back to him, likely a corruption or means Dabbah traces back to someone else or Sa'd bin Dabbah is meant].
From the descendants of Sa'd bin Dabbah is the judge Abdullah bin Shubrumah bin Al-Tufayl bin Hubayrah bin Al-Mundhir bin Hassan bin Dirar.
Among them is Zaid Al-Fawaris bin Husayn bin Dirar.
Among them is Al-Ghamr bin Amr bin Malik bin Zaid bin Ka'b bin Thuhalah bin Dhuhl bin Malik bin Bakr bin Sa'd bin Dabbah.
Dirar bin Amr had ten children who were called Al-Maradimah because each one of them was like a 'Mirdam' (stone breaker). They are the house of Dabbah.
Dabbah bin Add was on the religion of Sulayman bin Dawud, peace be upon him. It is narrated from Ibn Abbas that he said: Dabbah bin Add was on the religion of Sulayman bin Dawud, peace be upon him, and Asad bin Khuzaymah died on Islam.

**Lineage of Muzaynah**
Muzaynah was the wife of Amr bin Add; she prevailed over the lineage of her children. She is the daughter of Kalb bin Wabrah.
From the descendants of Amr bin Add are Uthman and Uways.
From the descendants of Uthman is Bilal bin Al-Harith bin Qadin bin Halawah bin Tha'labah bin Thawr bin Harmah bin Al-Asam bin Uthman bin Amr bin Add.
Among them is the poet Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma (with Damma on Sin), who is Rabi'ah bin Qurt bin Rabah bin Al-Awwam bin Qurt bin Al-Harith bin Mazin to the end of the lineage. The sons of Zuhayr are Ka'b and Bujayr. Every 'Sulma' in Arabs is with Fatha on Sin except Al-Aslami Abu Zuhayr, for he found it with Damma.
From the descendants of Uways bin Amr is Al-Qadi bin Ma'unah bin Hurrah bin Iyas bin Hilal bin Thabit bin Ubayd bin Sarah bin Sariyah bin Dahman bin Tha'labah bin Salman bin Uways bin Amr bin Add.
Among them is Al-Nu'man bin Ma'di bin Abid bin Sajl bin Hujayr bin Nasr bin Hasanah bin Ka'b bin Abd Thawr to the end of the lineage.

Khamis bin Add.
He said: Banu Khamis were with Abrahah Al-Ashram the Abyssinian, so they perished on the Day of the Elephant. Only sixty men survived from them. To this day, they remain sixty men, not exceeding that; if a boy is born to them, a man among them dies. They are counted among Banu Tamim; those in Kufa are among Banu Mujashi', and those in Basra are among Banu Abdullah bin Darim.
He said: Among Banu Khamis is Juz' bin Nadlah bin Malik bin Zaid bin Ghiyath bin Malik bin Yazid bin Harb bin Khamis bin Add.

**Lineage of Tamim bin Murr bin Add**
He said: Murr bin Add begot Tamim, Amir, Tha'labah, Bakr, Arasah (who are in Judham), Al-Gharth (in Yemen), and Ya'fur.
Ya'fur bin Murr begot Al-Ma'afir, as they claim, who are the majority of Yemen. It was written on his grave: "I am Al-Ma'afir bin Ya'fur, Mudari." A genealogy that pleases Himyar. Some people say in another narration: "I am Al-Ma'afir bin Murr, Mudari, I planted a clan from Himyar." He said: Al-Ma'afir today say: Ma'afir bin Ya'fur bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Murr bin Add bin Zaid bin Babthajab [?].
As for Al-Gharth bin Murr, from his descendants is Sufah, who is Al-Zubayr bin Al-Gharth bin Murr. They held the license (Ijaza) for pilgrims in Jahiliyyah, leading the people. Then the license moved to Banu Ghatafan bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Zaid bin Manat.
Among the descendants of Al-Gharth bin Murr is Shurahbil bin Abd al-Uzza, who is called Shurahbil bin Habib, one of the best Muslims; he witnessed the conquests of Sham.
The descendants of Al-Gharth bin Murr were in Yemen, and [the flood of] Ma'rib descended upon them, Sa'd, and killed them, so the descendants of Al-Gharth bin Murr perished.
He said: As for Tamim bin Murr, he begot Zaid Manat, Amr, and Al-Harith.
From the descendants of Zaid Manat are Hajib, Laqit, and Alqamah, sons of Zurarah. Their mother is Madiyah Al-Darimiyah, one of the noble women in Jahiliyyah. He is Zurarah bin Udas bin Zaid bin Abdullah bin Darim bin Malik bin Zaid Manat bin Tamim bin Isma'in [sic] bin Tamim bin Nu'aym bin Zaid bin Abi Al-Nu'aym [bin] Atarid bin Hajib.
Atarid begot Malik, Qais, Laqit, Labid, and Umaydar. Umayr [Umaydar?] begot Muhammad, Laqit, Alqamah, Khuzaymah, Amr, Abu Al-Harith, Mas'ud, Malik the Scribe, Labid, and Ma'bad. From them is Al-Qa'qa' bin Amr bin Awf bin Al-Qamqa' bin Ma'bad bin Zurarah.
He said: Udas (with Damma on Ayn and Fatha on Dal) begot Dhumar, Ju'al, Sa'd, Mas'ud, Shurahbil, Amr, and Banwa.
He said: Zaid bin Ubaydallah begot Rabi'ah, Hayyan, Abdullah, Ja'a, Murrah, Malik, Mu'awiyah, and Al-Harith. And Hamman (derived from Al-Ahm), his name is Abd al-Uzza. And Udas, whom we mentioned.

The Allies (Ahlaf) from Banu Darim are all the sons of Zaid bin Abdullah except Banu Udas bin Zaid, who are with the rest of Banu Abdullah.
As for Abdullah bin Darim, his children are Mu'awiyah, Murrah, Abd Manat, Fahm, Muntabi'ah, Malik, Fa'yah, Rahb, Qannah, and Zaid. The House [of leadership] was in him. The name of Darim was Bahr.

(Section)
As for Darim, its derivation is from 'Darman', which is short steps. It is said: He came 'yadrimu' in his walk if he takes short steps. It could also be from saying: 'Rajul Adram' and 'Imra'ah Darma' if there is no bulk to their bones.
The children of Darim are Abdullah, Mujashi', Nahshal, Sadus, Khaybari, Jarir, Aban, Al-Jawwal, Munaf, and Sultan.
Jarir begot Fuqaym bin Jarir. Sadus begot Al-Harith bin Sadus.
As for Mujashi', its derivation is from 'Jasha'', which is the worst greed. Mujashi' had eloquence and clarity. He had children: Abdullah, Tha'labah, Sulaytan, Nu'man, Amr, Amir, Mujashi', Al-Ahmar, Al-Abyad, Al-Ahram, Haram, and Sufyan.
From the descendants of Sufyan is Al-Farazdaq, who is Hammam bin Ghalib bin Sa'sa'ah bin Najiyah bin Iqal bin Muhammad bin Sufyan bin Mujashi'.
Among them is Al-Aqra' bin Habis bin Iqal to the end of the lineage. The name of Al-Aqra' is Firas, and his brother is Yazid bin Habis.
As for Nahshal, its derivation is from their saying: 'Nahshala al-rajul' and 'Hanshala' if he ages and trembles. Nahshal is one of the names of the wolf. He had children: Harith, Jandal, and Sakhr.
From Banu Sakhr is Khuzaymah bin Ham bin Abdullah bin Hanzalah bin Nadlah bin Harith (who is Mutlaq) bin Sakhr bin Nahshal.
Among them is A'yun bin Nadlah bin Iqal, who is Abu Al-Nawar, wife of Al-Farazdaq. He is the one who hamstrung Aisha's camel.
Among them is Al-Aswad bin Ya'fur bin Abd Al-Aswad bin Jandal bin Nahshal.

(Section)
Malik bin Hanzalah begot Ka'b...

Jushaysh, Awf, Abu al-Aswad, and Yarbu'. These are Banu Malik and Banu Al-Adawiyya. Awf and Abu al-Aswad are called Banu Tahiyyah. Banu Tahiyyah are also called Banu Al-Adawiyya Al-Himal. Within Tahiyyah are Banu Al-Shaytan (a clan). Rabi'ah, Rizam, Ka'b, and Juhaysh are called Al-Hisan.
Jarir said:
"Are Tha'labah the horsemen, or Ziyaha?
You equated Tahiyyah and Al-Hisan with them."
In Banu Tahiyyah is Al-Shaytan bin Zayr bin Zahwan bin Rabi'ah bin Abi al-Aswad bin Malik.

As for Hanzalah bin Malik, he had eight sons. Five of them are Al-Barajim: Amr, Qais, Ghalib, Zultum (who is Al-Harith), and Kulfah. They were named Al-Barajim because they said: "We gather like the knuckles (Barajim) of the hand." Al-Barajim are what appear when you clench your fist. The other three are Malik, Rabi'ah, and Yarbu'.
The children of Yarbu' bin Hanzalah are Rabah, Tha'labah, Al-Harith, Sabirah, Kulayb, Ghadanah (who is Al-Asras), Al-Anbar, and Amr.
Tha'labah, Amr, Al-Harith, and Sabirah are called Al-Ahmal. Kulayb, Ghadanah, and Al-Anbar are called Al-Uqad because they made a pact against Rabah.
The derivation of Ghadanah is from 'Taghadun', which is relaxing in something.
Among them is Da'i bin Al-Harith bin Artah bin Shihab bin Ubayd bin Khadhil bin Qais bin Hanzalah bin Malik bin Sa'd bin Zaid bin Manat bin Tamim.
From the descendants of Awf bin Kulayb bin Yarbu' is Jarir bin Atiyah bin Al-Khatafa, who is Hudhayfah bin Zaid bin Salamah bin Zaid bin Kulayb bin Yarbu'.
From Banu Al-Anbar bin Yarbu' is Sajah, who claimed prophethood and married Musaylimah the Liar. She is Sajah bint Al-Aswad bin Aws bin Haqq bin Usamah bin Al-Anbar bin Yarbu'. Regarding her, Atarid bin Hajib says:
"Our prophetess has become a female surrounded by [people]...
And we used to see the prophets of people as males."
He said: Amr bin Yarbu' is the one who married a ghoul (Si'lah). It was said to him: You will find her the best woman as long as she does not see lightning. So he used to block the gaps of the house. She bore him Asal and Damdam. Then she saw lightning at some time and said: "Hold your sons, Amr, for I am escaping; lightning over the land of ghouls." Then she fled from him and passed. A Rajiz poet says about them:
"May Allah fight the sons of the Si'lat,
Amr bin Yarbu' the worst of people,
Neither virtuous nor wise."
He meant 'Sharar al-Nas' (worst of people) and 'Ghayr Akyas' (not wise) but changed Sin to Ta.

(Section)
As for Malik bin Zaid bin Manat, his children are Murrah, Tha'labah, Rabi'ah, Mu'awiyah, Qais, Sa'd, and Bakr. Mu'awiyah and Qais bin Malik are called Al-Kurdusan because they used to camp together.
As for Zaid Manat bin Tamim, his children are Sa'd (who is Al-Farazdaq [sic - likely means great leader or referencing poet]), Sabir, Amr, Abdullah, and Saramah.
Sa'd, who is 'Awafah al-Banna', begot Al-Harith, Jusham, 'Usayyah, Hammad, Imru' al-Qais, and Ka'b.
Abd Shams (with Damma on Ba in nominative, accusative, and genitive) originally 'Ubb Shams', meaning idol of sun, named so for his hugeness.
From the descendants of Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Zaid Manat is Al-Hammar, who is Abd al-Uzza bin Ka'b bin Sa'd.
Among them is the master of the tent-dwellers (Ahl al-Wabar) Qais bin Asim bin Sinan bin Khalid bin Munqidh bin Ubayd bin Al-Harith, who is Muqa'is bin Amr bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Zaid bin Manat. Qais bin Asim had thirty-three children, among them Al-Qa'qa', Samah, and Talabah. From the descendants of Talabah is Mayya, the beloved of Dhu al-Rummah.
Among them are Al-Aharith and Nu'm, two clans: Banu Rabi'ah bin Sa'd and Banu Al-A'raj bin Sa'd.
Among them is Hudath bin Murabbi' bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Sa'd.
Among them is Malik bin Imru' al-Qais bin Zaid Manat.
Among them is Al-Salil bin Sa'd bin Murri bin Sinan bin Humayr bin Muqa'is (who is Al-Harith bin Amr bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Zaid Manat). He was named Muqa'is because he held back (Taqa'asa) in Banu Sa'd. He was one of the horsemen and poets of the Arabs.
Among them is Al-Zibriqan bin Badr bin Imru' al-Qais bin Khalaf bin Bahdalah bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Zaid Manat. He was named Al-Zibriqan bin Badr bin Imru' al-Qais due to his beauty, and he was called the Moon of Najd; his name was Al-Husayn.
Among them is Al-Ahnaf, Sakhr bin Qais bin Mu'awiyah bin Husayn bin Abbad bin Urwah bin Ubayd to the end of the lineage.

(Section)
As for Amr bin Tamim, his children are Malik, Ka'b, Antar, Al-Harith, Al-Hujaym, Usayyid, and Al-Sulayb. As for Usayyid, it is the diminutive of Aswad in the dialect of Banu Tamim. He is nicknamed Al-Habat and his sons Al-Hubatan. He was nicknamed that because he ate a large amount of gum and his belly swelled (Habita), i.e., bloated.
From Banu Usayyid bin Amr is the poet Aws bin Hajar (moving Ha and Jim) bin Ghiyath bin Abdullah bin Adi bin Namir bin Usayyid bin Amr.
Among them is Aktham bin Sayfi bin Rabah bin Al-Harith bin Mahasin bin Mu'awiyah bin Sharif bin Jarwah bin Usayyid bin Amr. He was one of the wise men of the Arabs in Jahiliyyah and lived one hundred and ninety years. He is the one who said:
"If a man has lived ninety years
To one hundred, he wearies of life and struggles."

Aktham's derivation is from 'Kathamah', which is largeness of the belly.
Among them is Abu Halah bin Zurarah bin Nabbas bin Adi bin Habib bin Mirdas bin Salamah bin Jarrah bin Usayyid bin Amr bin Tamim. He was the husband of Khadijah bint Khuwaylid before the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Tamim are Jusham, Al-Harith, and Ka'b, who are Banu Shaqrah. He is Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Tamim. He was named Shaqrah for a verse of Khalid:
"I carry the solid spear, its knots...
On it from the blood of the people like Shaqr (anemones)."
Al-Shaqrah is a flower likened to anemones. He said: And on the horses blood like Shaqr.
From the descendants of Al-Harith are Ghaylan bin Tamim, Ghaykan, Ghassan, and Al-Jarmaz (who is Al-Harith bin Abdullah). Banu Malik bin Amr bin Tamim and Zaynabah bin Mazin bin Malik bin Amr bin Tamim, these tribes are called Al-Hissan.
From the descendants of Mazin bin Malik is Al-Dubari bin Hajbah bin Kinaniyah bin Harqus bin Mazin. From the descendants of Kinaniyah bin Harqus is the Kharijite Qatari bin Al-Fuja'ah, nicknamed Abu Na'amah. He rebelled in the time of Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr when he was twenty years old, and was greeted as Caliph. Some people attribute him to Banu Tamim.
The derivation of Mazin is from 'Al-Muzn', which is clouds. It is said: So-and-so 'yatamazzan' upon us if he is generous. Al-Mazin is also ant eggs.
Among the Arabs, Mazin are [several] clans: This Mazin bin Malik bin Amr bin Tamim, Mazin bin Sa'sa'ah brother of Amir bin Sa'sa'ah, Mazin bin Shayban, Mazin bin Mansur brother of Hawazin and Sulaym, Mazin known in Zubid bin Madhhij, Mazin bin Al-Najjar in Al-Ansar, Mazin bin Fazarah bin Dhubyan, Mazin bin Tha'labah bin Sa'd bin Sa'd bin Dhubyan, and Mazin bin Al-Azd bin Al-Gharth.
He said: Sa'd, Amr, and Al-Najim sons of Amr bin Tamim, Al-Harith, Mu'awiyah, and Hubayrah are called Al-Ajmal. They are the sons of Da'ah bint Ma'n, who is from the descendants of Iyad bin Nizar. Amr bin Jandal bin Al-Anbar bin Amr bin Tamim married her, and she bore him Al-Najim bin Amr bin Tamim.
These are the tribe of Tamim and its clans: Al-Hujaymi, Al-Anbari, Al-Mazini, Al-Darimi, Al-Mujashi'i, Al-Nahshali, Al-Sadusi, Al-Silawi [?], Al-Shamsi, Al-Yarbu'i, Al-Riyahi, Al-Sulayti, Al-Rahmi [?], Al-Fawani, Al-Minqari, Al-Sa'di, and Al-Utaridi, among others we belittled [skipped].
These are the tribes of the children of Ilyas bin Mudar.
His sons are the tribes of Qais bin Ghaylan bin Mudar bin Nizar.

**Lineage of Qais bin Aylan**
He said: Mudar begot Ilyas and Al-Nas (with Nun and stressed Sin, from saying 'Nasitu' the news if you hid it, and 'Nassat' the snake if it bit). He is Aylan. He was named Aylan because he was poor and used to ask his brother, so he said to him: "You are but a dependent ('Iyal) upon me," so he was named Aylan. It is said Aylan was named after a nurse who nursed Mudar bin Nizar, and his name was Aylan, just as Arabs were attributed to those who nursed them. It is said he was named Aylan [because] there was a man from Bajilah called Qais who had a horse named Kubbah, and they were neighbors and their horses were famous, so it was said: Qais Aylan and Qais Kubbah. Qais Aylan is Qais Mudar, and Qais Kubbah is Qais Mudar bin Al-Gharth bin Bajilah. According to this, he is Qais bin Mudar. The correct and famous view is that he is Qais Aylan, and he is Al-Nas bin Mudar.
He said: He begot Khasafah, Sa'd, and Amr. It is said he had a fourth son named Murrah, who left Hijaz seeking camels of his in the western region, fell into the land of the Berbers, married a woman from them, begot children, lived among them until he died, and his progeny spread. It is said that a group of Berbers are from his descendants. Many people have denied this and know only three children for him.

(Section)
As for Khasafah...

He begot Ikrimah and Muharib. Al-Kalbi said: Ikrimah bin Khasafah bin Qais, and Allah knows best.
He said: From the descendants of Muharib bin Khasafah are: Haddad bin Mu'awiyah bin Sa'd bin Badawah bin Dhuhl bin Tarif bin Khalaf bin Muharib, and Wahsh bin Muharib.
As for Ikrimah, from his descendants are Mansur and Abu Malik.
From the descendants of Abu Malik are Al-Harith and Al-Du'il, sons of Hammaz bin Rabah bin Abu Malik bin Ikrimah.
As for Mansur, he begot Hawazin, Mazin, Sulaym, and Salaman.

**Lineage of Hawazin**
He said: Hawazin is the plural of Hawzan, which is a type of bird. From the descendants of Hawazin are Bakr and Harb.
From the descendants of Bakr are Mu'awiyah, Sa'id, and Munabbih.
From the descendants of Mu'awiyah are Khalid, Umar, and Abu Amr (who is Khalid bin Ja'far bin Kilab bin Rabi'ah bin Amir bin Sa'sa'ah bin Mu'awiyah bin Bakr bin Hawazin bin Mansur bin Ikrimah bin Khasafah bin Qais).
From the descendants of Khalid bin Ja'far are Umar, Amir, Uwaymir, Anas, Hadan, Duraym, and Sur.
From the descendants of Arbad bin Qais bin Jarir is Khalid.
From the descendants of Ja'far bin Kilab are Mu'awiyah, Ghayd, Sulaym, Utbah, Malik, and Al-Ahwas.
From the descendants of Al-Ahwas is Alqamah bin Ulathah bin Awf bin Al-Ahwas bin Ja'far.
From the descendants of Malik are Amir bin Al-Tufayl bin Malik bin Ja'far, Labid bin Rabi'ah bin Malik, Abu Bara' (Mula'ib al-Asinnah), Mu'awiyah (Mu'awwid al-Hukama'), Ubaydah (Al-Waddah), and Tufayl (Al-Jandal). Between Qadar and Rabi'ah are the Mu'ammarun (long-lived). As for Labid, their mother is Umm al-Banin bint Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Amir bin Rabi'ah bin Amir bin Sa'sa'ah. About that, Labid says:
"They circled Umm al-Banin the four,
And we are the best of Amir bin Sa'sa'ah."
He made them four for the rhyme, but they are five.
Labid bin Rabi'ah accepted Islam. He is the one who said:
"Praise be to Allah, my term did not come to me,
Until I was clothed with the shirt of Islam."
And Sulayman bin Malik, who is Al-Nazil (the settler) when constrained. Among them is Abu Sharik, and Urwah (Al-Rahhal) bin Uqbah bin Ja'far.

(Section)
From the children of Kilab bin Rabi'ah are Shurahbil bin Qurt bin Al-A'war bin Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Kilab. And Ka'b (who is Al-Adbat), Al-Wahid, Abdullah, Abu Bakr (whose name is Ubayd), Khidash, Abd, Amr, Rabi'ah, Mu'awiyah, Amir, Al-Hawth (who is Qashif), and Ja'far (whom we mentioned).
From the descendants of Al-Adbat is Jubayr bin Wahb bin Zaid bin Al-Adbat.
Among them are Al-Dabab, who are Dabb, Dabib, Hisl, and Husayl sons of Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Kilab. From Al-Dabab is Shamir bin Dhi al-Jawshan, may Allah curse him and bless him not, the killer of Al-Husayn bin Ali, peace be upon him.
Among them are Yazid, Zur'ah, and Abs, sons of Amr bin Al-Sahn.
Among them is the poet Bahis bin Nuhah bin Nush bin Nahik bin Imam bin Jahdam bin Shihab bin Anas bin Zam'ah bin Ka'b bin Abi Bakr bin Kilab.

(Section)
From the descendants of Rabi'ah in Amir bin Sa'sa'ah are Kilab (whom we mentioned), Ka'b, and Amir.
From the descendants of Ka'b bin Rabi'ah are Kilab, Kulayb, Abdullah, Al-Ajlan, Habib, Ja'dah, Al-Harish, Qushayr, and Uqayl.
The children of Uqayl are Thawbah bin Al-Humayr bin Rabi'ah bin Ka'b bin Khafajah bin Amr bin Uqayl bin Ka'b.
Rabi'ah and Amir are allies. Amr and Abbad are allies. Awf and Mu'awiyah are allies. And Abdullah.
From Banu Amir bin Rabi'ah is Bishr bin Mu'awiyah bin Rabi'ah (Al-Bakka'), killer of Zuhayr bin Judhaymah.
Among them is Al-Ajlan, who is Abdullah bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah.
From Banu Ja'dah bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah is Al-Nabighah Al-Ja'di. He was born before the birth of Al-Nabighah Al-Dhubyani, and his life extended until he reached Islam and the Prophet (peace be upon him) and believed in him. He lived until the Caliphate of Ibn al-Zubayr and praised him in the Sacred Mosque; he was two hundred years old. His brother is Wahwah.
The sons of Abdullah bin Umar bin Udas [are] Banu Rabi'ah, the honor of Banu Amir bin Sa'sa'ah. Jarir bin Al-Khatafa meant them by Al-Ra'i's verse:
"Lower your gaze, for you are from Numayr,
You have reached neither Ka'b nor Kilab."
Numayr bin Amir bin Sa'sa'ah will be mentioned later, Allah Almighty willing.
It was said: Ka'b came in his sleep and was told: Your age is advanced, your bones are frail, and your term has approached, so tell your children to wish. He gathered them and said to them: Wish. Al-Huraysh said: I wish for vitality and strength over women; so they are the most marrying of Banu Amir. Qushayr said: I wish for survival and beauty; so they are the most handsome of Banu Amir and longest living. Amir said: Milk and dates; so they have the most milk and dates of Banu Amir. Uqayl said: I wish for camels, honor, and strength; so there is none stronger or mightier in Banu Amir than them, and they have the most camels.

(Section)
As for Amir in [bin] Sa'sa'ah...

He begot Numayr, Hilal, Suwa'ah, Rabi'ah, and Amr. Four of them left offspring.
Numayr begot Amr, Amir, Dinnah, Ka'b, Sira', and Al-Harith.
From Banu Sira' is Amir bin Habib bin Sira' bin Numayr.
From Banu Al-Harith is Ubayd Al-Ra'i, and his son Jandal bin Ubayd bin Al-Husayn bin Jandal bin Qatan bin Rabi'ah bin Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Numayr.
He said: From Banu Hilal bin Amir are Rabi'ah, Shu'bah, Shu'aybah, Nashirah, Amr, Abdullah, 'A'idhah, Nahik, Ja'far, Radmah, and Abd Manaf.
From Banu Hilal is Maymunah bint Al-Harith, wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him), bin Khuzaymah bin Al-Harith bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Abd Manaf. She was called Umm al-Masakin (Mother of the Poor) and died during the Prophet's life.
Among them is Abd al-Malik bin Abd al-Aziz bin Abdullah bin Murrah bin Hilal.

(Section)
As for Sa'sa'ah in [bin] Mu'awiyah, his children are Rabi'ah, Zaynabah, Manjur, Amr, Kabir, Qais, Yasar, Shawar, Ghalib, Mazin, Wa'ilah, Awf, Mu'awiyah, Al-Harith, 'A'idhah, and Murrah.
From the descendants of Murrah is Mu'awiyah bin Murrah bin Sa'sa'ah. This Murrah is Salul. It is said Salul is the wife of Murrah, a slave mother, and her children were attributed to her, so it was said Banu Salul bin Murrah, just as the lineage of Bahilah and Bajilah prevailed, who are daughters of Sa'b bin Sa'd al-Ashirah, and Salul bint Dhuhl bin Shayban. From her descendants is Abu Maryam Al-Saluli, who has companionship and narration.

(Section)
As for Mu'awiyah bin Bakr, his children are Sa'sa'ah (whom we mentioned), Hijris, Juhash, Shayban, Al-Salul, Awf, Rajwah, Rajiyah, Al-Harb, Jusham, and Nasr.
From the descendants of Jusham are Durayd and Abdullah bin Al-Simmah bin Al-Harith bin Bakr bin Alqamah bin Khuza'ah bin Jusham bin Mu'awiyah.
From Banu Nasr bin Mu'awiyah is Malik bin Awf bin Sa'd bin Rabi'ah bin Yarbu' bin Wa'il bin Dahman bin Nasr bin Mu'awiyah. He is the one who led the war of Khaybar [Hunayn], was defeated as a disbeliever until he joined Ta'if, then accepted Islam after that.

(Section)
As for Bakr bin Hawazin, his children are Mu'awiyah (whom we mentioned), Sa'd, and Munabbih.
From the descendants of Sa'd are Awf, Hisl, Sahr, and Habbah. Among them is the wet nurse of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), who is Al-Harith bin Abd al-Uzza bin Wada'ah bin Mullan bin Nadirah. His wife Halimah Al-Sa'diyah, the wet nurse of the Prophet (peace be upon him), is the daughter of Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Sijnah bin Jabir bin Rizam bin Nadirah bin Qasiyah bin Nasr bin Sa'd bin Bakr. She came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) on the day of Hunayn, so he stood up for her and spread his cloak for her, and she sat on it. Likewise, his foster sister Khudhafah bint Halimah Al-Sa'diyah, known as Al-Shayma', came to him, so he spread his cloak for her, and she sat on it.
As for Munabbih bin Bakr, his child is Lafif.

**Lineage of Thaqif**
As for Qasi, it is derived from Qaswah (harshness) because he was harsh on a man and killed him. Their poet said: "We are Qasi and Qasi is our father."
The derivation of Thaqif is from Thaqafah, which is perfecting a thing. Everything you straighten, you have 'Thaqqaftahu', meaning rectified and straightened it, and from straightening the spear.
He is Thaqif bin Bakr bin Hawazin. They differed in identifying him. It was said Munabbih bin Al-Nabit married Umaymah bint Sa'd bin Hudhayl, then Munabbih bin Bakr bin Hawazin married her after him, and she bore her son Qasi, who is Thaqif, to Munabbih [bin] Bakr, so he was attributed to him.
It is said that Thaqif was a slave of Salih the Prophet (peace be upon him), fled from him, and settled in the Haram. Abu Righal is the father of Thaqif.
It is said that Thaqif is from the remnants of Thamud. His father and Abu Righal were in the Haram pushing punishment away from him by neighboring the Haram. When he left the Haram, the vengeance that hit his people hit him. His grave is known and stoned. He has a story.
Umayyah bin Abi al-Salt Al-Thaqafi said:
"My people are Iyad, if they are nations...
Or if they gathered, the sheep would be lean.
People who have the arena of Iraq...
When they march together, honor and the flag."
He said: Consensus occurred after that he is Thaqif bin Munabbih in Qais bin Aylan, and Allah knows best.

He said: Thaqif bin Munabbih begot Awf, Hasm, Daris (who are in Azd in Al-Sarah), Salamah, Nasirah, and a woman named Al-Masad bin Amir bin Mu'awiyah bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Mas'ud, one of the two great men of the two towns. He believed in the Prophet (peace be upon him), so his people killed him.
Among them is Al-Mughira bin Shu'bah bin Abi Amir bin Mas'ud.
Qarib bin Mas'ud bin Mu'attib bin Malik.
Malik had children: Mu'attib, Attab (Attab is the hostage of Abu Maktum Al-Hasani), Abu Utbah, and Wuhayb.
Mu'attib bin Malik begot Mas'ud, Amir, Wahb, Amr, Murrah, Mu'ariyah, Salamah, and Rabi'ah.
Among them are Waqid bin Abdullah bin Mu'attib and Ghaylan bin Salamah bin Mu'attib.
From Thaqif is Al-Mukhtar bin Abi Ubayd bin Mas'ud bin Amr bin Awf bin Uqdah.
And Abu Mihjan Amr bin Habib bin Amr bin Umayr bin Awf bin Uqdah.
And Kinanah bin Abd Yalil bin Amr bin Awf bin Uqdah bin Uqdah [sic].
And Umayyah bin Abi al-Salt bin Rabi'ah bin Awf bin Uqdah.
And Uthman bin Yasiir bin Abd Awf bin Uqdah bin Ghirah.
And Al-Mughira bin Al-Akhnas bin Shariq bin Amr bin Wahb bin Ilaj bin Salamah bin Abd al-Uzza bin Ghirah bin Awf bin Thaqif.
Among them is the doctor of the Arabs, Al-Harith bin Kaladah bin Amr bin Ilaj.
And Turayh bin Isma'il bin Ubayd bin Usayyid bin Ilaj bin Abi Salamah bin Abd al-Uzza bin Anazah bin Awf bin Thaqif.
From the descendants of Jusham bin Thaqif is Abd al-Rahman bin Umm al-Hakam, who is the sister of Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan. His father is Abdullah bin Uthman bin Abdullah bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Habib bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Hutayt bin Jusham bin Thaqif.
These are the clans of Hawazin: They are Amir, Kilab, Al-Dabab, Ja'dah, Al-Harish, Qushayr, Uqayl, Khafajah, Al-Ajlan, Numayr, Hilal, Nasr, Sa'd, and Thaqif.

(Section)
As for Mazin bin Mansur, from his descendants is Utbah bin Ghazwan bin Jabir bin Wuhayb bin Shabib bin Wahb bin Zaid bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Awf bin Mazin bin Mansur. His conversion was after seven men, so he is the seventh in Islam. He is the one who settled Basra when Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) appointed him over it, and it was then called Al-Ubullah.
From Banu Mazin are Malik, Amr, and Adi sons of Mazin.

**Lineage of Sulaym bin Mansur**
He said: Sulaym begot Bahthah, derived from your saying 'Inna fulanan la-bahithah' meaning of his soil/nature. It is narrated that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "I am the son of the Atikas from Sulaym." It was said to those who mention Sulaym: The Atikas are grandmothers of his fathers and grandfathers. They are: Atikah bint Al-Awqas, a grandmother of his from Banu Zuhrah; second, Atikah bint Hilal bin Falij bin Abd Manaf; and third, Atikah Umm Hashim.
It is said that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by women from Banu Sulaym, and they put their breasts in the mouth of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), so they flowed with milk for him.
He said: From the descendants of Bahthah are Al-Harith, Imru' al-Qais, and Tha'labah.
From the descendants of Al-Harith is Al-Abbas bin Mirdas bin Abi Amir bin Harithah bin Abd Abs bin Rifa'ah bin Al-Harith bin Bahthah.
Taym bin Imru' al-Qais bin Bahthah.
From the descendants of Bahz (derivation of Bahz from saying 'Bahazahu' in his chest if he pushed him): Nasr bin Al-Hajjaj bin Ghalat bin Khalid bin Nuwayrah bin Jubayr bin Hilal bin Abd bin Zafar bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Nahz bin Imru' bin Nahshah. This Nasr is Al-Mutamanna, whom Umar bin Al-Khattab exiled to Basra, and he has a story.
Among them is Zaghb bin Malik bin Khafaf bin Imru' al-Qais.
Among them are Ri'l and Matrud sons of Malik bin Awf bin Imru' al-Qais bin Bahthah.
Among them is the Kharijite Qatari bin Al-Fuja'ah bin Iyas bin Abdullah bin Abd Yalil bin Salamah bin Umayr bin Khafaf bin Imru' al-Qais.
From the descendants of Usayyah bin Khafaf are Banu Al-Sharid, who are the house of Sulaym. Among them are Sakhr, Mu'awiyah, and their sister Al-Khansa', children of Muhammad bin Al-Sharid bin Rabah bin Yaqazah bin Usayyah.
Among them is Khafaf bin Nadbah (she is his mother, his father is Amr bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Al-Sharid).
Among them are Nubaythah and Habib sons of Ri'ab bin Rawahah bin Jumayl bin Uqbah, killer of Rabi'ah bin Mukaddam Al-Kinani bin Malik bin Zaid, and he has a story.
From Banu Tha'labah bin Bahthah is Safwan bin Al-Mu'attal Rukhsah bin Al-Mu'ammal bin Khuza'i bin Muharib bin Hilal bin Falij bin Dhakwan bin Tha'labah bin Bahthah bin Sulaym.
These are the clans of Banu Sulaym: They are Banu Usayyah, Banu Bahz, Banu Zaghb, Banu Ri'l, Banu Matrud, Banu Dhakwan, and Banu Al-Sharid. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) supplicated against Usayyah, Ri'l, and Dhakwan in Qunut, and said (peace be upon him): "Usayyah disobeyed Allah and His Messenger." Allah knows best regarding their action against the people of Bi'r Ma'unah.

**Lineage of Ghatafan bin Sa'd bin Qais**

The derivation of Ghatafan is from 'Ghataf', which is scanty eyelashes. Ghatafan is the brother of Sulaym and Salaman sons of Mansur bin Ikrimah bin Khasafah bin Qais bin Aylan through their mother.
He said: Ghatafan begot Rayth, Abdullah, Ghanam, Tha'labah, Udhrah, Munabbih, Mu'awiyah, Amir, Bahthah, and Awf.
Rayth begot Baghid, Ashja', Harb, and Al-Hun.
Ashja' begot Bakr, Sulaym, and Amr.
From the descendants of Ashja' is the centenarian Nasr bin Duhman bin Basar bin Subay' bin Bakr bin Ashja', who lived one hundred and twenty years and has news.
Among them is Nu'aym bin Mas'ud bin Amir bin Unayf bin Tha'labah bin Qunfudh bin Khalawah bin Subay' bin Bakr bin Ashja'. He accompanied the Prophet (peace be upon him) and was his scout on the Day of the Confederates (Al-Ahzab).
Among them is Mas'ud bin Rukhaylah bin Abid, who was the leader of Ashja' on the Day of the Confederates.
From the descendants of Ashja' is Shahmah bin Hilal bin Khalawah bin Subay' bin Bakr bin Ashja'.
Juhaynah is from Ghatafan bin Sa'd bin Qais.
He said: Abdullah bin Ghatafan begot Adwah, Bahthah, Ghanam, and Sinan (Nabhan).
Among them is the poet Salim bin Darah, who is Ruwaybah bin Ka'b bin Adi bin Jusham bin Awf bin Bahthah. He was called Darat al-Qamar (Halo of the Moon) for his beauty, or it is said Darat al-Qamar is Salim's mother. He is the one who said:
"I am Ibn Darah, my lineage is known...
Does Darah have any shame among people?
From the branches of Qais, and my maternal uncles are Banu Asad...
From the nobility of people, and my fire-stick from them strikes fire."
Salim bin Darah and Thabit bin Rafi' satirized each other. He said:
"Woe to you, O Ibn Waqi', who are you?
You are the one who appeared when we were hidden."
Ibn Qayl got angry for him and struck him with a sword. He was carried to Medina and died there. Al-Kumayt bin Ma'ruf bin Tha'labah bin Rabab bin Al-Asir bin Al-Ahjuwan Al-Asadi said:
"Do not increase the gaps in it, for...
The sword erased what Ibn Darah gathered."
From the descendants of Ashja' is Abu Sinan the Companion, bin Ma'qil bin Sinan bin Mutahhar bin Araki bin Fityan bin Subay' bin Bakr bin Ashja'.
He said: From the descendants of Banu Abdullah bin Ghatafan is Uqbah bin Wahb bin Kaldah bin Al-Ja'd bin Hilal bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Adi bin Jusham bin Awf bin Bahthah bin Abdullah bin Ghatafan.
Among them is Al-Hams, who is Amr bin Nasr bin Harithah bin Tarif bin Iman bin Naghis.
Fatimah bint Al-Hurshuf, one of the noble mothers, is the wife of Ziyad Al-Absi.

**Lineage of Abs bin Baghid**
He said: Abs begot Qati'ah and Darfah.
From Banu Qati'ah are the perfect ones (Al-Kamalah), Banu Ziyad: Al-Rabi', Umarah, Anas, and Qais, sons of Ziyad bin Sufyan bin Abdullah bin Nashib bin Hadm bin Awd bin Ghalib bin Qati'ah bin Abs. We mentioned their mother, daughter of Al-Hurshub. Banu Ziyad were called: Al-Rabi' the Perfect, Umarah the Giver, Qais the Generous, and Anas the Preserver.
Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad said to Yazid bin Al-Sa'iq (and Yazid, Zur'ah, Alis, and Amr bin Al-Sa'iq were also brothers from the men of Arabs): Al-Rabi' said: Umarah the Giver is better than Alis, Zur'ah the Subduer is better than Anas, and I am better than you, O saddle of the horse.
Among them is Jarir bin Ghalib bin Abis bin Sa'd bin Abdullah bin Nashib.
Among them is Urwah to the end of the lineage. Urwah was named Al-Sa'alik (of the brigands) because he used to gather the brigands, who are the poor, feed them, take care of them, and raid with them, taking whatever they could. He is the one who said:
"Whoever is like me, possessing dependents and little...
Wealth, throws himself into every peril."
Among them are Antar and Jundub sons of Amr bin Shaddad bin Mu'awiyah bin Zuhl bin Murad bin Makhzum. And Al-Da'ar bin Shaddad bin Mu'awiyah, and Al-Da'ar are ten.
Among them is Al-Hutay'ah the poet, who is Jarwal bin Aws bin Malik bin Hawbah bin Makhzum.
Among them is Khalid bin Sinan bin Attab bin Marbitah bin Makhzumah. He is the one who extinguished the fire of Al-Hadathan and has a story. It is said he was a prophet whose people neglected him. These are gathered by Makhzum bin Adali bin Malik bin Ghalib bin Qati'ah bin Abs.
Banu Zuhayr are ten.
Among them is Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman, who is Husayb bin Jabir bin Rabi'ah bin Jarwah bin Al-Harith bin Qati'ah bin Abs. It is said Al-Yaman is Jarwah bin Al-Harith, so Hudhayfah was attributed to his grandfather with a father in between. Al-Yaman, Hudhayfah's father, had shed blood in Jahiliyyah, so he fled to Medina and allied with Banu Abd al-Ashhal and married among them. His people called him Al-Yaman because of his settling among the people of Yemen [Ansar].
The clans of Abs: They are Banu Awf bin Ghalib, Banu Makhzum, and Banu Rawahah.
The war of Abs and Dhubyan lasted forty years. It was said to them: Which horses did you find best? They said: The reddish-brown (Kumayt) raised in spring. It was said: Which camels did you find best? They said: The red ones. It was said: Which women did you find best? They said: The daughters of the uncle. It was said: Which slaves did you find best? They said: The mixed-race (Muwalladin).
He said: Abs are tribes in the Arabs: Abs Baghid is these, Abs Akk, Abs Hakam, and Abs Hakam al-Rakb. The rest are Ans (with Nun) or [Abas] with Ya with two dots below and Shin Mu'jamah.

**Lineage of Dhubyan bin Baghid**

The derivation of Dhubyan is from 'Dhaba' the thing if it became soft and relaxed. Dhubyan is with Damma on Dhal or Kasra; Kasra is more correct and eloquent. Likewise Sufyan with Damma on Sin or Kasra.
He said: Dhubyan begot Sa'd, Fazarah, Amir, Salaman, and Haribah. Sa'd begot Awf and Tha'labah.
From the descendants of Awf are Haram and Kharijah sons of Sinan bin Abi Harithah bin Murrah bin Sinaynah bin Ghayz bin Murrah bin Sa'd bin Dhubyan. Haram was called 'Al-Jawad' (The Generous). Kharijah was called 'Al-Nuqayr' (Little pecker/Scrooge) because he would peck at the belly of his sheep [to check for fat], so he was named Al-Nuqayr.
Among them is Awf bin Sinan, whose name is Al-Harith bin Awf, the one responsible for the blood money (Hamalah) between Abs and Dhubyan.
Among them is the poet Al-Jawn bin Durrah bin Batnah bin Mihsan bin Jarwal bin Habib Al-Azm bin Abd al-Aziz bin Khuzaymah bin Sa'd bin Dhubyan.
Among them is Khuzaym Al-Na'im bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Khalifah bin Sinan to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Al-Harith bin Awf bin Sinan bin Abi Harithah.
Among them is Al-Nabighah, who is Ziyad bin Mu'awiyah bin Dabab bin Jabir bin Yarbu' bin Ghayz bin Murrah.
Among them is Ibn Al-Sayyadah the poet, whose name is Al-Rayyah bin Al-Abrad bin Zayyan bin Suraqah bin Salman bin Zalim bin Khuzaymah.
Among them are Husayn and Haram sons of Damdam bin Dabab.
Among them is Al-Harith bin Zalim bin Khuzaymah bin Yarbu' bin Ghayz bin Yarbu' bin Murrah.
Among them is Husayn bin Al-Humam bin Rabi'ah bin Sufyan bin Haram bin Wa'ilah bin Sahm bin Murrah bin Awf bin Sa'd bin Dhubyan.
From the descendants of Tha'labah bin Sa'd are Al-Shamakh (who is Ma'qil), his brother Yazid (who is Muzarrid), and their brother Sa'd. They are sons of Dirar bin Dab'i bin Asghar bin Iyas bin Abd Ghanam bin Juhash bin Sinan bin Umamah bin Amr bin Jahsh bin Thuhalah bin Mazin bin Tha'labah bin Sa'd bin Dhubyan.

(Section)
As for Fazarah, he begot Adi, Mazin, Shamkh, Zaf, Murrah, and Rumay.
From the descendants of Adi is Hudhayfah bin Badr bin Hawfah bin Ludan bin Tha'labah bin Adi bin Fazarah. In the family of Badr bin Amr is the honor of Fazarah.
The children of Badr bin Amr are this Hudhayfah, Haml, Malik, Awf, Al-Harith, Rabi'ah, Riyab, and Zayla. They are the house of Ghatafan.
From the descendants of Hudhayfah bin Badr are Uyaynah bin Hisn bin Hudhayfah and Asma' bin Kharijah bin Hisn. Uyaynah had accepted Islam, then apostatized, then accepted Islam at the hands of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him). He was foolish; he is the one to whom the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "The obeyed fool."
Among them is the poet Uwayf Al-Qawafi bin Mu'awiyah bin Uqbah bin Uyaynah bin Hisn.
Among them is Amr bin Hubayrah bin Ma'iyyah bin Miskin bin Khadij bin Nufaydh bin Hamah (who is Malik) bin Sa'di bin Adi bin Fazarah.
Among them is Manzur bin Zabban (with Fatha on Zay and Shadda on Ba) bin Sayyar bin Amr bin Al-Ashr bin Jabir bin Uqayl bin Hilal bin Musamma bin Mazin bin Fazarah. He was one of their nobles, marrying his daughters to the nobles of Quraysh: Al-Hasan bin Ali bin Abi Talib, Muhammad bin Talha bin Abdullah, Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr, and Al-Mundhir bin Al-Zubayr. About that Jarir said:
"Generosity belongs to Banu Dhubyan, as they knew...
And glory is in the family of Manzur bin Sayyar.
Quraysh is pleased with them as wet nurses for themselves...
And they are pleasing as nephews and in-laws."
Among them is Haram bin Qutbah bin Sinan bin Amr Al-Ashra. He is the one whom Amir bin Al-Tufayl and Alqamah bin Ulathah Al-Ja'fariyan sought for judgment, and he took a pledge from them because they were cousins.
Among them is Rayth bin Rabi'ah bin Awf bin Hilal bin Shamkh bin Fazarah, and Hassan bin La'y bin Shamkh.
Among them is the Companion of the Prophet (peace be upon him) Samurah bin Jundub Jarih bin Murrah bin Hadath bin Amr bin Jabir bin Husayn bin La'y bin Asam bin Shamkh bin Fazarah. Samurah was raised by Muray bin Thabit Al-Jamhi, who married his mother after his father.
These are the clans of Ghatafan: They are Banu Ashja', Banu Abdullah bin Ghatafan, Banu Namar, Abs, and Dhubyan. Within Abs are Banu Awf bin Ghalib, Banu Makhzum, and Banu Rawahah. Within Dhubyan are Banu Murrah, Banu Sahm, and Banu Fazarah.

**Lineage of Ghani and Bahilah sons of Qais bin Sa'd bin Qais**
He said: Sa'd bin Qais bin Ghatafan (whom we mentioned) begot Munabbih, who is A'sur. He was named A'sur for a verse he said:
"Amirah said: What is wrong with your head after...
Youth was lost, looking a detestable color?
O Amayrah, verily your father, his head has been changed...
By the passing of nights and the variation of ages (A'sur)."

A'sur begot Malik (who is Bahilah), Amr (who is Ghani), Al-Tufawah, Amir, Tha'labah, and Mu'awiyah.
From the descendants of Al-Tufawah are Tha'labah and Amir, named Al-Tufawah.
Malik bin A'sur begot Sa'd Manat. His mother is Bahilah bint Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah. He fathered from another Ma'n. Then he left behind after his father [text unclear, perhaps married] a Muqtitah [wife of father], and she bore him Awd and Hawah. Ma'n had children from another: Sha'ban, Zaid, Wa'il, Al-Harith, Harb, Wahib, Amr, Qutaybah, and Qa'b. Bahilah nursed them all, so they were attributed to her.
From Bahilah is Al-Asma'i, who is Abd al-Malik bin Qurayb bin Abd al-Malik bin Asma' bin Mutahhar bin Rabah (who is Al-Hubab) bin Sa'd bin Abd bin Ghanam [Qutaybah] bin Malik bin Bahilah bin A'sur.
Among them is Sahban bin Wa'il bin Ma'bad, the eloquent orator proverbial for his eloquence; it is said "More eloquent than Sahban bin Wa'il".
Among them is Sahb bin Sa'd bin Abd bin Ghanam bin Qutaybah.
Among them is Al-A'sha of Bahilah, who is Amir bin Al-Harith bin Rabah bin Abi Khalid bin Rabi'ah bin Zaid bin Amr bin Salamah bin Tha'labah bin Wa'il bin Ma'n.
Among them is Qutaybah bin Muslim bin Amr bin Al-Husayn bin Rabi'ah bin Khalid bin Usayyid bin Al-Khabar bin Ka'b bin Hilal bin Salamah bin Tha'labah bin Wa'il bin Ma'n bin Malik bin A'sur.
Qutaybah bin Muslim had brothers: Salih, Abdullah, Abd al-Rahman, Ziyad, Zurayq, Amr, Yaqidh, Ma'bad, Husayn, and Hammad. Qutaybah is the diminutive of Qitab, which are intestines.

(Section)
As for Ghani, he is Amr. He begot Ghanam and Ja'dah.
Ghanam begot Haylan, Nahthah, and Amr.
Among them is Rayyan bin Ka'b bin Haylan bin Ghanam bin Ghani.
And Al-Muhabbar Tufayl Al-Khayl bin Awf bin Khalaf bin Hulays bin Malik bin Mus'ad bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Jalan bin Ghanam bin Ghani. [Repetitive text regarding Tufayl].
And Qais Al-Nada bin Abdullah bin Amaliyah bin Tarif.
