Among them is Al-Harith bin Al-Ghadban bin Ka'b bin Adi bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Ladbal bin Nahthah bin Ghanam bin Uthman Qais bin Sa'd bin Qais bin Aylan.

**Lineage of Fahm and Adwan sons of Amr bin Qais bin Aylan**
The name of Adwan is Al-Harith. He was named Adwan because he aggressed (Ada) against his brother Fahm and killed him.
The mother of Fahm and Adwan is Jadilah bint Murr sister of Tamim bin Murr bin Add. She was the wife of Amr bin Qais, and her children were attributed to her, so it was said: Jadilah Qais.
Adwan begot Zaid, Yashkur, Malik, Akrashah, and Daws (it is said they are the Daws in Azd).
From Adwan is Amir bin Al-Zarib bin Amr bin Iyad [Yashkur] bin Adwan. He used to judge among the Arabs in Jahiliyyah, and he is the one who ruled regarding the hermaphrodite that he inherits based on where he urinates, and Islam confirmed that.
Among them is Abu Sayyarah, whose name is Umaylah bin Al-A'zal bin Khalid bin Sa'd bin Al-Harith bin Aws bin Yazid bin Adwan. He used to lead the people [in Hajj] in Jahiliyyah on a black donkey for forty years. It is said in the proverb: "Healthier than Abu Sayyarah's donkey."
In Adwan is Laqb bin Yashkur with Fatha on Lam and movement, and in Azd with Kasra on Lam and Sukun.

(Section)
As for Fahm, he begot Sa'd, Qayn, and Abidah.
From the descendants of Sa'd is Ta'abbata Sharran, who is Thabit bin Jabir bin Sufyan bin Adi bin Ka'b bin Harb bin Taym bin Sa'd bin Fahm.
Among them is Tha'labah bin Kinanah bin Amr bin Qayn bin Fahm.

This is the end of the lineage of Qais Aylan, which is the last of the lineage of Mudar bin Ilyas bin Nizar.
If Mudar is mentioned, they are Khandaf and Qais, sons of Mudar.
Khandaf is the wife of Ilyas bin Mudar, and her name is Layla bint Hulwan bin Imran bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah. She was named Khandaf due to a story: They camped at some stops seeking rainwater pools. A rabbit jumped running among their men, so the camels scattered. Her sons Amr and Amir got up. Amr caught the camels and reached them, so he was named Mudrikah (Overtaker). Amir caught the rabbit and cooked it (Tabakhaha), so he was named Tabikhah. The third son Umair hid under the tent (Inqama'a), so he was named Qama'ah.
Their mother went out looking for them when her children were late. Their father met her and said: "Where are you hurrying (Tukhandifin), O Layla?" Khandaf and Tabakhtur (strutting/hurrying) are the same. So she was named Khandaf.
Regarding Layla, their poet says:
"We belong to the most mighty and noble Ilyas...
We were birthed by Layla who did not commit sin."
However, she was known as Khandaf.
So the tribes of Mudar are from Khandaf and Qais.
The tribes of Khandaf are: Quraysh, Kinanah, Asad, Al-Qarah, Hudhayl, Al-Rabab, Khussah, Muzaynah, and Khamis.
The tribes of Qais are: Hawazin, Ghatafan, Sulaym, Fahm, Adwan, Ghani, Bahilah, and Muharib.
These are the mothers of the tribes of Mudar, and they branched into peoples and bellies as we have mentioned. Allah knows best.

**Lineage of Rabi'ah bin Nizar**

It used to be said that Rabi'ah and Mudar are the pure ones (Al-Sarihan). He said: Rabi'ah was older than Mudar, and he was the eldest son of his father. We only prioritized Mudar in the lineage because of their closeness to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).
He said: Nizar begot four: Mudar, Rabi'ah, Iyad, and Anmar.
Mudar and Rabi'ah are agreed upon.
As for Anmar bin Nizar, the lineage of Anmar bin Arash bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Al-Nabit bin Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan prevailed over his lineage, and Anmar's lineage became Banu Khath'am.
Anmar is the brother of Rabi'ah through his mother.
From the descendants of Anmar are Al-Gharth and Maslamah.
Salamah bint Anmar was with Arash bin Amr bin Al-Gharth, and she bore him Anmar Al-Sawad, so his children were from him. The Persians raided them frequently, so they entered into the Romans, became Christians, joined the non-Arabs (Ajam), were cut off from the Arabs, and their lineages became unknown.
However, the lineage of Iyad is more famous than the lineage of Anmar, and from them are known tribes and mentioned men as we will bring forth, Allah Almighty willing.
He said: The children of Rabi'ah are Asad, Dubay'ah, Su'dah, Imran, Abis, Kalb, Kilab, Mukalib, Maklabah, Awf, Nahish, Hazbah, 'Afrah, Hanh, Dalaf, Lu'ya, Dib, Dhu'ayb, Amr, Amir, and Mu'adiyah, sons of Rabi'ah bin Nizar.
Aklub entered Khath'am, Awf and Nahish into Madhhij, Banu Mu'adiyah into Kindah, and Kalb and Mazibbah joined Banu Dubay'ah.
Hisham bin Al-Kalbi said: The first house of Rabi'ah bin Nizar in which leadership, judgment, the banner, and the quarter-spoils (Mirba') resided, inheriting that elder from elder, was from Banu Dubay'ah to Anazah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah, and his name was Anazah 'Am. Then leadership shifted to Banu Abd al-Qais bin Afsa (with Sin Muhmalah) bin Du'mi bin Jadilah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah. Al-Dahyan held it among them; his name was Amir bin Sa'd bin Al-Khazraj bin Taym Allah bin Al-Namir bin Qasit. He was named Al-Dahyan because he used to sit for the people in the forenoon (Duha) to judge between them. About him the poet says:
"Allah built for Al-Dahyan a house and rank...
For in Al-Namir are houses of generosity and sovereignty."
Mudar the White was named for his whiteness, and from it is Al-Madirah, which is cooked with oil.
Rabi'ah, which is the helmet of weapons, and he was named Rabi'ah by it.
He said: The House and the Number are in Rabi'ah, so Asad bin Rabi'ah begot [children]. We begin with **Lineage of Dubay'ah bin Rabi'ah** for its brevity, then we return to the children of Asad, Allah Almighty willing.

**Lineage of Dubay'ah bin Rabi'ah**
Abu Ubaydah said: The mightiest house in Rabi'ah when war consumed them was the house of Dubay'ah bin Rabi'ah.
Dubay'ah begot Ahmas, Al-Harith Dhu al-Qiladah, Awf, Yazid, Al-Attaf, and Abbad.
Among them is Al-Harith Al-Adjam bin Abdullah bin Duqan bin Ulaybah bin Harith bin Jala bin Aksar bin Dubay'ah. He was named Al-Harith Al-Adjam due to a slant in his mouth from the strength of his affliction. He is the one who ordered Rabi'ah to braid their beards and dye their clothes red - it is narrated dye white - so they would be known among the Arabs. They had a quarter of the spoils (Mirba') over Ma'ad every year, whether staying or raiding. He is the one to whom Dubay'ah said: Whoever wins has the Mirba', so seek it. Whoever insults you, beat him; whoever beats you, kill him; and whoever kills you, you cost him one of two things: either he pays blood money or you overtake him and kill him. Abu Ubayd said: So they transgressed against people and perished.
Among them is Al-Musayyib, maternal uncle of Al-A'sha, who is Al-Musayyib bin Alas bin Malik bin Amr bin Thumamah bin Zaid bin Tha'labah bin Adi bin Jusham bin Bilal bin Jama'ah bin Jala bin Ahmas bin Dubay'ah.
Among them is Al-Mutalammis, who is Jarir bin Abd al-Masih bin Abdullah bin Zaid bin Duqan bin Ulaybah bin Harith bin Jala bin Ahmas bin Dubay'ah. Al-Mutalammis is the maternal uncle of Tarafa.
The attribution to Dubay'ah is Duba'i (with Damma on Dad and Fatha on Ba), to Muzaynah is Muzani, and to Juhaynah is Juhani.

**Lineage of the Children of Asad bin Rabi'ah**
From the descendants of Asad are Jadilah, Anazah (who is Amr, and Anazah entered into Abd al-Qais), Banu Mubashir, Malik, Mansur, and Banu Anazah.
From the descendants of Jadilah are Juran, Khandaf, Adi, and Du'mi.
From the descendants of Yadhkur bin Anazah is one of the two Qariz (gatherers of Qaraz leaves), about whom the poet says:
"So hope and wait for my return...
When the Anazi Qariz returns."
Among them is the second Qariz, who is Abu Nurhum. It is said the second Qariz is from Al-Namir bin Qasit; he went out to gather Qaraz and did not return. Thus they are the two Qarizs, and about them the poet Abu Dhu'ayb Al-Hudhali says:
"Until the two Qarizs return, both of them...
And Kulayb is resurrected for Wa'il."
From his descendants is Yadhkur bin Anazah bin Sabah bin Atik bin Aslam.
Among them is Ubayd bin Ashyam bin Yashkur bin Al-Harith bin Al-Du'il bin Al-Sabah bin Atik bin Aslam.
From Banu Amira bin Asad is Iyas bin Tha'labah bin Harithah bin Fahm bin Yadhkur bin Ulaybah bin Taysir bin Amira bin Asad.

**Lineage of Abd al-Qais bin Du'mi**

bin Jadilah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah.
From the descendants of [Abd] al-Qais are Al-Labu and Afsa.
Al-Sharaf said regarding Abd al-Qais concerning the children of Shann bin Afsa bin Abd al-Qais: Among them are Al-Dil bin Shann, Banu Sa'd, Khudhaymah, Amir, Habib, Asi, and Hammam.
Banu Al-Dil bin Shann bin Afsa bin Abd al-Qais.
The children of Shann were the first to mix in Al-Yamamah. Ubayd bin Al-Harith went out with them. The majority of Shann went to Iraq and found there a people from Iyad and Azd, so they expelled them from it. Iyad went out to Bahrain and its surroundings, and a group from Shann followed them and raided them for days, so sedition occurred between them. It was the days of Al-Juwar. Then Shann was defeated and went out to Abd al-Qais. They expelled Sa'sa'ah bin Sawhan and his brothers, Zaid and Sihan bin Abd al-Qais, and they were spoils.
Iyad went out to Azd and they fought. Abd al-Qais prevailed and moved from Bahrain, and Abd al-Qais settled it. About them the poet says:
"I found Shann of Iyad with spears fitting...
Shann matched its lid [Tabq]."
He said: From the descendants of Afsa bin Abd al-Qais are Lukayz and Sayyah.
From the descendants of Lukayz are Munabbih bin Bakr [Bukayr] bin Afsa, Malkan bin Sabah bin Afsa, Al-Dil, Anmar, and Muharib, sons of Amr bin Wadi'ah [Rabi'ah] bin Bukayr bin Afsa.
Among them is Al-Saltan, who is Qatham bin Habbah bin Qatham bin Ka'b bin Salama bin Abbad bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Hijris bin Tha'labah bin Amir bin Sa'd bin Al-Dil.
He said: From the descendants of Abd al-Qais are other clans: Among them are Usayr, Awf (and in Azd there is also Awf), and Duhn bin Udhrah bin Munabbih bin Bakrah bin Lukayz bin Afsa bin Abd al-Qais. Duhn are these, not Duhn Bajilah the clan of Ammar Al-Duhni. Among them is the poet 'A'idh bin Mihsan bin Tha'labah bin Wa'ilah bin Ada bin Duhn.
Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said in Kitab al-Aghani: Abd al-Qais bin Afsa bin Jadilah bin Asad. Genealogists err and say bin Du'mi bin Jadilah. Rather, Afsa is the son of Du'mi, grandfather of Bakr bin Wa'il bin Qasit bin Hinb bin Afsa bin Jadilah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah. Allah knows best.

**Lineage of Al-Namir bin Qasit**
bin Hinb bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Jadilah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah.
He said: From the descendants of Qasit are Ghanam, Wa'il, Alqamah, Amir, Suhaym [Suhays], and Mu'awiyah, sons of Qasit.
Among them is Al-Namir, and his children are Aws Manat and Aws Allat, Banu Tamim and Banu Qasit.
Among them is Amr bin Amir bin Zaid Manat bin Amir Al-Dahyan bin Sa'd bin Al-Khazraj bin Taym Allat, and he is Wabis Rabi'ah, leader of Banu Shayban, who took the Mirba' (quarter spoils) for forty years. His brother is Awf bin Sa'd.
From the descendants of Al-Dahyan is Buhata Khatal bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Jusham bin Hilal bin Rabi'ah bin Zaid Manat.
Among them is Natilah bint Khabbab bin Kulayb bin Malik bin Amr bin Amir Al-Dahyan the Younger bin Zaid Manat bin Amir Al-Dahyan the Elder, mother of Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib, may Allah be pleased with him.
Among them is Ma' al-Sama' Al-Nu'man bin Al-Mundhir, and she is from the descendants of Al-Dahyan the Elder.
Among them is Awb bin Jusham bin Hilal bin Rabi'ah bin Zaid Manat to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Suhayb bin Malik bin Abd Amr bin Tufayl bin Amir bin Jadilah bin Khuzaymah bin Ka'b bin Aws bin Manat bin Al-Namir. Suhayb's brother is Malik. He was named Suhayb because his father was a young boy for Khosrau at Al-Ubullah, and their homes were in the land of Mosul. The Romans raided that area and captured Suhayb while he was a small boy. He grew up among the Romans. Kalb bought him, then came with him to Mecca. Abdullah bin Jud'an bought him and sent him to the Prophet (peace be upon him). In the narration from the Prophet (peace be upon him): "I am the forerunner of the Arabs, Suhayb is the forerunner of the Romans, Salman is the forerunner of the Persians, and Bilal is the forerunner of the Abyssinians."
From Al-Namir bin Al-Qarya is Ayyub bin Zaid bin Qais bin Ziyad bin Salamah bin Jusham bin Al-Qarya (his mother), and his father is Malik bin Amr bin Amir bin Zaid bin Manat bin Amir Al-Dahyan.

**Lineage of Bakr bin Wa'il**
bin Qasit bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Jadilah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah.
Bakr begot Yashkur and Taghlib [Taghlib is brother of Bakr].
Among them is Al-Harith bin Hammam bin Murrah bin Dhuhl bin Shayban bin Tha'labah bin Ukabah bin Sa'b bin Ali bin Bakr bin Wa'il.
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Hammam are Bistam, Janawah, and Al-Salil, sons of Qais bin Mas'ud bin Qais bin Khalid bin Abdullah bin Dhi al-Jadayn bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Hammam.
From the descendants of Khalid bin Abdullah is Muwafi Al-Sarqis bin Jabir bin Khalid bin Abdullah bin Dhi al-Jadayn.
From the descendants of Al-Harith are Awf, Murrah, Uyaynah, Khalid, Qais, Jaylah, and Hujr.

(Section)
From the descendants of Hammam bin Murrah

is Ma'n bin Za'idah bin Abdullah bin Matar bin Sharik bin Amr bin Al-Salt bin Qais bin Shurahbil bin Murrah bin Hammam.
Among them is Khalid bin Yazid bin Marthad bin [nephew of?] Za'idah bin Abdullah bin Matar.
Among them is Al-Jarihi Shabib bin Yazid bin Nu'aym bin Qais bin Amr bin Qais bin Shurahbil bin Murrah.
Among them are Sahar, Ka'b, Abdullah, and Tha'labah, sons of Sa'd bin Hammam.
From the descendants of Hammam bin Murrah are Mazin, Habib, Murrah, Abisah, Awf, Amr, Abu Amr, Tha'labah, Bujayr, and Sa'd, sons of Hammam bin Murrah.

(Section)
From the descendants of Murrah bin Dhuhl is Jassas, killer of Kulayb bin Rabi'ah, Sa'd, Al-Dibb, Nadlah, Bujayr, Al-Harith, Abdullah, Shayban, Ka'b, Awf, and Jundub, sons of Murrah bin Dhuhl.
Among them is Al-Ghusayn bin Harithah bin Salamah bin Damdam bin Sa'd bin Murrah.
Murrah bin Dhuhl used to provide water, milk, honey, and sawiq to the pilgrims. About him the Rajiz says:
"O pilgrims, Murrah has died...
So be certain of thirst and heat."

(Section)
From the descendants of Dhuhl bin Shayban are Al-Harith, Abu Ghanam, Muhallim, Abu Murrah, Tha'labah, Ka'b, Awf, Abu Rabi'ah, and Muharib, sons of Dhuhl bin Shayban.
Among them is Awf bin Muhallim bin Sayyar bin Al-Harith bin Dhuhl, about whom the proverb says: "No free man in the valley of Awf." His daughter Umm Iyas was married to Al-Akil, Akil al-Murar the Elder, and she bore him Al-Harith the King.
Among them is Amr bin Abi Rabi'ah bin Dhuhl, called Amr Al-Muzdalif, because on the Day of Qisah, which is the Day of shaving forelocks (Tahlaq al-Limam), he threw his spear and said: "Advance (Izdalifu) behind this spear of mine," so he was named Al-Muzdalif.
From his descendants is Hani bin Qabisah bin Hashim bin Al-Muzdalif, who protected Al-Nu'man's family and wealth against Khosrau, and the Battle of Dhi Qar was because of that.

(Section)
From the descendants of Shayban bin Tha'labah are Subayh, Dhuhl, Dhuhl [sic], Muhallim, Auf, Qais, Amr, Ghanam, Harb, Abdullah, Al-Harith, Hilal, Taym, and Tha'labah.

(Section)
From the descendants of Qais bin Tha'labah are Sa'd and Taym (who are the Hazqan), Tha'labah, and Dubay'ah.
From the descendants of Dubay'ah are Sa'd and Rabi'ah, the Ma'dudun (Counted ones).
Among them is Al-A'sha the Elder, who is Maymun bin Qais bin Jandal bin Shurahbil bin Awf bin Sa'd bin Dubay'ah.
Among them is Al-Muraqqish the Younger, who is the nephew of the Elder; his name is Rabi'ah bin Sufyan bin Sa'd.
Among them is Tarafa, who is the nephew of Al-Muraqqish the Younger, Tarafa bin Al-Abd bin Sufyan.
Among them is Amr bin Qim'ah bin Dharih bin Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Dubay'ah. He is Rukni Sa'd; Rabi'ah [text unclear] counted from one belly.
Among them are the Maza'idah, sons of Amr bin Marthad bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Dubay'ah.
Among them are Al-Harith, Amr, Murrah, and Jarir, sons of Abbad bin Dubay'ah bin Qais.
Amr bin Abbad's mother was married to Al-Harith bin Abbad. Bujayr bin Al-Harith bin Abbad was killed by Muhalhil. Because of him, Al-Harith bin Abbad rose against Banu Taghlib and killed them, and they did not recover after that until Muhalhil perished in captivity.
Three men stood with him in their war: Awf bin Malik bin Dubay'ah bin Qais, who captured Muhalhil, and he remained a captive until he died in captivity of thirst. The second is Dubay'ah bin Dubay'ah bin Qais, nicknamed Majdar; nicknamed so for his shortness. He had the most beautiful face and hair among people. He is the one who forbade shaving the back of his hair [text unclear] ... and killed the first horseman who appeared to them from the strongest of people. The third is Sa'd bin Malik bin Dubay'ah bin Qais; he was a poet, and he kept inciting and provoking them until they gathered from every direction and were victorious over Taghlib.
From Qais bin Tha'labah is Baqil, who is proverbial for stuttering/inability to speak.

(Section)
As for Dhuhl bin Tha'labah, from his descendants are Shayban, Malik, and Amr bin Nawfal.
From the descendants of Shayban bin Dhuhl is Imran bin Hittan bin Zabyan bin Tha'l bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Sadus bin Shayban bin Dhuhl.
Sadus had ten sons, among them Al-Harith. Sadus had twenty-one male children. The poet said:
"If only my affair had pushed you away...
Long like the penis of Al-Harith bin Sadus."
Among them is Al-Husayn bin Al-Mundhir bin Al-Harith bin Wa'lah bin Khalid bin Badr bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Shayban.
Among them is the genealogist Daghfal bin Hanzalah bin Yazid bin Abdah bin Abdullah bin Nawfal bin Dhuhl.
Among them is Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Dhuhl.
Among them is Al-Qamqa' bin Thawr bin Iqal bin Amr bin Dhuhl.

(Section)
As for Taym Allat bin Tha'labah, his children are Amir, Adi, Hilal, Malik, and Al-Harith.
Among them is the generous Ikrimah Al-Fayyad bin Rib'i bin Amr bin Subay bin La'y bin Abdullah.
It is said... Luqaym bin Tha'labah and Qais bin Tha'labah are the Lahazim. A man said to them: Ally together and be like the Lahazim (submaxillary glands/cheeks), so they were named that.
Jarir said:
"We are satisfied with the judgment of the tribe Bakr bin Wa'il...
Whether it is in the two Dhuhls or in the Manazil."

The two Dhuhls are Dhuhl bin Tha'labah and Dhuhl bin Shayban.
These four are the sons of Tha'labah. Ukabah's mother is Al-Barsha' from Taghlib.
Abu Ubaydah said: There are no four brothers among the Arabs more noble, mightier, or of greater status than the sons of Tha'labah bin Ukabah; they are Shayban, Qais, Dhuhl, and Taym Allah. Tha'labah was called Al-A'azz (The Mightiest).
The mother of Ukabah bin Sa'b is from his descendants Jahdarah bin Rabi'ah bin Zaid bin Awf bin Ukabah.
From the descendants of Sa'b bin Ali is Zaman bin Malik bin Sa'b. And Lujaym.
From the descendants of Lujaym are Ijl bin Hanifah and Al-Awqas among others. Their mother is Hidham. Among them is Al-Find Al-Zamani, whose name is Sahl bin Shayban Al-Ashhal, who is Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Sa'b bin Ali bin Bakr bin Wa'il.
Regarding Hidham, the poet says:
"If Hidham speaks, then believe her...
For the saying is what Hidham said."

**Lineage of Ijl bin Lujaym bin Sa'b**
He said: Ijl had children: Rabi'ah, Dhuhl, Damrah, Dubay'ah, Ka'b, and Sa'd.
From the descendants of Sa'd are Wa'il, Sulayt, Habban, Salamah, Thumamah, and Tha'labah. They are Banu Abdullah bin Malik bin As'ad bin Khuzaymah bin Sa'd bin Ijl.
Among them is the poet Abu Al-Najm, who is Al-Fadl bin Qudamah from the descendants of Rabi'ah bin Ijl.
Among them is Al-Hanqa' Dughah, who was married to Jundab bin Al-Anbar and bore Adi bin Al-Harith.
From the descendants of Rabi'ah bin Ijl is Al-Budayl bin Al-Faraj.
From the descendants of Sa'd bin Ijl is Al-Furat bin Hayyan bin Tha'labah bin Abd al-Uzza bin Habbah bin Rabi'ah bin Sa'd bin Ijl; he had companionship with the Prophet (peace be upon him).
From the descendants of Dubay'ah bin Lujaym are Sa'd, Aswad, Rabi'ah, and Usamah, sons of Dubay'ah bin Lujaym bin Sa'b bin Ali bin Bakr bin Wa'il.

**Lineage of Hanifah bin Lujaym**
The name of Hanifah is Athal. Al-Zubayr bin Bakkar said: Hanifah is a woman to whom her children were attributed, and she is Hanifah bint Kahil bin Asad.
He said: Hanifah had children: Sa'd, Adi, Abis, Amir, and Al-Dul.
The children of Al-Dul are Tha'labah, Al-Harith, Al-Mughayrah, and Murrah.
Among them is Hawdhah Al-Wahhab Dhu al-Taj bin Ali bin Thumamah bin Abdullah. Hawdhah is the sandgrouse, and Hawdhah was named after it. Hawdhah is the one about whom Al-A'sha says:
"Whoever sees Hawdhah prostrates without suspecting,
Whether he wraps [the turban] over the crown or puts it down."
He is Thumamah bin Amr bin Abd al-Aziz bin Suhaym bin Murrah bin Al-Dul bin Dubay'ah [Hanifah?].
Among them is Qatadah bin Maslamah bin Abi Ubaydah, who is Al-Ja'd bin Taghlib bin Al-Dul bin Hanifah.
Among them is Abdullah bin Tha'labah bin Yarbu' bin Tha'labah bin Al-Dul bin Hanifah.
Al-Dul is with Damma on Dal and Waw. In Abd al-Qais it is with Kasra on Dal and Ya. In Kinanah it is with Damma on Dal and broken Hamza.
He said: From Banu Hanifah is Musaylimah the Liar and his brother Al-Mahabbah, sons of Thumamah bin Qais bin Kathir bin Habib bin Abd Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Al-Dul bin Hanifah.
Among them is Najdah the Kharijite, son of Amir bin Sayyar bin Al-Mutarrah bin Rabi'ah bin Aid bin Al-Harith bin Adi bin Hanifah.

(Section)
From the descendants of Ali bin Bakr are Mu'adiyah, Ka'b, Al-Sid, and Ghani. From the descendants of Bakr bin Wa'il according to this is Yashkur.

**Lineage of Yashkur bin Bakr bin Wa'il**
From the descendants of Yashkur bin Bakr are Ka'b, Harith, Adi, and Kinanah. In the descendants of Ka'b are the number and honor. With them are Habib, Al-Atik, and Banu Anz bin Ghanam bin Ka'b.
From the descendants of Kinanah bin Yashkur is Al-Harith bin Hillizah bin Makruh bin Yazid bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Ubayd bin Sa'd bin Khath'am bin Amir bin Zubyan bin Kinanah bin Yashkur.
Among them is Suwayd bin Abi Kahil bin Abi Harith bin Hisl bin Harithah bin Malik bin Ubayd bin As'ad to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Ka'b bin Ju'al, about whom Jarir says:
"You were named Ka'b by the evil of bones...
And your father was named Ju'al (dung beetle)."
These are the tribes of Bakr bin Wa'il: They are Yashkur bin Bakr, Hanifah and Ijl sons of Lujaym, and Shayban, Qais, Dhuhl, and Taym Allat sons of Tha'labah bin Ukabah.

**Lineage of Taghlib bin Wa'il**
bin Qasit bin Hinb bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Jadilah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah.
He said: From the descendants of Taghlib are Al-Araqim, Bakr, Ghanam, and Imran.
From the descendants of Al-Aws are Al-Harith and Taym Allah, sons of Al-Aws bin Taghlib.
From the descendants of Ghanam bin Taghlib are Kulayb and Muhalhil, sons of Rabi'ah bin Murrah bin Al-Harith bin Zuhayr bin Jusham bin Bakr bin Habib bin Amr bin Ghanam bin Taghlib.
He was called the Lord of Ma'ad, and Ma'ad only united under him. He was the bearer of their banner on the Day of Khazaza and the Day of Al-Kulab. He is the one proverbial for might; it is said: "Mightier than Kulayb Wa'il."
His name was Wa'il, but he was named Kulayb because he used to take a puppy (kalb), break its legs, then throw it on the ground. Where its barking reached was a sanctuary.
He was nicknamed Abu Nuwayrah because if Rabi'ah sought his pasture, no fire was lit except his fire, and no one spoke obscenity in his council. About him it is said:
"O Kulayb, the fire after you was lit...
And has become after you, O Kulayb, extinguished."

"And they talk about every great matter...
If you were a witness among them, they would not have forgotten."
Kulayb begot Al-Jar [Al-Hajras?] bin Qabil Jassas bin Murrah, a daughter, and a girl named Usamah. Hajras led the war of Bakr bin Wa'il after Muhalhil.
As for Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah, his name is Adi. He had two daughters: one is Ubaydah, who married into Hubayb bin Sa'd and bore a great tribe from Janb known as Banu Ubaydah. The other is Layla, mother of Amr bin Kulthum.

(Section)
As for Rabi'ah bin Murrah bin Al-Harith, he begot Kulayb and Muhalhil (mentioned before), Imru' al-Qais, Abdullah, and Nuwayrah.
From the descendants of Nuwayrah is Shihab, the leader of Taghlib on the Day of Dhi Qar. He is the one who blocked his house and his grandfather's. There were fifty-two houses; Taghlib blocked fifty-one houses, and he blocked the connection of his house, so he was against his tribe. His descendant is Al-Akhfash bin Shihab, Knight of the Stick.

(Section)
As for Zuhayr bin Jusham, he begot Ka'b and Sa'd. As for Sa'd, he is Dhu al-Barrah.
From his descendants is Imru' al-Qais bin Ka'b bin Zuhayr.
From the descendants of Sa'd bin Zuhayr is Amr bin Kulthum bin Malik bin Utab bin Sa'd bin Zuhayr.
Among them is the poet Al-Attabi, who is Kulthum bin Amr bin Ayyub bin Ubayd bin Hasan bin Al-Husayn bin Mas'ud bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Kulthum.
Among them are the kings in Islam, Banu Tawq bin Malik bin Attab bin Zafir bin Murrah bin Shar' bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Kulthum. Kulthum's name is Al-Abd.
Among them are Banu Taym, about whom Imru' al-Qais said:
"Did Banu Taym release the intestines of Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr... lamps of the darkness."
It is said Banu Taym whom Imru' al-Qais praised are from Tha'l, which is correct.
Among them is Al-Mu'alla; they are attributed to Utab bin Sa'd bin Zuhayr.
Among them is Abu Husayn Malik bin Asm bin Al-Nu'man bin Malik bin Utab bin Sa'd bin Zuhayr.

(Section)
Bakr bin Habib begot six: Jusham, Mu'awiyah, Malik, Tha'labah, Al-Harith, and Amr. They are Al-Araqim; their eyes were like the eyes of Arqam snakes, so they were named that. They are tribes; Jusham is the biggest, having number and honor.
Jusham begot Zuhayr, Al-Harith, and Sa'd. We have mentioned the children of Zuhayr.
As for Al-Harith, from his descendants is Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Jusham, who was the first to settle in Al-Jazirah.
As for Imran bin Al-Harith, from his descendants is Imran, mentioned before.
As for Sinhan bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Jusham, from his descendants is Imran Al-Jabab bin Mu'awiyah bin Imran. Among them is Farsan bin Awf bin Imran. We will mention the lineage of Farsan, Allah Almighty willing.

(Section)
As for Malik bin Bakr, he begot Usamah and Sa'd.
Usamah begot Akk (who is Taym) and Adi.
From the descendants of Taym is Kinanah, who are Quraysh Taghlib. Among them are two clans in Yemen with Akk bin Zubid and Adan called Al-Akhyuw and Al-Aturus. They are Kinanah Taghlib, not Kinanah bin Khuzaymah bin Mudrikah, so do not mistake.
From Banu Adi bin Usamah are Banu Hamdan: Sayf al-Dawla Ali bin Abdullah bin Hamdan, his brother Nasir al-Dawla, and their cousin Abu Firas Al-Harith bin Sa'id bin Hamdan bin Hamdun bin Rashid bin Adi bin Usamah bin Malik bin Bakr bin Habib [Salil?] and the clan of Ibn Huwayr.
He said: From the descendants of Al-Araqim is Hammam bin Mutarrif bin Ma'qil bin Mukhalid bin Al-Harith bin Zuhayr bin Jusham bin Bakr. He was the first to lead Taghlib in Islam, reconciled between Bakr and Taghlib, gave two hundred camels from his wealth, bore the blood money of a thousand men, married five hundred men from Taghlib into Bakr, and five hundred men from Bakr into Taghlib, and paid dowries from his wealth. So the reconciliation between them was completed to this day.
Among them is Al-Qatami; his name is Amr bin Shuyaym bin Amr bin Iyad bin Bakr bin Amir bin Usamah bin Malik bin Bakr bin Habib bin Amr bin Ghanam bin Taghlib.
Among them is the poet Al-Akhtal, who is Ghiyath bin Ghawth bin Al-Salt bin Tariqah bin Sinhan bin Amr bin Fadawlas bin Amr bin Malik bin Jusham.
He said: From the descendants of Imran bin Taghlib is Amr bin Khalid bin Ka'b bin Taym bin Imran.

**Lineage of Farsan bin Amr bin Awf**
bin Imran bin Sinhan bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Jusham bin Bakr bin Habib bin Amr bin Ghanam bin Taghlib.
He said: Farsan is a mountain that Imran claimed for his children, so they were named after it. Farsan and Dhurwah are two mountains in the land of Sham. Their poet said when they migrated to Yemen and those who remained remained:
"Farsan wept for the departure of his people...
And Dhurwah weeps from the weeping of Farsan."
Farsan, who is Imran, begot three: Humays, Bahr, and Bayan.
As for Humays, he is the eldest. Among them are Banu Sinan, and from Banu Sinan are Banu Al-Jaks, who were knights of Banu Husayn.
As for Bahr, from his descendants are Banu La'ish and the family of Mukhtar bin Asbahah, two great houses. From Banu Ya'ish are Jayyash bin Al-Hayn Al-Farsani, Sami', Ayyub, and Ribat sons of Sami', and Bawwab bin Abi Al-Husayn.

(Section)
As for Bayan bin Sinan...

From his descendants is Sahlah bin Al-Assaf bin Tuqmah bin Duman bin Awf bin Bayan bin Farsan (who is Imran). He is the one who migrated with the Farsanis from Sham to the land of Mawza' and Al-Jabrul and their surroundings, so his descendants are there to this day.
Sahlah begot Suhaybah and Hamma. From the descendants of Suhaybah are Zaharah, Aj'ad, and Ali, sons of Zaharah. Leadership was in Banu Aj'ad. From the descendants of Muhammad bin Aj'ad are Al-Ma'mun and Ali sons of Naji.
As for Ali bin Zaharah, from his descendants is Muhammad bin Qahtan bin Hassin bin Ali bin Zaharah. From Banu Qahtan are Banu Dawal bin Muhammad bin Qahtan bin Hassin bin Ali bin Zaharah.
From the descendants of Ali bin Zaharah also are Banu Fahis and Banu Adi. From Banu Adi is Muhammad bin Sadaqah bin Adi bin Ali bin Zaharah.

(Section)
As for Humays bin Sahlah, he begot Yahya. Yahya begot Abdullah and Ahmad, sons of Yahya. From the descendants of Ahmad bin Dawal bin Muhammad bin Qahtan bin Ahmad bin Isa bin Ahmad bin Yahya bin Humays, who is the owner of Al-Zawakiyah.
From the descendants of Abdullah bin Yahya is Al-Fayyad bin Ayyub bin Yahya bin Ayyub bin Yahya bin Humays. From the descendants of Yahya bin Abdullah bin Yahya bin Humays is Ishaq bin Muhammad bin Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Yahya bin Humays. Ishaq bin Muhammad had six children: Muhammad, Ayyub, Humays, Mughirah, Isa, and Yahya; they are Al-Juhhath.
Muhammad begot Taghlib and Muhammad, sons of Ishaq.
Ayyub bin Ishaq begot Al-Awra', Mughirah, and Muhammad. From the descendants of Al-Mu'awwidh are Ishaq and Ayyub sons of Humays.
As for Mughirah bin Ishaq, he begot Ayyub and Ishaq. From the descendants of Ishaq are Banu Al-Kubays bin Mughirah bin Ishaq bin Mughirah.
As for Isa bin Ishaq, his descendants are few.
As for Humays bin Ishaq, from his descendants is Humays bin Al-Aswad bin Yahya bin Humays bin Ishaq. Among them is Mu'arbid, grandfather of Banu Mu'rabah.
As for Yahya bin Ishaq, he begot Ayyub and Muhammad. Muhammad begot Yahya and Jabir. Yahya begot Muhammad Al-A'raj, Humays, and Khalaf.
As for Ayyub bin Muhammad bin Yahya bin Ishaq, he begot Muhammad, Ishaq, and Yahya Al-Abhar, who was among the brave.
This is the lineage of the children of Ishaq bin Muhammad bin Ishaq.

(Section)
As for Al-Mughirah Abdullah bin Muhammad, brother of Ishaq bin Muhammad bin Ishaq, he was the possessor of leadership after his father. He had two sons: Ishaq and Ayyub.
Ayyub had ten children, among them Hashim, Yahya, Bakr, Abdullah, Jami', Mu'arbid, and Abu Al-A'war. His sons are called Al-Fayalah (Elephants).
As for Hashim bin Ayyub, from his descendants are Banu Hashim, owners of Al-Mahziyah.
As for Mu'arbid bin Ayyub, his children are Banu Mu'arbid, owners of Al-Akramiyah.
As for Abdullah bin Ayyub, from his descendants is Bakr Al-Awam bin Al-Mughirah bin Ayyub bin Abdullah bin Ayyub [text unclear].
From the descendants of Abdullah bin Ayyub is Humays bin Abdullah.
As for Jami' bin Ayyub, from his descendants are Ayyub, Muhammad, Husayn, Yahya, and Mughirah bin Ishaq bin Jami' bin Ayyub, and they are known as Banu Jami'.
As for Abu Al-A'war bin Ayyub, from his descendants are Banu Manaf.
As for Yahya bin Ayyub, he begot Tami, Abu Al-Mughirah, and Bakr. Bakr bin Yahya begot Tami and Husayn. Husayn begot Muhammad bin Husayn.
Abu Al-Mughirah bin Yahya begot Yahya and Bakr. Yahya bin Abi Al-Mughirah begot Muhammad, Ahmad, Yahya, and Muhanna. These are the house of Abu Al-Mughirah and they have offspring.
As for Tami bin Yahya bin Ayyub, he begot Muhammad, Bakr, and Yahya. As for Muhammad bin Amir, he was one of the generous Arabs and had countless noble deeds. His residence was Al-Jadun. He had children: Tami, Jayyash, Husayn, Ali, Ahmad, and Abdullah.
As for Bakr bin Tami, his children are Muhammad and Tami.
As for Yahya bin Tami, his child is Muhammad bin Yahya bin Tami [text unclear]. This is the house of Banu Tami.

(Section)
As for Bakr bin Ayyub bin Abi Al-Mughirah

bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Ishaq bin Abdullah bin Yahya bin Humays bin Sahlah, he was the leader of the people of Mawza', and his brother Yahya was at Al-Jadun, and we have mentioned them. Bakr bin Ayyub begot Yahya, Husayn, Ayyub, and Mughirah.
As for Husayn bin Bakr, he had no offspring except a woman.
As for Ayyub bin Bakr, he begot Bakr, Yahya, Muhammad, and Husayn.
As for Yahya bin Bakr, he begot Bakr, Atwah, and Husayn. Atwah [Atwatah?] bin Yahya begot Al-Mughirah.
As for Bakr bin Yahya bin Al-Mughirah, he was the possessor of leadership after his father and was among the long-lived. He had fifteen children: Bakr, Muhammad, Tami, Mughirah, Ali, Ahmad, Abdullah, Yahya, Bistam, Abu Bakr, Husayn, Hasan, Jami', Umar, Fatik, and Jasir.
As for Yahya brother of Husayn bin Bakr, he begot Bakr, Tami, and Jami'.
These are the house of Banu Bakr bin Yahya bin Ayyub.
As for Anz bin Wa'il, from his descendants are Arashah bin Arashah, Wasih, and Adadah. Ruwayfidah is from the descendants of Anz. The sons of Wa'il are three: Bakr, Taghlib, and Anz.

**Lineage of Iyad bin Nizar**
He said: Iyad bin Nizar begot Amiy, Zuhr, Namarah, and Tha'labah. Namarah begot Al-Tammah, a great clan. About them Amr bin Kulthum says:
"Inform Banu Al-Tammah about us...
And Amiy, how did you find us?"
They had men and numbers, but they perished.
Iyad is the brother of Mudar by his mother, and Anmar is brother of Rabi'ah by his mother.
Afsa begot Du'mi bin Munabbih bin Al-Salt bin Al-Nabit bin Mansur bin Yaqdam bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Iyad.
It is said Ya'nuf bin Munabbih, who is Al-Nu'man bin Mansur bin Yaqdam bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Iyad.
From Du'mi is the eloquent wise man Quss bin Sa'idah bin Amr bin Tariq bin Shamr bin Adi bin Malik bin Abra'an [?] bin Al-Namir bin Wa'ilah bin Al-Zumyan bin Awdah bin Miyah bin Yaqdam bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Iyad.
Among them is Mazin bin Fayyan bin Tha'labah bin Awf bin Malik bin Kinanah bin Sababah bin Sa'd bin Al-Dil bin Ashayb bin Bard bin Afsa bin Du'mi bin Iyad.
And Amr Al-Qana bin Shayban bin Yahya bin Awf bin [text unclear] Malik bin Kinanah. They are the two whom Laqit bin Ya'mar Al-Iyadi praised saying:
"Like Mazin bin Qannan or his companion...
Amr Al-Qana the day he met the two Hariths together."
Among them is the generous Ka'b bin Amr bin Tha'labah bin Salwan bin Kinanah to the end of the lineage. Ka'b was proverbial for generosity and response [?], and his father Mamah was the King of Iyad.
From the descendants of Zuhr bin Iyad is Waki' bin Salamah bin Munabbih bin Hudhafah bin Zuhayr bin Du'mi bin Iyad.
As for Anmar bin Nizar, he has been mentioned previously.
These are the tribes of Nizar bin Ma'ad. We have mentioned the tribes of Mudar.
As for the tribes of [Rabi'ah] bin Nizar, they are Dubay'ah, Anazah, Abd al-Qais, Al-Namir, Bakr, Taghlib, and Anz. From the tribes of Bakr are Ijl, Hanifah, Lujaym, Yashkur, Shayban, Qais, Dhuhl, Taym Allat, and Sadus. These are the houses of the tribes of Rabi'ah bin Nizar.

**Lineage of Akk bin Adnan**
The name of Akk is Al-Harith. He had four children: Al-Nu'man and Al-Dahhak (who did not leave offspring), Al-Shahid, and Abdullah. Offspring are posterity and children, and in them are numbers and endurance.
Ibn Hisham said: Akk married into the Ash'aris and stayed among them, so Akk became in the lands of Yemen, so the language became one and the home one.
He said: Akk is gathered by two clans: Descendants of Al-Shahid and Descendants of Abdullah.
As for Al-Shahid, the numbers of his descendants are in Ghafiq and Sa'idah, sons of Nahshal bin Al-Shahid bin Akk. He begot five children: Amir, Malik, Wahshi, Sahl, and Suhayl.
From the descendants of Suhayl bin Ghafiq is Samlaqah bin Al-Hubab bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Shurahbil bin Malik bin Rahwan bin Sahl bin Ghafiq. Samlaqah was a leader over all Akk, obeyed among them. He is the most capable descendant of Al-Shahid and most exclusive to him.
When Samlaqah died, Banu Abdullah bin Akk, who are Abs and Bulan, said: We must appoint a man from us in place of Samlaqah so that there is a master from the descendants of Abdullah as there was Samlaqah from the descendants of Al-Shahid. No one among them could challenge Samlaqah in leadership during his time.
When he died, Banu Abdullah appointed Abu Shurahbil Al-Naji, who was Samlaqah's nephew (sister's son). Samlaqah's sons, Amr and Taym, got angry and said: We are more entitled to lead after our father. Banu Abdullah disliked it and said: He is your nephew (sister's son) and there is no one after him among us. We have seen fit to put him in his uncle's place, so part of him is for us and part for you, and we are equal in him. He was from you but exclusive, without us, yet we did not deny him leadership over all of us, so how can you dislike Abu Shurahbil while you have in him what we have of relationship?
His two sons went out to Bakil and Sari', and their offspring are from Hamdan and Himyar.

Abu Shurahbil was at Al-Sabja until he died there. Ghafiq and Sa'idah separated, except those who wanted to sit with Abs and Bulan. For that reason, Abs and Bulan are in Tihamah, and they are more numerous than their other brothers. Abu Shurahbil's traces are in Al-Sabja and Al-Jardah; in them are signs until our day.

(Section)
Samlaqah bin Yada bin Al-Dajja', the holder of Akk's command the day they fought Ghassan, is from the descendants of Amir bin Ghafiq [from?] Ghassan, Akram, Kari', and Al-Bari.
From the descendants of Ghassan are Sa'dah, Harith, Buh (other than Buh al-Jabiri), Rakb, Ash'ar, Hubayr, Al-Rasl, Rabi'ah, Amr, Taym, and Qanan. In Taym is the house of sovereignty for Ghassan, and their honor points to his side and group.
From the descendants of Kari' bin Amir are Banu Urayb; they are the house of Al-Adhruh, other than Al-Arwah of Himyar.
From the descendants of Akram bin Amir are Jumah, Al-Harith, Rayyan, Ali, and Awf. The numbers are in Awf. From them are the descendants of Shakir, Banu Abi Shakir in Al-Qati' from Sibya.
From the descendants of Al-Bari bin Amir are Jadwan, Baqir, Ahdab, Wafi, Aslam (with Fatha on Lam), and Muqassir bin Amr bin Bari bin Amir. All of them are known as Al-Qayanah, except Muqassir, for they are known as Al-Muqasirah. That is because he was born at six or seven months, so he was named Muqassir (Shortened/Deficient).
As for Al-Qayanah, she is Afham, wife of Amr Al-Bari. She is Al-Qayanah bint Al-Ayan bin Harith bin Salim bin Al-Hakam bin Sa'd. Their poet said:
"I am Ibn Qar, a day he is called Tari...
Ahdab and Aslam the wandering."
Al-Muqassirun are the scoundrels (Shuttar).

(Section)
As for Malik bin Ghafiq, his children are Suhar, Dihnah (who is Dhaki), and a woman named Salma who was with Rabi'ah bin Abs and bore Imran from him, then he died leaving her, and Malik married her and she bore him Manshak and Munabbih, sons of Malik bin Abs [sic - text confusing, possibly Malik bin Ghafiq].
From the descendants of Dihnah are Al-Ijl, Zaid, Suhayb, Salat, Zajran, and Mawhibah.
From them are Al-Rami and Al-Dani, sons of Aws bin Hamlah bin Wadi'.
From the descendants of Al-Rami are Banu Ru'b bin Ukabir bin Al-Rami.
From the descendants of Mawhibah are Dihnat al-Rim, Abu Siqqah, and Husayn, a house of sovereignty. They are Banu Ru'b bin Shalat bin Mawhibah bin Dihnah.
As for Suhar bin Malik bin Al-Samin, from them is Makhlab bin Janhar bin Al-Samin bin Suhar bin Muhanna.
From them are Banu Abi Al-Rum bin Ubayd bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Khalaf bin Tha'labah bin Al-Samin bin Suhar bin Al-Samin.
From them is Makhlab bin Janhar bin Al-Samin bin Suhar bin Malik bin Ghafiq, and it is a house of sovereignty among them.
As for Wahshi bin Ghafiq, his children are Siyam, and they are from Da'in, famous. Among them is the poet Muhammad bin Ibrahim Al-Siyami.

**Lineage of Sa'idah bin Nabat**

He is Ibn Ghashl bin Al-Shahid bin Akk [or Al]. He had three children: Mukhallad, Al-Harith, and Halilah (who is Jusham the Elder).
As for Mukhallad bin Sa'idah, his children are Jabal and Jusham.
Jabal begot Nasr, Al-Harith, Falaq, Qa'b, Al-Naqis, Al-Afi, Malik, and Khawat.
From the descendants of Malik bin Jabal are Ka'b, Zan, and Al-Anbar.
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Jabal is Aws (who is Harmah). Harmah begot Al-Raqib (who are Al-Raqabah) and Al-Qub, brother of Al-Raqib.
From the descendants of Raqib are Bujayr, Ka'b, Al-Khaqi, and Mu'attib. Their house of sovereignty is Al-Raqib in Banu Bahr.
The brother of Al-Raqib is named Al-Qub. From the descendants of Ka'b are Sa'idah and Asamah Wada'ah.
From the descendants of Wada'ah bin Al-Qub are Nuwayr, Zuhayb, Hutayt, Ward, and Abdullah. From Banu Abdullah bin Wada'ah are Banu Yusr, and they are their masters.
As for Nasr bin Jabal bin Mukhallad bin Sa'idah, from his descendants are Jabr, Muharib, and Fakhr.
From the descendants of Muharib are Al-Qalaqilah Al-Sughra.
From the descendants of Fakhr are the Fakhriyyun.
From the descendants of Jabr is Fakhr bin Nasr bin Jabal bin Yakhlud bin Sa'idah. From the descendants of Fakhr are Salih, Zulmah, Dhu al-Rijlayn, Zaid, and Jabr.
From the descendants of Dhu al-Rijlayn are Hurayth and Al-Ujayl.
From the descendants of Jabr bin Fakhr are Banu Abbad, known as Al-Abbadah.
From the descendants of Salih bin Fakhr are Abdullah, Al-Sha'r, Dahab, and Kulayb Abu al-Wafa.
From the descendants of Abdullah bin Salih is Abd al-Qahir. Abd al-Qahir begot Al-Muhdaj. Al-Muhdaj begot Salih the Younger, Yahya, and Abidah.
From the descendants of Salih the Younger are Heraclius (Hiraql), Habab, and Al-Asham. These three are Salih Al-Sughra.
Yahya begot Qarar. Qarar begot five: Dhu al-Sahqayn, Al-Bul'uk, Abdullah, and Yahya the Younger. These are Banu Qarar bin Yahya bin Al-Muhdaj.
Al-Muhdaj bin Abd al-Qahir begot Abdullah bin Salih the Elder; they are the house of their honor and sovereignty. From the descendants of Salih the Elder are Mahdi, Al-Rabid, and Kumayl; they are Banu Abadah bin Al-Muhdaj. From the descendants of Al-Mahdi are Habashi, Ziyad, and Sa'id. From the descendants of Al-Rabid is Kannaz. From the descendants of Kumayl are Sulayman and Al-Walid.
As for Qafi bin Jabal, his children are Hammad, Jami', and Sanbasir. From the descendants of Jami' are Banu Masal. From Banu Al-Sanbasir are Banu Al-Darir, the clan of Al-Ja'na Al-Mi'yar.
As for Jusham bin Yakhlud bin Sa'idah, he begot Za'l. Za'l begot Al-Harith bin Za'l, Ubaydah, Jalal, and Khanadah.
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Za'l is Amir. From Amir are Banu Rafi' (their first house of sovereignty), Hilal, and Sufyan bin Al-Harith bin Za'l.
Ubaydah bin Za'l begot Masal, Qadib, and Kamin.
From the descendants of Jalal bin Za'l are Mu'awwal, Tarif, Hayyan, and Hajij. From the descendants of Hajij is Al-Asghar bin Hajij bin Jalal the Elder bin Za'l.

(Section)
As for Al-Harith bin Sa'idah, his children are La'm and Sakhr the Elder. Their mother is Abdah bint Ubayd bin Thawban, sister of Barih and Ghanam; she was called Al-Sayyidah.
Sakhr begot Ba'j and Malik (twins). It is said when she gave birth to La'm she said: "In my belly is a rock (Sakhrah)," so he was named Sakhr. Then Sakhr begot Ba'j, Malik, and Sakhr the Younger bin Sakhr the Elder bin Al-Harith bin Sa'idah. Sakhr the Elder died while his wife was pregnant; she gave birth to a man and named him Sakhr the Younger. Sakhr the Younger begot Silah and Ghunaym (who is Abu Hirab) and Al-Asam. About that he says:
"From Ghanam. As for Ghunaym and Abu Hirab...
More beloved to Al-Hanma' like Al-Musab.
Not with weapons (Silah) nor a liar."
The numbers and sovereignty are in Sakhr bin Sakhr.
As for Malik bin Sakhr the Elder, they are Al-Hasha'ij Al-Muwashijah.
As for Ba'j, he begot Sahm, Ramz, and Al-Harith. Al-Harith and Sahm were enemies while young. That is because they fought over a citron, so their mother divided it between them with an iron [knife], so it was said there is still cutting of iron between them; its knowledge remains until today.
As for La'm and Al-Harith bin Sa'idah, their children are Malik, Jusham, Mahil, Al-Amir, and Al-Ahl (who are Al-Ahaliyah). Among them are Banu Muslim, inhabitants of Al-Rawha' from Surdad.

(Section)
As for Halilah bin Sa'idah, who is Jusham the Elder, his child is Qayn. Qayn begot Malik and Jusham the Younger.
From the descendants of Malik bin Qayn are 'Afr and Mu'awiyah (twins), 'Alaqah and Qasiyah (twins), and Wadi' (his grandfather named him one [name?]).
'Afr begot Zaid, Awf, and Subay'.
'Alaqah begot Abdullah and Habib. From the descendants of Abdullah bin 'Alaqah are Banu Abi Al-Qa'abis and Banu Abi Abd, inhabitants of Al-Falaq from them. From the descendants of Habib bin 'Alaqah is Abd al-Malik bin Sulayman, their house of sovereignty.
As for Qasiyah bin Malik bin Qayn, he begot Nasr and Awf.
As for Mu'awiyah bin Malik, his children are Al-Mu'raqab and Al-Jabir.
As for Awda' bin Malik, his children are Alil, Awfah, Abs, and Dhu'al. These are Banu Malik bin Qayn.
As for Jusham bin Qayn, who is Jusham the Younger, his children are Zaid, Mufarrih, Masruh, Ubaydah, Awf, Hamil, Hubayn, Walibah, and Daramah. They are Banu Al-Butayl and Banu Al-Harb. From Banu Al-Harb are the Al Al-Jarrah, their masters. Among them is Al-Harith bin Al-Aswad.
From Banu Zaid bin Jusham bin Qayn are Banu Khalaf bin Qayn the First.
As for Hamil bin Jusham bin Qayn, they are Al-Ahmul Darahim bin Husayn and Al-Jadun, and they have endurance and numbers there.

**Lineage of the Descendants of Abdullah bin Akk bin Adnan**
The leadership among his descendants is in Abs and Bulan, sons of Saharah bin Ghalib bin Abdullah bin Akk bin Adnan. Their mother is Layla bint Nahshal bin Al-Shahil.
As for Abs, from his descendants is Abu Al-Mushabbah bin Zuhayr bin Muhammad bin Malik bin Du'al bin Shabwah bin Thawban bin Abs bin Saharah bin Ghalib bin Abdullah bin Akk. The honor and sovereignty are in the descendants of Muhammad bin Malik.
Du'al begot Malik, Sarif, Zaid, and Kathir. Malik begot Muhammad. Muhammad begot Zuhayr; they are the Zuhayriyyun with the leadership of Du'al, and honor is among them. Among them is Umar bin Abd al-Jabbar bin Muhammad bin Adnan bin Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Al-Mushtahir bin Umar bin Al-Khattab bin Abi Al-Mushabbah.
As for Sarif bin Du'al, he begot Al-Dhakir, Jarw, and Ali. From the descendants of Al-Dhakir are Al-Abyad, Na'im, Mudhib, Al-Khazraj, and Al-Abhar.
Jarw begot 'Alaqah, Makhul, and Wahb.
As for Ali bin Zarif [Sarif], from his descendants are Al-Akkar, Harib, and Wahb. From them are Banu Al-Haris, the clan of Abu Al-Khayr, and they are the house of their leadership. Among them is Amr bin Adnan bin Ya'qub bin Isma'il bin Dawud bin Abi Al-Khayr bin Haras bin Wahb bin Ali bin Zarif.
As for Zaid bin Du'al, his children are Al-Faris and Abdullah. Al-Faris begot Ubadah, Ma'in, Ka'b, and Ubayd. Abdullah begot Zaid Al-Tahin, Tamam, and Atir. From the descendants of Al-Faris are Banu Al-Shakhakh, Al-Ma'adhinah, and Al-Nuhasiyyah. Among them are Banu Sakin and Banu Nujaym; their sovereignty is from Sakin to Nujaym.

(Section)
As for Shabwah bin Thawban, he begot Dhu'al and Hilal. The lineage of Dhu'al has passed. As for Hal [Hilal] bin Shabwah, from his descendants are Al-Daji' the Elder, Al-Hajib, Al-Askar, Al-Harith the Younger, Al-Maharim, Al-Harim, Al-Wadi', Al-Asaliq, and Al-Hajabah.
Al-Daji' the Elder and Al-Harith the Younger are Banu Al-Harith the Elder bin Kalb bin Hal. He begot two men, and from them are many houses that cannot be dispensed with [?]. Al-Asaliq are Banu Abdullah and Banu Hayy.
As for Al-Hajabah, from them are Banu Al-Hajib bin Al-Harith bin Kalb, and he had two sons: Abdullah and Al-Daji' the Younger. In the descendants of Al-Harith the Younger is the sovereignty of the descendants of Kalb.
Al-Harith the Elder begot Abd Manaf, Ka'b, and Al-Ashab. Abd Manaf begot Mukawwar and Qatadah the Poet. Qatadah begot Alqamah, Marwan, Ali, and Ubaydah. From the descendants of Ubaydah are Banu Aflaj.
As for Ka'b bin Al-Harith, from his descendants are Banu Masruq bin Hashf bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith the Younger bin Kalb bin Ahl [Hal] bin Shabwah. They are the house of their sovereignty in early Islam. His son Abd al-Rahman bin Masruq bin Bishr Akk Nadfayn is the hero of the Night of Al-Qarir. From them are Banu Ya'fur and Banu Tarim.
Ali bin Abd Manaf begot Al-Aylaj, Al-Zari', and Al-Hazim.
As for Al-Daji' the Elder, from his descendants are Al-Harith and Sulayman the Tabi'i bin Hajjaj bin Abdullah bin Wahb bin Khald bin Jalal bin Abdullah bin Wahb. Among them are Abd al-Rahman, Abd al-Malik, Amr, and Banu Muhammad bin Barakah bin Abdullah bin Wahb to the end of the lineage.

(Section)
As for Thawban bin Abs, he is the eldest son of Abs, and in that is the leadership and sovereignty. Their poet said:
"Bring the like of Thawban Al-Tiham and Ghanamah...
And like Aflah Al-Mindal in preferring her.
And like Shabwah Al-Fayafi or like Dhu'alah...
And Abi Mushabbah its branch and its refuge.
And Abi Shurahbil with whom boasted...
The youths of the family of Maladh and its agent."
He said: Thawban begot Shabwah and Ubayd. Shabwah has been mentioned.
As for Ubaydah bin Thawban, his children are Naj and Ghanam. And a woman named 'Aydah, who was with Abd Al-Harith bin Sa'idah, and she bore him Lam and Sakhr.
From the descendants of Naj are Amir, Qurad, Maladh, and Nabt.
From the descendants of Maladh is Husn bin Waddah bin Amahil bin Qasib bin Maladh bin Naj. From the descendants of Amahil are Banu Waddah.
From the descendants of Nabt bin Naj are Amir the Younger and Wakilah bin Al-Qayn, and Bay'ah Abu Ayid. From the descendants of Wakilah bin Al-Qayn bin Hasib bin Abd Maladh bin Nabt bin Naj bin Abd Thawban bin Abs is Abu Shurahbil Al-Naji. He was the master of Abs on the Day of Al-Rashah, and he is the leader after Samlaqah bin Al-Hubab.
As for Qurad bin Naj, from his descendants are Uqbah, Saqa, and Ka'b. From Banu Qurad are Banu Abi Yahya and Banu Al-Harith.
From the descendants of Amir bin Naj are Banu Hurayth and Banu [Kasaqir?] known as Al-Matawifah; that is because they used to patrol the sea, so they were named Al-Matawifah.

(Section)
As for Ghanam bin Ubayd

He begot Ghanam and Habak. Amir begot Kathir and died while his wife was pregnant. She gave birth to a man and named him Amir, who is Amir the Younger son of Amir the Elder.
As for Kathir bin Amir, he was the leader in his time and had four children, all of them notables: Jadd, Makn, Zaid, and Thabit.
From the descendants of Jadd bin Kathir are Hubb, Sani', Hamlah, and Khath'amah.
From the descendants of Hubb bin Jadd are Banu Abi Al-Yazid bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Kaldah bin Hubb bin Jadd. From Banu Al-Yazid is Al-Walid, and his clan is Banu Abis. It is said that Hubb, Sani', Hamlah, and Khath'amah are the bulk of Banu Jadd, no difference about them to this day.
From Banu Hamlah are Banu Abi Al-Dalim and Banu Harithah, inhabitants of Al-Hayjah.
As for Makn bin Kathir, from his descendants are Al-Muhaqqab, Sufyan, and Harid. Sovereignty among Banu Makn is in Banu Sufyan. Among them are Banu Khalid and Banu Hatim.
Sufyan begot Tayy after he grew old and aged. It is narrated that he met the Prophet (peace be upon him) and asked him to ask Allah to grant him a male child. He prayed for him, and he was granted Tayy. Tayy begot Abdullah and Ibrahim.
From the descendants of Ibrahim are Ma'n, Qudamah, and Mut'im, sons of Hasan bin Ibrahim bin Tayy. Among them are Banu Hadul, Banu Isma'il, and Banu Zurarah bin Mahdi bin Zurarah bin Abdullah bin Tayy. Among them are Banu Haydarah and Hamzah bin Abi Amr bin Zurarah bin Abdullah bin Tayy.
As for Al-Muhaqqab bin Makn, from his descendants are Ukkash and Abu Al-Arid, sons of Imran of Banu Makn.
As for Haris bin Makn, he begot Al-Aziz and Al-Jahim.
As for Zaid bin Kathir, he begot three: Ma'n and Abdullah bin Zaid. From the descendants of Abdullah are Banu Ma'la.
From the descendants of Ghazi bin Zaid is Abu Al-Haydam, and his clan is Banu Khashkhash bin Masak bin Adam bin Ghazi bin Zaid.
And Haytal, and his clan inhabits Hayj Al-Arj, Banu Abi Salatah bin Masak to the end of the lineage.
As for Ma'n bin Zaid, he begot Rashid and Fatik, and they are inhabitants of Al-Kuraykarah.
As for Thabit bin Kathir, he begot Sa'd, Zaid, Janah, and Araj. Among them are Banu Sabah bin Ahwar bin Sarh bin As'ad bin Thabit bin Kathir. Among them is the delegate to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), Hassaadah bin Silal bin Munabbih bin As'ad bin Thabit bin Kathir.
Among them are the descendants of Ju'ak Muhammad bin Abi Al-Rijal bin Al-Walid bin Araj bin Mihfah bin Al-Harith bin Ajar. In them is leadership and sovereignty.
As for Zaid bin Thabit, he begot Daniyan, Mutahhar, and Thabit (who is Al-Aqim [The Sterile] because he was sterile then was blessed with a child after he aged and grew old, so he named him Mahdi). He used to say: "I am sterile and Abu Mahdi... I go in the night and in the evening."
From the descendants of Mahdi is Al-Mut'im, and his clan inhabits Al-Kunbah, Banu Ubayd bin Mahdi. Among them is Jah, and his clan inhabits Al-Uqmiyah, Banu Al-Walid bin Mahdi.
And Thabit bin Zaid bin Thabit begot Sulba.

(Section)
As for Amir bin Ghanam, he begot Malik, Walibah, and Al-Ma'id. From them are Banu Akil Al-Sawda', Abu Al-Jalal, and Dhu al-Ra'yayn, and Banu Ka'b bin Malik bin Amir. Among them is the family of Abu Ja'far, Al-Ja'afirah, a house of sovereignty, they are sons of Amir bin Muhammad bin Malik.
Among them is Bin Abbas, owners of Al-Ha'ilah, and Banu Hani bin Al-Harith bin Walibah bin Malik bin Amir.
From the descendants of Al-Ma'iz bin Amir are Harith and Munabbih. Munabbih begot Masak. Masak begot Al-Asghar and Jarir. Sedition occurred between them until Al-Asghar went out to Dhu'al and Jarir to Shardad. The descendants of Al-Ma'sir today are in these two houses.

(Section)
As for Abs bin Saharah

He had four children: Thawban and Malik (their mother is Hind bint Nabt bin Nahshal, sister of Ghafiq and Sa'idah. She died with him, so he married her sister Sa'bah bint Nabt and she bore him Rabi'ah and Usayr). We have mentioned Thawban.
As for Malik, from them are Kalb, Sa'd, and Ashfal, sons of Masah bin Hisn bin Mask.
As for Ashmal, from them is Bint Labit. Among them are Ali, Abdullah, Uqbah, and Rafi', and Banu Kabdah, Banu Masruh, and Banu Surayh.
As for Kalb bin Munabbih, he begot Amir, Al-Harith, Ju'adah, Uyaynah, and Al-Ashab. Al-Ashab begot Hubb, Qabisah, and Masma'. Ju'adah begot Banu Al-Tufayl from the descendants of Abi Hirab bin Ma'ali, inhabitants of Al-Harajah in Dhu'al.
As for Al-Harith bin Kalb, he begot Rafi', Sabilah, Khalasah, and Khulaysah.
As for Ghamir bin Tayyib, from his descendants are Banu Abdullah, Banu Abi Zabiyah, and Banu Masruh. These are from Banu Sa'd bin Amr bin Amir bin Kalb.
As for Sa'd bin Mansak, he begot Jubran, Muwakkil, Rafi', and Bast (who is Aymar). From the descendants of Jubran are Banu Rawa, Banu Balilah, and Banu Hayy. From Muwakkil are Al-Aghbar and Banu Shahiyah. From the descendants of Bayh are Banu Zannil, Banu Suwarah, and Banu Durriyah.
As for Malik bin Mansak bin Malik, he begot Fakhir, Basil, and Kahil.
As for Munabbih, brother of Mansak bin Malik bin Abs, he begot Mujbir and Qais. As for Mujbir, his name was flipped so he was named Sarirah. From them are Al-Abyad, Abs, Sa'd, Al-Hadam, and Kimash bin Sarirah.
Al-Abyad begot Rafi', Tamer, Habban, and Sahajah, sons of Al-Abyad bin Kahmash bin Sarirah [repetition in text].
As for Qasi bin Munabbih, he begot Sa'd, Zaid, Khalid, Muthbat, and A'tab.

(Section)
As for Rabi'ah bin Abs, he begot three: Al-Khabith (his name was Al-Tayyib), Yakhilah (their mother is Umm Ghalib bint Bulan), and Imran. Imran was weak-legged, and his mother was Salma bint Malik bin Ghafiq, sister of Sahar and Dhahnah. His maternal brothers were Mansak and Munyah sons of Malik bin Abs.
As for Al-Khabith, he is Abu Al-Khaytha, inhabitants of the two valleys. Al-Khabith begot Ubadah (or Ubaydah). From his descendants are Thajf and Abdullah sons of Kabir bin Ubaydah bin Al-Khabith. Also Al-Ra'i bin Najf by another wife named Fatimah bint Za'n bin Munabbih, who is Umm Salma. Salma is the mother of Banu Sa'd bin Rashid.
Habib begot Masruh, Hamlah, Kalb, and Jabban.
Imran begot Najf; in him is justice and sovereignty.
Zaid begot Wada'ah, Alakiyah, and Qais. Alakiyah begot Al-Marqab, Hafiz, and Tamim. Hafiz begot Mansak, Khalid, Khallad, and Qawi. Tamim begot Murrah, Sawadah, and Nujayd. Al-Marqab begot Usayl, Akki, Rayya, Atiyah, Ma'zul, Al-Ajal, and Ghaliz. Ghaliz begot Ma'wal, the clan of Ibn Durayd. Atiyah begot Marakh and Watid. From Watid are Banu Simak. From Usayl are Banu Harun, Banu Suwayd, and others.
As for Qais bin Zaid, from his descendants are Mufarrih and Baslah sons of Qatafah bin Al-Hashaf bin Habbah bin Qais bin Zaid. Among them are Asir and Raziq sons of Khalil bin Al-Hashaf bin Qais bin Zaid.
As for Wada'ah bin Zaid, in him is honor and sovereignty. From them are Jubayr, Asim, Urayb, and Ahmad sons of Marwan. The family of Dahash is their house of sovereignty.

(Section)
As for Bajilah bin Rabi'ah bin Abs, he begot Faqihah, Amir, Muhibb, and Al-Wa'iz. Faqihah begot Abdullah, Umarah, Araja, and Nujaym. Their sovereignty is in Banu Umarah bin Faqihah. Among them are Banu Nuhaf and Banu Suwayd, called Banu Al-Wa'iz. As for Muhibb and Amir sons of Bajilah, they are few.

(Section)
As for Imran bin Rabi'ah in [bin] Abs

He begot Darm and Ubayd. Darm begot Ubayd. Darm begot Ubaydah and Masruh. Abdah begot Ubaydah, Ka'b, and Awf. Ubaydah begot Ka'b and Sa'd. Ka'b begot Aws and Ba'l. Hasas and Aylaj are sons of Ba'l bin Ka'b. Aws bin Ka'b begot Lujfah and Ja'usah. As for Abdullah... [text incomplete/unclear].
Sa'd begot Al-Bari and Amir. Amir bin Sa'd begot Banu Al-Sajfa', attributed to their mother. As for Awf bin Abdah bin Darm bin Imran.
As for Masruh bin Darm, from his descendants are Qus, Darah, and Maladh bin Zaid bin Masruh bin Darm. In the descendants of Qais bin Zaid are numbers and sovereignty. From the descendants of Qais bin Abdullah bin Al-Sabah bin Al-Namir bin Zaid bin Al-Nawm bin Qais bin Zaid bin Sarihah bin Masruh bin Darm bin Imran. From the descendants of Abdullah bin Al-Sabah are Banu Qashirah and Banu Darim.
As for Ali bin Al-Sabah, he is Ibn Al-Maranjiyah; in his descendants are numbers and sovereignty. From his descendants are Muhammad, Al-Mulaytim, Suhayl, Abd al-Aziz, Zull, and Abdullah. As for Zull, Suhayl, and Abd al-Aziz, they have a remnant. As for Abdullah bin Ali, he has offspring.
As for Muhammad bin Ali, he begot Ya'qub, Ali Al-Ashbat, and Sadaqah. From Ya'qub are Banu Al-Malil, Banu Al-Mahdhuf, and others.
From Ali Al-Ashbat is Jami', who had leadership in his days. From his descendants are Yusuf and Abdullah Dhu al-Jald. Yusuf begot Al-Musta'il, who is Hasan bin Yusuf bin Jami' bin Ali Al-Ashbat bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Sabah. His brother is Al-Musta'il Ya'qub and Isma'il. Hasan Al-Musta'il begot Ahmad, Jami', and Al-Ras [Al-Ra's?]. Sovereignty is in the descendants of Al-Musta'il bin Ahmad. He had ten children: Muhammad, Ya'qub, Ibrahim, Isa, Ali, Yusuf, Isma'il, Abdullah, Al-Hasan, and Salih.
As for Ubayd bin Imran, he begot Amir. Amir begot three: Al-Harith (who is Al-Arqab), Karbal, and Layz. As for Al-Harith bin Amir, he begot Ka'b, Aws, and Tihamah. From them are Banu Harash and Banu Al-Khawar, who are in Mahwan, and Banu Madh, who are in Al-Hanik.
As for Karbal bin Amir, he begot Abdullah and Rafi'. From the descendants of Abdullah bin Karbal are Banu Al-Samayda' and their clan. From Rafi' are Banu Junadah.
As for Layd [Layz] bin Amir, they are few; among them is Shabil, and they are their house of sovereignty.

(Section)
As for Asir bin Abs - he was named Asir (difficult) because his mother labored with him for three days and his birth was difficult, so he was named Asir - Asir begot Al-Harith, Ulyan, and Ubayd. Al-Harith begot Ka'b, Harnakah, Na'im, and Hazim. They are Hazmat Al-Sari from Sajid Husayn, Banu Al-Harith bin Asir.
From the descendants of Ka'b are Hajar and Al-Jub. From the descendants of Harnakah are Ablah, Abbad, and Id.
As for Ubayd bin Asir, he begot Tayfah and Al-Jard the Elder.
As for Ulyan and Thawban, sons of Shahr bin Asir, he begot Subay'ah, Al-Bari, Aslam, and Zaid. From the descendants of Aslam are Sahm, Al-Mughir, and Thawban, sons of Sahm bin Aslam bin Ulyan bin Asir.
As for Subay'ah bin Ulyan, he begot Al-Jard the Younger, Jawadim, Shahr the Younger, Zaid, and Rafaya. Their masters are Banu Al-Jard; among them is Isa bin Al-Ghalab, master of Akk in his time. From Banu Sarb is Abu Najih, who is not Najih Al-Zaydi.
As for Al-Thari bin Ulyan, he begot Qasiyah and Al-Dibah, sons of Shadid, and they inhabit Wadi Damad.

**Lineage of Bulan bin Saharah**
As for Bulan, he begot Rashid, Wada'ah, and Mahb. The genealogist says Wada'ah bin Sarb. As for Rashid, he begot Ali, Qahb, and Sa'd. The numbers are in Ali bin Rashid, who is the father of the Alawiyyin. Ali begot Al-Ashar and Adwan. Adwan begot Amir, Malik, and Al-A'war, Banu Adwan. Amir begot Jurayh and Abdullah. Jurayh begot Iyad, Tarif, Abdullah, Khalaf, and Matla. Abdullah bin Amir, brother of Jurayh, begot Al-Munaffir, Bahr, and Mijbar, Banu Abdullah bin Amir bin Adwan; they are brothers of the Jurayj [descendants] excluding the children of Ali.
Al-A'war Adwan begot Thabit and Hayy. Hayy begot Murrah, Halal, Bawwabah, and Zaid; these are the Awarah.
Malik bin Adwan begot Al-Harith. Al-Harith begot Sa'd. From Sa'd are Banu Abi Al-Ra'ari' bin Shu'ayb in Lahj.
As for Al-Ashar bin Ali, he begot Qatif and Ubayd. Qatif begot Juraym and Abdullah sons of Al-Ashar, Baljan, Salman, Bantha, Al-Faraj, Rahtham, and Thummah. Al-Rahid is Abu Al-Zubayr bin Ubayd bin Thummah bin Al-Ashar bin Ali bin Rashid. His children are called Al-Zabrah, Banu Abi Al-Zabrah.

(Section)
As for Qahb bin Rashid, he is Abu Al-Qahiyyin. Qahb begot Al-Harith and Anz. Al-Harith begot Al-Khulud and Sharmakhah. Al-Khulud begot Awf, Sa'd, Wahib, Mazar, and Mamdur. From Banu Mastur [Mamdur?] are Banu Al-Qay'ah, and they are the masters of Qahb, and leadership and sovereignty are among them to this day.

(Section)
As for Umayr bin Qahb, he begot Bashir, Abdullah, and Khunaqah, sons of Umayr bin Mahb.

(Section)
As for Sa'd bin Rashid...

He begot Harb, who is Abu Al-Harbatan. Adwan begot... Harb begot Sa'd the Younger. From his descendants is Qutbah bin Awf bin Hayy bin Sa'd the Younger bin Harb bin Sa'd the Elder bin Rashid. From his descendants is Al-Kamiz, who is Al-Badah.
From the descendants of Hal are Zaid bin Hal and Ammar bin Hal.
From the descendants of Qutbah are Banu Jidh'.
As for Adwan bin Harb, he begot Abdullah bin Adwan the Elder. He also begot Abu Al-Su'ud, who are inhabitants of Al-Sukariyah, Banu Abi Al-Su'ud. As for the children of Abdullah bin Adwan, they are in Sham with those of Akk who are there.

(Section)
As for Sahb, brother of Wada'ah, he begot Al-Wa'iz. Al-Wa'iz bin Sahb begot two men: Amir and Abdullah. Abdullah begot Qazbah, Shurahbil, Jami', Sari, Tajarra', Hurmuz, and Ghurab.
As for Amir, he begot Saffak and Malik. Malik begot Masak, Nujayd, Qutbah, Udayl, and Al-Harith. Al-Harith bin Malik begot Hayy and Malik.
Saffak bin Amir begot Ubayd, Jubayr, and Tayy. Tayy begot Junadah, Al-Raqsham, Al-Mutahhar, and Abdullah. Abdullah begot Bishr.
As for Jubayr bin Al-Saffak, he is Al-Nabighah.

(Section)
As for Halilah, whose name is Hal bin Amir bin Sahb in Bulan (it is said in his lineage Hal bin Amir bin Amr bin Wada'ah bin Sahb bin Bulan). Hal begot five: Imran, Shaybah, Jalal, Rufaydah, and Rihab.
Imran begot Qatabah bin Imran. From the descendants of Mu'attib are Haraz and Mashhur Abu Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Usah bin Mu'attib.
From the descendants of Yafi' bin Na'im are Dahaqah and Absah. Dahaqah begot Banu Al-Asr. Absah begot Banu Jamil and Banu Sufyan.
As for Harb bin Imran, he begot Thabit and Mamdur.
As for Shaybah bin Hal, he begot Na'im, Khalaf, and Aws. From them is Al-Aswad bin Hilal bin Al-Lahib bin Rafi' bin Shaybah bin Hal.
As for Rufaydah bin Hal, his children are Banu Awda' and Banu Abi Labih Al-Absah bin Siham.

(Section)
As for Wada'ah bin Bulan (sometimes they say Wada'ah bin Sahb bin Bulan), Wada'ah begot Malik and Ali. From the descendants of Ali are Al-Kulthum and Nuqtah, sons of Ka'b bin Ali bin Wada'ah.
Malik bin Wada'ah begot Jubra' and Al-Asam. As for Al-Asam, he is the father of the Sumiyyin. From his descendants are Ka'b, Yahya, and Awqabah; they are known as Banu Al-Awqabah, they have no sub-clans (Afkhadh).
As for Yahya bin Al-Asam, he begot Sa'd. Sa'd begot Raji, Hajib, and Hamlah.
As for Ka'b, honor is in him. From his descendants is Al-Atik bin Urayb bin Malik bin Ubayd bin Abdullah bin Ka'b bin Al-Asam. Al-Atik was the master of Banu Al-Asam, leader over all of Hawr, and matters were in his hand. Al-Atik begot Muhammad and Abdullah.
Muhammad begot Thummah, Zarfa, and Absah, who is the noblest of Banu Muhammad.
Abdullah bin Al-Atik begot Hakim, Muhanna, Nasr, and Abrahah.
In another narration, Yahya bin Al-Asam begot Rashid, and Rashid begot Hamlah.

These are the tribes of Akk bin Adnan: They are Ghafiq, Sa'idah, Abs, and Bulan. The clans of Ghafiq are Al-Qayanah, Al-Muqasirah, Al-Assan, Dihnah, Al-Zami, Al-Dani, Bassam, and Al-Mahalib. The clans of Sa'idah are Lam, Sahar, Yafjud'aj, Za'l, Qayn, Qasiyah, 'Alaqah, Hamil, Walibah, Fakhr, Al-Raydah, Zann, and Al-Raqabah. The clans of Aslaq [sic] are Ahjab, Taj, Ghanam, Mansak, Imran, Nuhaylah, Al-Hanbashi, Al-Harthah, Al-Hazmah, and Shaybah. The clans of Bulan are Al-Alawi, Al-Ulwi, Al-Harbi, Al-Qahbi, Al-Jaranij, Adwan, Al-Zabrah, Al-Wa'izat, Halilah, and Al-Sumi. All are tribes of Akk bin Adnan.

And from the descendants of Isma'il bin Ibrahim Al-Khalil, blessings of Allah be upon him and upon our Prophet and all Prophets, and peace.

**Lineage of the Descendants of Ishaq (Isaac) bin Ibrahim, Peace Be Upon Them**
He said: Ishaq begot Ya'qub (Jacob) and Al-Aysu (Esau).
From the descendants of Ya'qub are the Tribes (Asbat) of Bani Isra'il (Children of Israel).
Among them are Musa (Moses) bin Imran and Harun (Aaron) bin Imran, peace be upon them, sons of Yashar bin Qahat bin Lawi (Levi) bin Ya'qub. And Qarun (Korah) bin Safir bin Qahat.
From the descendants of Lawi bin Ya'qub are Qurayzah and Al-Nadir, sons of Al-Tamam bin Tanhum bin Awf bin Qais bin Bariq bin Finhas bin Al-Abd bin Al-Kahin bin Harun.
From the descendants of Harun is Ilyas (Elijah) bin Yasa bin Al-Ghafrzan bin Harun.
Among them is the Prophet Hizqil (Ezekiel) bin Buriya bin Hilqa bin Salum bin Saduq bin Hantub bin Adrama bin Finhas bin Al-Abd bin Al-Kahin bin Harun.
Among them is Yusha' (Joshua) bin Nun bin Ifra'im (Ephraim) bin Finhas bin Ya'qub [Joseph? context suggests Ephraim son of Joseph].
Among them are Sulayman (Solomon) bin Dawud (David), peace be upon them, bin Asay bin Adraban bin Bar'am bin Salamu bin Yahsun bin Abir Maran bin Buran bin Ja'run bin Farid (Perez) bin Yahuda (Judah) bin Ya'qub.
Among them is the wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him), Safiyyah bint Huyayy bin Akhtab bin Safnah bin Tha'labah bin Ubayd bin Al-Khazraj bin Abi Habib bin Al-Nadir bin Naham bin Takhum bin Isra'il bin the Tribe of Harun, peace be upon him.
Among them is Yahya (John) bin Zakariya (Zechariah), peace be upon them, bin Naswim bin Mank bin Ghawa'il bin Samlut bin Habib bin Suwayl bin Ya'qub bin Musa bin Imran.

(Section)
From the descendants of Al-Ays (Esau) bin Ishaq are the Kings of the Aryans [Persians]: Yazdegerd bin Shahriyar (King) bin Abrad (King) bin Hormizd (King) bin Parvez (King) - who is Khosrau Anushirvan - bin Qawad (King) bin Firuz (King) bin Yazdegerd (King) bin Bahram (King) bin Bahram (King) bin Bahram (King) bin Yazdegerd (King) bin Shapur (King) bin Ardashir bin Sasan (King of Kings) bin Qisdad (King) bin Faris (King) bin Hanius bin Harban bin Malka bin Al-Ays.
Among them is Isa (Jesus) bin Maryam (Mary), peace be upon them. Maryam bint Imran bin Mathan bin Sawdin bin Al-Na'rus bin Aba bin Bard bin Nahudis bin Madur bin Athlamiyah bin Ahnanliya bin Kanud bin Yawdan Naqis bin Marsiya bin Asran bin Saz bin 'Awhar, it is said bin Al-Ays.
Among them is Ayyub (Job) the Prophet, peace be upon him, bin Afras bin Razah bin Al-Baz bin Da'unak bin Al-Ays.
These Persians are from the descendants of Ishaq, peace be upon him. As for the First Persians, they are from the descendants of Ludh bin Sam (Shem), as their lineage will come, Allah Almighty willing. Some people claimed that the Romans are two sects: a sect from the descendants of Japheth and a sect from the descendants of Al-Ays bin Ishaq. Allah knows best the truth.
The lineage of the descendants of Ibrahim Al-Khalil, peace be upon him, has ended.

**Lineage of the People of Yemen**
They are the descendants of Qahtan bin Amir bin Shamikh bin Arphaxad bin Shem bin Noah, peace be upon him, bin Lamech bin Methuselah bin Enoch - who is Idris, peace be upon him - bin Jared bin Mahalalel bin Kenan bin Enos bin Seth bin Adam the Chosen, blessings of Allah be upon him.
Genealogists have differed regarding Qahtan. A group said: He is Qahtan bin Aber, who is Hud the Prophet, peace be upon him, bin Shelah. This is a saying that has spread among people, and all the people of Yemen follow it. Poets have articulated it universally and attributed Qahtan to Hud, peace be upon him, in their poems. They said he is Qahtan in Arabic.
A group said: He is Qahtan bin Hud, peace be upon him, bin Abdullah bin Rabah bin Al-Khulud bin Ad bin Uz bin Iram bin Shem.
A third group said: He is Qahtan bin Al-Hamisa' bin Yaman - and Yemen was named after him - bin Nabit bin Isma'il bin Ibrahim Al-Khalil, peace be upon them. They said all Arabs are from the descendants of Isma'il, and used as evidence the saying of Allah Almighty: {The religion of your father Ibrahim} [Al-Hajj: 78], and the address in the verse is to the believers because its beginning is {O you who have believed}. And the Prophet, peace be upon him, saying to a group from Aslam and Ansar: "Shoot, Banu Isma'il, for your father was an archer."
He said: The correct view among the sayings is that Qahtan bin Aber is not Hud. The two tribes meet at Aber, as Al-Quda'i said: "To Aber Ma'ad traces back and meets me."
There is no disagreement that Qahtan and Peleg (Faligh) are brothers. Qahtan is the father of Yemen, and Peleg is the father of Sham. However, the people of Yemen say Qahtan bin Hud bin Aber, and Peleg bin Aber, so that Hud would be father to Yemen specifically. And the people of Sham say Peleg bin Amir, who is Hud, so that he would be their father.

(Section)
The wonder from both groups is that they claim Hud as a father, while it is established that Hud is son of Ad, and Ad is from the descendants of Iram bin Shem, while the Arabs are from the descendants of Arphaxad bin Shem. If they were told they are children of Ad, they would deny that. Allah Almighty said, and He is the most truthful of speakers: {And to Ad [We sent] their brother Hud}. Exegetes said: Their brother in lineage.
Wahb bin Munabbih said: Hud is not the father of Yemen, because Yemen is from the descendants of Arphaxad bin Shem, and Hud is from the descendants of Iram bin Shem. Yemen claimed Hud as a father only when Mudar boasted of their father Isma'il, so Yemen claimed Hud as their father. These sayings are as you see, and Allah knows best the truth.
He said: The people of Yemen say: We are the 'Aribah (Original) Arabs, and we are older than the descendants of Isma'il and Ibrahim, blessings of Allah be upon them. They were named Yemen because they settled to the right (Yamin) of the sun.
We now return to mentioning the lineages. He said: Qahtan begot many children, and we will mention them, Allah Almighty willing. The famous lineage among them is in Al-Muzda'af Awf, who is Ya'rub the King. He is the one who manifested Arabic and it increased on his tongue, so he was named by it. He is the first to be greeted with the greeting of kings: "Good morning (An'im Sabahan)" and "May you refuse cursing (Abayta Al-La'n)."
Ya'rub begot Yashjub. Yashjub begot Abd Shams, who is Saba the Elder. Saba begot children, and the famous lineage among them is in Himyar and Kahlan. The distinct features for them are famous and known: Himyar are the Kings, and Kahlan are the Protectors.
We have seen fit to begin with the tribes of Kahlan, and begin from the tribes of Kahlan with Azd, and begin from Azd with the Ansar, who are Al-Aws and Al-Khazraj, because they were honored by supporting the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and the honor of Islam comes before the honor of Jahiliyyah.

**Lineage of Al-Azd bin Al-Gharth**
Bin Al-Nabit bin Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan. It is said Al-Azd and Al-Asad are two dialects with Zay and Sin. Hassan bin Thabit said:
"And we are Banu Al-Gharth bin Nabit bin Malik... bin Zaid bin Kahlan, Daws of glories."

The name of Al-Azd is Dhara. Al-Azd begot Marib, Nasr, Abdullah, Al-Hibr, Qidar, Al-A'id, Adiqah, and Al-Hun.
Al-Azd split into twenty-something tribes, and into bellies more than that. It is the root (Jurthumah) of the Ansar, and a great root from the roots of the Arabs. It is narrated that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Al-Azd is the root of the Arabs, so whoever loses his lineage let him come to them." We begin from the Ansar with Al-Azd.

**Lineage of the Ansar**
They are Al-Aws and Al-Khazraj, sons of Harithah Al-Anqa' (named for the length of his neck) bin Amr Muzayqiya bin Amir Ma' al-Sama' bin Harithah Al-Ghitrif bin Imru' al-Qais Al-Bitriq bin Tha'labah Al-Bahlul bin Mazin Zad al-Safar bin Al-Azd bin Al-Gharth bin Al-Nabit bin Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan.
Their mother is Qilah bint Al-Arqam bin Amr bin Jafnah (it is said bint Kahil bin Udhrah bin Zura'ah).
Al-Aws begot Malik (his mother is Hind bint Murr bin Kahil bin Udhrah bin Zura'ah). Malik begot five: Awf (they are the people of Quba), Amr (they are the people of the House [Bayt?]), Murr (they are the Ja'adirah, short black people), Jusham, and Imru' al-Qais (their mother is Hind bint Al-Khazraj, who is their cousin).
From the descendants of Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws are Banu Al-Sami'ah, who are Tha'labah, Awf, and Lawdhan, sons of Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws. They used to be called Banu Al-Samma', so the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) named them Banu Al-Sami'ah, and they became known by that from indoctrination.
Among them is Asim bin Thabit bin Abi Al-Aqlah, who is Qais bin Ismah bin Al-Nu'man bin Malik bin Umayyah bin Dubay'ah bin Zaid bin Malik bin Awf bin Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws. He is the one whom the swarm of bees/hornets protected (Hamathu al-Dubur - Dabr meaning swarm), and he is the victim of the bee when he was killed at Al-Raji'. From his descendants is the poet Al-Ahwas, who is Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Asim.
He said: In Ansar, it is Ummah bint Dubay'ah. In Dhubyan, it is Ummah Aliyah bint Mazin bin Tha'labah bin Sa'd. The rest of the Arabs, it is Umayyah (diminutive).
Among them is the one washed by Angels on the day of Uhud, Hanzalah bin Abi Amir, who is Abd Amr bin Al-Nu'man bin Malik bin Umayyah bin Dubay'ah to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Abdullah bin Jubayr bin Al-Nu'man bin Umayyah bin Al-Burak bin Imru' al-Qais bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws. Abdullah bin Jubayr was the commander of the archers on the hill on the Day of Uhud. When the polytheists were defeated, [his men] disobeyed him and descended the hill, but he stood firm with ten, so he was killed and they were killed with him. Jubayr's brother is Abdullah Khawwat bin Jubayr, owner of Dhat al-Nuhiyyayn in Jahiliyyah.
Among them is Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Layla, who is Sinan bin Bilal bin Uhayhah bin Al-Julah bin Al-Harish bin Jahjaba bin Kulfah bin Awf bin Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws. His son Muhammad held the judiciary in Kufa.
Among them is Al-Mundhir bin Uqbah bin Akhi Ibn al-Julah; he witnessed Badr and was killed on the Day of Bi'r Ma'unah. Uhayhah bin Al-Julah was in Jahiliyyah a noble master and poet. About him Khalid bin Ja'far bin Kilab Al-Kilabi says:
"If you intend disbelief in the family of Ya'rub...
Then call out with a voice: O Uhayhah, defend [me]."
Among them is Abu Umamah Sa'd bin Hunayf bin Wahb bin Al-Hakim bin Tha'labah bin Al-Harith bin Majda'ah bin Amr bin Hiyash bin Amr bin Awf bin Malik bin Al-Aws. The people agreed that he lead them in prayer while Amr [ibn al-As?] was besieged. Amr bin Hunayf is the brother of Sahl bin Hunayf; Umar bin Al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him) appointed him.

(Section)
From Banu Amr bin Malik bin Al-Aws is the Companion of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) Sa'd bin Mu'adh bin Al-Nu'man bin Imru' al-Qais bin Zaid bin Abd al-Ashhal bin Jusham bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj bin Amr (who is Al-Nabit) bin Malik. He died [after] the Trench, and the Throne shook for his death. They are the people of Rabih [Ratij?], and they are the greatest of Medina. And Za'ura bin Abd al-Ashhal bin Jusham.
Among them is Al-Bara' bin Azib bin Al-Harith bin Jusham bin Harithah bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Aws.
Among them is the poet Qais bin Al-Khatim bin Adi bin Amr bin Sawad bin Zafar.
Among them is Abu Qatada Al-Nu'man bin Zaid bin Amir bin Sawad bin Zafar. His eye was hit on the Day of Uhud, so the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) returned it, and he could see with it again, and it was his better eye.

(Section)
From Banu Jusham bin Malik bin Al-Aws is Khatmah, who is Abdullah bin Jusham. He was named Khatmah because he struck a man with a sword on his nose (Khatm). They are a clan. Among them is the poet Ibn Harashah, killer of the Jewish woman who satirized the Prophet (peace be upon him). Among them is Dhu al-Shahadatayn (Possessor of Two Testimonies) Khuzaymah bin Thabit bin Al-Fakih bin Tha'labah bin Sa'idah bin Abab bin Amir bin Khatmah. He governed Kufa for Ibn al-Zubayr.

(Section)
From Banu Murrah bin Malik bin Al-Aws is the poet Abu Qais bin Al-Aslat Amir bin Jusham bin Zaid bin Qais bin Amir bin Murrah bin Malik bin Al-Aws. And Jarwal bin Jarwal bin Al-Nu'man bin Al-Aslat, and Husayn bin Wahwah bin Al-Aslat.

(Section)
From Banu Imru' al-Qais in Malik bin Al-Aws is Hilal bin Umayyah bin Amir bin Qais bin Abd al-A'lam bin Amir bin Ka'b bin Malik, and he is Waqif Imru' al-Qais bin Malik bin Al-Aws.
Among them is the poet Qais bin Rifa'ah bin Al-Mundhir bin Abisah bin Namir bin Malik [and Hawazin?].
Among them is Umm Hakim bint Amr bin Qais bin Amir bin Ja'far bin Tha'labah bin Salim bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Al-Nakhat bin Ka'b bin Al-Nakhat bin Ka'b bin Haribah bin Aslam. She is the one about whom Qatari bin Al-Fuja'ah the Kharijite says a verse of poetry:
"By my life, I am abstinent in life...
And in living, as long as I do not meet Umm Hakim."
Among them is Sa'd bin Khaythama bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Al-Nahhat bin Ka'b bin Harithah bin Aslam bin Imru' al-Qais bin Malik bin Al-Aws. He witnessed Badr and was a Naqib (leader), and was killed on the Day of Uhud.
The clans of Al-Aws are Al-Nabit, Al-Ja'adirah, Banu Abd al-Ashhal, Banu Zafar, and Banu Khatmah.

**Lineage of Al-Khazraj**
