He said: Al-Khazraj begot five: Amr and Al-Harith (their mother is the daughter of Amir bin Al-Ghitrif Al-Azdi). Their brother Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah Al-Kindi died before Islam. About him, Hassan bin Thabit (may Allah be pleased with him) says:
"And if you call the two Hariths, the brother of Banu Kabdayha..."
Also Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj, Ka'b, Awf, and Jusham. Their mother is Mawiyah bint Ali bin Qais bin Ghassan. It used to be said: If you want glory, then perform Hajj in Jusham [seek refuge?]. Jusham is the family of Rabih.
From that, the children of Amr bin Al-Khazraj: Taym Allah bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Al-Khazraj. He has three names: Taym Allah, Al-Bahhar, and Al-Ayr. He was named Al-Bahhar because he killed a man and split (bahara) his head with an adze, or it is said because he circumcised himself with an adze. His mother is Al-Saduq bint Malik from Himyar.
From Banu Al-Bahhar is the poet of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), Hassan bin Thabit bin Hizam bin Amr bin Zaid Manat bin Adi bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Najjar.
Among them is Abu Ayyub, who is Khalid bin Zaid bin Kulayb bin Tha'labah bin Abdah.
Among them is Ubayy bin Ka'b bin Qais bin Ubayd bin Mu'awiyah bin Amr bin Malik bin Al-Najjar bin Awf bin Uthman bin Malik bin Al-Najjar. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) stayed with him in Medina.
Among them is Abu Talha, who is Zaid bin Sahl Al-Aswad bin Haram to the end of the lineage. Abu Talha was one of the noted archers. He witnessed Hunayn and used to shoot in front of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saying: "My soul is a ransom for your soul, and my face a protection for your face." The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "The voice of Abu Talha in the army is better than a hundred men."
Among them are Banu Al-Hasan bin Malik bin Amir bin Ghanam bin Adi bin Al-Najjar. About them Hassan bin Thabit says:
"The dwellings of Banu Al-Has'has are desolate...
The winds and the sky have erased them."
Among them is the servant of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), Anas bin Malik bin Al-Nadr bin Damdam bin Zaid bin Khuzam bin Jandal bin Amr bin Amir bin Ghanam bin Adi bin Al-Najjar. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) blessed him with wealth and children, so he lived until the time of Abd al-Malik bin Marwan and did not die until one hundred children issued from his loins.
Muhammad bin Sirin is the client of Anas bin Malik, and Al-Hasan bin Al-Husayn Al-Basri is the client of Jamilah bint Qutbah, wife of Anas bin Malik. Abu Khalid Muhammad bin Sirin is the brother of Anas bin Malik [by milk?] to Al-Bara' bin Malik. (Umm Al-Hasan is Umm Sulaym bint Milhan bin Khalid bin Zaid bin Khuzam bin Jundab to the end of the lineage). The Scribe of Ibn Sirin [or Ibn Sirin the scribe], Abu Muhammad bin Sirin and Anas died in Basra, from the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).
From Banu Mazin bin Al-Najjar is Habib bin Zaid bin 'Asim bin Amr bin Awf bin Mabdhul bin Amr bin Ghanam bin Mazin bin Al-Najjar. Musaylimah said to him: "Testify that there is no god but Allah." He said it. Then he said: "Testify that I am the Messenger of Allah." He said to him: "I do not hear." He said: "As for this, you do not hear?" So he cut off his hand. Then he repeated the speech to him, and he did as his first action, so he cut off his other hand. He kept repeating it to him until he cut off his legs. He repeated it, and he said: "I testify that Musaylimah is a liar. I did not testify while I was whole, shall I testify while I am cut to pieces?" So he cut out his tongue and he died, may Allah have mercy on him.

(Section)
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj...

Zaid, Jusham, Al-Khazraj, Awf, Sakhr, and Jardah.
Among them is Malik the Highest bin Tha'labah bin Ka'b bin Al-Khazraj bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj.
Among them is Zaid bin Thabit, companion of the Quran and Fara'id (Inheritance laws).
Among them is Abdullah bin Rawahah bin Tha'labah bin Imru' al-Qais bin Amr bin Imru' al-Qais the Elder bin Malik Al-Agharr. He witnessed Badr and Al-Aqabah, was a Naqib, and was killed on the Day of Mu'tah.
Among them is Sa'd bin Al-Rabi' bin Amr bin Abi Zuhayr bin Malik bin Imru' al-Qais bin Malik Al-Agharr. He was killed on the Day of Uhud.
Among them is the orator of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) on the Day of Banu Tamim, Thabit bin Qais bin Shammas bin Zuhayr bin Malik bin Imru' al-Qais Malik Al-Agharr. He was over the Ansar [army] and died at Al-Yamamah.
Among them is Bashir bin Sa'd bin Tha'labah bin Khilas bin Zaid bin Malik Al-Agharr. He was the first to pledge allegiance to Abu Bakr on the Day of the Saqifah. His mother [text incomplete?]. And Al-Nu'man bin Bashir, who governed Yemen for Mu'awiyah, then governed Kufa for Yazid bin Mu'awiyah.
Among them is Zaid bin Arqam bin Zaid bin Qais bin Al-Nu'man bin Malik Al-Agharr.
Among them is the poet Amr bin Al-Atnabah (she is his mother, her father is Shihab bin Zabban bin Qais), and his father is Amir bin Zaid Manat bin Malik Al-Amir.
From Banu Al-Khazraj is Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj, who is the one who showed the Adhan concerning Musaylimah [text seems corrupt, likely referring to Abdullah bin Zaid regarding Adhan].
Among them is Abu Al-Darda' Uwaymir bin Al-Khazraj bin Qais bin Anbasah bin Umayyah bin Malik bin Amir bin Adi bin Ka'b bin Al-Khazraj bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj.
Among them is Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri bin Malik bin Sinan bin Ubayd (who is Khudrah) bin Al-Abjar bin Jadhrah bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khazraj. Hadrah and Hadarah are brothers.

(Section)
From the descendants of Ka'b bin Al-Khazraj is Sa'd bin Ubadah. Sa'id bin Ubadah wrote in Jahiliyyah and was good at swimming like shooting; he was called Al-Kamil. He is Sa'd bin Ubadah bin Dulaym bin Harithah bin Abi Khuzaymah bin Tha'labah bin Tarif bin Al-Khazraj bin Sa'idah bin Ka'b bin Al-Khazraj. He was a Naqib, generous, feeding people, he and seven of his fathers up to Tarif. He is the one who said on the Day of Saqifah: "A leader from us and a leader from you," and did not pledge allegiance to Abu Bakr or Umar. He was killed by Jinn in Hawran. The cause of his death was that he urinated in a hole, was struck, and died instantly, and his skin turned green. A man in Medina said: We did not know of his death until we heard a voice saying about that:
"We killed the master of Khazraj Sa'd bin Ubadah...
We shot him with two arrows and did not miss his heart."
His son Qais bin Sa'd was one of the most generous Arabs. Ali appointed him over Egypt, then he was with Al-Hasan bin Ali on the day he marched to Mu'awiyah.
Among them is Al-Mundhir bin Lawdhan bin Abd Wudd bin Zaid bin Tha'labah bin Al-Khazraj bin Sa'idah bin Ka'b bin Al-Khazraj. He witnessed Badr, was a Naqib, and was killed on the Day of Bi'r Ma'unah; he was their leader.
Among them is Abu Dujana, who is Simak bin Kharashah bin Lawdhan bin Abd Wudd bin Zaid bin Tha'labah bin Al-Khazraj bin Sa'idah bin Al-Khazraj bin Ka'b bin Al-Khazraj.

(Section)
From Banu Awf bin Al-Khazraj is Malik bin Al-Ajlan bin Zaid bin Ghanam (who is Qawfal) bin Salim bin Awf bin Amr bin Awf bin Al-Khazraj. Malik was the master of Ansar in his time, and he is the one who killed Al-Qatyun...
Among them is Ubadah bin Al-Samit bin Qais bin Asram bin Murr bin Tha'labah bin Ghanam bin Qawfal.
Among them is the head of hypocrites Abdullah bin Ubayy bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Ubayd bin Malik Al-Hubla (named for his big belly). The mother of Ubayy is Salul Al-Khuza'iyyah, and he was known by her. His son Abdullah bin Abdullah bin Ubayy was among the best Muslims, witnessed Badr, and was martyred on the Day of Yamamah.
It used to be said: If you come to Medina, 'Fa-hawqil' (go to Hawqal/Qawqal) and you are safe.

(Section)
From Banu Jusham bin Al-Khazraj

Zaid Manat bin Habib bin Abd Harithah bin Malik Ghadb bin Ghanam bin Al-Khazraj. Ghadb (with Sukun on Dad) bin Ghadb. In Sulaym bin Mansur it is Ghadb bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith with moving Dad bin Ghadb.
From Banu Jusham bin Al-Khazraj are Bayadah and Zurayq.
As for Amir bin Zurayq bin Abd Harithah bin Malik bin Ghadb bin Al-Khazraj, he is from Banu Bayadah, and he is the one Quraysh killed with Khubayb bin Adi.
From Banu Zurayq is Dhakwan bin Abd bin Qais bin Khalid bin Mukhalid bin Amir bin Zurayq.
Rafi' bin Malik bin Zurayq Ajlan bin Amir bin Zurayq; he is the first to accept Islam from the Ansar.
From Banu Jusham bin Al-Khazraj is Tazid bin Jusham bin Al-Khazraj (with Ta with two dots above). Likewise in Quda'ah is Tazid bin Hulwan. What remains in Arabs is Yazid (with Ya with two dots below), so understand that.
From the descendants of Tazid is Mu'adh bin Jabal bin Amr bin Aws bin A'idh bin Adi bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Udayy bin Sa'd bin Ali bin Rashid bin Sardah bin Tazid bin Jusham bin Al-Khazraj. He is the one the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) sent to Al-Janad in the land of Yemen to judge between them and teach them the Quran and laws.
Among them is Salimah (with Kasra on Lam, and attribution to it is Salami with Fatha on Lam) bin Sa'd bin Ali bin Rashid bin Sardah bin Tazid bin Jusham bin Al-Khazraj.
From Banu Salimah is Amr bin Al-Harith bin Hizam bin Ka'b bin Salimah.
Among them is Jabir bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Haram bin Ka'b bin Uthman bin Ka'b bin Salimah.
Among them is Al-Bara' bin Ma'rur bin Sakhr bin Khansa' bin Ubayd bin Adi bin Ghanam bin Ka'b bin Salimah. He was a Naqib at Aqabah, the first to bequeath a third of his wealth, and the first to face the Qibla [before it was obligated?]. His son Bishr bin Al-Bara' witnessed Badr; he is the white curly-haired one. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Who is your master, O Banu Salimah?" They said to him: "Al-Jadd bin Qais, despite his stinginess." He said: "And what disease is worse than stinginess? Rather, your master is the white curly-haired Bishr bin Al-Bara'." About that Hassan bin Thabit says:
"O Jadd bin Qais, cure your stinginess, for it...
Refuses for you, with the Chosen One, to lead."
Bishr bin Al-Bara' is the one who ate the poisoned shoulder with the Prophet (peace be upon him) at Khaybar and died, may Allah have mercy on him.
Among them is Abu Qatada, whose name is Al-Nu'man bin Rib'i bin Nakdhabayh bin Khabbas bin Ubayd bin Adi bin Ghanam bin Ka'b bin Salimah. He is the Knight of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and the one who killed one of the horsemen on the day a raid was made on the herd of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in Medina, piercing two with one spear.
Among them is Ka'b bin Malik bin Abi Ka'b (who is Amr bin Al-Qayn bin Ka'b bin Sawad bin Ghanm bin Tha'labah bin Ubayd bin Adi bin Ghanam bin Ka'b bin Salimah). A Badri [? usually said not Badri], and his father Malik is the one about whom Mu'adh said: "My God forbid that my friend Al-Aqmar, meaning Malik bin Abi Ka'b, says about me..."
Among them is Abdullah bin Atik Qais bin Al-Aswad bin Mari bin Ka'b bin Ghanam bin Salamah, who is the killer of Ibn Abi Al-Huqayq the Jew.
The clans of Al-Khazraj are: Banu Al-Najjar, Banu Al-Has'has, Mazin, Khudrah, Sa'idah, Al-Qawaqil, Banu Bayadah, Banu Zurayq, and Banu Salimah.

**Lineage of Ghassan**
Muhammad bin Habib said: Ghassan is a water source between Zubid and Rima', which are two valleys in Yemen belonging to the Ash'aris. Whoever drank from it from Azd during the days they dispersed after the Flood of Al-Arim is Ghassani. It is said it is a water source at Al-Mushallal near Al-Juhfah. It is said Ghassan is a water source belonging to the Dam of Ma'rib in Yemen that was a drinking place for the children of Amr bin Mazin, so they were named after it. Hassan bin Thabit said:
"If you ask, we are a noble company...
Al-Azd is our lineage and the water is Ghassan."

Ibn Al-Kalbi said: The water of Ghassan belongs entirely to Mazin bin Al-Azd.
From Ghassan is the family of Jafnah bin Amr bin Amir, the kings of Sham. There were thirty kings among them from the descendants of Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah, who is Al-Harith the Elder. They ruled for six hundred and sixteen years until Islam came.
All of Al-Aws and Al-Khazraj are Ghassani, except those of them who were in Oman. He said: There may be some from Ghassan who are not Ansar, and there may be some from Mazin who are not Ghassani.
We have mentioned Al-Aws and Al-Khazraj, and we now mention the lineage of the children of Amr bin Mazin, then the children of Jafnah bin Amr, and those attributed to Ghassan.
He said: Amr bin Mazin had four children: Amr, Adi, Ka'b, and Tha'labah Al-Anqa'.
From the descendants of Amr bin Mazin bin Al-Azd are: Malik, Harithah, Al-Harith, Imru' al-Qais, Adi, Tha'labah, Sawad, Zaid Allah, Sa'b, Namir, Awf, Wajh, and Al-As. These are called Ghassan.
From them is Al-Harith bin Malik bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Mazin. And Amr, sons of Wajh bin Amr bin Mazin.
Among them are Qais, Tha'labah, and Imru' al-Qais, sons of Anmar bin Adi bin Amr bin Mazin.
Among them is Mu'awiyah bin Amr bin Adi bin Amr bin Mazin.
Among them are Al-Ghafiq, Sufah, Ubayd, Bahra', Tih, Hasiyah, and Banu Al-As bin Amr bin Mazin.
Among them is Abd al-Masih Amr bin Jinan bin Thaqilah, and his name is Al-Harith bin Al-As, owner of the palace over which Khalid bin Al-Walid made a treaty in Al-Hirah. They are worshipers called Banu Thaqilah. This Abd al-Masih is the nephew (sister's son) of Satih the Soothsayer, and he is the one whom Khosrau sent to Satih because of the vision Khosrau saw; its story is famous.
Among them is Jidha' bin Amr bin Mukhalid bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Adi bin Mazin. He is Zaid bin Ghassan on the Day of San. He committed a crime and fled to Sham. He is the one about whom it is said: "Take from Jidha' what he gave you."
From the descendants of Mazin is Satih the Soothsayer, who is Rabi'ah bin Mas'ud bin Abdi bin Mazin.

(Section)
From Banu Jafnah, kings of Jillaq (Damascus), are Al-Nu'man, Al-Mundhir, Al-Mundhir, and Jabalah, sons of Al-Harith the Younger bin Al-Harith the Lame bin Al-Harith the Elder, who is Abu Shamir bin Jafnah. He is the first of the kings of Sham, son of Amr bin Amir. The mother of Al-Harith the Elder is Mariya of the Two Earrings. Regarding that, Hassan bin Thabit Al-Ansari says:
"Children of Jafnah around their father's grave...
The grave of Ibn Mariya, the generous, the preferred."
Mariya is the daughter of Al-Arqam bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Jafnah. He said: Kindah claims that Mariya is the daughter of Zalim bin Wahb the Elder bin Al-Harith the Elder bin Mu'awiyah bin Thawr bin Murta' (who is Kindah).
He said: And Halimah is the daughter of Al-Harith the Elder. She is the one mentioned by Al-Nabighah when he said:
"And Thawr bin Marar died on the Day of Halimah...
Over time, all experiences have been tried."
The Day of Halimah is a great famous day among the days of the Arabs. It is proverbial. It was between Ghassan, kings of Sham, and Lakhm, kings of Iraq. It is the one proverbially referred to as: "The Day of Halimah is no secret."
Among them is Jabalah bin Al-Ayham bin Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Jafnah. He is the one who accepted Islam then became Christian and joined the Romans, then regretted it. He is the one who said:
"The nobles became Christian due to the shame of a slap...
And there was no harm in it had I been patient."
Among the kings of Ghassan, the most faithful of Arabs in protection, is Al-Samaw'al bin Adiya bin Hassan bin Rifa'ah bin Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Amir. He is the owner of Tayma' whom Al-A'sha mentioned saying:
"Al-Ablaq Al-Fard of Tayma' is his home...
A fortified fortress and a neighbor not treacherous."
He said: From Ghassan are Asa, Rabi'ah, Imru' al-Qais, and Mawiyah, clans in Hijaz.
And Banu Amr bin Al-Azd, and they are not from the descendants of Mazin.
He said: There may be among the descendants of Mazin those who are not from Ghassan.
The clans of Ghassan are Al-Aws, Al-Khazraj, the descendants of Mazin bin Al-Azd, the descendants of Jafnah bin Amr, some descendants of Amr bin Al-Azd, and some descendants of Afsa bin Luhay. So understand that.

**Lineage of Khuza'ah**
He said: Khuza'ah are the children of Rabi'ah, who are Luhay and Afsa, sons of Harithah bin Amr bin Amir.
Rabi'ah begot Amr. Amr begot Ka'b, Malih, Sa'd, Awf, and Adi.
They were named Khuza'ah because of their separation (Inkhiza') from Banu Amr bin Amir. Inkhiza' means lagging behind and holding back. Regarding that, the poet says:
"When we descended the valley of Marr, Khuza'ah separated...
Whatever was in the bellies of Karakir [?]."

The children of Afsa bin Harithah are Aslam, Malkan (with Fatha on Mim and Kasra), and Malik, sons of Afsa. They are Khuza'ah because of their separation from Banu Mazin from Al-Azd during their approach from Yemen. So all of Khuza'ah settled in Marr al-Zahran around the Haram. They held the guardianship (Hijabah) of the Kaaba for a long time. They are allies of Banu Hashim. For this reason, Abdullah bin Al-Abbas said: The Quran was revealed in the dialect of the two Ka'bs: Ka'b bin Lu'ay and Ka'b bin Amr bin Luhay.
It is said of Khuza'ah: Allies of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) with him in the document of the treaty in the Year of Hudaybiyyah, until he made peace with the polytheists of Quraysh. Quraysh included with it Banu Bakr bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah. A war occurred between Khuza'ah and Banu Bakr bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah. The polytheists of Quraysh helped their allies Banu Bakr and thereby broke the covenant. That was the cause for the Conquest of Mecca. He gave them a status he gave to no one else: he made them Emigrants (Muhajirin) while they were in their land, and wrote a document for them to that effect.

**Children of Amr bin Luhay and Afsa from the Lineage of Khuza'ah**

We begin with the children of Amr bin Luhay then follow with the children of Afsa, Allah Almighty willing.
He said: Harithah bin Amr Muzayqiya begot Rabi'ah (who is Luhay), Afsa, Adi, and Ka'b. Their mother is the daughter of Add bin Tabikhah.
Rabi'ah begot Amr. His mother is Fuhayrah bint Amr bin Al-Harith bin Mudad Al-Jurhumi. He is the one who slit the ears of the Bahirah, let loose the Sa'ibah, connected the Wasilah, protected the Hami, changed the religion of Isma'il, and called the Arabs to worship idols. Through his mother he took the Hijabah (guardianship of Kaaba). Her father was the last to hold Hijabah from Jurhum. Then Amr, King of Arabs, held it after him, and his sons after him until the time of Qusayy bin Kilab.
Amr begot Ka'b, Malih, and Awf. Their mother is Tumadir bint Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Dudan bin Asad.
He also begot Adi (his mother is daughter of Kahil bin Asad) and Sa'd (his mother is Umm Harithah, who is Amrah bint Sa'd bin Abdullah bin Murad bin Nuhaylah, who is proverbial; it is said: "Faster than the marriage of Umm Harithah").
From the descendants of Ka'b is Imran bin Al-Husayn Abd bin Khalaf bin Abd bin Salim bin Amirah bin Salul bin Habashiyah bin Salul bin Ka'b. Imran and Abu Hurairah accepted Islam in the year of Khaybar.
Among them is Khalil bin Qumayr bin Habashiyah bin Salul bin Ka'b. Qusayy married Hubba bint Khalil. Her brother Al-Muhtaris held the Hijabah; he is Abu Ghassan. Qusayy deceived him regarding the House and took the Hijabah. He took the Hijabah from his mother, and he has a story. He was the last of Khuza'ah to hold Hijabah, then Qusayy held it after him.
Among them is Rabi'ah bin Al-Fadl bin Munqidh bin Asf bin Kulayb bin Habashiyah bin Salul bin Ka'b bin Amr.
From the descendants of Malih bin Amr are Sa'd and Ghanam.
From Banu Sa'd bin Amir bin Bayad bin Subay' bin Khath'amah bin Sa'd bin Malih. His mother is Safiyyah bint Al-Harith bin Talha bin Abi Talha bin Abd al-Dar Al-Qurashi.
From Banu Ghanam is Kaldah bin Bishr bin Hamil bin Subaysh bin Tha'labah bin Habban bin Ghanam bin Malih bin Amr.
Among them is the poet Kuthayyir Azza bin Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Aswad bin Amir bin Uwaymir bin Mukhallad bin Sa'id bin Subay' bin Khath'amah bin Sa'd bin Malih.
From the descendants of Sa'd bin Amr are Al-Mustaliq (who is Judhaymah) and Al-Haya. Judhaymah was named Al-Mustaliq for his beautiful voice; he was the first to sing from Khuza'ah. Amir was named Al-Haya because he was beloved to his people.
From the descendants of Al-Haya Al-Mustaliq is Al-Harith bin Abi Dirar, who is Habib bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Judhaymah Al-Mustaliq. This Al-Harith is the father of Juwayriyah, wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him).
From the descendants of Al-Haba is Khalaf bin Kilab bin Ghadirah bin Hidam bin Amir (who is Al-Haba).
From the descendants of Adi bin Amr bin Rabi'ah is Al-Has'has bin Abd Amr bin Dubay'ah bin Amr bin Adi bin Amr bin Rabi'ah. He is the one who met the people of Badr [on their way] to Mecca while he was a disbeliever at the time, then he accepted Islam.
(Section) As for Afsa bin Rabi'ah, from his descendants are Aslam, Malik, and Malkan. These three are among those who separated (Khaza'a), so they were named Khuza'ah. He also had children: Imru' al-Qais, Adi, Amr, Juhal, Haras, Zaid, Daym, Jusham, Sawadah, and Khuzaymah. These are from Banu Ghassan.
From the descendants of Aslam are Salaman and Hawazin. Salaman begot Al-Harith, Rahman, and Mazin. Mazin begot Sahm and Jadidah (who is Malik) and they have offspring.
Among them is the one to whom the wolf spoke, Uhban bin Abbad bin Rabi'ah bin Ka'b bin Umayyah bin Yaqazah bin Jazimah bin Hadidah (who is Malik bin Mazin bin Salaman bin Aslam). He is the brother of Salamah bin Al-Akwa'. Al-Waqidi said: And the wolf spoke to Ibn Al-Aws Al-Aslami. He accompanied the Prophet (peace be upon him) and accepted Islam.
Among them is the Companion of the Prophet (peace be upon him) Abdullah bin Abi Awfa, who is Alqamah bin Khalid bin Al-Harith bin Abi Asad bin Rawa'ah bin Tha'labah bin Hawazin bin Aslam bin Afsa.
Among them is the poet Abl bin Ali bin Badr bin Sulayman bin Tamim bin Bahsh bin Aslam bin Afsa.
From the descendants of Afsa is Dhu al-Shimalayn (Possessor of Two Left Hands) Umair bin Amr bin Quwa bin Malkan bin Afsa. He witnessed Badr. He is called Dhu al-Yadayn (Possessor of Two Hands) because he used to work with both hands. He is the one mentioned in the Hadith that the Prophet (peace be upon him) spoke after prayer then made up what he missed. He is Dhu al-Shimalayn who was martyred on the Day of Badr.
Among them is Siba' bin Abd al-Uzza bin Nadlah to the end of the lineage. Hamzah bin Abd al-Muttalib killed him on the Day of Uhud. He leaned over him to take his armor, so Wahshi pierced him with the javelin and killed him.
From Banu Malik bin Afsa is Asma' bin Harithah bin Sayyid bin Abdullah bin Ghiyath bin Sa'id bin Amr bin Amir bin Tha'labah bin Malik bin Afsa. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to him: "Order your people to fast the Day of Ashura." He said: "And whoever has eaten..."
The clans of Khuza'ah are the children of Amr bin Luhay and his governors from the children of Afsa bin Luhay. In the descendants of Amr are Banu Qambar, Banu Salul, Banu Al-Mustaliq, and Banu Al-Haba. From the descendants of Afsa are Aslam and Salaman.

(Section) Lineage of Banu Adi bin Harithah bin Amr bin Amir

They are Bariq, Alma', and Su'ud (to whom Al-Su'ud is attributed, who was knowledgeable in magic/astrology 'Nirijan').
As for Bariq, it is a water source in Al-Sarah. Whoever landed there [due to] the flood of Al-Arim is Bariqi. Sa'd bin Adi bin Harithah landed there and begot Malik and Shayba. She is the mother [Alam?] of Amr, brother of Sa'd bin Adi bin Harithah, so they were named Bariq. A people settled in Al-Sarah between whom was hatred (Shana'an), so they were named Azd Shanu'ah.
As for Alma', he is Alma' bin Amr bin Adi.
Adi bin Harithah had children: Sa'd, Amr, Imran, Tha'labah, Anmar, Amr, and Sa'id. These are Bariq bin Mazin bin Tha'labah bin Kinanah bin Bariq (who is Sa'd bin Adi).
Among them is the poet Suraqah bin Mirdas bin Asma' bin Khalid bin Awf bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Tha'labah bin Kinanah bin Bariq.
Among them is Al-Harith bin Abd Yaghuth Bahitah bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Tha'labah bin Kinanah bin Bariq; he was a noble.
Among them is Shahhah bin Aws bin Suraym bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Anmar bin Bariq; he was a noble.
From the descendants of Amr bin Adi is Arfajah bin Khuzaymah bin Abd al-Uzza bin Zuhaym bin Tha'labah bin Malik bin Adi.
From the descendants of Imran bin Adi is Shukr. These are the children of Amr bin Imran bin Adi: Al-Afsam and Al-Iyaj sons of Asir bin Harithah bin Tha'labah bin Adi bin Harithah bin Tha'labah Al-Anqa' bin Amr Muzayqiya bin Amir Ma' al-Sama' bin Harithah.

**Lineage of the Descendants of Amr Muzayqiya bin Amir Ma' al-Sama'**
Amr was named Muzayqiya because he used to wear two suits every day, and when evening came he tore them (yumazziq), disdaining to wear them the next day. It was also said he was named Muzayqiya because the Kingdom of Saba was torn apart at his hands.
He said: Amr bin Amir begot Tha'labah, Jafnah, Ka'b, Imran, Harithah, and Al-Harith. And he informed him [text unclear] Amr, Imran, Al-Kahin bin Amir Ma' al-Sama' Al-Muharriq, Malik, Awf, Dhuhl, Ashar, and Wada'ah.
Imran begot Al-Asad and Al-Hajr (with moving Sin in Asad and Sukun on Jim in Hajr).
To Al-Asad were born Al-Atik, Suhayl, Al-Harith, Tha'labah, and Salamah.
From the descendants of Al-Atik is Zaid bin Mamri bin Abi Sahbanah bin Sardah min Fadih.
Among them is Al-Muhallab bin Abi Sufrah, whose name is Zalim bin Suraq bin Subh bin Kindi bin Amr bin Adi bin Qa'il bin Al-Harith bin Al-Atik bin Al-Asad bin Imran.
The children of Abu Sufrah are Al-Muhallab, Al-Mughira, Sufrah, Juwli, Bajf, Sabr, Labibah, Al-Ala, Al-Ma'arik, Hani, Al-Jarw, Al-Hawfazan, Al-Shammakh, Al-Minjab, Al-Izz, Abdullah, and Bishr. Amr bin Hafs bin Uthman bin Faddah bin Abi Sufrah was called Hazar Mard (Thousand Men); he was counted as a thousand knights. He governed Sindh and Ifriqiya.
The children of Al-Muhallab are Habib (who is Al-Harun; named Al-Harun because he stands firm in war like a restive beast 'Harun'), Al-Mughira, Yazid, Qabisah, Sa'id, Al-Mufaddal, Abd al-Malik, Al-Buhturi, Uthman, Abu Uyaynah, Khayr, Ziyad, Andarak, Marwan, Mujja'ad Al-Asajj, Amr, Mu'awiyah, Abdullah, Abd al-Rahman, Abd al-Aziz, Shabib, Samah, Mukhallad, and Al-Hajjaj.
From the descendants of Al-Muhallab are Rawh bin Hatim and Qabisah bin Al-Muhallab. He governed Egypt, Basra, Oman, Kerman, and Sindh. They were Amirs of reports [Akhbar - likely armies/regions] in the Abbasid state after the Umayyad.
From the descendants of Al-Muhallab is the grammarian Niftawayh, who is Ibrahim bin Arafah Sulayman bin Al-Mughira bin Habib bin Abi Sufrah.
From the descendants of Sahl bin Al-Asad are Thawban and Sahl. From the descendants of Thawban are Al-Ashraf, Murr, Awf, Ka'b, Tha'labah, Qasit, and Abdullah, sons of Qais bin Ziyad bin Murrah bin Qais bin Thawban bin Sahl bin Al-Azd. It was called Al-Asad Al-Daws.
From the descendants of Al-Hajr bin Imran are Zahran, Zaid Manat, and Al-Harith. From the descendants of Zahran are Al-Ril, Amr, Sa'd, Anzah, and Jamal, sons of Hidad bin Khuzaymah bin Zahran bin Al-Hajr. Among them is Amr bin Zahran. Azd bin Imran was 'Imrani'. Among them is Zaid bin Harithah bin Al-Harith bin Al-Hajr bin Imran. Among them is Al-Harith Muharriq bin Amr Muzayqiya bin Amir Ma' al-Sama'.

**Lineage of the Descendants of Nasr bin Al-Azd**

He said: Nasr begot Malik. Malik begot Abdullah, Muwaylik, Mayda'an, and Khamar. Hammad was a commoner. It is said in the proverb: "Harder than the donkey of Al-Kafr from Hammad." From the descendants of Abdullah bin Malik bin Nasr is Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Nasr. Al-Harith begot Ka'b and Nabshah, who is Masikhah, and to him Al-Qais Al-Makhah is attributed.
From Banu Masikhah are Banu Sharif bin Abd bin Masikhah bin Al-Harith, a clan in Hijaz. Among them is Abd al-Malik bin Khazarjan bin Sharif; he was a noble in Sham and governed in the time of Al-Hajjaj. From Banu Sharif are Taym, Kathir, Abdullah, Amr, and Aws, sons of Sharif.
From the descendants of Ka'b bin Al-Harith are Abdullah, Al-Ahjar, and Zahran.
From Banu Abdullah bin Ka'b is Ghamid, a clan. The name of Ghamid is Amr bin Abdullah bin Ka'b. He was named Ghamid because there was something between his people, so he repaired it and covered it (Taghammada) upon them, so they named him Ghamid.
From the descendants of Ghamid are Zabyan, Malik, and Sa'd Manat.
From Banu Sa'd Manat bin Ghamid are Banu Zabyan Al-A'raj, who is Abd Shams bin Al-Harith bin Kathir bin Jusham bin Sami' bin Zuhl bin Al-Awwam bin Bakr bin Tha'labah bin Sa'd Manat bin Ghamid.
Among them is Janb bin Zuhayr bin Al-Harith bin Kathir bin Jusham to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Jundub bin Al-Ahram bin Mash'ab bin Jim bin Jusham bin Salaman bin Ghanam bin Zabyan bin Ghamid.
Among them is Jundub bin Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Amir bin Malik bin Amir bin Zuhl bin Tha'labah bin Bayan bin Ghamid. These are the Janadibah of Azd.
Among them are Banu Sa'd Manat bin Ghamid, Al-Dul, a clan. From Banu Al-Dul are clans: Kathir, Tha'labah, Mazin, and Alyah, a clan. From the descendants of Al-Dul bin Walibah is a clan. From Banu Walibah are Saba, Dhuhl, Amr, and Banu Walibah, and they have offspring and renewal.

(Section) From Banu Al-Ahjar bin Ka'b is Thumalah, who is Awf bin Aslam bin Ahjar. He was named Thumalah because he fed his people and gave them milk with froth (Raghwah), so he was named Thumalah for the froth of the milk.
From the descendants of Thumalah are Amr, Uthman, and Sumaylah.
Among them is the grammarian Abu Al-Abbas Al-Mubarrad, who is Muhammad bin Yazid bin Abd Al-Akbar bin Umayr bin Hasban bin Salm bin Sa'd bin Abdullah bin Yazid bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Hadi Ashar Bilal bin Amr bin Awf bin Thumalah.
From Banu Al-Ahjar bin Ka'b is Lahb, a clan (with Sukun on Ha and Kasra on Lam). They possess divination (Iyafah), tracking (Qiyafah), cursing, and skill with animals. They are among the best diviners of the Arabs. Kuthayyir says about them:
"I headed to Lahb seeking knowledge from them...
For the knowledge of diviners has come to Lahb."
He said: In Adwan, Lahb is with Fatha on Lam and moving Ha.

(Section) As for Zahran bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Nasr bin Al-Azd, they are a great clan in Al-Sarah. Zahran begot Nasr, Al-Namir, Malik, Ubayrah, and Saql. Malik, Ubar [Ubayrah?], and Saql were called Banu Khunays.
As for Abdullah bin Zahran, he begot Adathan (with Tha with three dots above). And Adathan bin Abdullah bin Akk bin Adathan bin Abdullah bin Zahran. From here came the error and misspelling in Akk bin Adnan (with Nun) attributed to Azd. The correct is that Akk bin Adnan bin Add is from the people of Sham (with Nun), and Akk bin Adathan (with Tha with three dots) is from Azd: Akk bin Adathan bin Abdullah bin Al-Azd. So understand that.

(Section) As for Daws bin Adnan

He begot Ghanam and Munhib. Ghanam begot Fahm. Fahm begot Sulayman, Malik, and Tarif.
As for Sulayman, from his descendants is Abu Umayrah, whose name is Umayr bin Amir bin Abd Dhi al-Sara (which is the name of an idol) bin Tarif bin Ubayb [Abab?] bin Abi Ka'b (who is Munabbih) bin Sa'd bin Tha'labah bin Salm bin Fahm bin Ghanam bin Daws. He accompanied the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he prayed for him to memorize Hadith from him.
Among them is Dhu al-Nur Tufayl bin Amr bin Tarif bin Al-As bin Tha'labah bin Sulaym. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and said: "O Messenger of Allah, adultery has prevailed over Daws, so pray against them." The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "O Allah, guide Daws." He said: "O Messenger of Allah, send me to them." He did so. He said: "Make for me a sign by which they will be guided." He said: "O Allah, give him light." A light shone between his eyes. He said: "O Messenger of Allah, I fear they will say it is a mutilation." So it was shifted to the tip of his whip, illuminating for him in the dark night. He said: "O Messenger of Allah, make the slogan of Azd 'Ya Mansur Amit' [? text says 'Wara']." So he made the slogan of all Azd 'Wara' [? or 'Ya Mansur Amit'] to this day.
As for Malik bin Fahm, he begot Judhaymah, Awf, Nawa, Jahdam, Sulaymah, Shababah, Manah, Umayr, Tha'labah, Al-Harith, and Ma'n.
As for Judhaymah, he is the King Judhaymah Al-Abrash bin Malik bin Fahm bin Ghanam bin Daws. He is the one whom Al-Zabba' killed, and his nephew Amr bin Adi Al-Lakhmi, grandfather of Al-Nu'man bin Al-Mundhir, took revenge for him and inherited the kingdom. He is the first king from Lakhm. Some genealogists say Jahdam bin Judhaymah.
Jahdam begot Al-Aswad, Muhann, Ja'far, Ka'b, Malik, and Ubaydah. These are the Jahadimah, descendants of Jahdam bin Judhaymah the King.
From the descendants of Malik are Al-Ashaqir, a great clan, who are the descendants of Sa'd (who is Al-Ashqar) bin Abid bin Malik bin Amr bin Malik bin Fahm bin Ghanam bin Daws. Among them is the poet Ka'b Al-Ashqari.
From the descendants of Amr bin Malik are Wa'il, Tayalah, Abwasah, Kilab, Daj'an, and Matwiyah (who is Qasmalah Abu Al-Qasamil).
From the descendants of Amir bin Malik are Al-Jaramiz (plural of Jarmuzah), Al-Faradis (plural of Firdaws), Al-Qasamil (plural of Qasmalah), and Al-Ashaqir (plural of Al-Ashqar).
Among them is Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Durayd bin Atahiyah bin Khaytham bin Al-Husayn bin Hamami bin Rafi' bin Wahb bin Salamah bin Hadir bin Zalim bin Hasir bin Usayyid bin Amir bin Malik bin Amr bin Malik bin Fahm bin Ghanam bin Daws.
From Banu Bashir bin Malik is Al-Hurr bin Sujnan bin Qatanz bin Hani bin Zalim bin Najsham Hadir bin Farahid bin Shabuh bin Malik; he was a knight.
From Al-Farahid is Al-Khalil bin Ahmad Al-Farahidi bin Ahmad bin Sulaym Al-Arudi. He is the Imam in knowledge, grammar, language, meanings of poetry, and meanings of Arabs. He was called the Philosopher of the Arabs.
From the descendants of Malik bin Qutham is Abu Hamzah the Kharijite and Al-Mukhtar bin Abdullah bin Mazin bin Nuhas bin Salamah bin Malik.
Among them is the judge of Basra, Ka'b bin Siwar bin Bakr bin Abdullah bin Tha'labah bin Sulaym bin Dhuhl bin Laqit bin Al-Harith bin Malik. He was a judge for Umar over Basra and remained over it until he was killed with Aisha on the Day of the Camel; a stray arrow hit him and killed him.
From the descendants of Mann bin Malik are Sultan, Jaddad, Rabi'ah, Kard, Hajar, Zsd [Zaid?], Kawm, and Dubay'. Among them is Al-Karani, who is Jadi' bin Ali bin Shabib bin Amir bin Marari bin Sanam bin Sultan bin Rab'i bin Malik. He was the head of Azd in the days of tribalism and a Kurd in Khorasan.
Among them is Mas'ud bin Amr bin Adi bin Muharib bin Sanam bin Malih bin Shatan. He was the master of Azd, called Al-Qamar (The Moon). Banu Tamim killed him.
From the descendants of Mas'ud bin Amr are Emir Ahmad bin Emir Yahya bin Emir Mahatt bin Emir Al-Rabbad bin Al-Muthanna bin Maymun bin Mas'ud.
As for Munhib bin Daws, from them is Amr bin Hammah bin Al-Harith bin Rafi' bin Sa'd bin Tha'labah bin Lu'ay bin Amir bin Ghanim bin Dahman bin Munhib bin Daws. He is the one whose life was long and for whom the sandgrouse were frightened.
This is the lineage of Banu Abdullah bin Zahran.

**Lineage of the Descendants of Nasr bin Zahran**

He said: Nasr bin Zahran begot Uthman and Dahman.
Uthman begot Al-Nadr, Ghanim, Ghalib, and Abdullah (who is Hayy). Among them is Sikh in Malik bin Fahm bin Rabi'ah bin Sulaym bin Al-Namir bin Uthman bin Nasr bin Zahran. Among them is Al-Aws bin Amir bin Abdullah (who is Hama) bin Uthman. He was called Naja because a king imprisoned him and he escaped (Naja) from his prison, so he was named Naja.
Among them is Al-Yahmad (in Quda'ah, Yahmad is with Damma on Ya and Kasra on Mim). From the descendants of Al-Yahmad Al-Sari are Malik, Khalid, Majid, Humayd, Amr, Zam'ah, Ka'b, Sa'd, and Jahm bin Al-Yahmad bin Nasr.
Banu Abdullah bin Uthman bin Nasr bin Zahran. Among them is Al-Harith bin Shams bin Amr bin Ghalibah bin Uthman.
From the descendants of Al-Harran bin Malik bin Abd Shams bin Al-Harran bin Shams. Among them is Sabrah bin San bin Atif bin Kulthum bin Abd bin Baqil bin Abd Shams bin Al-Harran. He was the head of Azd on the Day of the Camel with Aisha.
Among them is Jarir bin Abdullah bin Asad Abid bin Ziyad bin Al-Harrar.
Among them is Uthman's companion, Al-Julanda bin Al-Mustakbir bin Mas'ud bin Al-Harrar bin Abd al-Uzza bin Bayda bin Shams bin Al-Harran bin Shams bin Amr bin Ghanam bin Ghalib bin Zahran. About him Al-Musayyib says:
"O Julanda, O son of Mustakbir... O best of those who walk among males."
From the descendants of Al-Julanda are Jayfar and Abd. From the descendants of Abd and Sulayman bin Abbad bin Abd Al-Julanda, were the two masters of the people of Oman.

(Section) From the descendants of Dahman bin Nasr is Sa'b. From the descendants of Sa'b are Yashkur, Adb, Al-Aws, and Al-Harb, sons of Mubashir bin Sa'b bin Dahman.
From the descendants of Yashkur is Ka'b bin Al-Ghitrif the Elder bin Amir bin Bakr bin Yashkur bin Sa'b bin Dahman.
From the descendants of Ka'b Al-Ghitrif are Wa'il, Hujr, Ras, Shamalah, Mihras, Hadr, Ruha, Malik, Amir, Hilal, Abdullah, and Barsani, sons of Ka'b bin Al-Ghitrif the Younger, who is the maternal uncle of Abu Hurairah.
From the descendants of Firas bin Ka'b is Sa'd bin Shibl, who is Hamm bin Hamalah bin Awf bin Amr bin Amir bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Al-Ghitrif. He is the grandfather of Qusayy bin Kilab, father of his mother Fatimah bint Sa'd bin Shibl. He was the first to build the wall of the Kaaba, so he was named Al-Jadir. They have a remnant in Medina.
These are Banu Abdullah bin Malik bin Nasr bin Al-Azd.

(Section) From the descendants of Mayda'an bin Malik bin Nasr bin Al-Azd is Rasib bin Malik bin Mayda'an, which is a clan. Among them is Dhu al-Thafinat Abdullah bin Wahb bin Rasib the Kharijite who was killed on the Day of Nahrawan; he was their leader.
From the descendants of Muwaylik bin Nasr is Ibn Al-Azd the King who killed the Mawla of Jurhum at Al-Qamas.

(Section) From the descendants of Al-Hinu bin Al-Azd are Hawalah, Za'nah, Amlah, Barid, Dihnah, Al-Hun, and Qais.
From the descendants of Qais is the King Al-Dahhak bin Qais bin Al-Hinu bin Al-Azd, King of the two Iraqs.
Among them are Hama, Ma'iy, Asim, Salam, Mubashir, and Dumr, sons of Al-Nabit bin Al-Hun bin Al-Hibr bin Al-Azd.
End of Azd bin Al-Gharth.

**Lineage of Al-Harith Muharriq bin Amr Muzayqiya bin Amir Ma' al-Sama'**
He was named Muharriq (Burner) because he was the first to punish with fire.
From the descendants of Al-Harith and Amr are Sawadah and Rifa'ah.
From his descendants are Al-Qantur, Amir, Al-Harith, Tha'labah, Al-Husayn, and Awn. Among them is Abu Al-Hakam Rafi' bin Sinan bin Khuzaymah bin Al-Namam bin Al-Khazraj bin Awf bin Al-Qantur (and the descendants of Awf are in Sham and they are few).
Among them is Abu Al-Man'asar Asad bin Qabad bin Abdullah bin Hali bin Al-Husayn bin Al-Qantur.
These are the tribes of Azd and its clans: Al-Aws, Al-Khazraj, Ghassan, Khuza'ah, Al-Hajr, Mazin, Alma', Tariq, Al-Hamtik, Ghamid, Thumalah, Lahb, Zahran, Walibah, Akk, Daws, Fahm, Al-Jahadim, Al-Ashaqir, Al-Qasamil, Al-Gharawibi, Al-Farahid, Al-Khazzan, Dahman, Yashkur, and Al-Rasib.

**Lineage of the Descendants of Al-Gharth bin Nabit**
He is Al-Khabbaz bin Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan. Al-Gharth begot Al-Azd (whom we mentioned), Amr, Qidar, and Muqta'.
From the descendants of Amr bin Al-Gharth are Bajilah and Khath'am, sons of Anmar bin Arash bin Amr bin Al-Gharth.
Genealogists differed regarding Bajilah and Khath'am. A group said: They are sons of Anmar bin Nizar attached to Al-Namir, and they attributed themselves to Anmar bin Arash out of ignorance. Regarding that, Labid says:
"Just as Bajilah strayed from its father...
And Khath'am, and affairs have changes."
Others said: Anmar bin Nizar had children Al-Gharth, Shahmah, and a daughter named Salamah bint Anmar bin Nizar. Arash bin Amr bin Al-Gharth married her, and she bore him a son whom she named after her father Anmar, so he begot Bajilah and Khath'am. Allah knows best. This is the descendant of Anmar bin Arash bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Al-Nabit bin Zaid bin Kahlan.
It is said that Bajilah is a woman, daughter of Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah. She bore to Anmar bin Arash children: Abqar, Al-Gharth, Suhayb, Wada'ah, and Suhayl. They were attributed to their mother Bajilah, and their father is Amr bin Al-Gharth brother of Al-Azd bin Al-Gharth.
It is said that Abqar is Bajilah bin Amr bin Al-Gharth.

And that Khath'am, whose name is Aftal (his mother is Hind bint Al-Ghafiq bin Qumk), was named Khath'am after a camel of Anmar. When they traveled on it, it smeared (Khath'ama) [or they smeared themselves with blood]. It is said because they smeared themselves (Takhath'amu) with blood. The name of Bajilah is Abqar bin Anmar. From the descendants of Anmar are Al-Gharth and Suhaybah, and their mother is Bajilah bint Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah.
Those who said Bajilah and Khath'am are from Yemen argued with what was narrated by Farwah bin Musayk Al-Ghutayfi, Tamim Al-Dari, and Abdullah bin Al-Abbas. The most complete is the Hadith of Farwah bin Musayk, he said: I said, O Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), inform me about Saba, what is it? Is it a mountain, a valley, a man, a woman, or a land? The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "It is not a mountain, nor a land, nor a woman, but a man who begot ten from the Arabs. Six of them went south (Yemen) and four went north (Sham). As for those who went north: Lakhm, Judham, Amilah, and Ghassan. As for those who went south: Himyar, Al-Azd, Kindah, Al-Ash'ar, Madhhij, and Anmar."
In the Hadith of Abu Sittah, a man said: O Messenger of Allah, which Anmar? Is it the one containing Bajilah and Khath'am? [Implicitly yes].
Afsa argued with the saying of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him): "A man from the best of Dhu Yaman will appear to you, upon him is a touch of kingship." Then Jarir bin Abdullah Al-Bajali appeared, and he was one of the most handsome and tallest of Arabs.
It is said that the reason Khath'am transferred its lineage to Nizar was a war that occurred between them and Nahd bin Zaid. Nahd, Janb, Sinhan, and Zubid allied against them and harmed Khath'am. So they attributed themselves to Nizar and said: We are Banu Kalb bin 'Afras bin Hilf bin Aftal, we are Banu Kalb bin Rabi'ah bin Nizar. And Shahran Al-Aridah said: We are Banu Anmar bin Nizar. So Anz, Adwan, and those near them from the tribes of Nizar supported them.
We return now to mentioning the lineage.
As for Bajilah, his name is Abqar. From the descendants of Bajilah is Jarir bin Abdullah bin Al-Salil, who is Jabir bin Malik bin Nasr bin Tha'labah bin Jusham bin Awf bin Khuzaymah bin Harith bin Adi bin Malik bin Sa'd bin Zaid bin Qais (who is Malik bin Abqar, who is Bajilah). He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he spread his cloak for him. It was said of Jarir that he is the Joseph of this Ummah for his beauty. Jarir bin Abdullah accepted Islam forty days before the death of the Prophet (peace be upon him). About him the poet says:
"Were it not for Jarir, Bajilah would have perished...
What an excellent youth, the lineage of the tribe."
From Bajilah is Al-Kahin Saniq bin Sa'b bin Yashkur to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Judge Abu Yusuf, who is Ya'qub bin Ibrahim bin Habib bin Sa'd.
Among them is Khalid bin Abdullah bin Zaid bin Asad bin Karb bin Amir bin Abdullah bin Abd Shams bin Khath'amah bin Jarir bin Sa'd Al-Kahin bin Sa'b bin Yashkur bin Ath'am [? Khath'am?] bin Afrak bin Yazid bin Qar bin Abqar. From the clans of Bajilah is Khalid bin Abdullah Al-Qasri.
From their clans is Uraynah bin Zaid bin Qasr bin Abqar. Among them are the Uraynis who took the camels of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and he did with them what he did, and their story is famous.

(Section)
As for Khath'am, his name is Aftal. From his descendants is Anas bin Mudrikah bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Al-Ulayth bin Harithah bin Amr bin Taym Allah bin Mubashir bin Aklub bin Rabi'ah bin 'Afras bin Hilf bin Khath'am.
Among them is the guide of the Abyssinians, Nufayl bin Habib bin Abdullah bin Harith bin Amir bin Malik bin Wahb bin Halimah (who is Al-Harith bin Aklub bin Rabi'ah bin 'Afras bin Hilf bin Khath'am).
Among them is Aban bin Al-Walid bin Malik bin Abdullah (who is Abu Hasa) bin Al-Harith bin Amir bin Al-Amarah bin Sa'd bin As'ad bin Zuhl bin Awf bin Wadad bin Tha'labah bin Khath'am.
The clans of Khath'am are Shahran, Nahis, and Karar bin 'Afras.
From the descendants of [bin] Al-Gharth are Dhubyan bin Tha'labah bin Mu'awiyah bin Zaid bin Al-Gharth, Aklub bin Rabi'ah bin 'Afras, Al Shahran, and Al Nahis.
As for 'Afras, in them are the number and honor of Khath'am. From Khath'am is Ham bin Nahis. Al-Hutay'ah said:
"I gathered from Amir in them and from Asad...
And from Tamim and from Haw and from Ham."

(Section)
As for Ahmas bin Al-Gharth bin Anmar

His count is in Bajilah. Likewise, the children of Zaid bin Al-Gharth and the children of Anmar bin Arash, all of these are counted in Bajilah.
From Ahmas is Rabi'ah bin Khuwaylid bin Hilal bin Abid bin Kulayb bin Amr bin Lu'ay bin Rahn bin Mu'awiyah bin Aslam bin Ahmas. He had companionship with the Prophet (peace be upon him).
Among them is Sayyid bin Ma'bad bin Ubayd bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Amir bin Ali bin Aslam bin Ahmas. He also accompanied the Prophet (peace be upon him).
From Ahmas is Rahn bin Mu'awiyah bin Aslam bin Ahmas Rahn.
From the descendants of Zaid bin Al-Gharth is Umm Kharijah bint Sa'd bin Abdullah bin Qurad bin Tha'labah bin Mu'awiyah Umm Zaid. She is the one proverbial; it is said: "Faster than the marriage of Umm Kharijah."
From Khath'am is Asma' bint Umays bin Ma'bad bin Al-Harith bin Taym bin Ka'b bin Malik bin Fajajah bin Amir bin Matriyah bin Zaid bin Malik bin Bishr bin Wahb Allah bin Khalaf bin Khath'am. She was the wife of Ja'far bin Abi Talib, then Abu Bakr married her after him, then Ali married her after him, and she has children from each of them.
He said: From Banu Adi [text unclear] Malik Nakal from Uthman bin As'ad bin Awf bin Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan, to whom Al-Bakali is attributed.

**Lineage of Hamdan and Alhan**
Sons of Malik bin Zaid bin Arsala bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Khiyar (who is Al-Nabit) bin Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan.
As for Alhan, their numbers decreased so they entered into Hamdan. From the descendants of Alhan are Takil the Elder, Anas, Siham, Siyam, and Sahab.
As for Hamdan, his name is Arsala bin Malik. Hamdan begot Nawf and Amr. Amr begot Zaid. Zaid begot Tubba' the Elder, who is Jadal Dhi Murar. Kingship and honor were in the descendants of Amr bin Hamdan, then their numbers decreased in Hashid bin Jusham when they were from them. Numbers decrease in noble houses because of restricting themselves to equals (Kafa'ah), and if an equal is found, he does not provide what is advanced of money and precious gifts before marriage and offspring.
As for Nawf bin Hamdan, in his descendants are the numbers. Nawf begot Khaywan. Khaywan begot Jusham bin Khaywan bin Nawf bin Hamdan.

(Section)
As for Hashid, he begot Jusham, Tarim, and Simam.
Jusham bin Hashid begot Sa'd, Rabi'ah, Zaid, Muray, Malik, Ma'mar, and Urayb.
From the descendants of Urayb bin Jusham is Hujur bin Aslam bin Ulyan bin Zaid bin Urayb bin Jusham bin Hashid.
From the descendants of Qadim bin Zaid are Adran, Adhran (a clan), Abdullah, Qablan, Jabir, Akk, Sabrah, and Al-Qadam (Banu Qadim bin Zaid).
As for Hujur bin Aslam, he begot Awam and Qawlah.
From the descendants of Awam bin Hujur is 'Ahim bin Rabi'ah bin Abd bin Awam bin Hujur.
Among them are the Kings Banu Al-Sulhi, children of Sufyan bin Huda bin Ubayd bin Awam bin Hujur.
Among them is Tahm bin Huda bin Ubayd bin Awam bin Hujur Abi Al-Haytham bin Muhammad bin Sa'id bin Yusuf bin Sa'id bin Jada' bin Hashf the Elder bin Malik bin Rifa'ah bin Amir bin Mulah.
Among them is Hashf the Younger bin Jada' bin Hashf the Elder.
Among them are Ahmad, Shu'ayb, and Hassan, sons of Amir bin Al-Hujur bin Malik bin Rifa'ah.
From the descendants of Amir bin Wahith is Yusuf Al-Iyad bin Abdullah bin Uthman bin Abdullah bin Sa'id bin Yazid bin Abdullah bin Rafi' bin Al-Harith bin Amir bin Fahith. He is the grandfather of Banu Abi Al-Khattab bin Shurahbil, people of Al-Harib.
From Banu Qadim bin Zaid are Murad, Ayham, Tahm, Awf, Mayis, Arab, and Hawaz, sons of Jabir bin Abdullah bin Qadim bin Zaid.
As for Murad, his children are the Muradis, and they are five: Abtah, Amsah, Handas, Awfan, Munabbih, and Suma.
As for Qahm with Qaf alone (while all others in Arabs are with Fa), from the descendants of Qahm bin Jabir are Ayfa', Malik, Jahl, and Masruf.
From the descendants of Arad bin Abdullah bin Qadim bin Abdullah bin Zaid are Hadur, Tawr, Sayif, Musbih, Mughith, and Jusham. From them is the pious jurist and exegete Atiyah bin Al-Harith bin Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Harith bin Jadd Bani Abdullah bin Qadim.
From the descendants of Al-Ahnum are Malik, Kawab, Mukanna, Sam, Al-Fahish, Sufyan, and Abd Subhan. From them are Banu Al-Sharqi, and the people of Al-Qadah Nufayl, and Banu Abd al-Uzza from Latim from the land of Sharo.
As for Qadam bin Qadim, he begot Shawir, Ahlas, Al-Sahil, and Madlajah.
From the descendants of Jusham bin Hashid is Shibam (a clan), who is Sa'd in Hashid. And Rabi'ah bin Wa'iz (a clan) from Yazid bin Jusham bin Hashid.
Banu Malik bin Jusham bin Hashid are Rafi', Amir, Zaid, Mashih, Kabir, and Qata'.
From the descendants of Rafi' are Mashih, Sa'd, and Asbah, sons of Rafi' bin Malik bin Jusham bin Hashid.
Among them is the master of Hamdan, companion of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him), Sa'id bin Qais Al-Malik bin Jart bin Malik bin Harb Al-Malik bin Ma'di Karib bin Sayf bin Amr bin Dubay' bin Sa'b bin Mu'awiyah bin Kabir bin Malik bin Jusham. About him Ali bin Abi Talib (may Allah be pleased with him) says:
"Leading them is the protector of reality, Majid...
Son of Qais, and the noble is a protector.

If I were a doorkeeper at the gate of Paradise...
I would have said to Hamdan: Enter in peace."
Among them is Ja'far bin Hamid bin Habab bin Mas'ud bin Habban bin Masruj bin Hatban bin Munabbih bin Hayy bin Murr bin Jabir.
Among them is the poet Al-A'sha of Hamdan, who is Abd al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Al-Harith bin Nizam bin Jusham bin Amr bin Malik bin Abd Al-Jinn bin Zaid bin Al-Harith bin Qais bin Amir bin Malik bin Jusham bin Hashid.
Amr bin Luhay Al-Khuza'i pushed the idol Ya'uq to Khaywan.
Among them is Adi bin Qusayy bin Sa'd bin Rafi' bin Malik bin Jusham bin Hashid.
Among them are Jusham and Madhkar sons of Yam bin Asba bin Dafi'.
From the descendants of Jusham are Dhuhl and Al-Namir sons of Salamah bin Dhi Dawl bin Dhi Jusham bin Yam.
From the descendants of Madhkar are Habrah, Al-Ghurr, and Muwajid, sons of Madhkar bin Yam.
From Banu Muwajid are Al-Aklum, Khayb, Bu'aysah, Jakhdab, and Ruwayd, sons of Muwajid. Among them is the jurist Ubaydah bin Al-Ajda' bin Salman bin Habib bin Muwajid bin Madhkar bin Yam.
From the descendants of Habrah are Amr and Akhzam (with dotted Kha and Zay). From his descendants are Shurahbil, Malik, Nu'aym, and Yafdil sons of Harith bin Malik bin Harith bin Malik bin Hujr bin Amr bin Masruq bin Adb bin Shurayh bin Asad bin Amr bin Habrah.
From the descendants of Yafdil bin Harith are Mamran, Abdullah, Ula, and Hamzah sons of Yafdil bin Harith.
From the descendants of Nu'aym bin Harith are Abdullah and Yafdil sons of Nu'aym bin Harith.
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Asba is Wishah, master of Banu Al-Dahhak bin Al-Abbas bin Sa'd bin Qais bin Ahmad bin Ma'bad bin Hamzah bin Haram bin Amr bin Marthad bin Al-Harith bin Asba. Among them is Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Al-Dahhak. He was the King of Hamdan and its sword and the owner of battles; it is said he led one hundred and fifty battles in his war and the war of Yahya bin Al-Husayn Al-Alawi, and he captured his son Abu Al-Qasim.
From the descendants of Wada'ah bin Amir bin Masih bin Malik bin Jusham bin Hashid bin Abdullah and Masih sons of Wada'ah. Wada'ah was called in Jahiliyyah 'Usarat al-Misk' (Extract of Musk).
From the descendants of Abdullah is Masruq bin Al-Ajda' bin Malik bin Abdullah bin Murr bin Salaman bin Ma'mar bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Abdullah bin Wada'ah. Al-Ajda' came to Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) and said: I am Al-Ajda' bin Malik. He said: You are Abd al-Rahman.
Among them is Al-Mundhir bin Al-Zuhayr bin Hujr bin Mu'awiyah bin Murr bin Al-Harith bin Sa'id bin Abdullah bin Wada'ah. He was the first to make saddles and bridles for horses. It is said Malalah bin Arhab was the first to do that.
From the descendants of Masikh bin Wada'ah are Namar, Malik, and Salhah.

(Section)
As for Bakil in Jusham bin Khaywan bin Nawf in Hamdan

He begot Duman, Khaywan, and Sudan.
From the descendants of Duman are Sa'b and Mu'awiyah.
From the descendants of Sa'b bin Duman are Nahm and Shakir, two clans, sons of Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Mu'awiyah bin Sa'b bin Duman. They are the ones about whom Ali, may Allah honor his face, said on the Day of Siffin: "If their number completed a thousand, Allah would be worshipped with His true worship."
From the descendants of Nahm are Sahr, Bir, 'Asasah, and Harith.
From the descendants of Harith bin Nahm is the generous Ju'al bin Abdullah bin Jusham bin Harith bin Nahm.
Among them is the poet Amr bin Barraqah bin Munabbih bin Shahr bin Nahm, and he was brave.
From the descendants of Shakir are Al-Harith and Jamimah bin Shakir. Among them is the poet Malalah bin Abd bin Amir bin Shakir. Among them is Al-Mutajarrid bin Qais bin Murrah bin Al-Ghurr bin Wa'ilah bin Shakir.
From Banu Sa'b bin Duman is Al-Hasan bin Ahmad bin Ya'qub bin Dawud bin Sulayman Dhi al-Rumayh the poet bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Hasan bin Al-Walid Al-Azhar bin Amr bin Tariq bin Adham bin Qais bin Rabi'ah bin Abd Ulyan bin Arhab (who is Murrah bin Al-Da'am the Younger bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Da'am the Elder bin Malik the Elder bin Mu'awiyah bin Sa'b bin Duman bin Bakil).
Al-Da'am the Younger begot Marhabah and Arhab. Arhab begot Malalah, Sufyan, and Ulyan. Arhab was called Arhab of the Noble and saddle-blankets (Ahlas) of horses. Then it applied to all of Hamdan, so it was said: O Hamdan, Ahlas of horses. The Arabs say: No one possesses equestrian skill after forty years unless he is from the sons of Hamdan and Arhab.
From Banu Malalah is Abu Ruhm the poet bin Mut'im bin Tufayl bin Malik bin Malalah bin Arhab (who is Murrah).
From the descendants of Sufyan bin Mu'awiyah are Sabarah, Saf, and Bari. Among them is Malik bin Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Al-Ami bin Salman bin Mu'adiyah bin Ka'b bin Alwi bin Ulyan bin Arhab.
From the descendants of Mu'awiyah bin Duman are Ali and Al-Husayn, sons of Salih bin Muslim bin Habyan bin Shafi bin Hani bin Rafi' bin Qala bin Amr bin Qani' bin Silal bin Thawr (who is Malik bin Mu'adiyah bin Duman).
As for Marhabah bin Al-Da'am, they were called in Jahiliyyah Marhabah Al-Dawsar. The meaning of Dawsar is the army if it reaches twelve thousand is called Al-Dawsar. They were called Wayidah, Wayid, and Al-Dawsar.
Marhabah bin Al-Da'am begot [children]. Among them is the poet Amr bin Ziyad bin Wahb bin Bada bin Nahd bin Marhabah.
Among them is Amr bin Durr bin Abdullah bin Zurarah, the Judge and Jurist, bin Matriyah bin Amr bin Munabbih bin Ghalib bin Waqsh bin Jusham bin Marhabah. From his descendants is the virtuous jurist, Imam of the niche of Dhamar Mosque, Judge Ahmad bin Salah bin Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Husayn Najad bin Faydal bin Ghalib bin Judge Umar, the famous scholar, bin Durr bin Abdullah bin Zurarah, the Judge and Jurist, bin Mu'awiyah bin Umayrah bin Munabbih bin Ghalib bin Waqsh bin Wahbah bin Al-Da'am the Younger. The Judge is the mother of children [or 'has children'? text slightly unclear]. Some of them live in Sham, some in Sana'a, and some in Dhamar.
This is the lineage of the descendants of Hamdan. Within Hashid are the clans: Hujur, Qadam, Adran, Lahith, Al-Ahnum, Shawir, Haywan, and Udhar. The clans of Alhan are Yam, Sham, Jusham, Madhkar, Habrah, Al-Ghurr, and Wada'ah. The clans of Bakil are Banu Al-Da'am, Marhabah, Arhab, Nahm, and Shakir.
It is narrated that the Prophet (peace be upon him) [was pleased] when all of Hamdan accepted Islam in one day. Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) wrote about that to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). When he read his letter, he fell prostrate to Allah Almighty and said: "Peace be upon Hamdan."

**Lineage of Madhhij**
And his brothers Tayy, Al-Ash'ar, and Murrah, sons of Udad bin Yashjub (who is Amr) bin Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan. From his descendants are Lakhm, Judham, Amilah, and Kindah, as their explanation will come, Allah willing.
As for Madhhij, there is difference of opinion. A group said Madhhij bin Malik bin Udad, his children were attributed to him. Hisham bin Al-Sa'ib said: Rather, it is a red hill upon which Malik bin Udad was born, so his children were known by it. Al-Sharfi [Al-Sharqi?] bin Al-Qatami said: Madhhij is neither mother nor father, but a red hill in Yemen where the children of Malik bin Udad gathered and said: Come let us make Madhhij ours, it protects us and we protect it. So whoever was from the children of Malik bin Udad is Madhhiji. It is said Madhhij are various tribes that gathered (Tamadhhajat), i.e., assembled; you say 'Madhhajtu al-shay'a' if you gathered it.
Ibn Al-Kalbi said: Malik, Tayy, and Al-Ash'ar are sons of Udad bin Madhhij. There is difference regarding Tayy bin Udad. A group said Zunn is brother of Malik, their mother is Madhhij, and he is Madhhij, this one. Some say Madhhij is a woman's name. Others said Tayn [Tayy?] is brother of Malik, and Layla is a mother to her [them?], and this is the correct view, Allah knows best.

It is narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: "The most numerous tribes in Paradise are Madhhij."
He said: Madhhij begot Jald, Sa'd Al-Ashirah, Murad (who is Yuhayir), Ans (whose name is Zaid), and Lamis bint Ans. Their mother is Salma bint Mansur bin Ikrimah bin Khasafah bin Qais bin Aylan.
As for Jald bin Madhhij, from his descendants are Al-Harith, the Harithis, Banu Masliyah, Al-Nakha', Ruha', Sada', and Janb. As for the Harithis, they are the kings of Najran, Banu Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Ulah bin Jald bin Madhhij. And Ri'l is a clan with Banu Al-Harith in Basra. He said: Al-Harith bin Ka'b, Abs bin Baghis, and Dabbah bin Add are brothers from the same mother.
From them is Abd Al-Hajar. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) so he named him Abdullah bin Abd Al-Madan, who is Amr bin Al-Dayyan, who is Yazid bin Qatan bin Ziyad bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Malik bin Mula'ib al-Asinnah bin Rabi'ah bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b.
From Banu Abd Al-Hajar are Abdullah, Malik, and Bishr. From the descendants of Bishr is Abu Ali bin Bishr. From the descendants of Abdullah bin Abd Al-Hajar is Al-Amin Al-Rabi' bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-Hajar.
Among them is Al-Hajar Al-Kamil.
Among them is Al-Simt bin Al-Raqraq bin Bishr bin Muhammad bin Azd bin Bishr bin Al-Walid bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-Hajar. Their mother is Al-Fadl bin Al-Minhal bin Al-Sabah bin Abd al-Aziz bin Amr bin Al-Minhal bin Salman Al-Amir bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-Hajar.
Among them is Zarif bin Bishr bin Muhammad bin Al-Minhal bin Salman Al-Amir.
Among them is Emir Muhammad bin Yahya bin Malik bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-Hajar.
Among them is Mani' bin Al-Mansur bin Mani' bin Al-Mu'afi bin Abi Al-Qasim Muhammad bin Al-Rabi' bin Abdullah bin Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Yahya bin Malik bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-Hajar.
Among them are Atwah and Abbad sons of Bishr bin Al-Ruh bin Al-Rabi' bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Al-Abbas bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-Hajar.

(Section)
From Banu Abd Al-Madan are Yazid Al-Abham, Abdullah Al-Abham, Abdullah Abu Shurayh, Malik, Al-Harith, and Ubayd.
From Banu Al-Dayyan are Banu Ziyad bin Al-Nadr bin Bishr bin Malik bin Al-Dayyan, companion of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him), Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad bin Anas bin Al-Dayyan, Sharik bin Al-A'war bin Anas bin Al-Dayyan, and Al-Bahr bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Abdullah bin Shurayh bin Mujrim bin Harf bin Aqas bin Al-Dayyan.

(Section)
From Banu Al-Harith bin Malik bin Rabi'ah bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Shu' bin Al-Harith and Ma'bad bin Tamim bin Ma'shar bin Tamim and Muhammad sons of Rabi'ah bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ziyad and Qatan and Al-Muja'ad and Al-Hammash and Al-Harith and Ka'b and Abdullah.
From Banu Al-Hammash is Rabi'ah Al-Nahhas the poet, who is Qais bin Amr bin Malik bin Khalaf bin Qutawiyah bin Jurayh bin Amir (who is Al-Hammash bin Rabi'ah bin Ka'b).
From the descendants of Ka'b bin Rabi'ah bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah is Al-Ma'qil. From Banu Rabi'ah Al-Mufaddal are Ruha' and Salamah. From Banu Salamah are Muraydah and Murshid. As for Salamah bin Al-Ma'qil, they are called Al-Mara'id.
Among them are Al-Dabab (with Fatha on Dad, and in Amir bin Sa'sa'ah Al-Dabab with Kasra on Dad), who is Rabi'ah bin Dhihn from Ras from Banu Al-Harith.
Among them is Sharik bin Al-A'war, who is Al-Harith bin Abd Yaghuth bin Khala'ah bin Salamah bin Wahb, and his brother Abdullah bin Al-A'war (who is Al-Harith bin Abd Yaghuth). They were noble leaders.
Among them is Al-Ma'mun, who is Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Qais bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah Al-Mathal.
Among them is Tufayl Al-Lahlah from Zaid bin Abd Yaghuth bin Salah, who gouged the eye of Amir bin Al-Tufayl on the Day of Fayf al-Rih.
Among them is Abd Yaghuth bin Al-Harith bin Waqqas bin Salah, killed before the Conquest on the Day of Al-Kulab.
Among them is Al-Awwah Abdullah bin Zaid bin Harrah bin Ha'an bin Al-Shaytan bin Abi Rabi'ah (who is Al-Harith bin Al-Ma'qil).
Among them is Dhu al-Ghussah Al-Husayn bin Yazid bin Shaddad bin Qabab bin Salamah bin Wahb bin Abdullah bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b, head of Banu Al-Harith for a hundred years. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him). About him Abdullah bin Al-Hajjaj says:
"Even if you are the Sheikh who choked on pebbles...
I am the stallion, O Kathir, who satirized you."
Addressing Kathir bin Shihab bin Al-Husayn Dhu al-Ghussah. He was named Dhu al-Ghussah because he had a choking (Ghussah) in his throat and could not speak clearly because of it.
From the descendants of Dhu al-Ghussah are Qais, Amr, Yazid, and Al-Harith.
Among them is Shihab bin Aban bin Al-Shaytan bin Qabban bin Salamah, and he was the fortress of them both.

(Section)
From Banu Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b are Salah, Rizam, Talim, and Mu'adiyah.
121 - Banu Al-Harith bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Ulah.
Among them is Al-Muhajjal, who is Mu'awiyah bin Harb bin Fawalah bin Ma'lumah bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Amr bin Ulah. He had whiteness so he was named Al-Muhajjal. His son is Yazid.

He and Yazid bin Abd Al-Madan came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) as a delegation.
From Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith are Malik and Ka'b. From Banu Al-Harith, these two, is Asma' bin Salamah, who is Al-Dabab bin Al-Harith bin Rabi'ah. From Al-Dabab is Shurayh bin Hani bin Yazid bin Nahik bin Durayd bin Sufyan bin Al-Dabab.
From the descendants of Ka'b bin Rabi'ah is Aslam bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah.
From the descendants of Malik bin Rabi'ah are Al-Harith, Ka'b, Rabi'ah, Amr, Wahb, Qatan, and Al-Hayjan. From them are Zuhayr, Qatan, Jafnah, Amr, Durayd, and Hamanah, sons of Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Ka'b. They were archers who encompass, and they are Bani Maris Al-A'rad.

(Section)
As for Masliyah bin Amir bin Amr bin Ulah bin Jald bin Madhhij, they are a clan with Banu Al-Harith. Masliyah begot Kinanah and Asad. Their mother is Kaysah bint Awn bin Nakha'.
From Banu Kinanah bin Masliyah are Al-Abyad bin Kinanah bin Masliyah and Subh, a house of numbers. From them is Ibn Mu'awiyah bin Subh, about whom Amr Al-Zubaydi says: "My father, the ostrich of the desert [desolate land], owner of the white [horse?], wished to kill me." He was a horseman, and his brother Tufah was a poet.
Among them is Shurayh bin Yaghuth bin Al-Harith bin Subayh; he witnessed Al-Jamal and Siffin with Ali and was a poet.
Among them is Shurah Al-Ad, Amir bin Isma'il bin Amir bin Nafi' bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Hudhayfah bin Awf bin Subayh, the commander who killed Marwan bin Muhammad bin Marwan, the last of the Banu Umayyah kings.
Among them is the poet Al-Harith bin Tha'labah bin Fashirah bin Al-Abyad bin Kinanah bin Masliyah, who is called Ibn Jananah, and he is Jahili. He and Subayh, their mother is Jananah bint Al-A'mar bin Maslamah.
As for Asad bin Masliyah, he begot Rabi'ah, Umaymah, and Zabyan, and they are in Yemen.

(Section)
As for Al-Nakha', who is Jasr (with Fatha on Jim) bin Amr bin Ulah bin Madhhij. He was named Al-Nakha' because he distanced himself (Intakha'a) from his people. He begot Malik and Awf. Malik begot Sa'd and Amr.
From the descendants of Sa'd are Qais, Suhbar, Amir, and Abdullah (their mother is Rabtah Qabil bin Najiyah bin Al-Humam bin Al-Ash'ar), and Hasan, Judhaymah, and Harithah (their mother is bint Darim bin Malik bin Tamim). Hasan and Zann are in Kufa, they have a mosque there.
From the descendants of Qais bin Malik bin Al-Nakha' is Tamad bin Al-Harith bin Awf bin Jusham bin Ka'b bin Qais. He is the first leader in Al-Nakha'. From his descendants are Hayda' bin Sinan bin Ada' and Arin bin Mu'awiyah bin Hayd bin Hayd bin Hilal bin Abd Yaghuth bin Amr bin Ada'.
From the descendants of Dhuhl bin Ka'b bin Qais from Sa'd bin Malik bin Nakha' is the poet Al-Nakha'i, who is Malik bin Al-Harith bin Abd Yaghuth from Ada'.
From the descendants of Dhuhl bin Ka'b is Maslamah bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Khudhaymah bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Al-Nakha'. He witnessed Al-Qadisiyah, and witnessed Al-Jamal and Siffin with Ali. He had a great trial on the Day of Siffin.
Among them is Abdullah bin Al-Ash'ath bin Amr bin Ka'b bin Awf bin Awf bin Abdullah bin Amir bin Hasan bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Al-Nakha'; he was a noble.
Among them is Al-Hajjaj bin Artah bin Nur bin Hubayrah bin Shurahbil the Jurist bin Salaman bin Amir bin Haribah bin Malik bin Al-Nakha'.
He said: Habil bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Al-Nakha' begot Munabbih, Dhuhl, Jusham, Sulayman, Malik, Salamat, Mu'awiyah, and Ghalib.
Among them is the Judge Sharik bin Abdullah bin Sharik, who is Al-Harith bin Aws bin Al-Harith bin Wahl bin Habil.
Among them is Sinan bin Anas bin Amr bin Hayy bin Harith, who killed Al-Husayn bin Ali.
From Banu Suhyan bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Suhyan bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Al-Nakha' is one who was a companion of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him) and Al-Hajjaj killed him.
He said: Awf bin Al-Nakha' begot Jusham and Al-Haynamah. From them is Yazid bin Al-Kafkaf, who is Qais bin Yazid bin Abdullah bin Qais bin Abdullah bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Shaytan bin Jusham bin Awf bin Al-Nakha'. He was a companion of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him); he prayed over him and said Takbir four times.
Among them is Al-Mustawzir bin Jahfal bin Awf from Al-Nakha'; he was a noble master.
Among them is Hilal bin Jusham bin Awf bin Al-Nakha'.
He said: Al-Bahnuh bin Awf begot Al-A'azz, Abd al-Uzza, and Dhuhr. From them is Al-Hasan bin Abdullah bin Urwah the Jurist.

(Section)
As for Harith in [bin] Ulah, he begot Munabbih and Yazid, who is Sada'.
From the descendants of Munabbih are Zaha' and Abdullah. Zaha' is bint Madhhij. From them is Di'bil, a clan in Banu Al-Harith. In the proverb: "Di'bil is not spoken to." He was noble.
Zaha' begot Sulaym. Sulaym begot Yuhan, Jusham, Sa'b, Judhaymah, and Awf.
Abdullah bin Munabbih begot Sahm, Amr, Rahib, and Sakhr. Among them is the clan of Malik bin Murarah Al-Rahawi; the Prophet (peace be upon him) sent him with Mu'adh.
As for Yazid, who is Sada', he begot Munabbih, Al-Harith, Al-Ay, Haffan, Shahran, and Sinhan. These six are called Janb; they sided (Janabu) with Sada' and allied with Sa'd Al-Ashirah, and Sada' allied with Banu Al-Harith bin Ka'b.

From Janb are these: Mu'awiyah bin Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Shadid bin Sada' bin Harith bin Ulah in some sayings, and there is difference in it. He is the one who married the daughter of Muhalhil bin Rabi'ah Al-Taghlibi. About him Muhalhil says:
"I married her for her loss to Al-Araqim in...
Janb, and the dowry was from skin.
If two doors sought her hand...
A nose bridge would sweat blood from the suitor."
In Mu'awiyah is the House and Kingship. Among them is the Jurist Abu Zabyan Husayn Harith bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Wahsh bin Malik bin Rabi'ah bin Munyah bin Yazid bin Sada' Al-Harith Harb bin Ulah bin Khald bin Madhhij.
In the descendants of Khald bin Madhhij from the tribes are Banu Al-Harith, Banu Masliyah, Al-Nakha', Ruha', Sada', Sa'd Al-Ashirah, Murad, and Ans.
It is said that Taffas begot Madhhij in one narration a great head, and that Madhhij begot Malik. And Jalahah (who is Tayy) sons of Udad bin Zaid bin Amr bin Udas bin Zaid bin Kahlan.

**Lineage of Sa'd Al-Ashirah**
Ibn Madhhij. He was named Sa'd Al-Ashirah (The Clan) because he did not die until three hundred men of his children and grandchildren rode with him. He said: From the descendants of Sa'd Al-Ashirah are Hakam, Sa'b, Janb, Ju'fi, Harit, Aws Allah, Zaid Allah, Wahb Allah, Man Allah, Abdullah, Sa'd Allah, Anas Allah, Nisab, Wisab, Ans, Khans, Hasan, and Urrah. It is said Namirah in Qarar. It is said Namirah bin Masah bin Harad. From Namirah are Al-Hada' and Sulaym, two clans entered into Farada.
As for Anas Allah, Zaid Allah, A'id Allah, and Harith, they are clans that entered into Ju'fi.
From Abdullah bin Al-Hakam is Abdullah bin Kinanah bin Abdullah bin Al-Hakam. His mother is the Jewess daughter of Yanbu' bin Al-Hun bin Khuzaymah. Some genealogists erred and attributed Al-Hakam to Khuzaymah his son [sic - likely father/ancestor confusion]. Some said:
"Abu Hakam bin Al-Hawn unless you claim Madhhij...
And leave a sheikh from Khuzaymah bright."
The correct is that his name is Ibn Sa'd Al-Ashirah, and he used a kunya.
[He] begot Ism, Jusham, Silham, and Sahm. And Aslam.
Sahm bin Al-Hakam begot Mazzah, and the name of Mazzah is Sufyan. From Mazzah are Harith, Uhays, Abdullah, Qadah, Marwah, Hadaqah, Bunduqah, and Huddah.
As for Harith, it is with Damma on Ha and Fatha on Ra. Likewise in Quda'ah. What remains in Arabs is Harith with Fatha on Ha and Sukun on Ra.
Harith begot Tamnam, Ulal, Jadilah, Kabir, and Duwwah.
From the descendants of Duwwah is the Emir, master of Khorasan, Al-Jarrah bin Abdullah bin Ju'adah bin Aflah bin Ziyadah bin Ism bin Duwwah bin Harith bin Mazzah from Sahm bin Al-Hakam.
From the descendants of Ghanam bin Harith are the people of Sabya. Khalid bin Abd al-Wahid bin Khalid from Sulayman bin Jalil bin Abd Al-Jadd. It is said Duwwah bin Ghanam bin Harith, and it is said Duwwah bin Juzhum. And the people of Al-Fawi Bamdallah [sic] bin Al-Ghitrif the Elder bin Jalil bin Abd Al-Jadd.
The people of Al-Akhsab are Banu Wahb and Banu Mukatim bin Abdullah. The sons of Sawasah are Al-Asba and Atiyah sons of Ubayd bin Abd Al-Jadd. Atiyah bin Sulayman bin Atiyah bin Ubayd bin Abd Al-Jadd. And Abdullah bin Atiyah bin Muhammad bin Atiyah bin Abdullah bin Abd Al-A'la bin Abd al-Rahman bin Abd Al-Jadd. These are gathered by Abd Al-Jadd bin Rabi'ah bin Hajri bin Abdullah bin Al-Mutbayyid bin Awf bin Habib bin Ghanam bin Harith bin Silham bin Al-Hakam.
Among them are the people of Al-Amad bin Qahtabah bin Rahm Rabi'ah Rawhah bin Rabi'ah and Wahb bin Sa'id bin Rabi'ah bin Hajri to the end of the lineage.
From the children of Abdullah bin Al-Mutbayyid are Awf, Al-Harith, Wahan, Murad, Sa'd, Al-Ghawwas, and Atr.
From the children of Ghanam bin Harith are Ka'b, Fin, Jadilah, Amir, Kasimah, and Masak bin Habib.
From the children of Harb bin Silham are Ka'b and Abdullah. Ka'b bin Harb begot Amr bin Taliq bin Ka'b. Abdullah bin Harb [begot] Ma'niyan, Ulal, Al-Ism, Wast, and Mar'ah.
As for Abdullah bin Silham bin Abd Al-Hakam, he begot Hirr, Tamr, Zaid, Sawma'ah, and Baqil.
As for Qadah bin Mazzah, he begot Shurahbil bin Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Al-Khamkham bin Qadah. Among them are Abd Al-Qayl and Uwaymir sons of Abdullah bin Al-Khamkham bin Qadah. Among them are Sa'id, Abahum, and Kathir, sons of 'Aqaqah. The brother of 'Aqaqah is 'Arij and Al-Khattab, sons of Amir bin Qadah.
From the descendants of Al-Khamkham is Marwan bin Awf bin Al-Khamkham. Among them are Attab and Nafi' sons of Shurahbil bin Ka'b bin Ans bin Al-Khamkham. Among them are Jabalah, Araki, and their sisters, children of Yahya bin Al-Khamkham.
As for Hadaqah bin Fazzah [Mazzah], from his descendants is Umayr bin Basbas bin Bashir bin Uwaymir bin Al-Harith bin Uwaymir Kabir bin Al-Sabl bin Hadaqah. About him the poet says:
"Straighten their chests for her, O Basbas...
There is no Abbas in the desert of Umayr."

From the descendants of Umayr is Abdullah bin Sa'd bin Jabir bin Umay' [?]. He had Abdah daughter of Bint Afaf sister of Uthman; she bore him children in Medina.
As for Jusham bin Al-Hakam, his children are Amir, Ghalib, Talib, Bajilah, Bakr, Al-Harith, and Ju'thman. Among them is Abs bin Amir bin Jusham bin Al-Hakam.
Al-Sharqi said regarding the meaning of children saying "Hada Hada" and that is Bunduqah: That Al-Hada raided Bunduqah and took from it, then Bunduqah raided it and avenged itself.
The clans of Hakam are: Qadah, Hadaqah, Bunduqah, Mazzah, Hays, Abs, Namir, Sawma'ah, and Banu Abd Al-Jadd.

**Lineage of Zubid bin Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah**
He said: Zubid, Udad, and their sister Bajilah are children of Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah. The name of Zubid is Munabbih. He was named Zubid because Munabbih the Younger said: "Who adds (Yazidu) a support?" His uncles, all sons of Munabbih the Elder, answered him, so they were all called Zubid.
Zubid the Younger begot Mu'awiyah, Amr, Rabi'ah, Al-Ahnaf, Kulayb, Al-Harith, Abdullah, and Ka'b. These are Banu Zubid the Younger, who is from Munabbih bin Salamah bin Mazin bin Rabi'ah bin Zaid the Elder, who is Munabbih bin Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah.
Mazin is a tribe in Zubid, and Banu Mazin is well-known. There are also tribes of Mazin, mentioned previously in the lineage of Tamim.
Zubid the Elder begot Rabi'ah, Amr, and Al-Harith.
Among them is the knight, the knight of the Arabs, the brave one, youth of Jahiliyyah and elder of Islam, Amr bin Ma'di Karib bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Asm bin Zubid. He was a knight who mobilized with Amr bin Ma'di Karib.
Among them is Mahmiyah bin Jaz' bin Abd Yaghuth bin Uwayj bin Amr bin Zubid the Younger. He was over the spoils, and he was an ally of Banu Sahm. His daughter was married to Al-Fadl bin Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib, and she bore him Umm Kulthum.
Among them is Amir Al-Asqa', who is the poet, bin Hind bin Al-Harith bin Rabi'ah bin Imru' al-Qais bin Amr bin Zubid.

**Lineage of Awd bin Sa'b bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah**
He said: The children of Awd are Munabbih and Ka'b.
Munabbih begot Awf and Sa'd. Sa'd begot Malik, Abid, Hurab, Badal, Awf (who is Al-Awfah and is Imama), and Abd.
Among them is the poet Al-Afwah Al-Awdi Sala'ah bin Amr bin Awf bin Al-Harith bin Munabbih bin Awd.
Among them is Abdullah bin Al-Nu'man bin Qais bin Salamah bin Al-Afkal, who is Awf bin Al-Harith bin Awf bin Munabbih bin Awd; he was a noble.
Among them is the poet Abu Al-Miqdad bin Al-Harith bin Awf bin Al-Harith bin Abdullah bin Ka'b bin Munabbih bin Awd.
Among them is the Jurist Abd al-Rahman bin Idris bin Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Aswad bin Hajbah Al-Ashab bin Yazid bin Halawah bin Amir (who is Al-Za'afir) bin Sa'd bin Munabbih bin Awd.
Al-Mundhir said: There is no mosque in Kufa whose Qibla is more correct than the mosque of Banu Awd, because Abdullah bin Mas'ud established their mosque.
He said: From Banu Ka'b bin Awd are Malik (who is Al-Ward), Salamah, Wahb, Jadiyah, and Rummman.
Among them is Humayd bin Salamah bin Abdullah bin Ka'b bin Mu'awiyah bin Qarn bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Awd.
Among them is Harsah bin Murr bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Hary bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Tha'labah bin Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Awd.
Among them is Shabib bin Abdullah bin Shakal bin Murr bin Khadiah bin Ka'b bin Awd.
Among them is the Judge Numafiyah [?] bin Sawad bin Thumamah bin Salamah bin Ramad bin Ka'b bin Awd.

**Lineage of Ju'fi bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah**
Al-Kala'i said: He is Ka'far [Ja'far?] the Poet bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah.
He said: Ja'far begot Marran and Harim, who are Al-Arqaman. Their mother is Hind bint Layth bin Bakr bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah.
Marran bin Ja'far begot Dhuhl, Wa'il, and Jusham.
Among them is Asma' bin Wahr bin Al-Khadash bin Marran bin Ja'far. He was a leader in Jahiliyyah. His father Dahr also led, and Amr bin Dahr led. About him the poet says:
"Your evil if you meet what you wish...
Like what Al-Mann met from Amr bin Dahr."
From the descendants of Amr bin Dahr are Sa'd and Salamah. Sa'd begot Al-Harith and Bada'.
Among them is Shurahbil bin Al-Shaytan (who is Al-Ashab) bin Al-Harith bin Al-Ashab bin Awf bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Dahr. He is the leader of Banu Ja'far, killed by Banu Ja'dah. About him Al-Nabighah Al-Ja'di says:
"We relieved Ma'ad from Shurahbil after...
He showed them in it the morning stars cleansed."
He was frequent in raiding.
Among them is Alqamah Al-Harrath bin Malik bin Hajar bin Al-Harith bin Al-Ashab. He led after Shurahbil, raided Banu Amir and they killed him. It was said regarding that:
"And Alqamah Al-Harrath met a disaster... silent."
Among them is Al-Habis bin Al-Ahwas bin Rabi'ah bin Salaman bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Dahr. He was a horseman. About him the Amirite woman said:
"Would that all my people were Hubaysah."

He witnessed Al-Qadisiyah.
Among them is Rabab bin Mas'ud bin Miqdad bin Ji'al bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Dahr; he was a noble.
From the descendants of Bada' bin Sa'd bin Amr is Al-Jarrah bin Husayn bin Al-Harith Qais bin Malik bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Subjan bin Bada'. Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr appointed him over Wadi Al-Qura, and there are many poets there, so he banned them. Bin Ju'fi.
From the descendants of Wa'il bin Marwan bin Ju'fi is Ja'an bin Jalilah bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Qabil bin Marwan bin Ju'fi. He has a remnant in Yemen. Among them is Hajar from Jalilah bin Ka'b.

(Section) As for Harim bin Ju'fi, he begot Awf, Malik, and Dhuhl.
Awf begot Sa'd and Ka'b. Sa'd begot Ka'b and Awf. Ka'b begot Malik, Hanzalah, Harb, and Nahwiyah.
From the descendants of Malik bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Harim bin Ju'fi is Al-Mukhtar bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Tha'labah bin Munyah bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Harim bin Ju'fi.
Among them are Zuhr bin Al-Ajam and Murid sons of Qais bin Shaja'ah bin Al-Mujammi' bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Sa'd. He witnessed Al-Qadisiyah. And Abdullah bin Al-Hasan bin Amr bin Khalid bin Al-Mujammi' Al-Fatik the Poet. And Banu Sadaqah, Lawmah, and Al-Ash'ar witnessed Dayr al-Jamajim with Ibn al-Ash'ath and fought on that day.
From the descendants of Mu'awiyah bin Ka'b bin Jara bin Jabir bin Awf bin Mu'awiyah bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Harim. Among them is Al-Ash'ar Murrah and the little poet (Shuway'ir) Muhammad sons of Abu Hamran (who is Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Awf bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Harim).
Among them is the Jurist Suwayd bin Ghaflah bin Awsajah bin Amir bin Wada' bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Awf bin Sa'd. He reached the time of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and came to him but found he had died. He accompanied Abu Bakr and came to him, so he started hitting him with the pearl (whip) saying: "You ate my dates and disobeyed my command."
Among them is Zajr bin Qais bin Malik bin Mu'awiyah bin Sa'd. He was one of the horsemen and witnessed Siffin with Ali, and Ali appointed him over Al-Mada'in. His four sons were nobles.
