From the descendants of Salamah bin Amr bin Dahr bin Al-Tuwayb and Amr Al-Mu'tarid. Among them is Abu Shaybah Zaid bin Malik bin Abdullah bin Al-Duwayb bin Salamah bin Amr bin Dahr. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) with two sons, Safah and Abd al-Rahman. He had two thousand five hundred in stipend. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) granted him Wadi Ju'fi in Yemen, and the name of the valley is Jardan. Al-Hajjaj appointed Abd al-Rahman over Isfahan. His son Khaythamah bin Abd al-Rahman the Jurist, and Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman held the Opinion (Ra'y).
From the descendants of Dhuhl bin Ju'fi is Qais bin Maslamah bin Shurahbil bin Al-Shaytan bin Al-Harith bin Al-Ashab (who is Fud) bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Al-Harith bin Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Dhuhl bin Marwan [or Harim?]. And Umar and Ali. He witnessed Siffin with Ali - may Allah be pleased with him.
From the descendants of Zuhl bin Khuzaym is Tarfah bin Abd bin Qalit bin Khawli bin Rabi'ah bin Awf bin Mu'awiyah bin Zuhl bin Khuzaym. He is the one who lived long.
The clans of Ju'fi are Al-Hada', Dahr, Khuzaym, and Farat.

**Lineage of Zaid Allah, Anas Allah, Aws Allah, A'idh Allah, and Harith sons of Sa'd Al-Ashirah**
As for Zaid Allah, he begot Amir, Ashras, Al-Du'il, and Awf. Ashras, Al-Du'il, and Awf entered into Banu Taghlib and attributed themselves to Zaid bin Amr bin Ghanam bin Taghlib. Amir remained on his lineage, and from him branched the descendants of Zaid bin Amr bin Ghanam bin Taghlib and the descendants of Zaid [Allah]. Their count is in Ju'fi.
As for Aws Allah, he begot Aslam, and they are a tribe in Yemen.
As for Anas Allah, he begot Dahr, Malawith, Ali, and Bilal. They are clans. Among them is Abdullah bin Diyan bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Rabi'ah bin Bilal bin Anas Allah. He witnessed Siffin with Ali - may Allah be pleased with him. From his descendants is Abd al-Aziz bin Thabit bin Abdullah bin Hassan - they are in Rayy, numerous and brave.
As for A'idh Allah, he begot Manat and Aws Manat (who is Mahan). Their mother is the daughter of Layth bin Bakr bin Abd Manat bin Kinanah. Abd Manat begot Aws, Iyas, Awf, Ghanam, and Asad.
He begot Awf, Khadij, Sulaym, Sa'd, Tha'lab, Salamah, and Abdullah.

From the descendants of Asad bin Abd Manat bin A'idh Allah is Malik bin Masruq bin Asad bin Abd Manat bin A'idh Allah, head of the delegation that came to the Prophet (peace be upon him). Through him came the relationship of Madhhij to the Prophet (peace be upon him).
Among them is Mujammi' bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Halah Al-Madhhiji. And Hamad bin Iyas bin Abd A'idh Allah was killed with Al-Husayn bin Ali - may Allah be pleased with him - (O Kind One). His son Abdullah was killed with Al-Mukhtar.
Among them is Urwah bin Halawah, who was one of Ali's companions - may Allah be pleased with him - and witnessed his battles.
And Amr bin Abdullah bin Amr governed Kufa while it was divided into four quarters. Abdullah bin Amr bin Abd al-Aziz appointed him when he governed Kufa.
From the descendants of Iyas bin Abd Manat is Abu Umayr Urwah bin Jabir bin Badiyah bin Al-Du'il bin Iyas bin Abd Manat.
As for Fa'id bin Abdullah bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah, he begot Dhuhl, Malik, Abdullah, Amr, and Mu'awiyah. From Banu Mu'awiyah is Ubaydah bin Wahban who came with the Prophet [?] - and Abdullah bin Kinanah was one of the horsemen of the Arabs in Madhhij.
As for Harith bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah, he begot Amr and Al-Adl. Al-Adl was over the market police. If he got angry at a man and wanted him killed, he would push him to him [the executioner?], so people said: "Placed in the hands of Adl."

**Lineage of Yuhabir, who is Murad**
He said: Murad begot Najiyah and Zahir.
Najiyah begot Abdullah, Mufarrij, Kinanah, Malik, Shukr, Namirah, and Daman.
It is said that Radman is from Himyar.
Atif bin Abdullah bin Najiyah bin Murad is said to be from Azd. In Murad there are people from Azd and others who attributed themselves to Murad.
They were named Murad because they rebelled (Tamarradu).
From the descendants of Najiyah bin Murad is the poet Farwah bin Musayk bin Al-Harith bin Salamah bin Al-Harith bin Al-Dhu'ub bin Malik bin Munyah bin Atif bin Abdullah bin Najiyah bin Murad. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he appointed him over Najran. Umar bin Al-Khattab - may Allah be pleased with him - appointed him.
Among them is Sharik bin Uthman bin Abd Yaghuth bin Asr bin Malik bin Awf bin Munyah bin Atif. He led in Jahiliyyah.
Among them is the poet Amr bin Waqqas bin Abd Yaghuth bin Makhdash, who led.
From the descendants of Hani bin Urwah bin Ghran bin Amr bin Waqqas. And Hani and Sharik sons of Utbah bin Abdullah.
Among them is Amr bin Nimran.
Among them is Ma'dan Al-Mutawwaj bin Nimran bin Khalifah bin Mu'awiyah bin Makhdash, who used to raid Hadramaut and take their food.
Among them is Al-Harith (who is Al-Mutasallim) bin Qais bin Salamah bin Nada bin Munyah bin Atif. He was a noble. Banu Al-Harith killed him on the Day of Al-Razm, the day Al-Husayn Dhu al-Fiddah was killed.
From the descendants of Ruman bin Najiyah is Uways bin Amr bin Qarn bin Malik bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Aswad bin Ruman bin Najiyah bin Murad, about whom the Prophet said: "Through his intercession, the like of Rabi'ah and Mudar will enter Paradise." He was an ascetic and good man among the Successors, may Allah have mercy on him.
Among them is Abd al-Rahman, the killer of Ali bin Abi Talib.
From Banu Malik bin Najiyah are Al-Haysam, Abdullah, and Rabi'ah.
Among them is Salman bin Yashkur bin Najiyah, a clan, the clan of Ubaydah Al-Salmani. Ubaydah Al-Salmani said: I accepted Islam two years before the death of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and prayed, but I did not meet the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) until he died, and I came after him to his Companions. He is Ubaydah bin Amr bin Abdullah bin Amir bin Malik bin Munyah bin Malik bin Abdullah bin Salman bin Yashkur bin Najiyah.
From Banu Salman is Jinad bin Al-Harith, killed with Al-Husayn bin Ali. And Banu Ru'yah (who is Al-Harith bin Abdullah) was a noble. It is said that Salman is from Azd.
From the descendants of Najiyah bin Murad are Al-Qarh (Kararah, a clan) and Amir (Qali'ah, a clan). They are the Mus'aban. It is said they are from Azd.
As for Namirah bin Najiyah, it was said he is son of Sa'd Al-Ashirah and attributed to Murad. He had children Al-Hadd and Sulaym, two clans.
As for Kinanah bin Najiyah, he begot Jamal, Rabi'ah, Ka'b, Janb, Tha'labah, and Malik.
From them are Al-Harith, Bahar, and Malik sons of Amir bin Sa'd bin Murrah bin Jamal bin Kinanah bin Najiyah. They are called Al-Ma'aqil.
Among them is Amr bin Abdullah bin Al-Bahar, who is Al-Ajda', mutilated at Nahavand. His brother Shurahbil was wealthy.
Among them is Amr bin Murrah bin Jamal, Sheikh of Al-A'mash.
Among them is Hind bin Amr bin Khalid bin Ka'b bin Rabi'ah bin Jamal bin Kinanah bin Najiyah bin Murad. He was killed on the Day of the Camel with Ali - may Allah be pleased with him. Abdullah bin Yathrabi Al-Dabbi killed him. He is the one who said to Aliya and Zaid bin Sawhan:
"Who will convey the secret to me...
I killed Ali and Hind Al-Jamal."
As for Al-Sawhan, he was on the religion of Ali.

(Section) As for Zahir bin Murad

He begot Awsan. Awsan begot Amr and Amir. Amir begot Salamah, Zahir, Bada, Samurah, Ad, Wudd, Qais, Malik, and Jadal.
Among them is Qais bin Hubayrah bin Al-Makshuh bin Abd Yaghuth bin Al-Ghazil bin Salamah bin Bada bin Amir bin Awsan bin Zahir bin Murad. Qais bin Hubayrah was the knight of Madhhij and the killer of Al-Aswad Al-Ansi the Liar - who claimed prophethood in Sana'a. Hubayrah was the master of Murad. Hubayrah was called Al-Makshuh because he branded his flank (Kashh). He is the nephew of Amr bin Amir bin Ali bin Aslam bin Ahmas bin Al-Gharth bin Anmar bin Nuhaylah, and he is counted in Murad.
From the descendants of Zahir bin Amir bin Awbathan bin Zahir bin Murad are Al-Rabad, Wahb, Namad, A'la, Al-Amm, Badul, and Salyan. They are tribes. It is said they are from Tayy from Banu Amr bin Al-Gharth.
Mudar used to call Dawma 'Ghadr'. Al-Sayyid said: "Not Ghadr, but the Habti of Mudar." Among them is Safwan bin Ghassan bin Al-Rabad.
He said: Counted in Murad is (Tajub), a man from Himyar who shed blood among his people and fled to Murad saying: "I came to you traversing (Ajubu) the lands," so they named him Tajub. They are the clan of Abd al-Rahman bin Muljam, may Allah curse him, killer of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. In Murad are the clans: Khamkham, Ghatif, Salman, Qarn, and Tajub.

**Lineage of Ans**
His name is Zaid bin Madhhij.
He said: Ans begot Sa'd the Elder, Sa'd the Younger, Shihab, Malik, Amr, Amir, Mu'awiyah, Atik, Aziz, Yam, Jusham, and Al-Qaryah.
It is said: Al-Qaryah is from Al-Namir bin Qasit. From them is Al-Aswad Al-Ansi the Liar who claimed prophethood in Yemen. He is Al-Aswad bin Ayhalah bin Radman bin Najiyah bin Murad.
Zahir, A'la, and Al-Amm bin Ka'b (who is Al-Humar) bin Awf bin Sa'b bin Malik bin Ans.
Among them are Banu Al-Dakhm bin Gharib bin Ans.
Among them is Al-Aswad bin Ka'b bin Awf bin Sa'd bin Sa'b bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Abdullah bin Sa'd bin Ans.
Among them are Ammar, Al-Harith, and Abdullah, sons of Yasir bin Amir bin Malik bin Kinanah bin Qais bin Al-Husayn bin Lud bin Tha'labah bin Awf bin Harithah bin Amir the Elder bin Abs.
Ammar witnessed all battles with the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Yasir came from Yemen to Mecca and allied with Abu Hudhayfah bin Al-Mughira Al-Makhzumi. Abu Hudhayfah married him to his slave girl named Sumayyah, and she bore Ammar. Abu Hudhayfah freed him. He was with Ali on the Day of Siffin. Ammar, his father Yasir, his mother Sumayyah, and his brother Abdullah accepted Islam. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed by them while they were being tortured and said: "Patience, family of Yasir, for your appointment is Paradise."
Sumayyah, mother of Ammar, and her husband Yasir were the first two martyrs, and they were martyred in Islam. Abu Jahl came to her with an iron spear and struck her, and she died.
In Ans are the clans: Fahd, Yam, Banu Sa'b, and Banu Al-Qaryah.
These are the descendants of Madhhij Malik bin Udad.
They are the descendants of Ulah bin Khald: The Harithis, Banu Masliyah, Al-Nakha', Ruha', Sada', Sa'd Al-Ashirah, Murad, and Ans.
It was said that Taffas begot Madhhij in one narration [as] a great head. And that Madhhij begot Malik. And Jalahah (who is Tayy) sons of Udad bin Zaid bin Amr bin Udas bin Zaid bin Kahlan.

**Lineage of Tayy**
He is Jalhamah bin Udad. He was named Tayy because he was the first to plaster (Tawa) the water wells.
He said: Tayy begot Fatra, Al-Gharth, and Al-Harith. The numbers of his descendants are in two clans: Jadilah and Al-Gharth.
As for Jadilah, she is Jadilah bint Subay' from Himyar. Her children were attributed to her. She is the mother of Haydab and Jawr, sons of Kharijah bin Sa'd bin Fatra bin Tayy. Banu Jawr are Sahlis living in the plains, and Banu Jundab [Haydab?] live in the two mountains, Aja and Salma, which are the mountains of Tayy. It is said they are among the most beautiful lands of Allah Almighty.
From them are the Tha'alibah of Tayy. They are three, each one the uncle of the other. The first is Tha'labah bin Duman bin Jundab bin Kharijah bin Sa'd bin Fatra bin Tayy. The second is Tha'labah bin Dhuhl bin Ruman. The third is Tha'labah bin Jad'a' bin Dhuhl bin Ruman.
From the descendants of Tha'labah bin Jad'a' are Taym, Ulwah, Khaybari, Ka'b, and Atik.
From Banu Taym is Al-Mu'alla bin Taym, whom Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr stayed with and said about him:
"As if when I alighted at Al-Mu'alla's...
I alighted on the towers of Shamam."
From the descendants of Al-Mu'alla is Shabib bin Amr bin Kurayb bin Al-Mu'alla; he was a poet and horseman.
Among them is Al-Harith bin Al-Nu'man bin Qais bin Taym; he had great merit in Islam during the days of Apostasy, and was the leader of Jadilah on the day of Musaylimah the Liar. Banu Taym are those about whom Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr says:
"Did Banu Taym release the intestines of Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr... lamps of the darkness."

From Banu Khaybari is Shihab bin Harithah bin Zarif bin Khaybari bin Tha'labah; he led.
From Banu Akwah bin Tha'labah is Hamil bin Tha'labah bin Rabi' bin Amr bin Malik bin Akwah bin Tha'labah; he was a noble leader.
From Banu Jad'an bin Dhuhl is Malik bin Akwah.
From the descendants of Malik are Tarif and Ammah. From the descendants of Uwanah bin Shabib bin Al-Fari' bin Masja'ah bin Rafi' bin Shamas bin Harithah bin Hilf bin Malik bin Jad'an. This Uwanah is Abu Al-Shaqra', husband of Abd al-Malik bin Marwan.
Among them is Al-Burj bin Mushir the Poet bin Al-Hulas bin Wahb bin Qais bin Tarif bin Malik bin Jad'a'.

(Section)
From the descendants of Thumamah bin Malik bin Jad'a' are Amr, Al-Harith, and Malik. From the descendants of Amr bin Thumamah are Tarif, Malik, Umayrah, Ma'n, Ahmad, Rahm, Zaid, Rabi', Ka'b, Samim, Kabir, Al-Harith, and Sahar.
They are called Banu Adasah, and mostly known by her. Adasah is daughter of Husayf bin Al-Hawfaz bin Al-Gharth.
Among them is the Governor Abu Al-Mahdi Al-Hajjaj bin Al-Ha [?] bin Abdullah bin Shams bin Amr bin Thumamah.
Among them is Ahmar Tayy, who is Ziyad bin Zaid bin Al-Kasam bin Zaid bin Wahb bin Amr bin Tarif bin Amr bin Thumamah. He was a companion of Abdullah bin Al-Hurr and was a horseman.
Among them is Aws bin Harithah bin Lam bin Amr bin Tarif bin Amr bin Thumamah. Aws led for two hundred years, and is one of the long-lived. His brother Aws Sa'id Al-Abras also led.
Qais, Unayf, Kubayri, and Masruq are sons of Harithah bin Lam.
In Lam is the House and the Number. From the descendants of Lam are Tha'labah, Al-Nu'man, Ubaydullah, Abdullah, and Shihab.
Among them is Jahm bin Ward bin Manzurah bin Yasar bin Fatnah bin Shihab bin Lam, companion of Al-Hazzazah in the days of Shabib bin Amr.
Among them is Jundab bin Ammar bin Shihab bin Lam, martyr of Al-Qadisiyah and a poet.
From the descendants of Aws bin Harithah bin Lam is Khuzaym bin Aws; he had two thousand five hundred in stipend assigned to him by Umar, may Allah be pleased with him.
Among them is Abu Laha Bujayr bin Aws.
And Rabi' bin Muray, he was a mentioned noble. About him Abu Zaid Al-Ta'i says:
"By the life of your father, O Ibn Abi Muray...
Destruction has been decreed for other than you."
In Rabi' bin Muray is the House and the Number.
Haribah and Midras sons of Aws.
Urwah Al-Diyar bin Midras bin Aws.
Urwah bin Abaq bin Sarih bin Sa'd bin Harithah bin Lam. He was noble. He witnessed Nahrawan with Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, and was killed that day. He had said: "Tayy, no one overcomes them, nor are ten of us killed." Urwah was among those killed that day.
Among them is Uram bin Al-Mundhir bin Qais bin Harithah bin Lam. He is the one who lived long and said:
"By Allah, I do not know if I reached a nation...
In the era of Dhu al-Qarnayn or narrated boldness."
From the descendants of Malik bin Amr are Rabi', Ma'qil, Husayn, Abu Al-Kasr, and Al-A'sha. Their mother is Lamis bint Al-Adkham from Sal; they are known by her. And Sabakil, Al-Khali', and Suhal; their mother is Al-Sakariyah, they are known by her.
From the descendants of Malik bin Amr are Rabi', Ma'qil, Husayn, Qais, and Hari; their mother is from Al-Gharth... [text missing].
Among them is Al-Kurus bin Zaid bin Mu'adh bin Ma'qil bin Malik.
Among them is Haja Al-Fawaris bin Abi Musad bin Malik. These are Banu Dhuhl bin Ruman.

(Section)
From Banu Tha'labah bin Ruman bin Jundab bin Harithah bin Sa'd bin Fitrah bin Tayy are Mas'ud and Wa'il (who is Al-Ahnaf).
Among them is the poet Amr bin Tha'labah bin Mulqat bin Amr bin Tha'labah bin Awf Wa'il bin Tha'labah bin Ruman.
It is said to him Al-Asad Al-Rahis, who is Qaban bin Amr bin Umayr bin Tha'labah bin Ghiyath bin Mulqat bin Amr bin Tha'labah, killer of Antarah Al-Absi. He is the one saying:
"I killed Muhallim and his brother Amr...
And Antarah of the Horsemen I have killed.
I am the Lion, the Rahis (crusher), so best of tribe...
I am with the stars when lineage is traced."

As for Al-Gharth bin Tayy, the second clan of Tayy, he had children: Amr, Luway, Qais, Abu Sud, and Zaid.
From the descendants of Amr bin Al-Gharth are Duhni, Thuql, Tha'labah (who is Jarm), Aswaran (who is Nabhan), and Ghusayn (who is Bulan).
Among them is the poet Abu Zaid Harmalah bin Al-Mundhir bin Ma'di Karib bin Hanzalah bin Abi Dihm bin Hassan bin Jannah bin Saghbah bin Al-Harith bin Al-Huwayrith bin Rabi'ah bin Malik bin Sa'd bin Hani bin Amir bin Al-Gharth.
Among them is the King of Al-Hirah Iyas bin Qabisah bin Yaghfar bin Al-Nu'man bin Hannah. He is the one praised by Al-A'sha.
He said: Zaid bin Al-Gharth begot a woman called Hind. Thawr bin Kalb bin Wabrah married her, and she bore him Rufaydah, Arabiyah, Sahya, and Suhbiya.
Yakuna bin Al-Gharth begot Usamah, and he has no offspring.
Qais bin Al-Gharth begot Al-Mufaddal. He is the first who said 'Al-Sa'd bin Ya'mad' Tayy bin Tayy.
As for Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Gharth, he begot Salaman, Jarwal, Amr, and Qais. As for Barr and Amr, they [text unclear].
As for Salaman bin Tha'l bin Amr, from his descendants is Thawr bin Uthur bin Yahya bin Salaman bin Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Gharth.
From the descendants of Ma'n are Dadd, Luhaym, Amr, Wahb, Abu Harithah, Imru' al-Qais, and Usayyid.
From Uthur is Buhtur, a great clan. From the descendants of Buhtur are Qaws and Khalid.
From the descendants of Salaman is Tha'labah. From them is Antarah bin Al-Akhras bin Tha'labah bin Subayh bin Ma'bad bin Ubayd bin Adi bin Aflat bin Salsalah bin Ghanam bin Yaghuth bin Qa'n bin Atud.
Among them is Al-Tirammah bin Abdullah bin Khaybari bin Aflat bin Salsalah. He is the one Ali sent to Mu'awiyah bin Abi Sufyan. When he entered Damascus, he called out and prolonged it. They said: "O Bedouin, do you have news from the sky?" He said to them: "The Angel of Death is in the air, and Ali is in the rear, and he commanded me to take your souls." Then he entered upon Mu'awiyah and there was speech between them.
Among them is Muhammad bin Salih bin Alaq bin Hassan bin Al-Farah bin Di'bil bin Al-Harraj bin Shabib bin Mas'ud bin Sa'id bin Al-Salim bin Rabi' bin Ali bin Hawban bin Amr bin Khalid bin Ma'bad bin Adi bin Aghlab bin Salsalah bin Ma'n bin Amr. Salsalah was a noble and the owner of the Battle of Dhi Al-Mahasir.
Among them is the poet Adi bin Al-A'waj bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Rayyan bin Amr bin Salsalah, Jahili/Islami. About him he says:
"I left poetry and replaced it with...
The Book of Allah, which has no partner.
If the caller of the dawn stands up...
I bid farewell to wine and drinking companions."
From Banu Ma'n bin Amr bin Al-Masih bin Ka'b bin Tarif bin Abdullah, and Amr bin Ghanam bin Harithah bin Thawb bin Ma'n bin Atud. He lived one hundred and fifty years, came to the Prophet (peace be upon him), and was the best archer of the Arabs. He is the one about whom Imru' al-Qais said:
"Many an archer from Banu Tha'l has snow on his hands from his shelter."
From Banu Amr bin Al-Gharth is the poet Abu Tammam Habib Aws bin Sarwan bin Al-Harith bin Qais bin Ruman bin Yazid bin Sa'd bin Kahil bin Amr bin Ali Amr bin Al-Gharth.

(Section)
As for Buhtur bin Atud bin Salaman bin Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Gharth, he begot Badul, A'ud, Ayman, and Saq. Their mother is Al-Hurmiyah; they are known by her.
Among them is Al-Walid bin Khalid Jabir bin Zalim bin Harithah bin Ghiyath bin Hudi bin Tadul from Buhtur. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he wrote a document for him which is with them to this day.
Among them, i.e., from Banu Buhtur, is Abu Ubadah Al-Walid bin Ubayd bin Yahya bin Shamlal bin Jabir bin Sulaym bin Salamah bin Mushir bin Al-Harith bin Jusham bin Harithah bin Judi bin Tadul bin Buhtur bin Qarin bin Atin bin Salaman Jabas bin Abi Ka'b bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Sa'd bin Qarn bin Atin.
From Banu Salaman is Qais bin Shamir bin Abd Hudi bin Thummah bin Zuhayr bin Salamah bin Salaman.
Among them is Aws bin Amr bin Adi bin Wa'il bin Awn bin Tha'labah bin Salaman.
From the descendants of Jarwal bin Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Tayy are Mu'awiyah, Rabi'ah, Rukaiys, and Anik.
From Banu Mu'awiyah bin Jarwal are Sanbis and Lawdhan. Their mother is Aminah bint Abdullah bin Al-Dul bin Hanifah.

(Section)
As for Sanbis bin Mu'awiyah bin Jarwal, he begot Amr bin Adi. The children of Amr are called Banu Uqdah; she is Uqdah bint Mughir bin Bulan.
Among them is Abd bin Al-Hisl bin Labid bin Juwayr bin Amr bin Sanbis. He accompanied Ali, may Allah be pleased with him.
Among them is Dhu al-Husayn, who is Abd al-Malik bin Abdullah bin Harithah bin Armah bin Suhban bin Ghanam bin Amr bin Sanbis.
From the descendants of Adi bin Sanbis is Aban bin Adi. The children of Aban are in Banu Darim; they say Aban bin Darim.
(Section): From Banu Rabi'ah bin Jarwal...

The generous one, proverbial and honored, Hatim bin Abdullah bin Sa'd bin Al-Hashraj bin Imru' al-Qais bin Adi bin Ahzam bin Abi Ahzam (who is Harumah) bin Rabi'ah bin Jarwal bin Tha'l bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Tayy.
His children are Adi bin Hatim and Abdullah bin Hatim. Adi was nicknamed Abu Tarif. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him), who threw him a cushion and made him sit on it, while he (peace be upon him) sat on the ground. Adi said: "I was pleased with what I saw of his generosity, and I did not leave until I accepted Islam."
He witnessed Al-Qadisiyah, Mihran, Al-Ta'if, and Al-Nukhaylah, carrying the banner. He witnessed Al-Jamal, Siffin, and Al-Nahrawan with Ali - may Allah be pleased with him. His eye was gouged out on the Day of the Camel, and his other son was killed with the Kharijites. Adi died in the time of Al-Mukhtar at the age of one hundred and twenty years.
He has no offspring except through his two daughters, Saffanah and Amrah. The offspring of Hatim Al-Ta'i are only from the descendants of Abdullah, and they reside at Nahr Karbala.
From the descendants of Al-Hashraj is Milhan bin Harithah bin Sa'd bin Al-Hashraj; he was a noble. He is son of Amr bin Al-Hashraj. Milhan, La'm, and Hulays witnessed Siffin with Mu'awiyah.
Among them is Atif bin Harithah bin Al-Hashraj, brother of Adi through his mother.
Among them is Banu Atif Abu Hanbal Jariyah bin Amr bin Adi bin Ahzam. He is the one with whom Imru' al-Qais stayed and praised; he was a horseman. He is the one about whom the poet said:
"Protector of locusts, Abu Hanbal...
Protected the leg of the locust from people."
He has famous goodness, and Abu Huthayl was counted among the loyal ones. He said: It is Jariyah with Jim and Ya with two dots below. Likewise in Yarbu', Sulaym, and Al-Ansar; these four are with Jim. Whatever else remains in the Arabs is with Ha Muhmalah and Tha with three dots. Likewise Akhzam with Kha and Zay (dotted) in Tayy. And Ahzam in Habrah in Hamdan with Ha and Ra undotted. In Khath'am Ajram bin Yahish with Jim and Ra.
Among them is Qais bin Azib bin Zaid bin Adi bin Abd bin Khuzaymah bin Murr bin Ahzam.
Among them is Attad bin Zaid Al-Bakka' bin Tha'labah bin Jarwal bin Amalah, they are Al-Ajnub bin Ahzam.
He said: Al-Jarmaz with Ra before Zay. Likewise in Banu Asad Al-Jarmaz bin Kahil. In Khuza'ah Al-Jazr with Zay before Ra, so understand that.
Among them is the poet Al-Tirammah bin Hakim Nafarain Qais bin Jahd bin Rida bin Malik bin Amr bin Rabi'ah bin Jarwal bin Tha'l.
Among them is the poet Ghariq Qais bin Jarwah bin Sayf bin Wa'il bin Amr bin Amr bin Malik bin Aman.
From Banu Jarwal is the wife of Hatim, Al-Nawar bint Marhalah bin Adi bin Jusham bin Abi Jabiyah bin Jady bin Jarwal.
Among them is Ibn Arabi bin Has bin Ziyad bin Jady bin Jarwal.

(Section)
From Banu Tha'labah (who is Jarm) bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Samh.
From them is Qamran bin Tha'labah bin Amr. Tha'labah is Jarm.
Among them is Has bin Sa'd bin Al-Mundhir bin Sa'd bin Tathrabi bin Abd Rabbih bin Qamran. Umar appointed him judge of Homs. He was over Tayy of Sham with Mu'awiyah. He was killed at Siffin; his killer Zaid bin Adi bin Hatim killed him and fled to Mu'awiyah and joined Aja and Salma.
Among them are Malik and Tha'labah sons of Raban bin Hayyan bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Jarm.
Among them is Ma'qil bin Hann bin Jariyah bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Tayy. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and believed in him. He named him Zaid Al-Khayr. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "I have not heard of anyone but when I saw him he was less than what I heard about him, except Zaid." His son was Mukanna, and he was nicknamed by him.
Hurayth was a horseman, and Urwah witnessed Al-Qadisiyah.
From Banu Sa'd is Sadus, who is Khalid bin Al-Asma' bin Ubayd bin Rabi'ah bin Nasr bin Sa'd bin Nayhan. He said: Every Sadus in the Arabs has Fatha on Ayn [Sin?] except Sadus bin Asma' Al-Ta'i, for it has Damma on Sin.
Among them is Wazar bin Jabir bin Sadus, who is said to have killed Antarah Al-Absi, and it is said Al-Asad Al-Rahis killed him. Wazar bin Jabir came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) but did not accept Islam.
Among them is Al-Samit bin Malik bin Sa'd bin Shihab. From his children is Janab bin Adi bin Harithah bin Alqamah bin Qumaylah the Poet bin Adiyah bin Zafar bin Malik bin Al-Samit.
Among them is Qahtabah Ziyad bin Shabib bin Khalid bin Ma'dan bin Abd Shams bin Qais bin Aklub bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Al-Samit.
Qahtabah begot Hamid and Al-Hasan, sons of Qahtabah.
Among them is the worshiper Abd al-Hamid bin Amr bin Hassan bin Sulayman bin Adal bin Salamah bin Shams bin Shamsad bin Jabir bin Rihab bin Amr bin Al-Samit.
Also Al-Jarrah bin Ya'qub bin Ka'b bin Wahb bin Khuzaymah bin Amr bin Jarm; he was a horseman.
Among them is Rafi' bin Umayr bin Jabir bin Harithah bin Amr. He is the grandfather of Raja' bin Mihsan bin Tha'labah bin Amr bin Jarm. He was the guide of Khalid bin Al-Walid from Iraq to Sham. Khalid said about him:
"Excellent is Rafi', how he found the way...
He fled from Fura to Suwa

In five (days), if the army traveled them it would crush...
What men did not travel before him, I see."
And Sahm bin Malik bin Kulthum bin Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Taym bin Shahr bin Qais bin Muslih bin Sam' bin Jarm.
Among them is the poet Amr bin Ammar bin Amr bin Amabah Rabi' bin Munhib bin Samh bin Jarm.

(Section)
From Banu Aswadan (who is Shihab) are Sa'd and Nabil.
From Nabil is Zaid Al-Khayl bin Thawr bin Kinanah bin Malik bin Nabil bin Nabhan.

(Section)
From Banu Bulan (who is Ghusayn) bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Tayy are Mu'attir, Umar, and Ja'niyah.
Mu'attir is the one who killed Al-Hafni. Al-Hafni raided them, so Mu'attir killed him. The poet said:
"May Allah not cut between Mu'attir...
A bond of love, Ubayd, a stab before the attack."
Mu'attir the poet is Khalid bin Ghanimah bin Zaid bin Sayfi bin Saghir bin Amr bin Mu'attir bin Bulan.
Among them is Tha'labah bin Amir bin Al-Muzdalif bin Abi Amr bin Mu'attir.
From the descendants of Murr bin Amr bin Al-Gharth is Al-Kuhayf bin Mulkhu Al-Kuhayf bin Murr bin Amr bin Al-Gharth.
Among them is Batat bin Malik bin Qaym Allat bin Zahu bin Amr bin Al-Gharth bin Tayy.
From the descendants of Bulan bin Murrah is the one who invented the Arabic script and taught it to the Arabs, so it is the pen of the Arabs to this day.
This is the lineage of Tayy, and they are two clans as we mentioned: Jadilah and Al-Gharth.
With Jadilah from the clans are Malbah [?], Banu Taym, Banu Tarif, Banu Namarah, Khaybari, and Sinbis.
The clans of Al-Gharth have been mentioned, which are Jarm, Bulan, and others.

**Lineage of Al-Ash'ar**
He is Al-Khiyar, and his name is Al-Nabit. He was named Ash'ar because he was born hairy (Ash'ar) on the body. He is the brother of Tayy, Madhhij, and Murrah as we mentioned and presented. They are the sons of Udad bin Zaid bin Amr bin Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan.
From the descendants of Ash'ar are Al-Jamahir, Jiddah, Al-Argham, Al-Adgham, Wa'il, Kahil, Abd Shams, Abd Al-Thurayya, Zaid, and Murrah. They are ten; seven of them left offspring, and Murrah did not.
From the descendants of Al-Jamahir are Najiyah, Al-Hanik, Hassan, Jadal, Natah, Rikab, and Kahil.
From the descendants of Kahil bin Al-Jamahir are Adi, Malik, Al-Harith, Abs, Hubays, Sulaym, Aws Allah, Gharisah, Awsab, Rida, and Amir.
From the descendants of Najiyah bin Al-Jamahir are Dalil, Ghasil, Al-Ahl, Dajran, Dhumamah, Bara', Ashib, Siba'ah, Sa'd, and Shabib; all are clans.
From the descendants of Al-Habik, whose name is Al-Aysar bin Al-Jamahir bin Ash'ar, are Sadus, Shayib, Yasir, Majid, Marbitah, Adal, and Za'anij; all are clans.
Al-Kala'i said: The abode of the Ash'aris was Hadramaut in Jahiliyyah, then they moved to Zubid and Rama' before the state of Islam. Al-Rakb came and settled in the land of Jabish and Wadi Al-Milh and the adjacent mountains and Yemen, so they settled there and populated it.
Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani said in Kitab al-Aghani: The Ash'aris and Akk bin Adnan used to descend from Tihamah to Sham, and settled between Jeddah and Mecca to the sea, and return to Yemen. When Islam came, Abu Musa migrated among the Ash'aris to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) in a ship. The wind cast them to the land of the Negus (Najashi), where they found Ja'far bin Abi Talib and his companions. They remained with them until they left in two ships. It is narrated that Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari came to the Prophet - peace be upon him - in Mecca then returned to his land until he came, he and his people, with the people of the two ships.
He said: From the descendants of Al-Jamahir bin Ash'ar is Abu Musa, whose name is Abdullah bin Qais bin Sulaym bin Haddar bin Harb bin Amir bin Umar bin Bakr bin Amir bin Ghadw bin Wa'il bin Najiyah bin Al-Jamahir bin Ash'ar. His mother is Tughyah bint Wahb Al-Akkisiyyah. Tughyah accepted Islam and died in Medina.
Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari arrived while the Prophet (peace be upon him) was in Khaybar, so they came to him there. He did not allocate shares to anyone who did not attend the conquest except them, and bequeathed for them in the dates of Khaybar one hundred loads (Wasq) every year.
Then Abu Musa and his people migrated for Jihad to Iraq, Khorasan, Qom, and other lands.
Abu Musa - may Allah be pleased with him - married Umm Kulthum bint Al-Fadl bin Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib, and she bore him Musa, by whom he was nicknamed.
From the children of Abu Musa are Abu Burdah, Abu Bakr, Al-Harith, Abdullah, and Ibrahim. He is his eldest son, born in the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), carried to him, so he prayed for blessing for him, chewed a date for him (Tahnik), and named him Ibrahim. He has offspring in Qom and elsewhere. They are the ones whom Abu Tammam Al-Ta'i and Al-Buhturi praise.
Al-Buhturi said praising Emir Muhammad bin Ali bin Isa bin Musa Talha Al-Ash'ari Al-Qummi:
"O son of the Ghuwatim and Awatik, a lineage...
Boasted of by uncles and fathers.
And maternal uncles from Hashim of generosity...
If they are not [literally], they have in it what they willed.
A King, noble of deeds, Talha is his pride...
Sufficed by his land's generosity and sky."

Among the clients (Mawali) of Ibrahim bin Abi Musa is Hammad bin Sulayman, the jurist of Kufa. He was well-versed in arts of knowledge and is the teacher of Imam Abu Hanifa Al-Nu'man bin Thabit. Abu Hanifa is from the sons of the other Persian who settled with Taym of Kufa and allied with them. So these are his patrons, and it is not a patronage of emancipation as some people claimed.
Among the clients of Abu Burdah bin Abi Musa is Khalaf Al-Ahmar. He was knowledgeable in grammar. He freed him and his father, and they were from Merv. Khalaf Al-Ahmar was knowledgeable in grammar, poetry, and language, and was Basran. He is the teacher of Abu Nuwas Al-Hakami.
He said: When Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari accepted Islam, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) appointed him over Zubid, Rima', and its coasts up to Aden in Yemen. Abu Musa was trusted by Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq - may Allah be pleased with him - over charities. Umar bin Al-Khattab - may Allah be pleased with him - appointed him over Basra, then appointed him over Iraq. He had conquests there, opening Ahvaz. He was with Ali at Siffin and was one of the two arbitrators. He was known for Fiqh and Quran recitation, and was among the most illustrious of Yemen's people in status and lineage.
Then he migrated to Mecca and settled in the east of Al-Ma'la. He neighbored the graves in Al-Abtah in the ravine known as Shi'b Abi Musa. He dug a well there known as Bi'r Abi Musa, and said: "I neighbor a people who do not betray," meaning the people of the graves.
Abu Musa had brothers who accepted Islam: Abu Burdah (his name is Amir bin Qais) and Abu Ruhm bin Qais. It is said they had a fourth brother named Majdi bin Qais, and it is said Majdi is Abu Burdah.
Abu Burdah bin Abi Musa was a judge over Kufa, and his son Bilal was a judge over Basra. So he is a judge son of a judge son of a judge, three judges in one line. About him the poet says:
"O son of the two judges, a judge...
Determined, proceeding on the path."
From the descendants of Abu Musa is the Sheikh, the Imam, the master of Kalam (Theology), Abu Al-Hasan Al-Ash'ari. He is Ali bin Isma'il bin Abdullah bin Musa bin Bilal bin Abi Burdah bin Abi Musa Al-Ash'ari. He is the Sheikh of the school attributed to the Ash'aris. He was an Imam knowledgeable in religious matters, and he is the one who refuted the deviating sects. A multitude of scholars and a large crowd followed him in Iraq, Khorasan, Mecca, and Yemen. His school spread among people and the Ummah received it with acceptance.
He said: Among the Ash'aris who narrated Hadith are Abu Musa, Abu Malik, and Abu Amir (who is other than Abu Musa). Abu Musa's uncle is named Abd bin Sulayman bin Hasad; he was among the senior Companions. He was killed on the Day of Awtas while commanding for the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) after killing nine in duels. Abu Amir is the one about whom the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Excellent is the tribe Al-Azd and the Ash'aris; they do not flee in battle nor steal spoils. They are from me and I am from them."
As for Abu Burdah, brother of Abu Musa, his name is Amir bin Qais; he has companionship and narration. Abu Burdah bin Abi Musa is also Amir, his narration is from his father as well. The third Abu Burdah is Yazid bin Abdullah bin Abi Burdah bin Abi Musa.
He said: From the descendants of Ash'ar are Amir and Arid - two origins from which many clans branched. They are sons of Udhar bin Wa'il bin Najiyah bin Al-Jamahir bin Al-Ash'ar.
From the descendants of Amir are Sha'dhaf, Baqdam, Jamad, and Shahlah. It is said Jamad and Shahlah are sons of Wa'il bin Ash'ar.
From the descendants of Amir the Younger is Awsham; his children are called Al-Awarishm, and they are in the mountain, companions of Zaymah Al-Ash'ari.

From the descendants of Arid are Thabit, Na'im, Ghashamah, and Al-Muhanna. From the descendants of Al-Muhanna are Ghasil, Amlas, Jashib, and Adl (who is Abu Al-Ayadil).
From the descendants of Najiyah bin Al-Jamahir bin Ash'ar is Abu Masami' bin Ubayd bin Bilal bin Zaid bin Hadid bin Amir bin Al-Husayn bin Hayy bin Harith bin Tu'mah bin Ukamah bin Dajran bin Najiyah bin Al-Jamahir bin Ash'ar. He was an ally of Quraysh and was killed at Badr as a disbeliever.
Among them is Al-Shayib bin Malik bin Amir bin Hani bin Jafaf bin Kulthum bin Qar'ab bin Zaid bin Dajran. He was a noble and was in charge of Al-Mukhtar's police and was killed with him.
Al-Shayib's brother, Sa'd bin Malik, was among the nobles of Iraq. His father Malik bin Amir came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and witnessed Al-Qadisiyah. He was the first to cross the Tigris. The children of Dajran inhabit Qom, and they have large numbers there.
He said: From the descendants of Al-Arghamin [Al-Argham bin?] Al-Ash'ar is Yattaba'. From the descendants of Yattaba' are Banu Yattaba' bin Al-Argham bin Al-Ash'ar. He said Yattaba' is with Damma on Ya with two dots below and middle Tha with three dots between two Yas. Likewise in Azd, Lakhm, and Adnan. As for Tatta', its beginning is Ta with three dots delayed [?]. In Bajilah, Abtha' bin Yazid bin Qais bin Abqar with Hamza followed by Ya with two dots below and after it Ta with three dots.
The clans of Al-Asha'ir are Wa'il, Najiyah, Dajran, Al-Hanik, Al-Jamahir, Sadus, Sayib, Amir, Yaqrum, Shafdaf, Hammad, Shahlah, Arid, Thabit, Na'im, Asamah, Al-Muhanna, Asil, and Al-Rakb. The connection of the lineages of these tribes has been mentioned.

(Section)
As for Al-Rakb, they are from the descendants of Al-An'am bin Al-Ash'ar. It is said they are from the descendants of Ju'fi bin Sa'd Al-Ashirah. They are Abdullah, Al-Akhwar, Zaid, Miswar, Rafi', and As'ad, sons of Al-An'am bin Al-Ash'ar.
From the clans of Al-Rakb are Al-Salatin Banu Fihr, Banu Hakim, and Fakhir. From the descendants of Hakim are Al-Zubayr, Al-Zahhaf, Zamil, and Al-Khadi', whose descendants are called Al-Ukhdu'.

**Lineage of Lakhm, Judham, and Amilah**
Sons of Adi bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Udad bin Zaid bin Amr bin Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan. The brother of Lakhm, Judham, and Amilah is Ufayra' and Kindah.
The name of Lakhm is Malik. The name of Judham is Amir.
They were two brothers who fought. One of them cut off (Jadhama) the finger of his companion, and the other slapped (Latama) him. So he was named Judham because his finger was cut off, and the other was named Lakhm because his brother slapped him. Al-Lakhmah means the slap.
It is narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: "Faith is the faith of Lakhm and Judham. Blessings of Allah be upon Judham; they fight the disbelievers on the tops of palm branches, supporting Allah and His Messenger."
He said: He begot Namarah and Jarmalah. From the descendants of Namarah are Amr and Adi.
Adi was the first to wear the turban (I'tama) so he was named Amam. From his descendants is Qasir bin Sa'd bin Khuzaymah bin Qais bin Malik bin Adi bin Namarah bin Lakhm. He is the one who was with Jadhimah Al-Abrash on the Day of Al-Zabba', and he is the one who plotted for Amr until he killed Al-Zabba', and he has a story.
From the descendants of Amr bin Namarah are the Kings of Al-Hirah: Al-Nu'man Al-Aswad, and Amr bin Hind (Hind is his mother, daughter of Al-Harith Al-Saffal Al-Kindi). Their father is Al-Mundhir bin Al-Mundhir bin Imru' al-Qais bin Amr bin Adi bin Nasr bin Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Mas'ud bin Malik bin Amr bin Amarah bin Lakhm.
Amr bin Adi is the one who killed Al-Zabba' avenging his uncle Jadhimah Al-Abrash Al-Azdi and became king. He ruled after him. He is the first to rule from the descendants of Al-Nadr [Nasr?]. His reign was one hundred and eighteen years.
It is said that the Companions of the Cave are from the descendants of Adi bin Nasr.
From the descendants of Amr bin Namarah are Malik, Rayth, Habib, Awdah, and Hadhamah (who are Al-Abbad).
Aman, who are Al-Akhbuth, which is Hani bin Habib who is in Tayy, the clan of the poet Al-Tirammah bin Hakim.
Among them is Al-Dar, who is Hani bin Habib bin Amr bin Namarah bin Lakhm. Banu Al-Dar are a clan. Among them is Tamim Al-Dari bin Aws bin Harith bin Sawad bin Khudhaymah bin Dara' bin Adi bin Al-Dar. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him), he and Tamim bin Aws [Nu'aym bin Aws?], and he granted them Hebron (Habra) and Bayt Aynun in Sham.
Tamim Al-Dari did not leave a land but traversed it, nor a valley but walked it. He traversed the lands of Darkness and lands beyond the Romans, and described it to the Prophet (peace be upon him).
Among them are Ruwan and Wahb sons of Malik bin Sawad bin Khudhaymah; he came to the Prophet (peace be upon him).
Among them is Al-Falkah bin Al-Nu'man bin Jubaylah bin Tufawah bin Rabi'ah bin Dara' bin Adi bin Al-Dar.
Among them is Abu Hind bin Abdullah bin Abs bin Rabi'ah bin Dara'. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and he named him Al-Tayyib.
These are Banu Al-Dar.

(Section) From the descendants of Jazilah bin Lakhm

Hujr, Arashah, Aran, Yashkur, and Jalil. Mudkhal Banu Jalil are in Ghassan.
From Banu Aran are Wa'isah bin Aran and Rashidah (who is Khalifah) bin Aran bin Jazilah bin Lakhm. Banu Rashidah are a large clan. They are the clan of Hatib bin Abi Balta'ah, ally of Banu Asad bin Abd al-Uzza, who witnessed Badr.
From the descendants of Aras bin Arashah are Ghanam, Amr, Awf, and Sab' (who are Al-Jamarat). Many of them are in Al-Hirah. Among them is Sa'id bin Darghnam Aras.
Among them are Khuzam, Nuhalah, and Uyaynah, sons of Al-Arja bin Ghanam Awd sons of Sijistan [?], who was with Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Ash'ath.
Sa'd and Mu'awiyah sons of Awf bin Arash. Their mother is Hind bint Da'jan bin Lahm, by whom they are known.
From Shaja', A' bin Amr Awd bin Ubayd. Many of them are in Anbar and the rest in Sham.
From the descendants of Arash bin Arashah bin Jazilah is Zamamah. From the descendants of Rabi'ah are Ka'b, Sa'dah, Harthamah (a clan), and Wa'il who is Manarah (a clan); she is his mother, daughter of Ka'b bin Amr bin Jalil, by whom they are known.
From Ramimah bin Hurr bin Uthman bin Al-Mundhir bin Qais bin Shahran bin Gharan bin Jundab bin Hind bin Sa'b bin Amr bin Ramimah.
Among them is Abu Mihjan bin Abdullah bin Al-Mundhir bin Qais bin Shahran, the first to enter Constantinople, and was killed at its gate in the days of Maslamah bin Abd al-Malik.
Among them is Qatil bin Hajur bin Da'jan bin Unayb bin Kulayb bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Zamimah bin Jarash, who used to fight in the days of tribalism in Sham.
From the descendants of Hujr bin Jazilah bin Lakhm is Abd al-Malik bin Umayr bin Suwayd bin Amlas bin Abd Shams bin Sa'd bin Al-Wasi' bin Al-Harith bin Baysalah bin Ubayy bin Awd bin Bashir bin Lakhm; he was a judge in Kufa.
Among them is Samhar bin Da'r bin Hujr bin Jazilah bin Lakhm, to whom Samhari spears are attributed.
Among them is Malik bin Da'r bin Hujr bin Jazilah bin Lakhm. Malik is the one who extracted Joseph the Truthful from the well. It is narrated that Joseph the Truthful (peace be upon him) prayed for Malik bin Da'r for blessing in children when he extracted him from the well and brought news of him to his father Jacob, who asked him to pray to Allah for him for many children as he had no children (it is said a blind female was born to him). So he prayed to Allah for him for many children.
Malik had children, firstly every two in a belly (twins) for twelve years, twenty-four children. They are: Al-Shar'abi, Al-Mashraqi, Al-Sindi, Al-Sandali, Al-Sarandi, Al-Bulaydi, Al-Sadd, Al-Hasm, Al-Ba'id, Al-Arish, Al-Udays, Al-Ammash, Shams, Bayhas, Asas, Halawis, Al-Muhadhdhab, Al-Usayfih, Al-Sahih, Al-Dakhkhal, Al-Dhayyal, Fayzi, Sayghi, and Musaddi'. These are the children of Malik bin Da'r. It is said that Malik bin Da'r bin Tharib bin Anqa bin Midian bin Ibrahim Al-Khalil, so they attributed themselves to Lakhm. Allah knows best.

(Section) From the descendants of Murrah bin Udad is Af'a Najran [Bahrran?] Ibn Al-Husayn bin Al-Hurr bin Al-Husayn bin Al-Harith bin Adham bin Murrah bin Udad. He is the judge whom Banu Nizar sought for judgment. It is said they sought judgment from Al-Husayn Al-Jurhumi. Allah knows best.
It is said that Al-Ma'afir is from the descendants of Amr bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Udad, and they are Al-Ma'afir bin Ya'fur. It is said their lineage is in Tamim as mentioned in the lineage of Tamim. The correct is that Al-Ma'afir is from the descendants of Himyar and they are in Yemen. Allah knows best.
The clans of Lakhm are Al-Dariyyun Banu Al-Dar bin Hani, Banu Rashidah, and Banu Aris Banu Manarah.

**Lineage of Judham**
He said: Judham begot Haram and Jusham.
From the descendants of Haram are Afsa and Ghatafan, sons of Sa'd bin Zubid bin Iyas bin Haram bin Judham. In them are numbers and honor.
From the descendants of Afsa is Ibn Imru' al-Qais bin Tha'labah bin Dinan bin Awf bin Athmar bin Zinba' bin Mazin bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Zaid bin Manat bin Afsa. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) and was a noble master. The Prophet (peace be upon him) gave him command over Banu Sa'd bin Malik. His son Nabil bin Qais was a noble master in Sham.
Among them is the Vizier of Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, Rawh bin Zinba' bin Rawh bin Haddad bin Jadidah bin Umayyah bin Imru' al-Qais bin Kinanah bin Wa'il bin Malik bin Zaid Manat bin Afsa.
From the descendants of Wa'il bin Zaid Manat is Afsa bin Haram.
As for Ghatafan bin Sa'd bin Zubid bin Iyas bin Judham, his children are Abs, Nasrah, Anamah, Abdullah, Rayth, and Harith; all are clans. Rayth and Abdullah attributed themselves to Ghatafan bin Qais bin Aylan, and it is said that Ghatafan bin As'ad bin Qais bin Aylan [?].
From them is Rawh bin Shurahbil bin Abdullah bin Tha'labah bin Khalijah bin Harithah bin Zaid bin Asm bin Karmah bin Sa'd bin Atamah bin Ghatafan.
Adarah is in Kindah in Banu Sahrah.

(Section) As for Jusham bin Judham, from his descendants is Adi (a clan) bin Amr bin Sawd bin Bakr bin Jusham.
Among them are Hasan and Uqbah sons of Bakr bin Sawd bin Zubid bin Jusham.
Among them are Abdullah, Jahif, and Dahr sons of Unayb bin Aslam bin Malik bin Shanu'ah bin Badil Jusham bin Judham.

**Lineage of Amilah**
His name is Al-Harith bin Adi. His name is Al-Harith bin Adi bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Udad bin Zaid bin Amr bin Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan. He is the brother of Lakhm and Judham.
It is said Amilah is the wife of Al-Harith bin Adi, and she is Umm Waladiyah Al-Dahr and Mu'awiyah, and her children were attributed to her. She is Amilah bint Malik bin Wadi'ah from Quda'ah. Amilah (Al-Harith) begot Mu'awiyah and Al-Dahr.
From the descendants of Mu'awiyah are Sha'l, Ijl, and Salamah. From them is Shihab bin Barham bin Ma'qil bin Malik bin Adi bin Harithah bin Tha'labah bin Qati'ah bin Amr bin Haynah bin Jadhimah bin Sha'l bin Mu'awiyah bin Amilah; he was a noble.
Among them is Hamar bin Ma'qil bin Malik; he was a noble with Maslamah bin Abd al-Malik.
Among them is the poet Adi bin Al-Riqa' bin Zaid bin Khalid bin Adi bin Al-Riqa' bin Amr bin Adi bin Sha'l bin Mu'awiyah bin Amilah.
From Banu Salamah bin Mu'awiyah bin Amilah. From Banu Salamah bin Mu'awiyah are Nadin Awad the poet and Awad Al-Bahili the poet, another ancient one from them.
Among them is Qa'is who captured Adi bin Hatim Al-Ta'i and took ransom from him.

(Section) Al-Dahr from Amilah begot Awkalan and Salman. From them is Al-Tamyan bin Azm bin Awkalan bin Al-Zahr bin Amilah.
Among them are Masas, Al-Hariq, Awf, and Aylan, sons of Amir bin Mazin bin Murr bin Azm bin Awkalan.
Among them is Tha'labah bin Salamah bin Haram bin Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah. He was a pious ascetic jurist. Maslamah bin Abd al-Malik used to consult him in affairs. He is the one who advised him to pledge allegiance to Umar bin Abd al-Aziz.
We returned to connect his lineage, he is Kindah bin Tha'labah bin Mazin Murri bin Hazm bin Awkalan. He governed Jordan and was among the horsemen.

**Lineage of Kindah**
He is Thawr bin Amr bin Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan. This is the saying of Al-Kalbi.
Ibn Hisham said: He is Kindi bin Thawr bin Ghafir.
Ibn Ishaq said: He is Thawr bin Malik bin Zaid bin Amr bin Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan.
Al-Zubayr said: He is Murta' bin Kindah. He was named Kindah because he was ungrateful (Kanada) to his father, i.e., disobeyed him.
He said: Kindah are two origins: Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin and Al-Ashras.
Mu'awiyah bin Kindah the Kings. They are Banu Amr and Banu Al-Harith sons of Mu'awiyah bin Kindah.
Hujr Akil al-Murar bin Wahb bin Rabi'ah bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah was born.
Hujr Akil al-Murar begot Al-Harith Al-Walladah [or Al-Wiladah], or Imru' al-Qais (who is son of Hujr Malik), and Mu'awiyah (who is Abu Banu Hassan).
From his descendants is Imru' al-Qais bin Amr bin Raja' bin Haywah Jubayrah bin Al-Ahnaf bin Imru' al-Qais.
Hujr bin Amr was named Akil al-Murar because he ate Al-Murar, a plant with bitterness.
From his descendants are Hujr, Umar, Al-Maqsur, and Al-Harith. Their mother is Hind bint Zalim bin Wahb bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah.
From Banu Amr Al-Maqsur bin Hujr Akil al-Murar bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah: Amr Al-Maqsur had children: Al-Harith the King, Imru' al-Qais, Hujr, Abu Karib, and Ma'di Karib.
Al-Harith the King had five children: Hujr King of Banu Asad and Kinanah; Shurahbil King of Banu Tamim and Al-Rabab; Salamah King of Banu Bakr and Taghlib sons of Wa'il; Ma'di Karib King of Qais and Aylan. Qais was wandering (Sayyarah), and any people he settled with, he was their king. And Hind (a woman).
These are the children of Al-Harith bin Amr Al-Maqsur Akil al-Murar bin Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah. The mother of Al-Harith the King is Umm Iyas bint Awf bin Muhallim bin Dhuhl bin Shayban.
From Banu Shurahbil the King bin Al-Harith the King is Abu Al-Jabr bin Amr bin Yazid bin Shurahbil.
From Banu Salamah the King is Amr bin Abi Karib bin As bin Salamah Malik bin Salamah the King. The children of Malik are with their maternal uncles Banu Dabbah bin Add.
Among them is Al-Ala bin Sumayr bin Al-Harith bin Salamah. He is the one who entered with Ulaykan bin Harsah bin Amr bin Dirar upon Abdullah bin Ziyad, who asked: Who is this with you? He said: My Lord in Jahiliyyah, and my ally in Islam.
From Banu Imru' al-Qais bin Amr Al-Maqsur is Al-Nu'man bin Yazid bin Shurahbil bin Yazid bin Imru' al-Qais bin Amr Al-Maqsur. Al-Nu'man is the maternal uncle of Al-Ash'ath bin Qais. He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him).
As for Banu Hujr bin Amr Al-Maqsur (who is the uncle of Al-Ash'ath bin Qais), they are in Sham, called Banu Mil'aqah (their mother, attributed to her).
As for Mu'awiyah bin Al-Jawn, brother of Amr bin Hujr Akil al-Murar, his children are Kindi, Amr, and Akhdar sons of Salih bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Shurahbil bin Al-Nu'man bin Amr bin Al-Jawn. They have judges among them more than one.
Among them is Hassan bin Amr bin Al-Jawn, who was over Tamim on the Day of Jabalah.
Among them is Mu'awiyah bin Shurahbil bin Akhdar bin Al-Jawn, with Banu Amir on the Day of Jabalah.
Among them is Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Aswad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Al-Aswad bin Al-Harith bin Shurahbil bin Kinda bin Al-Jawn.

As for Al-Harith Al-Walladah, brother of Hujr Akil al-Murar bin Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah, his child is Abdullah (who is Al-Shaytan). He came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) with a group of them. He said: "Who are you?" They said: "Banu Al-Shaytan." He said: "You are Banu Abdullah." So some say: In Banu Abdullah, and some say: Banu Al-Shaytan.
From the descendants of Al-Bastan [Al-Shaytan?] Al-Ja'sas is Ma'dan bin Al-Aswad bin Ma'di Karib bin Thumamah bin Al-Aswad bin Al-Shaytan, and he is in Yemen.
And Hujr (who is Al-Ghard). He was named Al-Ghard for his hands and generosity. The Yemenis say: Al-Ghard with dotted Ayn, and it is a clan.
From his children are the Four Kings: Majush, Mahus, Khamr, and Al-Dahhah. And their sister Al-Ghardah, children of Ma'di Karib bin Wali'ah bin Shurahbil bin Hujr Al-Ghard. About them the poet says:
"O eye, weep for the Four Kings...
Majus, Hamra, Al-Fan'ah, and Masrah.
And that I will not contain [?]."
They are Kings of Hadramaut.
Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith Al-Walladah, a clan in Yemen.
Amr and Imru' al-Qais, their mother is Lamis bint Amr bin Wahb in Yemen.
Amr and Imru' al-Qais by Salamah, a clan, their mother is Fatimah bint Al-A'il bin Mu'awiyah.
These are Banu Al-Harith Al-Walladah.
From the descendants of Al-Shaytan is Abdullah bin Yahya bin Amr bin Shurahbil bin Yazid bin Amr bin Al-Aswad bin Al-Shaytan (who is Ubaydullah).
Among them is the poet Abu Hayy, and Masruq bin Ma'di Karib bin Thumamah bin Al-Aswad bin Abdullah bin Al-Harith Al-Walladah.
Among them is Ma'dan Al-Jaghshish. He is the one who asked the Prophet (peace be upon him) when he came to him with Al-Ash'ath bin Qais, saying: "Are we not from you, O Messenger of Allah?" He remained silent twice, then said: "We are Banu Al-Nadr bin Kinanah, we do not deny our mother nor disown our father." Al-Ash'ath said to his companion: "May Allah smash your mouth, why didn't you stay silent?"
It is narrated that the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib used this lineage." That is because Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib used to say to Kindah when he traveled to Sham: "We are Banu Akil al-Murar."

(Section)
As for Banu Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin, from them is Al-Ash'ath bin Qais bin Ma'di Karib bin Mu'awiyah bin Jabalah bin Adi bin Rabi'ah bin Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin bin Al-Harith Al-Sa'al [Al-Saffal?] bin Mu'awiyah bin Thawr (who is Kindah). Al-Ash'ath bin Qais was noble and brave. He rebelled against Al-Hajjaj in the Caliphate of Abd al-Malik bin Marwan, and he has a story.
Among them is Ya'qub bin Ishaq bin Al-Sabah bin Imran bin Isma'il bin Muhammad bin Al-Ash'ath.
From Banu Karib is Shurahbil bin Ma'di Karib; he had two thousand five hundred in stipend. His brother Al-Aswad bin Ma'di Karib was a noble. These are Jahili/Islamic.
About Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin, Al-A'sha says:
"- And Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin are handsome of face, tall of stature."
The general nation [?].
Among them are Hujr and Al-Harith sons of Adi bin Rabi'ah bin Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin. As for Hujr, he is the companion of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. From his descendants are Murrah and Shurahbil sons of Hujr bin Adi; they are two clans.
As for Al-Harith bin Hujr, his mother is Mulaykah bint Al-Sahhar bin Dhuhl bin Mu'awiyah, who are called Al-Khalf Al-Azid because they did not enter into the alliance.
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Adi bin Rabi'ah and Shurahbil bin Al-Harith. About him Al-Nabighah says:
"Kanash and Hani and Banu Farwah... and Al-Ash'ath bin Qais a captive.
And to Al-Jir Qash'am they returned it... where their horses became weary."
Mazad had killed him, so they went out supporting each other under three banners: Kays on a banner, Al-Qash'am bin Yazid on a banner, and Al-Ash'ath bin Qais on a banner. They met Banu Al-Ma'qil from Banu Al-Harith bin Ka'b. Kanash, Al-Qash'am, and Banu Farwah bin Zurarah bin Al-Arqam were killed. Al-Ash'ath was captured. Al-Ash'ath said: "I do not care if I missed bitter ones [?]." [Text unclear regarding what happened to Madhhij and Ka'b]. He fell upon Banu Al-Harith bin Ka'b, so they captured him. He was ransomed for three thousand camels; no other Arab was ransomed for such. Regarding that, Amr bin Ma'di Karib Al-Zubaydi said:
"He came to us seeking revenge for his father Qais ... So the army of that Samdi destroyed him.
His ransom was two thousand young she-camels and a thousand ... of new ones and old."

(Section)
As for Wahb bin Rabi'ah bin Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin, from his descendants are Amr and Rabi'ah (their mother is Bint Al-Mathal bin Mu'awiyah). And Hujr and Abu Al-Jabr Al-Mazlum (their mother is Wazrab bint Amr bin Tha'labah Al-Iyadi Amr bin Ka'b bin Mamah). And Abd.
From the descendants of Abd is Al-Miqdam bin Ma'di Karib.
From the descendants of Amr bin Ka'b are Al-Aswad, Ma'di Karib, Amr, and Al-Arqam sons of Al-Nu'man bin Amr bin Wahb. Al-Aswad was their master, and he is the one Al-A'sha praised in his famous poem:
"Do not complain to me, but seek Al-Aswad ... People of generosity and people of action."

Ma'di Karib is Al-Ajzham (The Amputated). Qais bin Ma'di Karib struck his hand and cut it off, so he was named Al-Ajzham.
On that day, Banu Wahb bin Rabi'ah allied against Banu Adi. With Hujr were Banu Adi. Banu Al-Harith bin Adi did not enter the alliance with them, so they were named the Solitary Tribe (Al-Hayy Al-Farid).
Banu Al-Arqam are a clan. Among them are Banu Farwah bin Zurarah bin Al-Arqam, killed on the day Al-Ash'ath went out with them seeking revenge for his father. Al-Qash'am bin Yazid Al-Arqam was killed that day.
As for Rabi'ah bin Wahb bin Rabi'ah bin Mu'awiyah, from his descendants are Shajarah, Harmalah, and Amr. Shajarah begot offspring in Hadramaut, having numbers, honor, and governance. They are called Banu Shajarat. Among them are Banu Al-Aswad and Mu'awiyah bin Ans Al-Aswad bin Al-Aswad and Abdullah bin Ila Karib bin Abd Rabbih Wahb bin Rabi'ah bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Thawr (who is Kindah).
Al-Miqdam came to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), believed in him, and accompanied him.
As for Abu Al-Jabr Al-Mazlum bin Wahb bin Rabi'ah, from his descendants is Abdullah bin Rabi'ah. From his descendants is Abdullah bin Rabi'ah Murrah bin Maslamah bin Abi Al-Harakat, one of the companions of Ali (may Allah be pleased with him); he appointed him over Al-Sawad. He was one of the twenty who witnessed the oath of Yemen and Rabi'ah. And whoever was with Ali from Kindah.
Among them is Ma'di Karib bin Rabi'ah bin Maslamah bin Abi Al-Jabr.
As for Hujr bin Wahb bin Rabi'ah, from his descendants are Qais, Adi, Salamah Shurahbil Al-Akhram, and Wahb.
Among them is Amr bin Abi Qurrah, who is Salamah bin Mu'awiyah bin Wahb Qais bin Hujr bin Wahb bin Rabi'ah bin Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin.
Judgeship in Kufa from Kindah: Four judges. Al-Qash'am bin Zurarah bin Al-Arqam, then Shurayh bin Al-Harith, then Amr [whom we mentioned], then Hasan bin Hasan Al-Hujri. Hatim bin Abdullah Al-Qasri appointed him.

(Section)
From the descendants of Rabi'ah bin Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin, who is Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Thawr (who is Kindah). Al-Kala'i said: He is Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith the Younger bin Thawr the Younger bin Murabbi' the Younger bin Mu'awiyah the Elder bin Thawr (who is Kindah).
From the descendants of Mu'awiyah Al-Akramin are Hujr (whom we mentioned), Al-Muthall, and Al-Atik.
From the descendants of Al-Muthall is the poet Qatan bin Qais bin Al-Sahhar bin Bahdalah bin Al-Muthall.
Among them is Juww Al-Sha'tha' Ziyad bin Yazid bin Al-Nu'man bin Salamah bin Al-Sahhar, killed with Al-Husayn bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both.
From the descendants of Shayban (his mother is Bayda' bint Al-Abyad bin Imru' al-Qais), he came to the Prophet (peace be upon him).
As for Thab bin Qais bin Al-Harith bin Siyan, he also came and lived a long time. The poet says about him:
"Would that I lived the days of Khalid...
Like the life of Aba Thab bin Qais bin Khalid."

(Section)
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah are Imru' al-Qais, Malik, Al-Tumah, and Harith.
From the descendants of Imru' al-Qais are Bin Al-Harith, Khadij, Bakr, Al-Abyad, and Tha'labah.
From the descendants of Malik bin Al-Harith are Salamah and Al-Mundhir bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah.
From the descendants of Abu Al-Amarrat is Umair bin Yazid bin Amr bin Shurahbil bin Al-Nu'man bin Al-Mundhir.
From the descendants of Al-Tumah bin Al-Harith are Malik sons of Al-Tumah.
From the descendants of Harith bin Al-Harith are Malik, Sa'd, Awf, and Amir, sons of Harith bin Al-Harith, and they have offspring.
From Banu Mu'awiyah the Younger bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah the Elder bin Kindah is Dhuhl, and he has offspring.

(Section)
From the descendants of Al-Harith the Elder are Banu Shihab. Among them are Al-Hanaf, Hujr, Maslamah, Ja'far, Abu Al-Husayn, Al-Ahnaf, and Abdullah, sons of Ghaylan bin Al-Amarrat bin Kabir bin Shihab the Younger bin Abd Malik bin Aqil bin Jumhur bin Amr bin Su'ubah bin Bara'id bin Malik bin Shihab the Middle bin Abd Malik bin Shihab the Elder bin Al-Aqil bin Rabi'ah bin Wahb bin Al-Harith the Elder bin Kindah.
Abbad bin Al-Amarrat was among the loyal nobles and governed Sana'a.
Among their poets and notables is Abd al-Khaliq bin Al-Talh bin Muhammad bin Jumhur. He is the one who satirized the Abna' (Persians) during their war, and whom Muhammad bin Ya'fur sought help against them with his poem inciting. He and Abdullah Al-Akili were the most poetic of their era.
From the descendants of Shihab the Elder are Muhammad, Kabir, Al-Walid, Hujr, Yahya, Al-Qashm, and Al-Jumhur.

(Section)
From the descendants of Mu'awiyah the Elder bin Kindah is Hujr. From his descendants is Al-Salt bin Hujr; his brothers Yazid and Abs came with him.
Among them is Al-Nu'man bin Ma'dan bin Al-Harith bin Adi bin Adi bin Al-Sahhar bin Wahl; he was a companion of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him.

(Section)
From the descendants of Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Thawr are Nada and Al-Ra's.
From the descendants of Nada are Awf, Malik, Thabit, and Al-Harith, sons of Nada bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Thawr.

From the descendants of Al-Ra's bin Al-Harith are Amir, Damrah, Zaid Manat, and Farsan, Banu Al-Ra'is.
From them is the Judge Shurayh bin Qais bin Al-Harith bin Humaym bin Mu'awiyah bin Amir bin Al-Ra's bin Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Kindah. He held the judiciary of Kufa for nine [caliphs/governors]. The first was Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him; Umar appointed him. Then Uthman, then Ali, then Al-Hasan, then Mu'awiyah, then Yazid, then Mu'awiyah bin Yazid, then Marwan bin Al-Hakam, then Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. The last of them was Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. Shurayh was a learned jurist. There is no one in Kufa from Banu Al-Ra's except him.

(Section)
As for Ashras bin Kindah, he begot Al-Sukun and Al-Sakasik. Their mother is Tu'mah bint Al-Jamahir bin Al-Ash'ar. They are two clans. Al-Sukun (with Damma on Sin and Fatha). It is said they are Al-Sakn and Al-Saksak.
From the descendants of Al-Sukun are Shabib and Uhnah. Their mother is Asma' bint Murta'.
From the descendants of Shabib are Ashras and Shaka. Ashras begot Adi and Sa'd.
From them are Shawm, Amir, and Uwah, sons of Adi bin Ashras bin Shabib bin Al-Sukun.
Among them is the poet Ibn Al-Ghazalah Rabi'ah bin Abdullah bin Rabi'ah bin Salamah bin Al-Harith bin Shawm bin Adi bin Ashras bin Shabib bin Al-Sukun.
Among them is Al-Dahhak bin Qais bin Al-Nu'man bin Al-Juwayrah bin Abd bin Amr bin Abi Al-Ghayd bin Al-Ghayd bin Qais bin Al-Harith bin Shawm bin Adi bin Ashras bin Shabib bin Al-Sukun. Al-Dahhak and Al-Sayyid were killed with Al-Hakam bin Awanah, and he was over the garrisons of Al-Sudd.
Among them are Nabhan and Jariyah sons of Kulthum bin Khunasah bin Amr bin Wa'il bin Sawm.
From the descendants of Sa'd bin Ashras bin Shabib is Qabirah bin Jariyah bin Abd Shams bin Mu'awiyah bin Ja'far bin Usamah bin Sa'd bin Ashras bin Shabib. The House is in Qabirah.
From them is Jidh' bin Ja'far bin Ja'ah bin Qabirah. He led and Al-Sukun united. His son Mu'awiyah Khadij was killed with Muhammad bin Abi Bakr.
Among them is Al-Tujibi Kumatuh [Kinanah?] bin Ashras bin Abab bin Harithah bin Awf bin Harithah bin Qabirah. He is the one who struck Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, with a column. About him Uqbah bin Al-Walid says:
"Indeed, the best of people after three...
Is the slain Tujibi who came from Egypt."
Among them is Murid (who is Muharriq), Malik, and Salamah, sons of Al-Adjam bin Sa'd bin Ashras bin Shabib bin Al-Sukun.
From the descendants of Murid are Murrah, Warsha', Qais, and Al-Harith. Their mother is Darmakah bint Abdullah bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Dhuhl bin Shayban; they are known by her.
Among them is Ali bin Salamah bin Qais bin Shayban bin Murrah bin Murid; he was a companion of Abdullah bin Mas'ud.
From Shakamah bin Shabib bin Al-Sukun are Malik, Salamah, Rabi'ah, and Al-Nadr. Their mother is Asirah bint Malik bin Tha'labah bin Dudan bin Asad.
From them is Ma'dan bin Jawwash bin Salamah bin Al-Mundhir Al-Masri the Poet bin Salamah bin Shakamah. He is the one who paid the blood money of Ziyad bin Al-Rabi' bin Ziyad Al-Kalbi in the time of Uthman bin Affan. The clients of Rabi'ah bin Dhuhl bin Shayban killed him, and their enmity was regarding them.
From the descendants of Shakamah bin Shabib are Salamah, Rabi'ah, and Amr. Their mother is Durrah bint Nasr bin Lakhm.
Among them is Al-Husayn bin Bishr bin Na'il bin Labid Ju'aydah bin Al-Harith bin Salamah bin Shakamah. He was a master. His son Yazid bin Al-Husayn governed Homs. His son Mu'awiyah bin Yazid governed Homs as well.
Among them is Bajr (his name is Al-Jarrah) bin Al-Munsalit bin Numayr bin Amr bin Abdullah bin Lihaf bin Sabur bin Anmar bin Sabrah bin Al-Munik bin Malikh bin Amr bin Shakamah. He was the hostage of Al-Sukun when they fell in Al-Jazirah to Banu Taghlib. To him Qais bin Shihab says:
"The best young man in Al-Sukun...
Hanzalah bin Mazid Al-Mawhun."
Among them is the Kharijite Hayyah bin Asim bin Amira bin Jarib bin Arqam bin Abd Yaghuth bin Dharih bin Jawah bin Malik, who rebelled in Al-Jazirah before Abu Ja'far.
Among them is Ukaydir bin Abd al-Malik bin Abd Al-Jinn bin A'yan Al-Harith bin Mu'awiyah bin Halawah bin Ibamah bin Salamah bin Shakamah, owner of Dumat al-Jandal. The Prophet (peace be upon him) made a treaty with him for something he would pay him, so he did. When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) passed away, he withheld it. So Ibn Jarir expelled him from Mawsa' Dumat al-Jandal. He joined Al-Hirah and built a building there which he named Dumat al-Jandal. Suwayd bin Shabib [z] bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Ulaym said regarding the expulsion of Ukaydir from Dumah:
"O you who saw a caravan departing in the morning...
From the family of Akdar, its grief makes me cry.
They exchanged the caravan for a land of residence...
And traveling from a high fortified palace."

Among them is Bishr bin Abd al-Malik bin Abd Al-Jinn to the end of the lineage, who taught the people of Anbar Arabic science. This Bishr is called Al-Hazm. The first to write Arabic script were a group from Tayy from Bulan. Bishr used to say: Murr Amr bin Murrah and Aslam bin Hadrah are the ones who invented this script and taught it to the people of Anbar. So Bishr bin Abd al-Malik from the people of Al-Hirah learned it from the people of Anbar. Bishr went to Mecca and married the daughter of Harb, sister of Abu Sufyan bin Harb. She bore him Harith Na'm Bishr the Scribe [? text corrupted, likely: Al-Harith, so Bishr was known as the Scribe] from Harith bin Umayyah bin Abd Shams and Abi Tufaysh bin Abd Manaf bin Zuhrah. So Bishr was called the Scribe. They are called today Banu Al-Katib in Kufa. Then he came to Sham and taught them there.

(Section)
From the descendants of Uqbah bin Al-Sukun are Tha'labah and Iyad. Their mother is Sahlah bint Afsa bin Jadilah from Asad.
Among them is Abbad bin Iyad, a clan in Kufa called Abbad Al-Sukun. They emigrated with Banu Shayban. Among them are Muzaynah, Shubrah, Dayfi, Salamah, and Qawih Al-Nar, Banu Abbad bin Iyad bin Uqbah bin Al-Sukun.
From the descendants of Ulbah bin Uqbah bin Al-Sukun is Amr bin Qais bin Thawr bin Hamran bin Amr bin Mazin bin Jashmah bin Al-Harith bin Al-Mukhsaf bin Malik bin Ka'b bin Bakr bin Tha'labah bin Uqbah bin Al-Sukun. He was a noble. He is the one who killed Muhammad bin Abi Hudhayfah bin Mu'awiyah, and he is the one who got angry at Mu'awiyah for killing Hujr bin Adi. His son Isa bin Amr (Abu Jamal) governed Basra for Abu Ja'far Al-Mansur twice. Abu Thawr bin Abi Jamal governed Homs for Harun Al-Rashid.
From the descendants of Tha'labah is Malik bin Malik bin Tadul bin Al-Harith bin Bakr bin Tha'labah bin Uqbah bin Al-Sukun.
Among them are Bara'im, who is Malik bin Mu'awiyah bin Tha'labah bin Uqbah bin Al-Sukun. They are a clan. From the descendants of Al-Bara'im is Al-Salqam, who is Aws bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Salamah bin Awf bin Bara'im. He was with Imru' al-Qais bin Hujr in the land of the Romans and was among those who carried him [?]. They are counted among Banu Taghlib.

(Section)
As for the second clan from the descendants of Ashras, they are Al-Sakasik. It is said Al-Saksak bin Kindah.
From the descendants of Al-Saksak are Amir, Khidash, Sa't, Urayf, Abdullah, Al-Rajm, Dam, Awlad, Hutaym, Al-Qasasah, Al-Ajwad, Al-Ajdur (who is Jadir), Al-Aysur (who is Yasir), Al-U'tud, Khammas, Urayf, and Haj'am.
From the descendants of Anas bin Al-Saksak is Nuh bin Amr bin Hawa bin Mani' bin Sabib bin Zur'ah bin Malik bin Amr bin Zaid bin Thawr bin Khadas bin Mall bin Abd bin Sa'd bin Ahmad bin Khadas bin Mall bin Abd al-Rahman bin Ka'b bin Sa'd bin Mani' bin Sayfi bin Sa'b bin Al-Sakasik bin Ashras. He was a noble in Sham. It is said that the family of Abu Al-Agharr in Yemen or the family of Ibn Rabi'ah Bumah are from Banu Sa'b.
From Banu Amir bin Zaid bin Bishr bin Al-Ash'ar, he was a noble.
From Banu Al-Adum is Mu'awiyah bin Abd Al-A'la, who was the Lion of the Arabs in the days of Marwan bin Muhammad.
Among them is Abu Al-Zubayr, son-in-law of Mu'adh bin Jabal. And Ziyad and Murid, sons of Abu Kabshah, who is Jibril bin Sayyarah bin Hayy bin Qurt bin Safal bin Al-Muqallad bin Ma'di Karib bin Urayf bin Al-Saksak.
It is said that from Banu Al-Saksak are Hani, Udrah, Mudhakir, Bakwah, Saharah, Al-Miqdas, Tamah, and Da'im, sons of Saksak.
From Al-Israr is Amr bin Sa'd bin Habil, who is the head of Al-Israr.
Ibn Ishaq said: Al-Sakasik bin Wa'ilah bin Himyar bin Saba. The correct is what we started with. Allah knows best.

(Section)
From the descendants of Kindah are Al-Sadaf and Tujib. Our Lord [Rabuna?] Al-Sadaf bin Malik bin Murta' bin Kindah. Others said: Ibn Amr bin Malik bin Ashras bin Kindah. Some said: Mushal bin Amr bin Ami bin Hadramaut bin Safinsah [?] to Hadramaut. Those of the descendants of Malik Al-Sadaf in the land of Hadramaut attribute themselves to Kindah, and those in Kufa attribute themselves to Hadramaut. It is Al-Sadaf with Kasra on Dal. If you attribute to it, you open it and say Sadafi, just as you attribute to Thamarah, Shaqrah, and Salamah (a clan of Ansar), saying Thamari, Shaqari, and Salami with Fatha in all.
As for Tujib, it is said she is a woman from Madhhij, daughter of Thawban bin Sulaym bin Ruha. Her children bin Ufayr bin Adi bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Udad (who is Abu Kindah) were attributed to her. Tujib gave birth in Al-Sukun bin Kindah, so they are the nobles of Al-Sukun.
It is said that Tujib are Adi and Sa'd sons of Ashras bin Shabib bin Al-Sukun, and their mother is Najib bint Thawban. Among them is Al-Tujibi, one of the killers of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, and his lineage has passed.
This is the lineage of Kindah, who is Thawr bin Ufayr bin Adi bin Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Udad bin Zaid bin Amr bin Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan. It is said Al-Harith bin Murrah bin Al-Harith bin Hadramaut bin Saba the Younger from Himyar. Allah knows best the truth.

This is the lineage of Kindah, which consists of two roots: Banu Mu'awiyah and Banu Al-Ashras. Al-Ashras begot two clans: Al-Sukun and Al-Sakasik, and we have mentioned them.
These are the famous tribes of Kahlan attributed to Zaid bin Kahlan. The children of Zaid are Malik and Urayb, as we mentioned. We attributed the children of Zaid to Malik, and Urayb to Zaid bin [Kahlan].
From the descendants of Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan are Al-Azd, Khath'am, Bajilah, and Hamdan. We have mentioned their tribes and clans.
From the descendants of Urayb bin Zaid bin Kahlan are Madhhij, Tayy, Al-Ash'ar, Lakhm, Judham, Amilah, and Kindah. We have mentioned their definition, tribes, and clans in their places in the book. Understand that, you will be correct, Allah Almighty willing.

**Lineage of Himyar**
His name is Al-Aranjaj bin Saba the Elder, whose name is Abd Shams bin Yashjub bin Ya'rub, who is Al-Muzdalif bin Qahtan bin Aber bin Shelah bin Arphaxad bin Shem bin Noah, peace be upon him.
Himyar had twelve children: Al-Hamisa', Malik, Urayb, Wa'il, Aws, Murrah. The famous lineage among his descendants is in Al-Hamisa' and Malik. Al-Hamisa' is the father of the Tubba' Kings, and [Mariylgha?] is their mother. Malik is the father of Quda'ah and its tribes.
We will mention of the lineage of Himyar what is most famous, leaning towards brevity, for Himyar are a vast creation and a large multitude. Time has passed over them, and they exceeded counting and calculation.
Most tribes of Himyar are from the descendants of Saba the Younger bin Ka'b bin Kahf Al-Zulm bin Sahl bin Zaid Al-Jumhur bin Amr bin Qais bin Mu'awiyah bin Jusham Al-Uzma bin Abd Shams the King bin Wa'il bin Al-Gharth bin Jaydan bin Qatan bin Urayb bin Zuhayr bin A'yan bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar the King.
We will start their lineage from the top and then descend to the last of them, Allah Almighty willing.
From the descendants of Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar are Al-Awra', Bumaysa', Al-Halim, Salim, Maswar, Yush, and Ayman.
From the descendants of Ayman is Zuhayr. From the descendants of Zuhayr bin Ayman are Mathub, Utbah, Al-Tajjah, Nakhlan, and Al-Ashru'.
From the descendants of Jaydan bin Qatan is Jaylan bin Ya'fur bin Shurahbil bin Ahmas bin Al-Awr bin Harir bin Qaytun bin Karkar bin Haydan bin Qatan.
Among them are Zaidan and Marran sons of Al-Harir bin Al-Rafi' bin Harir bin Qaytun.
Among them is the Prophet Hanzalah bin Safwan bin Sayfi (it is said Hanzalah bin Al-Afyun bin Al-Harith bin Qahtan). He was sent to four tribes of Qahtan who were in the East: Yar'u and Bal and Qadman sons of Yamin bin Qahtan, and Aslam and Abu Wra' sons of Al-Harith bin Qahtan. They denied him, killed him, and threw him into a well called Al-Rass. They are the ones Allah Almighty mentioned saying: {And the Companions of the Rass}. Some poets of Qahtan said about them:
"My eye wept for the people of Bar'wil and Qadman...
And Aslam and to Zar' basar to Qahtan."
Among them is the wife of the Prophet (peace be upon him), Qutwazah bint Basturah.
Among them is Radman bin Al-Gharth bin Haydan bin Qatan. (Repeated: From Radman bin Al-Gharth bin Haydan bin Qatan).
From the descendants of Radman bin Al-Gharth bin Jadan, and Al-Safa'ah bin Aws bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Amr bin Asuan bin Qarn bin Radman.
Among them are Banu Maljan bin Maljan bin Haydan: Nabhan, Adra', Al-Hurr, Falh, Labth, Husayn, and Juhays.
From the descendants of the King Zur'ah Dhu Manakh are Marwah, Al-Mawkif, Al-Qafa'ah, Al-Samdanah, Al-Suwwar, and Jusham.
From the descendants of Murrah bin Abd Shams are Kithamah, Ayhamah, Sanhajah, Lawatah [Lawathah], Zanatah, and Maratah. They are in the Maghreb and built Ifriqiya in the land of the Berbers. He left there these tribes from his people, so they multiplied there and became kings there. Ayhamah is also in Yemen.
From the descendants of Dhi Manakh is the Emir Ja'far bin Ibrahim bin Abi Ja'far bin Abdullah bin Abbas bin Shas bin Zur'ah bin Amir bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Amr bin Dhuhl bin Abdullah bin Wafid bin Shas bin Al-Aswad bin Majid bin Ka'b bin Zaid Yaksum bin Al-Aswad bin Majid bin Zur'ah Dhi Manakh bin Abd Shams the King. He is the owner of Mikhlaf Raymah, Al-Marjawah, and Al-Ta'kar. At that time it was attributed to him and called Mikhlaf Ibn Ja'far. He ruled in Yemen for fifty years, then the Qarmatian came in the year two hundred and seventy-one, killed him, and took his land. He has a story.

(Section) From the descendants of the King Al-Suwwar

His name is Zuhayr bin the King bin Abd Shams, the Tubba' Kings, and they are the Kings of Yahsub.
Among them is Sakht bin Zur'ah bin Al-Harith bin Yusuf Dhu Nuwas bin Amr bin the Tubba' Abi Karib As'ad Al-Kamil bin Kulaykarib (who is Hassan) bin Al-Ra'id (who is Al-Sa'b) bin the Tubba' Al-Akbar (who is Maymun Al-Aqran) bin Shams bin Abs bin Al-Suwwar bin Afriqis bin Abrahah Dhu al-Manar bin Al-Harith Al-Ra'ish bin Sadad bin Al-Maltat bin Amr bin Dhi Abyan bin the King bin Dhi Yaqdam bin the King Al-Suwwar.
Among them is Hassan bin Amr bin As'ad Al-Kamil.
Al-Kala'i said: Dhu Nuwas bin Hassan bin As'ad Al-Kamil is the Middle Tubba'.
Among them are Afriqis and Amr Dhu al-Adh'ar, sons of Abrahah Dhu al-Manar.
Yankaf bin Sa'd bin Yasir Yun'im bin Amr Dhu al-Adh'ar bin Abrahah Dhu al-Manar.

(Section) Among them are the Kings of Maswar, the family of Al-Muntab bin Amr bin Dhi Abyan. Among them is Dhu al-Janah bin Al-Attaf bin Al-Mithqab wa Al-Manjum bin Malik bin Zaid bin Ghalib bin Al-Muntab.
From the descendants of Shahr the Elder is Shahr Dhu al-Janah the Younger bin Shurahbil bin Yaghfar bin Al-Harith bin Shams Dhu al-Janah the Elder from the heart [descendants?] of As'ad Al-Kamil.
From Banu Al-Maltat is the father of Bilqis the Queen, who is Al-Hadhhad Abi Sharh bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Al-Ra'is bin Sadad bin Al-Maltat bin Amr bin Dhi Yaqdam bin the King Al-Suwwar.
It is said Al-Hadhhad bin Abi Sharh bin Shurahbil bin Yazid bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Saba the Younger. His daughters are Bilqis and Shams.
Among them is Bazil bin Shurahbil bin Amr Dhi Ghamdan bin Al-Sarh Yahsub.
Among them are the Amalekites of Himyar, father of Al-Zabba' the Queen. She is Na'ilah bint Amr bin Zarib bin Hassan bin Adhniyah bin Al-Samayda' bin Hawbar bin Urayb bin Mazin bin Rab'i the King (who is Bar bin Al-Amliq bin Al-Samayda' bin Al-Suwwar). The Amalekites were kings of Sham and are not from the children of Amlaq bin Ludh bin Shem.

(Section) From the descendants of Amrah bin Qais bin Mu'awiyah bin Jusham Al-Uzma is Sha'b the Elder bin Amr bin Sha'ban bin Amr bin Qais.
Among them is the Jurist from whom Hadith and narrations are attributed, Amir bin Shurahbil bin Qatan bin Al-Sha'b the Younger bin Shurahbil bin Hassan bin Al-Sha'b the Elder. This Sha'b is in Wadi Nakhlah from Himyar. Al-Sha'b the Younger is in Kufa from Hamdan. And Al-Sha'b from Azd. And Al-Sha'b is a group from Al-Asha'irah. He said: Hamdan claims that Al-Sha'bi is one of them.
He said: From Al-Ush'ub are Al-Adahib. They are Banu Abi Himyar, Banu Kurayj, Banu Hudays, Banu Hubayl, Banu Hudays [repeat], Banu Hubayl [repeat], and Banu Husayn. They are in Yemen in Wadi Nakhlah and its vicinity.
Among them is Tanukh (other than Tanukh of Quda'ah) and Al-Jashi' and Al-Sayyid, sons of Thabit bin Ziyad bin Hayyan bin Dhi al-Sha'bayn bin Al-Sha'b the Elder.

(Section) From the descendants of Zaid Al-Jumhur is Shar'ab bin Sahl, to whom the Shar'abi spears are attributed. Al-Shara'ib are two clans gathered by Al-Kalathimah and Al-Karadimah. The origin of Al-Shara'ib is in Wadi Nakhlah, and those in Wafat are from the land of Hajur. The land of Banu Zaid bin Hajar is Far'. Banu Zaid bin A'shab bin Uwayhim [?], and that is false. The origin of Al-Shara'ib is Al-Shammakh, Amir, Al-Harith, Aqarib, and Al-Hamatah, sons of Shar'ab.
Among them are Banu Hisham, Banu Mari', Banu Amr Yathban Ba'nah (they are Banu Abi Himyar), and Banu Ibrahim.

(Section) Among them is the family of Dhu Ru'ayn the Elder, who is Tarnam bin Sahl bin Zaid Al-Jumhur.
Among them is the delegate to the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), Al-Harith bin Abd Kulal bin Mu'awiyah bin Urayb bin Mu'awiyah bin Ma'di bin Al-Harith bin Zaid bin Yarim bin Malik bin I'tidhar bin Yarim Dhu Ru'ayn.
From the descendants of Al-Shuraha is the family of Al-Mahdi: Kings of Anmar and Shuraha bin Shurahbil bin Tarnam bin Sha'ban Dhi Harth bin Al-Harith bin Zaid bin Yarim Dhu Ru'ayn. They are Kings of Musab.
Among them is Mathub bin Dhi Harth, who are Sha'ban bin Al-Harith bin Zaid to the end of the lineage.
From the descendants of Dhi Harth are the Shurahiyyun, Kings of Wasab.
Among them are Al-Amluk bin Al-Harith bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Yartham Dhu Ru'ayn.
Among them is Dhu Ru'ayn the Younger, who is Shurahbil bin Jusham bin Al-Gharth bin Yankaf bin Jaydan bin Lahi'ah bin Mathub bin Dhi Ru'ayn the Elder.
Among them is the Prophet Salih bin Al-Hamisa' bin Dhi Mazin bin Jaydan bin Al-Harij bin Zaid bin Yarim Dhu Ru'ayn. He was a prophet not a messenger. It is said Salih was his slave. In the report, Ali bin Abi Talib said: "Thaqif was a slave of Salih, and Muhammad is the heir of Salih, and I am the heir of Muhammad, so who will buy Thaqif from me for a precious price?" He said: Sa'id bin Al-Sabbaq bin Qais Al-Hamdani bought him from him.

Among them is Ka'b al-Ahbar bin Mani' bin Harsa' bin Dhi Hajun bin Muqsim bin Mathub bin Dhi Ru'ayn the Elder.
He said: Among them is Yafi' bin Qatil bin Zaid bin Lassah bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Yarim bin Dhi Ru'ayn. Yafi' is the bravest house in Himyar, but their horsemen are few.
