They are Al-Athrun, Awdan, Al-Tarahim, Banu Hashid, Al-Ay'ud, Bayt Shu'ayb, Bayt Khayr, Al-Sawin (people of the sea), Banu Al-Saba, Banu Al-Ayil, Al-Aryum, Al-Asdud, and Al-Asrun. They have wealth.
The nobles of Yafi' are Banu Ahmad bin Abd al-Jabbar bin Abdullah bin Ziyad bin Asim bin Marthad bin Yafsil bin Dhi Hibas bin Al-Nadir bin Yarim the Younger bin Amr bin Mahatt bin Dhi Yarn bin Yarim the Elder bin Shurahbil bin Yafi'.
Among them are Banu Walid Bakhran. They are brave and generous, from the descendants of Yafi' bin Amr bin Murrah bin Dhi Yarn bin Yarim the Elder bin Shurahbil bin Yafi'.
He said: From the descendants of Zaid Al-Jumhur is Sayban (with Sin unpointed; what remains in Arabs is Shayban with Shin pointed). He is Sayban bin Al-Gharth bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sahl bin Zaid bin Qais bin Mu'awiyah bin Jusham Al-Uzma. It is the clan of Yahya bin Abi Amr and Al-Shaybani.
The tribes of Dhi Ru'ayn are Al-Uklul, Al-Amluk, Yafi', Kahlan, and Banu Walid.

**Lineage of Saba the Younger**
Saba the Younger had children: Himyar the Younger (who is Zur'ah), Hadramaut, Al-Hamisa', Awf, Ma'bad, Marbah, and Banatah among others.
From the descendants of Himyar the Younger bin Saba the Younger are Sadad (with Sin unpointed), Sayghi, Al-Salaf, Al-Fayyad, Huwal, Al-Hamisa', Al-Wasiyah, Dhu Afyan, Awf, and Sa'd.
From them is Al-Ma'raf, who is Amr bin Mu'awiyah bin Allaq bin Sadad bin Zur'ah (who is Himyar the Younger).
Among them is Al-Baz bin Muhammad bin Dhi Asbal bin Dhi Afyan bin Zur'ah.

(Section) From the family of Jayfar and his son Al-Harith bin Zur'ah bin Yasar bin Abi Amr bin Sayfi bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
From the descendants of Jayfar are Al-Nu'man, Abd al-Malik, Rawh, Al-Hawari, Al-Zaba', Ja'far, Al-Fadl, Al-Nadal, and Muhammad, sons of Jayfar.
The mother of Jayfar is Al-Dhalfa' bint Zur'ah bin Sadad bin Zaid bin Qais bin Sayfi bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
From his descendants is Ibrahim bin Al-Fadl bin Jayfar bin Sa'dah, and Banu Abd al-Malik bin Jayfar.
From the descendants of Yasar bin Jayfar is Muhammad bin Aban bin Maymun bin Jarir bin Hujr bin Zur'ah bin Amr bin Hujr bin Dhi Shammar bin Abd Shams bin Yasar bin Jayfar. He led the war against Ma'n bin Za'idah and resisted him in Sa'dah and took revenge for Amr bin Zaid Al-Ubali because Ma'n had killed him.
Among them is Al-Abyad bin Hammal, for whom the Prophet (peace be upon him) stood up and spread his cloak and said: "If the noble of a people comes to you, honor him." He granted him the Mountain of Salt in the plain of Ma'rib. It was said to him: "O Messenger of Allah, you granted him the fresh water [salt that is like fresh water in abundance], and there is no salt for the people of Yemen other than it." So he asked him to return it, and he returned it. The name of Al-Abyad bin Hammal is Al-Harith bin Murid bin Dhi Lajban bin Amir bin Dhi Al-Anbar bin Hafan bin Shurahbil bin Ma'dan bin Malik bin Dhi Sam bin Zaid bin Jahlan bin Awf bin Amr bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
It is said that Banu Al-Karandi are from his descendants in Al-Basa. And from Banu Ammah bin Dhi Al-Kala' in Al-Ana.
From Banu Al-Karandi are the Kings of Al-Ma'afir from the time of Al-Mansur to today. Among them is Sultan Ya'fur bin Sultan Al-Sayyid bin Sultan Abdullah bin Emir Ahmad bin Emir Ja'far bin Emir Isma'il bin Emir Ahmad bin Emir Muhammad Al-Karandi bin Abdullah bin Abs bin Thumamah bin Uqayb bin Haram bin Al-Abyad bin Al-Hammal.

(Section) Among them is Dhu Fayish, who is Salamah the Qayl (Chief) bin Dhi Bahr bin Dhi Fayish the Elder bin Salamah bin Zaid bin Murrah bin Urayb bin Marthad bin Maryam bin Wudd bin Yusuf bin Baris bin Yahsub bin Wahman bin Malik bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
From the descendants of Yahsub are Jahran, Radman, and Nahr, sons of Al-Harith bin Yahsub. Among them are the Naba'iyyun in Yemen from the family of Dhu Taba' bin Malik bin Al-Harith bin Al-Sarh bin Yahsub.
He said: Naba' in Himyar (with Nun before Ba). And Dhu in Yahsub (with Ba with one dot before Ta with two dots above) [Yuhsab? text unclear].
He said: Yahsub is attributed to two men: Yahsub Duman and Yahsub Marhab. They are between Ajul and Zubid from the land of Al-Wahsh. Duman is bin Dahman bin Malik bin Sa'd.

(Section) Among them are the family of Dhu Huwal

Umm Ashyam then Kahlan. Among them is the knight of Himyar in his age and the uprooter of the Qarmatian veins in his era, Emir As'ad bin Abi Ya'fur Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Ya'fur bin Uthman bin [Abd] Rahman bin Kurayb bin Al-Waddah bin Ibrahim bin Mani' bin Awf bin Badr Hayy (who is Al-Fayyad bin Amir bin Dhi Huwal the Younger bin Awsajah bin Abi Rad bin Al-Sharmah bin Dhi Huwal the Elder bin Thuraym bin Dhi Mikar Al-Hayman, who is Yahmad bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger).
Among them is Abdullah bin Qahtan bin Abdullah bin Abi Ya'fur, owner of Kahlan, who supported the Ash'aris against Emir Ibn Ziyad in Zubid.
Among them are Uthman, Al-Husayn, Abdullah, Ubayd, Abd Al-Hakim, Abd Al-Wahhab, Abd Al-Qahir, Abd Al-Aziz, and Abd Al-Samad, sons of Ahmad bin Ya'fur bin Abd al-Rahman bin Kurayb.
Among them is Hassan bin Uthman bin Abd al-Rahman. He is the one who rose against Al-Nasir Ahmad bin Yahya bin Al-Husayn Al-Alawi in Sa'dah, seized his power, and ruled Sa'dah. He is the grandfather of the Awasiq in Harash. He is Ahmad bin Yazid bin Amr bin Thabit bin Al-Dayyan bin Amr bin Al-Musayyib bin Amr bin Nasib bin Awsajah. Thabit bin Al-Dayyan is the one who entered into the peace between Himyar and Sayf bin Dhi Yazan and the family of Dhu Manakh and Hadramaut.
From the descendants of Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad are Yazid, Sa'd, Adi, Al-Harith, Qabab, Alhan, Dhu Maqar, Wisab, and Khawlan Abi.
Among them is Al-Awza' bin Yazid bin Malik; among them is the jurist Abd al-Rahman Al-Awza'i.
As for Khawlan bin Malik, they are different from Khawlan bin Amr bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah. Among them are the Suhaymiyyun in the nobility of Khawlan.
Others said Khawlan is from Dhi Asbah.
Abu Nasr said: Khawlan bin Amr bin Malik bin Sahl, and he knows best what he says.
Al-Azhari said: Malik bin Sahl begot Amr, Asran, Hakim, and Ka'b, all clans. Others said: And Abdullah as well.
Abdullah begot Al-Sa'b Dhu al-Qarnayn bin Abdullah bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
It is said Dhu al-Qarnayn is from Kahlan, who is Al-Sa'b bin Jabir bin Al-Gharth bin Al-Nabit bin Malik bin Zaid bin Kahlan.
The second is Dhu al-Qarnayn Al-Ruhi, who is Alexander who built Alexandria, other than the one we mentioned.
The third is Amr bin Hind, called Dhu al-Qarnayn for two horns (plaits/bumps) on his head.
As for Ans bin Malik: From it are the monuments of Himyar: Thab, Hakar, Mawkal, Amniq, and Aqbal. The clans of Ans are these: Saran, Zabyan, Al-Nawm, Madamah, and Adanah in this homeland. Today from Ans of Madhhij are four clans. And Al-Qariyah are children of Kanar. And Fahd and Tays are children of Saghar.
Section: Among them are the family of Dhu Asbah, who is Al-Harith bin Malik bin Zaid bin Al-Gharth bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger. He was named Dhu Asbah because a king of Himyar sent him to a tribe near him and ordered him not to sleep until he raided them in the morning (yusbihahum), but he slept and woke up (asbaha) before reaching the people. So Himyar said: Al-Harith Asbaha (woke up in the morning).
The Asbahi whips are attributed to Dhu Asbah because he was the first to punish by whipping, so they were attributed to him.
From the descendants of Dhu Asbah are Amr, Abdullah, and Rafi'.
Amr begot Musbih, Jubayl, Nuwayrah, Hassan, and Talha.
Abdullah begot Al-Awd (to whom Mount Al-Awd in the region of Sajlan is attributed), Al-Qabid, Al-Masahuh, and Al-Baqir.
From them is Abrahah bin Al-Sabah bin Shurahbil bin Lahi'ah bin Mazid Al-Khayr bin Yankaf bin Tanuf bin Shurahbil bin Ma'di Karib bin Musbih bin Amr bin Al-Harith Dhu Asbah.
Among them is the jurist of Medina, Imam Malik bin Anas

bin Abi Amir bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Uthman bin Jubayl bin Amr bin Dhi Asbah. He is the teacher of Imam Muhammad bin Idris Al-Shafi'i.
From Yankaf Tanuf are Banu Abi Al-Araf Bahrran, who is from the descendants of Al-Walid bin Dhi Yar'ash bin Dhi Suhaym bin Khawlan Yankaf Tanuf.
Abu Nasr said: Abrahah bin Al-Sabah begot Ma'di Karib, Shurahbil, Nuwayrah, Masah, and Bahr.
Ma'di Karib from Abrahah begot Tarim. Tarim Al-Nadr, master of the people of Sham, led. His mother is Saffah bint Ma'bad bin Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib. He is the one who raided Ifriqiya. Al-Nadir is the son of the cousin of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). There were many births between Quraysh and Al-Sabah.
Shurahbil bin Abrahah begot Abrahah the Younger. Abrahah the Younger begot Al-Qasim (who was the delegate to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, and was killed with Ali - may Allah be pleased with him - at Siffin), Karina, Kariman, Shurahbil, Ubar, Yaghfar, Muhammad, and Al-Hajjaj Al-Sabah. They migrated to Sham in the Caliphate of Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him.
Bujayr bin Abrahah begot the one coming to Iraq in the days of Ya'fur bin Abd al-Rahman Al-Hawali, and he held the police of Muhammad bin Ya'fur, and was a generous poet.
Bujayr begot - also - Ibrahim bin Fahn bin Bujayr. He is the one whom Hashim bin Abdullah bin Malik Al-Khuza'i appointed as deputy over Yemen when Muhammad Al-Amin bin Harun Al-Rashid appointed him over it. He said: Then he appointed after that him and Al-Umr bin Abbad Al-Shihabi Yazid bin Jarir bin Abdullah Al-Qushayri. Al-Hamdani said: When Iyad bin Al-Umr Al-Shihabi appointed deputies over Sana'a, he appointed Abdullah bin Ubaydullah owner of Al-Raymah in Shawwal year two hundred and eighteen, when the news of Al-Ma'mun's death reached him, so he went to Iraq.
He said: From the descendants of Bujayr is Rahmah bin Bujayr, who held the judiciary in Sana'a during the governorship of Umayr bin Al-Rabi' bin Abdullah Al-Madani in the days of Al-Saffah.
From the descendants of Bujayr is Ahmad bin Hafs, who governed Sana'a for Muhammad bin Ya'fur.
He said: In Abrahah are the Abbasids from the descendants of Abbas bin Nawf bin Murr bin Dhi Shahim.

(Section) Among them is Dhu Jadan, who is Alqamah bin Al-Harith bin Zaid bin Al-Gharth bin Al-Ashraf bin Sa'd bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
From them is Al-Nu'man bin Mu'awiyah bin Shurahbil bin Shas bin Yaghuth bin Alqamah bin Dhi Jadan bin Aslam bin Zaid bin A'la bin Alqamah bin Jadan.
Among them is Alqamah bin Dhi Fayfan bin Dhi Tij bin Dhi Qayfan bin Mu'adiyah bin Shurahbil to the end of the lineage.
Section: Among them are Al-Tarahim, and they are nobles of Himyar. About them the poet says:
"People are Himyar and Al-Tarahim are its head...
And your father is its eyeball and you are the pupil."
Among them is Dhu Tarakhum, who is Zur'ah bin Tarim bin Dhi Al-Rumhayn bin Yaghfar bin Bimajrad [?] bin Salim bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger. The brother of Tarakhum is Najd Dhu Al-Anwaj, who is Adhniyah bin Tarim Dhi Al-Rumhayn.
From the descendants of Shurahbil bin Al-Harith bin Malik are Bilqis and Shams, daughters of Al-Hadhhad bin Abi Sharh bin Shurahbil bin Yazid bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith.
Among them is Al-Munsib bin Nawf Dhi Tha'laban bin Shurahbil bin Al-Harith.
And Dhu Athkalan and Dhu Khalil, brother of Dhi Tha'laban, from the descendants of Al-Harith bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
Section: Among them is the family of Dhu Al-Kala'. Among them is the companion of Siffin, Dhu Al-Kala' the Younger Yazid bin Amr bin Kur bin Zaid bin Shurahbil bin Al-Aswad (who is the grandfather of Banu Wa'il, Kings of Wahazah) bin Amr bin Malik bin Zaid Dhu Al-Kala' the Elder bin Ya'fur bin Yazid bin Al-Nu'man bin Zaid bin Shihal bin Wahazah bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
Al-Aswad is also the grandfather of Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Kala'i, author of the poem in which he boasts.
Dhu Al-Kala' the Younger freed his slaves, who were twenty thousand souls. Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, said to him: "Bakh Bakh (Bravo) to you." He said: "I do not think it expiates my sin; that is because I was absent from people for forty days, so two hundred thousand prostrated to me."
Among them is Yankaf bin Zur'ah bin Yaghfar bin Al-Sumay'ah. Al-Sumayfa' bin Ya'fur bin Bakur.
Among them is Dhu Suhaym, who is Murr bin Amir bin Al-Harith bin Zaid bin Murrah bin Suhaym. The Umaris are chiefs by designation of Sa'dah.

Among them is the poet Al-Sayf Al-Himyari, who is Isma'il bin Muhammad bin Yazid bin Ziyad bin Ziyad bin Rabi'ah, the clan of Yazid bin Mufarrigh. Al-Kala' are numerous in Yemen, and most of them are in Sham.
In Jabal Sabr are Banu Al-Mu'allim bin Abd al-Rahman bin Shurahbil bin Ya'fur bin Bakur.
In Hajjah are Banu Al-Shami from the descendants of Muhammad bin Ibrahim bin Abd al-Rahim bin Abdullah bin Abd al-Rahman bin Shurahbil bin Ya'fur bin Bakur.
Among them is a group in the land of Ayan.
Among them are the Abbasids of Surdad and Al-Hattal the Astronomers of Tur, from the descendants of Bujayr bin Risan bin Sa'dan bin Ma'di bin Zura'ah bin Thumamah bin Al-Aswad bin Amr bin Malik.
He said: Al-Kala' is a verbal noun. Clans from Himyar gathered and 'Takalla'at'. Takallu' is gathering, like Tashakkul, Taqarrush, and Tahassud, meaning one. They gathered to ally in adjacent homelands in the land of Himyar, and they gathered to be neighbors. Most homelands are named after their owner. These clans allied under the leadership of the Qayl (Chief) Ibn Al-Nu'man bin Zaid bin Shihal bin Wahazah. They were eighteen tribes. Muhammad bin Al-Hasan bin Ahmad bin Ya'qub Al-Hamdani mentioned they were nineteen tribes, and included Manah bin Abd Shams among them.
These are the names of the tribes: Wahazah and Maytam sons of Sa'd bin Awf. Al-Sahul and Al-Jayir sons of Sawadah bin Amr bin Awf. Rayman, Gharwan, Ba'dan (he and Jusham Al-Uzma bin Abd Shams bin Wa'il). Al-Ashru', Nakhlan, Uran, and Anan, sons of Mathub bin Urayb bin Zuhayr bin Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar. Zibja', Takalim, Takil, Nahik, and Zinba', sons of Urayb the Younger bin Haywan bin Qatan Urayb the Elder bin Zuhayr bin Ayman bin Al-Hamisa' bin Himyar. And Al-Tafa'ah bin Abd bin the King Al-Suwwar bin Wa'il the King.
These tribes allied (Takalla'at) upon Zaid bin Al-Nu'man bin Yazid bin Shihal bin Wahazah and made him a Qayl for them in the time of Tubba' Al-Aqran Malik As'ad bin Malik the First. Then he made Yazid bin Ya'fur bin Yazid bin Al-Nu'man a Qayl over these divisions of tribes, so Yazid was named Dhu Al-Kala' meaning (Leader of the Kala'). He was on the right wing of Tubba' when he invaded the land of Persia. Regarding that As'ad the Tubba' says:
"And We placed on the Right Flank
Brother of War, Dhu Al-Kala' Yazid.
Rashid in command in war and endeavor
Neither reckless, hasty nor cowardly."

Section: Among them are the family of Dhu Yazan, to whom Yazani spears are attributed. Among them is Kamdir the Younger bin Ghafir the Middle bin Zura'ah bin Ghafir the Elder bin Amir bin Dhi Yazan the Elder bin Aslam bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Yazid bin Al-Gharth bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Yazid bin Sadad bin Zura'ah bin Amir bin Sayf the Younger.
Dhu Yazan married the daughter of As'ad Al-Kamil, so by that birth the family of Dhu Yazan attained the kingship of Yemen.
Among them is the flood of generosity Murrah bin Awf bin Ma'di Karib bin Sayf the Elder bin Amir bin Dhi Yazan. His wealth was looted due to his intense generosity [Manhaban?].
Among them is Al-Thamar bin Farmal bin Amr bin Sinan bin Al-Gharth bin Sa'd bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
Among them is the family of Dhu Baghamah, who is Amr bin Amir bin Amr bin Al-Nu'man bin Qais bin Ubayd bin Al-Sayf the Elder.
He said: The family of Dhu Yazan are between Al-Haj and Marjah, and they are Al-Athrun. Lunays Biljaj Muhammad bin Isma'il was a noble master.
They have large numbers and huge crowds in Hadramaut and Yemen, and many of them are in Homs and Sham.
Among them is the family of Dhu Yahr the Younger, who is Yaghfar bin Zaid bin Shurahbil bin Shamir bin Zur'ah bin Shurahbil bin Awf bin Ya'fur bin Al-Harith bin Sharh Al Yaghfar Dhi Yahr the Elder bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Malik bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
Among them is the genealogist Abu Nasr Muhammad Abdullah bin Sa'id bin Ubaydullah bin Muhammad bin Wahb Al Shurahbil bin Ghuraib bin Wahb bin Al-Zaid Dhi Yahr the Younger.
Among them is Hadur bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
Among them is the Prophet Shu'ayb, peace be upon him, bin Dhi Mahdam bin Al-Muqaddam bin Hadur. Allah - Exalted - sent him to the people of Hadur, but they killed him. When they heard a caller saying:
"A people will know who fought Allah openly...
Even if they plotted, He was stronger and more cunning.
Thus Allah misguides he who has a disease in his heart..."
So Allah sent the Prophet Marhaba from the tribe of Judah bin Jacob to Nebuchadnezzar and ordered him to invade the Arabs who killed their prophet among them, so Allah - Exalted - destroyed them at his hands.
Hadur is a mountain in Yemen containing his grave and his house known as Bayt Shu'ayb today. As for Hadur Yanasib, it is in Shardad Wadi Al-Mahjam.
He said: From the descendants of Hadur is Dhu Ridwan, and the Ridwanis today are in Al-Hajadib. And Yaris (with Ya with two dots below) and Al-Sabun [?]. And Taris (with Ta with two dots above) from Hadramaut.

Among them are Al-An'um from the descendants of Nu'aym bin Hadur, Shari' bin Hadur. And Sari' in Yemen in Radman, and Sari' in Al Afyan. Sari' is a valley between La'ah and Surdad. From the descendants of Hadur are Salih, Matih, Warhan, and Samar Naba'.
From the descendants of Malik bin Zaid are Saqr Abd Sam'an bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Zaid bin Sadad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
From the descendants of Mudar is Al-Gharth, bin Ghiyath bin Mughith bin Al-Gharth bin Sam'an bin Zaid bin Manfa.

(Section) Among them are Al-Salaf and Al-Fayyad sons of Ghiyab bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger. From the descendants of Al-Salaf are Dhu Sarman, Dhu Warhan, and Nawal, sons of Al-Salaf. And Mudrij bin Marthad bin Dhi Yamin Dar'an bin Al-Salaf. Among them are Al-Hajawib Bahrain, Banu Hajdab bin Naqil bin Nawal bin Al-Salaf.
From the descendants of Al-Fayyad are Al-Surad, Al-Uruf, and Awf, sons of Hatban bin Balad bin Al-Fayafi.
Among them are Al-Diyhiyun from the descendants of Dhi Ribh bin Awf bin Hatban bin Balad bin Al-Fayyad bin Zur'ah bin Saba the Younger.
It is said that Al-Fayafi is from Al-Salaf and not from Al-Zur'ah, but he is son of his father.
From the descendants of Zur'ah bin Saba are Asal. As for Al-Sharaf and Ghalib, they are sons of Dhi Aqban bin Zur'ah. Al-Hamisa' and Al-Maharif are sons of Zur'ah (who is Himyar the Younger bin Saba the Younger).

(Section) From the descendants of Hadramaut bin Saba the Younger are Al-Harith, Murrah, Shabib, and Rabi'.
From them are Tarim, Sham, and Saba. They are Al-Asba' in Hadramaut, many tribes entered into them from the descendants of Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid. And from the descendants of Al-Sahul.
From the descendants of Al-Gharth bin Sa'd bin Awf are Al-Akhruj, Haraz, Himyar, Na'lan, Al-Mu'allal, Al-Ghayum, Sahnan, Yasar, Hawzan, Al-Rahbah, and Jil, sons of Al-Gharth bin Sa'd bin Awf bin Adi bin Malik bin Zaid bin Al-Harith bin Hadramaut.
From the descendants of Al-Rahbah bin Al-Gharth are Dhamar, Luqman, Marib, Asbah, Ghassan, and Da'wan.
From the descendants of Haraz bin Al-Gharth are Jusham, Sahih, Sadab, and Nun.
As for Himyar bin Al-Gharth, he is Himyar Al-Adli, son of Hadramaut, neither Himyar the Elder nor Himyar the Younger. He is counted among their minor ones, people of Atamah and people of eloquence. They are many in Egypt and Ifriqiya.
From the descendants of Hadramaut are Shiyam, Tarim, Burs, and Nu'aym, sons of Hassan (who is Abd bin Hadaq) bin Al-Harith bin Hadramaut.
Among them is Saba, who is Al-Asba'. Among them is Muhammad bin Amr bin Abdullah bin Zaid, killer of Ma'n bin Za'idah Al-Shaybani.
He said: Among them is Dhu Awsan, who is Amr bin Amir bin Mu'awiyah bin Qais bin Wa'il bin Marthad bin Qais bin Murrah bin Hadramaut.
Among them is the genealogist Al-Awsani, from whom Al-Hasan bin Ya'qub Al-Hamdani narrated. He is Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Isma'il bin Muhammad bin Qais bin Amr bin Dhi Awsan.
From the descendants of Dhu Awsan are Ba'la and Sahrah.
Dhu Awsan gave his wealth in Wadi Zahr as charity entirely, and made it food for whoever passed the road, rich or poor. That was in Jahiliyyah, then Islam came and it continued like that to this day. The yield of this wealth gathered in a year from dates, barley, and grapes was sixty thousand dinars.
This which we mentioned are the prominent clans of Himyar.
Most of them are from the descendants of Saba the Younger. They are: Al Jayfar, Al Al-Abyad bin Al-Hammal (Al-Karandiyyun), Dhu Fayish, Usayb (who is Al-Anbu'), Jahran, Dhamar, and Sha'r.
Among them is the family of Dhu Juwal, from whom are Al-Awasij. Dhu Maqar, Musab, Ans, and Khawlan (from whom is Al-Awza'). The family of Dhu Asbah. Among them are Banu Abi Al-Uddab Najraz.
The Abbasids from the descendants of Abrahah. Dhu Jadan, from whom are Dhu Fayfan and Al-Sha'rani. Among them are Al-Tarahim, Dhu Tha'laban, Dhu Atkalan, Dhu Khalil, and Dhu Sirwah. Among them are the family of Dhu Al-Kala' and Al-Kala'. Among them are Dhu Yazan, the family of Dhu Yazan, the family of Dhu Yahr, the family of Hadur, Al-Salaf, Al-Fayyad, Maqra, and Alhan.
These are gathered by Mundhir bin Zur'ah (who is Himyar the Younger bin Saba the Younger).
Among them is Hadramaut bin Saba the Younger, gathering Al-Asba', and Dhu Asan. These are all descendants of Saba the Younger.
From the tribes of Himyar are a group from that: The Tubba' Kings, they are from the descendants of Yaqdam. And the family of Al-Muntab, Kings of Husur.
The descendants of the King Abd Shams: among them are Al-Ashmus, the family of Dhu Manakh, Kithamah, Abhamah, Sanhajah, Zananah, Lawathah, and Maranah. Among them are the Amalekites, Al-Asha'ub, Al-Adahib, and Al-Shara'ib; from them are Banu Mari' and Tanukh. From him is Dhu Ru'ayn. From them are Al-Amluk, Al-Uklul, Yafi', Banu Walid, Kahlan, and Al-Shuraha. This is what we mentioned of the tribes of Himyar.
He said: From Himyar are Al-Aqyal Al-Abahilah and Al-Adwa' Al-Mathaminah.
As for Al-Aqyal, from them is the strength of armies. Al-Abahilah are those left to their opinion. Al-Mufhal [Al-Abhal] is the sent one who does what he wants. In the Hadith, the Prophet (peace be upon him) wrote to the Aqyal Al-Abahilah from the people of Hadramaut.

As for Al-Adwa', it is everyone whose name begins with (Dhu), such as Dhi Manakh, Dhi Ru'ayn, Dhi Al-Kala', Dhi Maqar, Dhi Yahr, Dhi Sahar, Dhi Murrah, Dhi Tha'laban, Dhi Athkalan, Dhi Khalil, Dhi Tarah, Dhi Fayfan, Dhi Yazan, Dhi Asbah, Dhi Tarakhum, Dhi Yahsub, and Dhi Fayish, among others too long to mention. They are of the status of Emirs.
As for Al-Thaminah (the Eight), they are eight from Himyar. When Sayf Dhi Yazan died, the people of Yemen were returned to these eight houses: Al Dhi Yazan, Al Khalil, Al Athkalan, Al Dhi Tha'laban, Al Dhi Ma'ahir, and Al Dhi Jadan [only 6 listed?]. The greatest of them was Al Dhi Yazan due to the birth of Abi Karib As'ad Al-Kamil to them (Bani As'ad Al-Kamil), and Al Dhi Manakh because they are the uncles of the Tubba's. The other six houses used to see superiority over them.
He said: Kingship among the people of Yemen was in seven categories: (Himyar, Azd, Hamdan, Bajilah, Kindah, Tayy, and Lakhm). That is mentioned in places of the book, so understand that.

**Lineage of Quda'ah**
He is Ibn Malik bin Amr bin Murrah bin Zaid bin Malik bin Himyar. The derivation of Quda'ah is from 'Qad'', which is overcoming, because they overcame. The name of Quda'ah was Amr. It is said he was called Quda'ah Amr, then when the might of his people was shattered (Taqadda'a), i.e., went far, he was named Quda'ah.
People differed regarding the lineage of Quda'ah: A group said Quda'ah bin Ma'ad bin Adnan. He is Bakrah, and was nicknamed by it. It is said Quda'ah is a woman from Jurhum whom Ma'ad bin Adnan married, then Malik bin Amr succeeded upon her, and she gave birth to Quda'ah on the bed of Malik, so he was attributed to Malik. Arabs used to attribute men to their mother's husband, as they attributed Banu Abd Manat bin Kinanah to Ali bin Mas'ud Al-Azdi because he succeeded Abd Manat bin Kinanah upon his wife, and children were born to him from her, so he nursed his children and Abd Manat's children from her, so they were all attributed to him, and were called Banu Ali. Likewise, Sa'd Hudhaym from Quda'ah is Sa'd bin Zaid, Hudhaym nursed him so he was attributed to his nurse. Likewise, Ukl nursed Banu Awf bin Qais bin Wa'il bin Awf bin Abd Manat, so they were attributed to their nurses. As for Ghusayn, Bulan nursed him so it prevailed over his name. Aswadan, Nabhan nursed him so it prevailed over his name. Tha'labah, a woman called Jurhum nursed him so it prevailed over his name.
It is said that Mu'anah Al-Jurhumiyyah was under Amr bin Malik bin Murrah bin Zaid bin Malik bin Himyar and bore Quda'ah. Then Ma'ad bin Adnan married her. She was from the people of Mecca. The Himyari married her at the time of Hajj, then Ma'ad bin Adnan married her after him, and she bore him Nizar. Quda'ah was raised with his brother Nizar in the lap of Ma'ad bin Adnan, so he was attributed to him.
Others said: Quda'ah is son of Himyar. This is what people are upon today, and is famous among them.
Al-Aflah bin Ya'qub Al-Quda'i from the descendants of Abd Manat from Mashja'ah bin Al-Taym bin Al-Nahr bin Barrah said: "We are Banu Al-Sheikh Al-Hayjan Al-Azhari, Quda'ah bin Malik bin Himyar. The lineage is known, not denied; whoever says other than it will not be supported."
"O caller, call us and rejoice...
And be Quda'i and do not be Nizari."
He said: The reason for the departure of Quda'ah bin Ma'ad [sic] bin Khuzaymah bin Zaid Al-Quda'i is that he loved Fatimah bint Yadhkur bin Anazah bin Asad bin Rabi'ah bin Nizar. He is the one who said:
"When Al-Jauza' was followed by Al-Thurayya...
I thought thoughts about the family of Fatimah."
He said: So he proposed to her father, but he refused to marry her to him. Her father used to come between them. One day he and her father were absent gathering Qaraz. Khuzaymah killed him and hid his news. They asked him about him, he said: My last meeting with him was that he came to one of the two Qarizs about whom Abu Dhu'ayb says:
"Until the two Qarizs return, both of them...
And Kulayb is resurrected for Wa'il."
He said: His news was hidden from his people until Khuzaymah bin Nahd said:
"A girl, on her mouth was wine...
Mixed with ginger.
I killed her father for her love...
Will that facilitate closeness or will I attain [?]."
Then Rabi'ah knew of his killing him, so war and fighting erupted between them until Khuzaymah was killed. Quda'ah left their homes; they used to dwell from Mecca and Ta'if, while Rabi'ah dwelt at Marr Asfan. Quda'ah scattered in Sham and denied Ma'ad bin Adnan and attributed themselves to Al-Namir.
Al-Sharqi bin Al-Qatami said: Quda'ah remained in Ma'ad in Jahiliyyah and early Islam until the days of Ibn al-Zubayr and Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. Seditions and raids occurred between Umair bin Al-Hubab Al-Sulami against Kalb, and raids of Humayd bin Al-Harith bin Harb bin Bajdal Al-Kalbi against Fazarah. So Quda'ah allied with the people of Yemen, and the lineage of Yemen prevailed over Quda'ah.

Muhammad bin Habib said: The lineage of Quda'ah was only corrupted by the war that was between Sham in the days of Humayd bin Hurayth and Umair bin Al-Hubab. That is because Khalid bin Zaid bin Mu'awiyah was opposing Banu Marwan and those who supported them, and fanatical against them. He said to his maternal uncles from Kalb, who are the masters of Quda'ah: "Obey me" - and he was obeyed among them - "and ally with Yemen and attribute yourselves to them, for you will humiliate the rule of Banu Marwan and those who support them from Qais Ghaylan." Some obeyed him and others disobeyed. Some used to say: "We allied with Yemen," and some said: "We are from them." The poet said:
"Quda'ah claimed it is from Himyar...
May God cut off the nose of the liar Quda'ah."
Abd al-Malik bin Habib said: I heard Muhammad bin Salam Al-Basri the Genealogist say: The Arabs are three roots: Nizar, Yemen, and Quda'ah. It was said to him: Is Nizar more or Yemen? He said: Whatever Quda'ah wills; if it joins Ma'ad, Nizar is more, and if it joins Yemen, Yemen is more. These sayings are as you see, and the lineage of Yemen prevailed over Quda'ah. Understand that.
He said: Quda'ah are all three clans: Banu Imran, Banu Aslam, Banu Amr. All are sons of Al-Haf bin Quda'ah. Quda'ah had children: Al-Hami, Al-Hari, Wadi'ah, and Ubadah.
Section: As for Imran bin Al-Haf, from his descendants are the Kings of Daj'am. They are three: Amr the King bin Malik, the King bin Al-Nu'man, and the King Daj'am (who is Amr bin Sa'd bin Salij, whose name is Amr bin Hulwan bin Imran bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah).
Among them is Dawud Al-Labaq bin Amr bin Daj'am bin Shaybah bin Amr bin Awf bin Daj'am.
Among them is Al-Harith bin Maydalah bin Hawtharah bin Amr bin Awf bin Daj'am.
Among them is Jarm, who are Amr and Awf sons of Raban bin Hulwan bin Imran bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah. From Jarm are Malkan (moving Lam), Qudamah, Jiddam, and Najiyah, sons of Jarm.
Among them are Ma'dhirah bin Adi bin Sumayr bin Matrud bin Qudamah bin Jarm, and A'jab bin Qudamah bin Jarm, and Rasib bin Al-Khazraj bin Jaddah bin Jarm.
As for Raban, these are with open Ra and stressed Ba.
From the descendants of Raban are Mu'awiyah, Ra'ih, Awf, Wa'il, Ulaym, Awf, Asad, Abid, Tazid, Jadrah, and Arwan. Among them is Washiq bin Udhrah bin Mu'awiyah bin Raban.

(Section) Among them is Tazid (with two dots above) bin Hulwan bin Imran. To them the Tazidi cloaks are attributed. There is no Tazid in Arabs except Tazid bin Hulwan in Quda'ah and Tazid in Ansar. The rest is with Ya with two dots below. Understand that.

(Section) From the descendants of Wabrah bin Taghlib Al-Ghalba' bin Hulwan bin Imran are Kalb, Al-Asad, Al-Namir, Al-Dhi'b, Al-Sirhan, Al-Sid, Al-Dab', Al-Fahd, Al-Dubb, Al-Tha'lab, Al-Dabb, and Al-Wabar. Among them is Tanukh, whose name is Fahm bin Asad bin Wabrah. They are three. It is said Tanukh is a name for tribes from Quda'ah who agreed on that. The meaning of Tanukh is staying/residing (Tuqim).
Among them is Al-Qayn, who is Al-Nu'man bin Jasr bin Shi' Allah bin Al-Asad bin Wabrah. And Al-Gharth bin Taym bin Al-Nahr bin Wabrah.
Among them is the Soothsayer Satih, who is Rabi'ah bin Amr bin Al-Dhi'b bin Wabrah. In a narration, he is made from Quda'ah to Ibn Ghassan.
Among them is 'Adi bin Tanjah bin Al-Tha'lab bin Wabrah.
Among them is Abdullah bin Yasir bin Asad bin Haram bin Habib bin Ghanam bin Ka'b bin Taym bin Mu'awiyah bin Yasir bin Yarbu' bin Al-Wabar bin Wabrah. Al-Wabar entered into Juhaynah.
Section: From the descendants of Kalb bin Wabrah

Al-Farafisah (with Fatha on Fa) bin Al-Ahwas bin Amr bin Tha'labah bin Al-Harith bin Al-Husaym bin Damdam bin Adi bin Janab bin Hubal bin Abdullah bin Kinanah bin Awf bin Udhrah bin Zaid Allat bin Rufaydah bin Thawr bin Kalb. The children of Al-Farafisah are Al-Hallaj, Umayr, Dabb, Murr, and Hassan.
From the descendants of Qayd bin Kalb bin Zaid Allat are Taym Allat, Sa'd Allat, Aws Allat, Amr Allat, Jaba' Allat, Sakr Allat, Sahm Allat, Shi' Allat, Abd Allat, Wahb Allat, and Awf Allat.
From them is Aslam (with Damma on Lam) bin Tadul Allat bin Rufaydah.
From the descendants of Aslam is Jabalah bin Iyas bin Abd Al-Alam bin Taym bin Sa'd bin Habib bin Amr bin Dhuhl bin Aslam.
Among them is the Companion of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) and his Mawla Zaid bin Harithah bin Shurahbil (or Sharahbil) bin Abd al-Uzza bin Imru' al-Qais bin Amir bin Al-Nu'man bin Amir bin Abd Wudd bin Awf bin Kinanah bin Awf bin Udhrah bin Zaid Allat bin Rufaydah bin Thawr bin Kalb. And his son Usamah bin Zaid was a Companion of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). And his brother La'mah Ayman son of Umm Ayman, the Mawlah of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him). Ibn Umm Ayman was killed on the Day of Hunayn in front of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) defending him.
Among them is Jabal bin Mu'awiyah bin Umayr bin Amir bin Bakr bin Amir bin Awf bin Ghurah.
Among them is Dihyah bin Khalifah bin Farwah bin Fadalah bin Zaid bin Imru' al-Qais bin Al-Khazraj (who is Zaid Ma'nah) bin Amir bin Bakr bin Amir bin Udhrah. Gabriel, peace be upon him, used to take his likeness.
Among them are Bakr, Ka'b, and Al-Ukanibun, sons of Awf bin Udhrah. As for Shahmah, he is from Ka'b bin Wa'il bin Kinanah bin Awf bin Udhrah.

(Section) As for Aslam bin Al-Haf in Quda'ah, it is with Damma on Lam. Likewise in Quda'ah Aslam bin Badul, and in Akk Aslam Al-Qayanah bin Ghafiq. These three have Damma on Lam. The rest are with Fatha on Lam.
From the descendants of Aslam bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah are Nahr [Bahra'], Juhaynah, and Sa'd Hudhaym, sons of Zaid bin Layth bin Sud bin Aslam.
From the descendants of Bahra' are Malik, Sabah, Jazimah, Zaid, Mu'awiyah, Ka'b, and Abu Sud. These are Nahr [Bahra'] of Yemen. As for Nahd of Sham, they are Amir, Fahm, Amr, and Hanzalah. As for Khuzaymah bin Nahd and Rifa'ah bin Nadr bin Ma'd bin Zaman bin Asad bin Nahd.
It has been said: The Kings of Himyar Al-Sirwahi are from the descendants of Nahd bin Zaid.
As for Juhaynah bin Zaid, from his descendants are Qais and Ghatafan sons of Mawda'ah bin Uqbah, and Ghanam bin Al-Rabi'ah bin Shadan bin Qais bin Habsah.
As for Sa'd Hudhaym bin Zaid, from his descendants are Udhrah, Dinnah (with Nun), Mu'awiyah, Salaman, Al-Harith, Ka'b, and Wa'il.
From Banu Udhrah are Kahil, Kabir, Awf, and Abu Harith. They are Ghabin bin Labid bin Ada Banu Umayyah bin Abdullah bin Razah bin Rabi'ah bin Hizam bin Dinnah bin Abd bin Kabir bin Udhrah.
Among them is Razah bin Rabi'ah, brother of Qusayy through his mother, and he is the one who supported him until he prevailed over the Kaaba.
Among them is Urwah bin Hizam, companion of Afra'. Among them is companion of Buthaynah, Jamil.
Among them is Abdullah bin Ma'mar bin Al-Harith bin Al-Khaybari bin Abd bin Kathir bin Udhrah.
As for Jamil bin Ma'mar Al-Jumahi, he is the one whose voice Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, praised while Quraysh was in its assembly around the Kaaba, except that Umar bin Al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, had accepted Islam and testified that there is no god but Allah alone without partner and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger. Peace be upon him.
From Banu Aslam is Sinhan bin Amr bin Harithah bin Tha'labah bin Sa'd bin Ka'b bin Sud bin Aslam.
Among them is Mas'ud bin Amir bin Harithah bin Tha'labah... etc. lineage.
Among them is Ibn Yazid bin Adi bin Adi bin Al-Harith bin Sa'd bin Asad bin Ka'b bin Sud.
And Nahik bin Asad bin Sud bin Aslam.
Among them are Banu Salm bin Usayf bin Ka'b bin Murrah bin Jusham bin Ghamam bin Abab, and Amir bin Murrah bin Jusham, and Banu Yazid bin Al-Har bin Murrah, and Banu Malik, and Banu Amir bin Tha'labah bin Murrah. These are gathered by Murrah bin Jusham bin Amir bin Abab. And these are gathered by Abab bin Tha'labah bin Asad bin Ka'b bin Sud bin Aslam.

(Section) As for Amr bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah bin Malik bin Amr bin Murrah bin Zaid bin Malik bin Himyar bin Saba the Elder Al-Malik bin Yashjub Al-Malik bin Nu'man Al-Malik bin Ghatafan bin Al-Hamisa' bin Samr bin Nabit bin Isma'il bin Ibrahim peace be upon them.

From his descendants are Bahra', Bali, Khawlan, and Haydan.
From the descendants of Bahra' are Qasit, Abdullah, Amr, Arij, Ahwad, Qaysar, Awf, Murrah, Masraha, and Wa'ilah. Among them is Harith bin Qasit bin Bahra' (with Damma on Ba and Fatha on Ra). Likewise Harith bin Silham bin Hakam. The rest of the Arabs are Harith with Fatha on Ha and Sukun on Ra.
Among them is Al-Miqdad bin Amr bin Tha'labah bin Amir bin Malik bin Thumamah bin Matrud bin Zuhayr bin Lu'ay bin Bahra'. A Companion, Emigrant. He was married to Duba'ah bint Al-Abbas bin Abd al-Muttalib. He is the Knight of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, on the Day of Badr. His father Amr was an ally of Al-Aswad bin Abd Yaghuth Al-Bakri from Quraysh, who died and Al-Aswad succeeded upon his wife, so he was attributed to him. Abu Al-Miqdad had been captured to Hadramaut, stayed in Kindah for a time, then was released and settled in Mecca, so he was called Al-Kindi. However, Al-Kindi is Al-Miqdad bin Ma'di, one of the Emigrant Companions. So understand that.
As for Bali bin Amr bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah, from his descendants is Al-Mujadhdhar bin Ziyad bin Zamzamah bin Amr bin Amarah (with Fatha on Ayn and Shadda on Mim) bin Malik bin Yashir bin Amr bin Qais bin Taym bin Sa'd bin Arash bin Amir bin Umaylah bin Qasmil bin Maran bin Bali. The name of Al-Mujadhdhar was Abdullah. He was named Mujadhdhar because he had a thick throat, and 'Al-Ghaliz' is called Mujadhdhar. He was an ally of Banu Awf from the Ansar.
Among them is Abu Aqil Aqil Abd al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Tha'labah bin Suhar bin Amir bin Al-Harith bin Malik bin Unayf bin Jusham bin Abdullah bin Arash bin Amir bin... to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Asim bin Adi bin Al-Jadd bin Al-Ajlan bin Harithah bin Dub'ah bin Hizam bin Ju'al bin Amr bin Jusham bin Radm bin Dahman bin Hamim bin Dhuhl bin Hani bin Bali.
From Bali is Ka'b bin Ujrah Al-Ansari, Companion of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and Thabit bin Aqdam, killer of Tulayhah on the Day of Apostasy.
As for Haydan, from the descendants of Amr bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah, and from his descendants are Maji and Mahrah sons of Amr bin Haydan.
From the descendants of Majid are Yahya and Hayy (with Kasra on Ha, and in Khawlan Hayy bin Khawlan with Fatha on Ha). Among them are Amr, Wada'ah, Abdal, Al-Aqari', Banu Masih, Junadah, Urayb, Ka'b, and Yazid. These are clans of Banu Zubid and their number is about five thousand. Among them is Al-Kahl, a people beyond the sea.
As for Mahrah, from his descendants are Sama'ah, Al-Dabr, Al-Duwayr, Al-Natu', Al-Amur, Tha'la, and Taym. A great multitude connected from Akhwar to Oman, about two hundred thousand men, their number counted only by Allah Almighty. They are also the people of Al-Shihr. All these tribes, their call is: O family of Haydan.
He said: Banu Amr bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah were in Ma'rib, and they are Bahra', Bali, Khawlan, and Haydan. They separated when the Kings of Yemen expelled them to govern the countries. Bahra' and Bali were among those expelled in the campaign of Quda'ah to Sham along with Kalb, Salih, Taym, and Al-Wabar [Al-Bark?]. Juhaynah, Nahd, Udhrah Banu Zaid, and Khazam bin Zabban were among those sent to Hijaz. Then Nahd returned to the land of Najd with a group from Jarm. The rest settled in Hijaz. Tanukh went to Harrin and joined Sham. Haydan and Khawlan stayed behind in Yemen. In Sa'dah and what adjoins it from Khawlan are one hundred thousand men. Allah knows best.

(Section) As for Khawlan bin Amr bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah, he had seven children: Hayy, Sa'd, Rashwan, Al-Azi', Hani, Razih, and Suhar. The Naji of Khawlan is the eldest of them and the banner holder. He had seven children: Adi, Murid, Ghanam, Amr, Sa'd, Anuf, and Mansur. Most of Banu Hayy hunt Mudar. Among them is the genealogist Zaid bin Maslamah bin Nu'aym bin Malik bin Al-Layth bin Asad bin Ghanam bin Hayy bin Khawlan.
Among them are Abu Al-Husayn and Abu Sa'id Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Sulayman bin Ahmad Al-Mukhtar Muhammad bin Nawfal bin Al-Mukhalid bin Abdullah bin Al-Khiyar bin Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Amr bin Zaid bin Amr bin Marthad bin Hayy bin Khawlan.
From the descendants of Muhammad bin Nawfal bin Mukhalid are Al-Khiyar, Al-Mukhtar, and Jubran.
From Banu Al-Khiyar are Banu Ahmad in Mikhlaf Alhan, sultans and masters, and Banu Abi Ya'la Yuhraz.
From Banu Al-Mukhtar bin Muhammad bin Nawfal are Banu Al-Ahwa'i in Bahrain, and others in Bara', and to them Mount Khayrat Bira' is attributed.

As for Sa'd bin Khawlan, he is the King in Sirwah. He had four children: Rabi'ah, Sa'd, Al-Harith, and Amr. Qaladih Amr.
As for Rabi'ah bin Sa'd, in him are wealth and numbers. He had children: Rashwan, Sa'd, Kamil, Muzawwad, Nu'aym, Dahikah, Hajar, and Aqariab.
Among them is the one who came to Al-Mu'tadid Billah, Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Abbad bin Muhammad bin Kathir bin Jarir bin Hajar bin Raghbah bin Sa'd bin Khawlan.
Amr bin Zaid bin Asmah is Mughriq the Elder. He was named Mughriq because he carried Banu Bajr on riding the sea, and a group of them drowned. The rest went out to Egypt and lived there. Among them are Al-Muslim, Ahmad, and Abdullah, sons of Muhammad bin Abbad.
From the descendants of Abbad also are Muhkam, Muslim, Hajjaj, Al-Wajih, Ahmad, and Al-Haydam. He is a man of Khawlan and owner of Al-Qanakat and Al-Manasib Al-Ulumiyyin and the tribes of their workers.
Al-Haydam rebelled against the Sultan and opposed. That is because Hammad appointed Al-Haydam. Al-Haydam's sister, a slave girl, was described to him [Hammad]... [text corrupted]... her son Nafisah. He sent to buy her, and she was... [text unclear]. She said: Her matter is to Al-Haydam. Al-Haydam was at Jabal Batkas. He made... and sent someone who broke in on her and took her. The news reached her brother Al-Haydam, so he went down to La'ah and struck the neck of the agent. He wrote to Hammad informing him of his deed, and that he killed some clients without his order, and that he seeks justice from him. He hated making peace with him, so Al-Haydam found no escape from fighting him. He fought him for a time, then Hammad overcame him and sent him to Iraq with a group of his companions. Among them was Al-Dahhak bin Kathir Al-Umari.
When they reached Harun Al-Rashid, he said to Al-Haydam: "You are the one rebelling against the Commander of the Faithful and killer of his soldiers with sedition?" Hammad had secretly instructed someone to advise Al-Haydam, saying to him: "If the Commander of the Faithful asks you about your harem, admit it, for he will pardon you." He said: "Yes." Harun permitted his killing, so he ordered it and his neck was struck.
Then he called Al-Dahhak bin Kathir and mentioned that to him. He said: "The one who did that is Hammad your servant," and mentioned the desire to him and how the affair of Al-Haydam started. Harun regretted killing Al-Haydam, released Al-Dahhak and his companions, greeted them, ordered them carried to Yemen, and was angry with Hammad until he died.
Among them is the master of Quda'ah in his time, who undertook the war against Rabi'ah bin Nizar and expelled them from Yemen, Amr bin Malik bin Zaid bin Usamah bin Zaid bin Artah to the end of the lineage.
Among them is Malik the Younger and Al-Asba', sons of Hajar bin Sa'd bin Amr, whose lineage we presented.
Among them is the grandfather of Al-Akul, Yazid bin Al-Mutawakkil bin Hajar bin Sa'd bin Amr.
From the descendants of Yazid Al-Mutawakkil are the family of Al-Mughirah, the family of Al-Harith, and the family of Ghanam, sons of Yazid bin Amr bin Zaid bin Al-Tawakkil.
Among them is Mughriq, one of the archers and poets of Khawlan.
From the descendants of Al-Asba' is Yazid bin Amr bin Abdullah bin Al-Asba'. As for the children of Sahl bin Al-Asba', they joined Jabal Hayum, so his descendants today are in Al-Ahyum.
From the descendants of Al-Layth bin Malik bin Yazid bin Usamah bin Zaid bin Artah are Malik, Al-Ubayd, and Amr bin Al-Layl. His sons Al-Ubayd and Malik are in Banu Hajar bin Zaid. In Banu Al-Ubayd is the leadership of Banu Bahr.
Sa'd in Al-Layth was among the masters and nobles of Banu Malik. He is the one saying:
"Your time demands from you what we advanced...
And what you aimed for became broken.
Ibn Hajar wanted a youth of my clan...
And short of what he aimed for is cutting the nape."
From the descendants of Awf bin Zaid bin Usamah bin Zaid bin Artah are Mas'ud, Kathir, Jabir, Malik, Rifa'ah, Sa'b, and Awd; all are clans. Wealth and valor were in the descendants of Awf, and in Banu Malik were sovereignty and unity.
From Banu Awf is the Knight of Arabs, Master of Banu Awf, and Tongue of Khawlan, Amr bin Yazid bin Amr bin Mas'ud bin Amr bin Mas'ud bin Awf.
As for the children of Malik, Jabir, Rifa'ah, Sa'b, and Awd, they settled in the abode of Anz bin Wa'il, and they are there to this day. Among them is a group who went out with Banu Malik bin Zaid to Zubid and Hays. Likewise Amr, Jarir, Atik, and Jabir are houses; some of them went out to Zubid, Hays, and Tihamah with their sisters in Banu Awf.
Regarding that, Amr, brother of Banu Awf, says:
"A group of us passed surrounding with spears...
Mshahim [?], their homes became in Zubid."

As for Sa'd bin Sa'd bin Khawlan, from his descendants are Harith, Ghalib, Samhak, and Qaym. Taym perished.
From the descendants of Samhak bin Sa'd bin Sa'd are the people of Al-Khabith, the people of Mutarrif, Banu Salamah, Al Jarir, Al Akram, Salamah, and Samhak. These are the leaders of Banu Sa'd.
Among them are the people of Al-Arj. From the descendants of Ziyad bin Sulayman bin Al-Fahish bin Harith bin Sa'd bin Sa'd bin Khawlan.
Among them is Mahmoud bin Ali bin Amr bin Jabir bin Amr bin Musafir bin Amr bin Ziyad bin Sulayman.
Among them are the Abdalis, Banu Al-Jiyad bin Ziyad bin Sulayman.
Among them is Zubid bin Al-Khiyar, their number about three hundred; their master is Yahya Abu Al-Husayn Al-Zubaydi.
From Banu Abdullah bin Al-Khiyar is Amr bin Yazid bin Abdullah bin Al-Jiyad. He led, but did not remain long in his leadership until he was stabbed in Banu Ghalib. The majority of Banu Al-Khiyar are in Hijaz due to events that occurred between them and Al-Rabi'ah and between Ziyad and Tawa'irat [?]. As for Banu Harb, they headed to Al-Arj. As for Banu Ghalib, they headed to Jabal Yasuma and Wadi Nakhlah.
Al-Kala'i said: The reason for the relocation of Banu Harith bin Sa'd bin Khawlan is that they fought with their brothers Banu Rabi'ah bin Sa'd bin Khawlan, and killing increased between them in Sa'dah. So they moved to Hijaz, they and their brothers Banu Ghalib bin Sa'd bin Sa'd bin Khawlan in the year one hundred and thirty-one. Banu Ghalib settled in Al-Arj, and Banu Harith marched to the valleys of Marr, where there were Sulayman, Muzaynah, Anrah, Murrah, and Azim. Banu Harith drove them out and inhabited it. They had from the Caliph the money of Iraq brought to them repeatedly from the pilgrims, as well as authority over the Amir of the Two Sanctuaries towards it and Mount Arwan at the top of Arafat. Those who remained of Banu Harith and Banu Ghalib in the land of Khawlan stayed under the shadow and protection of Al-Harith bin Amr.
From the descendants of Ghalib bin Sa'd bin Sa'd are Muqis, Khabir, and Sabil, three clans in Banu Hamrah, and Nasim bin Ghalib. And the Abdiyyun in Wadi Sarum (Sarum bin Sa'd).
About them Amr bin Zaid Al-Ghalibi says:
"And I attributed their father to Sa'd...
To a lineage from the breach of Amrah piercing.
Masters of Banu Jabr and Nasim are my brothers...
And living Muqis from the offspring of Ghalib.
Are not Banu Al-Sadat from the family of Ghalib...
If they detain high shoulders from it."
As for Rashwan bin Khawlan, he is the companion of Ghaylan. He had children: Harith, Lahiq, Mulhaq (with Sa'd), Munabbih, and Khawli.
From the descendants of Khawli is Bint in Barsam. Most of these clans are in Tamim; they went out with Banu Haqq bin Khawlan in anger against Banu Khawlan. That is because Malik bin Amr, their master, when seditions stirred between Banu Hayy and Banu Sa'd, he squeezed them [?]. When the turn of fortune went against Banu Hayy, he said: "I will not inhabit the land of Khawlan after my uncle Khalid bin Qais." The daughter of his uncle Khalid bin Qais was under him (his wife). Banu Mulhaq bin Rashwan went out to Anz bin Wa'il and attributed themselves among them.
As for Al-Azma' bin Khawlan, he is the owner of Hars. He had ten children, all with offspring: Marwan, Al-Karb, Al-Ashraf, Hasa, Amr, Abdullah, Tha'la, and Amira Al-Nasik. Those ignorant of the lineage of Banu Shihab in Kindah used to say: Shihab bin Al-Azma', making him the tenth child.
From the descendants of Hasa Al-Azma' are Malik, Yashkur, Nur, Khalid Jawhar, Al-Karb, and Al-Ahwas on the weight of Al-Amluk.
From Maran are Al-Ra'a, attributed as Ra'awi. To Maran are attributed Al-Qass Al-Maraniyyah. From them is the biggest estate of Khawlan. He had children: Hilal, Al-Ghala, Ali, Sa'd, and Jas'a. Harar begot Shurahbil, Jami', and Jabir. Lineage from Shurahbil is in Banu Nasr bin Jama'ah bin Shurahbil bin Hilal.
As for Al-Ghala, it is with Ghayn Mu'jamah. From his descendants are Hudhayfah, Habib, Walih, and Urayb.
As for Razih bin Khawlan, he had ten children: Mazid, Uwayd, Thaghla, Ibna, Bari, Nawa, Jadal, Nu'aym, Amr Yazid, and Hudayr. The family of Muslim bin Abbad bin Razih is more than a fifth of Khawlan.
They said: And Nu'aym is from the descendants of Al-Rabi'ah bin Sa'd, and entered into Razih, so they said Nu'aym bin Tha'lan bin Razih. Some Himyaris in Sa'dah informed me that Rabi'ah errs in the saying of Amr against Nu'aym that he is Ba'li [adopted?] and Nu'aym was undutiful to his father:
"We begot Nu'ayf so he came to a Ba'li...
And Nu'aym was undutiful to his father the day he marched.
He followed his father the day he came to them...
And became a delegate among them and confused."
As for Suhar bin Khawlan, there are seven children: Hadir, Yusr, Sabil, Tariq, Amir, and Alqamah. Hadir and Sa'd bin Hadir begot the Fatimids of the people of Al-Assah. Their maternal uncles are Banu Sa'd bin Sa'd bin Hadir and Hasbah from the time of Al-Mubayyad Ibrahim bin Musa Al-Alawi in the days of Al-Ma'mun. They were for a long time not known except as Banu Sa'd bin Sa'd until Ibn Attad Al-Akili said:
"If you are from Sa'd bin Sa'd correcting...
Then I am to that birth confirming."
Al-Abbasi Al-Issi said

"Attribute me, my origin, and my origin is high...
And your origin is attribution to thin roots.
And I am established in the peak of its Sa'd...
Or Sa'd other than me when truths heat up.
So whomever I wish I attach to Sa'd, and whomever I wish...
Of people I attach him to whom he belongs."
At that time, their affiliation to Sa'd bin Hadir appeared. They are the most responsive of Khawlan and farthest in fame.
From the ancient men of Banu Suhar is Alqamah bin Zaid; he was a traveler to kings in Yemen and Sham. And the family of Abi Qazimah who rose with Ibrahim bin Musa Al-Radi bin Ja'far bin Muhammad and ruined Sa'dah with him, and rose with those of Khawlan who rose against Muhammad bin Abbad and killed him. They went out with Yahya bin Al-Husayn bin Al-Qasim bin Ibrahim to Al-Rass.
The arrival of Al-Hadi Yahya bin Al-Husayn to Sa'dah was on the sixth of Safar year two hundred and eighty-four. There was a great sedition between Khawlan and Rabi'ah. He reconciled them, their word agreed, so they made him king over the land of Khawlan. They marched with him to Yemen until he possessed it. They were the pillar of his affair and the system of his state. They remained on that during the life of Yahya bin Al-Husayn Al-Hadi, the life of his son Muhammad bin Yahya, and the life of his daughter [son?] Al-Nasir bin Yahya.
As'ad bin Abi Ya'fur imprisoned Al-Hamdani. They asked him for him. He informed them that only As'ad imprisoned him for a crime against him. Al-Hasan bin Muhammad bin Abi Al-Abbas rode to As'ad bin Abi Ya'fur and apologized to him, and said: "Al-Nasir only wrote to me to imprison him for him, so ask him." They said: "If he says yes, he writes to me so I release him." He left. The group of Al-Assa returned to Al-Nasir and informed him what As'ad said. He distanced them and was harsh to them, and [As'ad?] was harsh to him, and they showed dissent.
Al-Hasan bin Abi Al-Abbas led a group for him and fought him at Madbaghah Kayfi. Al-Nasir asked Khawlan to leave and informed him that he had conquered [?]. He was satisfied and dismissed those crowds and returned from him until it was proven to him that the release of Al-Hamdani was from Ibn Ziyad, owner of Zubid.
He turned away from Al-Nasir and summoned Hassan bin Uthman bin Ahmad bin Ya'fur. Hassan was an enemy of Al-Nasir due to an offense he presented to him. Then Al-Nasir gathered against them [with] Gaza [raid?] from them. As'ad's condition tightened, and the group of men of Rabi'ah and most of Banu Sa'd and factions of Hamdan and many people of Sana'a separated. Their locations were grouped.
Zaid bin Abi Al-Abbas fought forty men from the children of Al-Asham. He attacked them and defeated them, reciting:
"The might of Al-Ahras has known...
That I am Zaid bin Abi Al-Abbas.
I protect with my sword my harem and my head."
He was that day with a broken leg, bandaged with a turban, not riding except carried to [?]. Zaid bin Abi Al-Abbas was the Knight of the Arabs. He attacked with those with him and they defeated the Alawi. Those with him scattered, and he had the merit [length?], called the Attack of Zaid.
Then Hassan bin Uthman bin Ya'fur marched to Al-Hawar. Between them was the Day of Al-Batin, one of the greatest days of the Arabs. Al-Husayn bin Yahya bin Al-Husayn, brother of Al-Nasir, was killed in it. Al-Nasir's heart split, he stayed ill for days, then died. They marched with Hassan to Sa'dah and he possessed it. Then Rabi'ah rose against him, and Zaid confronted it in the kingship of Arabs after stances that were not for anyone of the knights of the Arabs.

(Section) Some genealogists of Khawlan said that he has children other than the mentioned nine: Abs, Wahim, Jabir, Simran, Hars, Al-Jundub, Al-Ukhdud, Baqir, and Hasan bin Abi Al-Haqq. Al-Karb is from Banu Hayy bin Khawlan. The clans of Al-Karb are Al Al-Jadi' and Al Halwan. What is correct is that Al-Karb is from the descendants of Al-Azma' bin Khawlan.
As for Abs bin Khawlan, his children are Amr, Nu'aym, Murrah, Ziyad, and Abd. The sarah [nobles?] of Abs are from his house and Nu'aym, and they are a house. And Abs begot Unayk and Zahra, all clans.
Wahim begot Al-Ajlan, and between them are clans.
Simran begot A'yal, Al-Ba'id, Al-Ya'mal, Sa'd, and Amir, all clans.
Al-Jundub begot Malik and Kinanah, two clans.
Hars begot Al-Huwayrith, a clan.
Baqir begot Samra, Sa'b, Muntaha, Al-Ayn, Khuraym, Attad, and Maran the Younger, all clans.
Al-Muslim said: And Hurrah bin Al-Rabi'ah bin Sa'd and Al-Adyum, and they are Banu Arbamah from the descendants of Hani. And Nasim in Banu Humantazah the Musahhamiyyin, other than Sahm and Wahim.
As for Khawlan of the East, it was said Khawlan had children other than those mentioned: Habib, Amr, Al-Ashab in Qais, Nabsb, Dhakwan, Sa'd, Hurrah, and Shihab.
From the descendants of Habib are Habab, Hurayth, Bakr, and Al-Thalib, clans.
From the descendants of Amr are Amir and Masban (with stressed Sad), two clans.

From the descendants of Al-Ashab are Rihab and Hurayth, two clans.
From the descendants of Dhi Hurrah are Arafat, Kayn, Allan, Jadara', Dahwat, Al-Sarb, and Hudhayfah. All these are called Khawlan Al-Aliyah.
It is narrated that the Prophet (peace be upon him) prayed for Al-Sakasik, Al-Safkun [Al-Sukun?], Khawlan Al-Aliyah, and Al-Amluk (kings of Radman and kings of Dhi Zu'ayr).
Abu Muslim Al-Khawlani was one of them; he is one of the ascetic Successors. His name is Abd al-Rahman bin Muslim, or Abdullah bin Ayyub. He accepted Islam before the death of the Prophet (peace be upon him). He has a story with Al-Aswad Al-Ansi the Liar who claimed prophethood in Sana'a; he burned him with fire but it did not harm him, so he exiled him. He migrated to Medina and arrived during the Caliphate of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him. He has famous virtues and miracles.
Among them also is Abu Idris Al-Khawlani, whose name is A'idhullah bin Abdullah bin Amr. Both are jurists from the people of Iraq. Abu Idris is the one who said: "Mosques are the councils of the noble." Abu Idris was a judge in Damascus for Mu'awiyah and his son until the days of Abd al-Malik bin Marwan. Abu Idris was born in the year of Hunayn, met a group of Companions, and was among the senior Successors.
Among them are Abu Hani the Muhaddith and Shurahbil bin Muslim the Muhaddith.
The homelands of Khawlan Al-Aliyah are east of Mikhlaf Khawlan. Allah knows best.

He said: These are the lineages of Quda'ah. They are three clans: Banu Imran, Banu Amr, and Banu Aslam. They are gathered by Al-Haf bin Quda'ah.
From the descendants of Al-Haf also is Abdullah. From his descendants is Ka'b bin Amr bin Zur'ah bin Abdullah bin Al-Haf bin Quda'ah.
The families of Imran are Jarm bin Rayyan, Salih and Bin Zaid sons of Hulwan, Kalb, Tanukh, Al-Ayn, Khushayn, and Al-Bark. They are gathered by Wabrah bin Taghlib Al-Ghalba'.
As for Banu Amr, they are Khawlan, Bahra', Bali, Mahrah, Majidun from Majid, Al-Ayadil, La [?], Al-Awza', Tanukhi, and Banu Mustih.
The tribes of Khawlan are Banu Akarib, Banu Bajz, Banu Awf, Banu Malik, Banu Harith, Banu Ghalib, The Abdalis, The Zubidis, Banu Munyah, Marran, Al-Karb, Al-Ra'a, Banu Jama'ah, Razih, Banu Urys, Al-Atyam, and The Fatimids.
As for Banu Aslam, they are Nahd, Juhaynah, Sa'd Hudhaym, and Udhrah.
These are the tribes and clans of Quda'ah. Allah knows best.

**Section on the Children of Saba the Elder**
The children of Saba the Elder are Jurhum, Wahim, Zari'ah, Abu Al-Samra', Mubashir, Abd Al-Nur, Hadramaut (who is Aflah), Nasr, La'a, Humayra', and Kahlan. We have mentioned the latter two.
From the descendants of Qahtan are Al-Khiyar, Anmar, Al-Madi, Al-Asib, Ma'zab, Sami', Al-Musammi', Al-Naghsham, Al-Mutalammis, Zalim, Al-Ghashim, Al-Atami (or Al-Qadi with Qaf), Al-Harith, Yamin, Ya'rub, Idhak, and Jurhum. Their mother is Ad.
From the descendants of Jurhum bin Qahtan is Amr bin Al-Mudad bin Amr bin Al-Harith bin Amr bin Hayy bin Bi from Jurhum bin Al-Gharth bin Sa'd bin Jurhum bin Qahtan bin Aber bin Shelah bin Arphaxad bin Shem bin Noah, peace be upon him.
Noah, peace be upon him, was called Adam the Younger. The Almighty said: {And We made his descendants those remaining.} As for the children of Adam, they perished in the Flood, and none of them remained.
These are the lineages of the Arabs from the children of Arphaxad bin Shem bin Noah. We will mention the lineage of the Arabs' brothers, the children of Shem, and mention the lineage of the Non-Arabs (Ajam) after that, Allah willing.

(Section) He said: Shem bin Noah had five children: Arphaxad, Iram, Aswad, Ludh, and Uwaylim.
As for Arphaxad, he is the father of the Arabs, and we have mentioned them.
As for Iram, from his descendants are Ad, Thamud, and the First Amalekites.
From the descendants of Ad is the Prophet Hud, peace be upon him: Son of Abdullah bin Riyah bin Al-Julud bin Al-Aharith bin Ad bin Iram bin Shem bin Noah, peace be upon him. And Asal bin Uwaydi bin Iram.
Among them is Luqman bin Ad bin Hudhayl bin Mhal bin Sand bin Ad.
From the descendants of Thamud is Salih bin Ubayd bin Jabir bin Thamud bin Jas bin Iram bin Shem bin Mahrash bin Al-Dafran bin Amr bin Thamud. And Janda' bin Amr bin Aswas bin Al-Rumayl bin Amr bin Thamud. Among them is Salih bin Amr bin Dinyah bin Kasih bin Ahqab bin Thamud. These are gathered by Thamud bin Jabir bin Iram bin Shem.
From the Amalekites is the master of Amalekites Mu'awiyah bin Bakr bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Hawwas bin Layth bin Qad bin Jamru bin Amlaq bin Ludh bin Iram bin Shem. Among them is Pharaoh Al-Thak [?], who is Qabus bin Mus'ab bin Mu'awiyah bin Al-Hawwas... etc lineage.
Among them are Tasm and Jadis bin Ludh bin Iram bin Shem. Among them is Al-A'naf bin Haran bin Malik bin Saran bin Jadis bin Amir bin Iram bin Shem.
As for Aswad bin Iram, from his descendants are the First Hawsh. They are Kurd, Nasik, Basik, Aran, Jablan, Sharan, Mahrajan, Uru, Nabati, Arnad, Salam, Sus, Sadd, and Alul.
From them are Warham and Khatit, sons of Aswad. Among them are Aylam, Ansu, Amlan, and Arad bin Aswad bin Shem.

book_title: Introduction to Genealogies and Noting Those of Noble Lineage
text:
It is said that Khorasan, Persia, and Kurdistan mostly descend from Nafeh bin Nukh. Al-Kalbi said: Persia descends from Umeem bin Aswad bin Sam. From Lawdh bin Sam and Aras bin Umeem bin Yalmah bin Abirwasin bin Amliq bin Abir bin Ashliha bin Lawdh bin Sam, also called Jurjan bin Umeem, according to Al-Kalbi: Tasam bin Abbarin Al-Saliha. From the descendants of Amliq bin Lawdh came the Persians, Iblis, Luwaym, Nuhaim, and Wabar. These groups were among the first brothers of the Arabs descending from Sam bin Nuh (Noah), peace be upon him.

Among the children of Nuh were Ham and Yafith, and it is said he had a fourth son, Lam. From Lam came Khorasat bin Lam, as testified by Al-Afuh Al-Awdi when mentioning the kings of Yemen. Regarding Ham, his descendants included Kush, Masrat, Thuban, Misr (Egypt), Safar, Kawthar, Al-Aziyah, Buya, Kurd, Bara, Rayh, Ra’awa, Hais, Tajah, and Maran. From Misr came the Copts and Sahalaba and Canaan, the sons of Misr bin Ham, giving Egypt its name. Among them were also Jalut bin Saklujim bin Misr bin Ham, as well as Andalusia and Sous from Sufar bin Mart bin Ham, Sind from Naufal Ham, India and Mazan from Kush. Nimrod descended from Ka’b bin Sanharib bin Nimrod bin Kush bin Ham.

As for Yafith bin Nuh, his descendants included the Nabateans, Harir, Qazah, Kerman, Oman, China, Ahur, Harmer, Nile, Copts, Naufal, Khayfar, Masih, Piron, Yunaan, and Kahil. From them came the Great Nabatean son of Lunta bin Yafith, the Turks, and the descendants of Masih Diajugh and Majugh from Khayfarin bin Yafith. The Sicilians and Basahiyeh descend from Tuwayl bin Yafith and Marhan bin Piron bin Yafith.

From Sheeth bin Adam (peace be upon him) descended Anus bin Al-Ma’ous bin Awj bin ‘Unuq bin Sheeth bin Kadim, and from Qabil bin Adam came Arzel bin Lamak bin Matushalh bin Azil bin ‘Add bin Anouh bin Qabil bin Adam. Habil (Abel) was killed and left no descendants.

Among the children of Adam (peace be upon him) were Habil, Qabil, Abdullah, Abdur-Rahman, Abdul-Harith, Saleh, Aylad, Fata, Ayyar, Shard, Surur, and Sarwas. It is narrated that Adam had forty sons in twenty tribes, with each tribe consisting of a man and a woman. Allah knows best and is Most Wise.

Yusuf bin Muhammad Al-Bakri, the scribe of this book, said: I have endeavored to accurately record the genealogies of tribes, the heads of families, branches, and clans, and have carefully reconciled differences to avoid errors, bias, and confusion. Whatever mistakes or oversights remain, we seek Allah’s refuge from them despite my diligence.

The copying of this book was completed on a Friday, the seventh of Rajab, year 627 AH, and further notes were added in 627 AH. The book was completed with Allah’s help on Tuesday, the 28th of Muharram, year 785 AH. Praise be to Allah abundantly.
